original: The vintner, who, by mixing poison with his wines, destroys more lives than any one disease in the bill of mortality; the lawyer, who persuades you to a purchase which he knows is mortgaged for more than the worth, to the ruin of you and your family; the goldsmith or scrivener, who takes all your fortune to dispose of, when he has beforehand resolved to break the following day, do surely deserve the gallows much better than the wretch who is carried thither for stealing a horse.
modernized: The vintner who mixes poison in his wines, responsible for more lives lost than any single disease; the lawyer who convinces you to invest in mortgaged property, leading to your and your family's ruin; the goldsmith or scrivener who misappropriates your entire fortune, intending to disappear the next day, surely deserve the gallows more than a thief who steals a horse.

original: Such, and much worse, is our condition at present, if I had leisure or liberty to lay it before you; and, therefore, the next thing which might be considered is, whether there may be any probable remedy found, at the least against some part of these evils; for most of them are wholly desperate.
modernized: Our current state is extremely critical and unforgiving, as I don't have the time or opportunity to explain in detail; thus, we need to consider whether we can find any potential solutions, even just for some aspects of these issues. Most of them are entirely hopeless.

original: It is commonly charged upon the gentlemen of the army, that the beastly vice of drinking to excess, hath been lately, from their example, restored among us; which for some years before was almost dropped in England.
modernized: The army officers are often accused of causing the excessive drinking habit to return, and this habit had been somewhat rare in England for some years. However, the allegations are true; the army officers have successfully restored this behavior among us.

original: But, whoever the introducers were, they have succeeded to a miracle; many of the young nobility and gentry are already become great proficients, and are under no manner of concern to hide their talent, but are got beyond all sense of shame or fear of reproach.
modernized: It is the army officers who have managed to persuade many young nobles and high-ranking individuals to become proficient in excessive drinking, and they no longer feel the need to hide their actions, as they have lost all sense of shame or concern for rebuke.

original: A dozen such men in power would be able to reform a kingdom.
modernized: Twelve individuals in positions of power would have the capacity to transform a kingdom.

original: He hath no employment under the Crown; nor is likely to get or solicit for any: his education having not turned him that way.
modernized: He has no job under the Crown and is not seeking one; his education did not set him on that path.

original: I will assure for no man's future conduct; but he who hath hitherto practised the rules of virtue with so much difficulty in so great and busy a station, deserves your thanks, and the best return you can make him; and you, my brethren, have no other to give him, than that of representing you in Parliament.
modernized: I won't guarantee anyone's future actions, but the person who has thus far demonstrated virtue with considerable effort in a high and busy position deserves your appreciation and the best reward you can offer; and you, my fellow citizens, have no other means to offer him except by representing you in Parliament.

original: Tell me not of your engagements and promises to another: your promises were sins of inconsideration, at best; and you are bound to repent and annul them.
modernized: Don't speak to me about your commitments and promises to another; they were thoughtless at best, and you are obliged to repent and revoke them.

original: That gentleman, although with good reputation, is already engaged on the other side.
modernized: Though he has a good reputation, this gentleman is already committed to the opposition.

original: He hath four hundred pounds a year under the Crown, which he is too wise to part with, by sacrificing so good an establishment to the empty names of virtue, and love of his country.
modernized: He receives 400 pounds a year from the Crown, which he is too shrewd to give up by sacrificing a good establishment for the empty titles of virtue and love of his country.

original: I can assure you, the Drapier is in the interest of the present Lord Mayor, whatever you may be told to the contrary.
modernized: I can assure you, the Drapier is in support of the current Lord Mayor, contrary to whatever you may be told.

original: I have lately heard him declare so in public company, and offer some of these very reasons in defence of his opinion; although he hath a regard and esteem for the other gentleman, but would not hazard the good of the city and the kingdom for a compliment.
modernized: I recently heard him express this in public, offering the reasoning I've presented as justification for his viewpoint, despite his respect and esteem for the other gentleman, but he wouldn't risk the wellbeing of the city and the kingdom for flattery.

original: I think it may therefore be of some use to lay before you the chief causes of this wretched condition we are in, and then it will be easier to assign what remedies are in our power toward removing, at least, some part of these evils.
modernized: It might be beneficial to explain the main reasons for the desperate situation we find ourselves in, which would make finding potential solutions easier. This way we could address, at least partially, some of these issues.

original: It is with the utmost Concern, that We, Your Majesty's most dutiful subjects, the Commons of IRELAND in Parliament assembled, find ourselves indispensably obliged, to represent to Your Majesty, our unanimous Opinion: That the importing and uttering of Copper Farthings and Halfpence by virtue of the Patent lately granted to William Wood, Esq.; under the Great Seal of Great Britain, will be highly prejudicial to Your Majesty's Revenue, destructive of the trade and commerce of this nation, and of the most dangerous consequence to the properties of the subject.
modernized: We, the citizens of Ireland, humbly address King Your Majesty with extreme concern. In a joint session of our parliament, we find it compulsory to express our collective concern: The import and circulation of Copper Farthings and Halfpence, as per the recent patent granted to William Wood, ESQ., under the Great Seal of Great Britain, poses a significant risk to Your Majesty's revenue, harms our national trade and commerce, and poses catastrophic consequences for our citizens' property.

original: By what I could discover, the Yahoos appear to be the most unteachable of all animals: their capacity never reaching higher than to draw or carry burdens.
modernized: Based on my observations, Yahoos seem to be the least teachable of all animals, capable only of tasks like carrying burdens.

original: Yet I am of opinion, this defect arises chiefly from a perverse, restive disposition; for they are cunning, malicious, treacherous, and revengeful.
modernized: I believe the source of their inability to learn is primarily due to a stubborn, disobedient nature; they are cunning, malicious, deceitful, and vengeful.

original: They are strong and hardy, but of a cowardly spirit, and, by consequence, insolent, abject, and cruel.
modernized: They are strong and robust but cowardly, which leads to their being boisterous, submissive, and cruel.

original: It is observed, that the red haired of both sexes are more libidinous and mischievous than the rest, whom yet they much exceed in strength and activity.
modernized: It's been noted that red-haired individuals, both male and female, are more sexual and destructive than the rest, though they are still surpassed by their red-haired counterparts in strength and agility.

original: When I went out to-day, I found it had rained mightily in the night, and the streets were as dirty as winter: it is very refreshing after ten days dry. -- I went into the City, and dined with Stratford, thanked him for his books, gave him joy of his being director, of which he had the first notice by a letter from me.
modernized: Today, when I stepped outside, I discovered that it had poured heavily in the night, leaving the streets covered in mud. After ten days of dry weather, the rain felt refreshing. I went to the city for lunch with Stratford, where I thanked him for sending the books, expressed my delight at his new role as director of the South Sea Company, and let him know he was the first to hear about it from my letter to him.

original: I ate sturgeon, and it lies on my stomach.
modernized: For dinner, I ate sturgeon, and now I'm experiencing noticeable

original: I almost finished Prior's Journey at the printer's; and came home pretty late, with Patrick at my heels.
modernized: I was close to finishing Prior's Journey at the printer's and came home late in the evening, accompanied by Patrick.

original: I will now apply what I have said to you, my brethren and fellow-citizens.
modernized: I will now apply what I previously said to all of you, my fellow citizens and brothers.

original: Count upon it, as a truth next to your creed, that no one person in office, of which he is not master for life, whether born here or in England, will ever hazard that office for the good of this country.
modernized: Trust firmly in it, as a truth second only to your religious beliefs, that no government official who is not secure for life will risk their position for the benefit of the country, regardless of whether they are born here or in England.

original: One of your candidates is of this kind, and I believe him to be an honest gentleman, as the word honest is generally understood.
modernized: One of your candidates fits this description, and I believe him to be an honest individual, using the word 'honest' in its common understanding.

original: But he loves his employment better than he doth you, or his country, or all the countries upon earth.
modernized: However, they prioritize their job over you and our country, as well as any other countries worldwide.

original: Will you contribute and give him city security to pay him the value of his employment, if it should be taken from him, during his life, for voting on all occasions with the honest country party in the House? -- although I must question, whether he would do it even upon that condition.
modernized: Will you offer city security to pay them the value of their employment, in case it is taken away from them during their lifetime, if they vote with the honest majority of the country's representatives in the House? -- It is questionable if they would even do so upon those conditions.

original: These people are under continual disquietudes, never enjoying a minutes peace of mind; and their disturbances proceed from causes which very little affect the rest of mortals.
modernized: These individuals live in a state of perpetual anxiety, seldom finding peace of mind. Their worries stem from celestial events that have minimal impact on most people.

original: Their apprehensions arise from several changes they dread in the celestial bodies: for instance, that the earth, by the continual approaches of the sun towards it, must, in course of time, be absorbed, or swallowed up; that the face of the sun, will, by degrees, be encrusted with its own effluvia, and give no more light to the world; that the earth very narrowly escaped a brush from the tail of the last comet, which would have infallibly reduced it to ashes; and that the next, which they have calculated for one-and-thirty years hence, will probably destroy us.
modernized: They fear changes in the celestial bodies, such as the possibility that the Earth, as the sun approaches it, will eventually be swallowed or engulfed; that the Sun's face will become encrusted and lose its light; that the Earth narrowly escaped a collision with the last comet's tail, which would have destroyed it; and that the next comet, calculated to appear after thirty years, may end up destroying us.

original: For if, in its perihelion, it should approach within a certain degree of the sun (as by their calculations they have reason to dread) it will receive a degree of heat ten thousand times more intense than that of red hot glowing iron, and in its absence from the sun, carry a blazing tail ten hundred thousand and fourteen miles long, through which, if the earth should pass at the distance of one hundred thousand miles from the nucleus, or main body of the comet, it must in its passage be set on fire, and reduced to ashes: that the sun, daily spending its rays without any nutriment to supply them, will at last be wholly consumed and annihilated; which must be attended with the destruction of this earth, and of all the planets that receive their light from it.
modernized: If, during its closest approach to the Sun, a comet should come within a certain distance (as they have reason to fear based on their calculations), it would receive heat ten thousand times greater than that of red-hot iron. In the comet's absence from the Sun, it would have a tail ten hundred thousand and fourteen miles long. If the Earth were to pass at a distance of one hundred thousand miles from the comet's nucleus or core, it would be set on fire and destroyed: if they are correct, the Sun, which burns its rays without being replenished, will eventually be consumed and annihilated. This would lead to the destruction of the Earth, along with all planets receiving light from it.

original: He said, by the best computation he could make, we were at least a hundred leagues.
modernized: He estimated that we were at least one hundred leagues away based on his best calculations.

original: I assured him that he must be mistaken by almost half, for I had not left the country from whence I came above two hours before I dropt into the sea.
modernized: To be precise, I had only been away from home for about two hours before I fell into the sea, so he was off by nearly half.

original: Whereupon he began again to think that my brain was disturbed, of which he gave me a hint, and advised me to go to bed in a cabin he had provided.
modernized: He started to believe that my mind might be troubled, hinting at this and advising me to rest in the cabin he had prepared.

original: I assured him I was well refreshed with his good entertainment and company, and as much in my senses as ever I was in my life.
modernized: I assured him that I felt perfectly fine after enjoying his hospitality and company as much as ever.

original: When the evil day is come (if it must come) let us mark and observe those who presume to offer these halfpence in payment.
modernized: When the day of deceit arrives (if it must), let's take note of those who offer these coins as payment.

original: Let their names, and trades, and places of abode be made public, that every one may be aware of them, as betrayers of their country, and confederates with Mr. Wood.
modernized: Make the names, professions, and addresses of these individuals known to everyone, as they betray their country and conspire with Mr. Wood.

original: Let them be watched at markets and fairs, and let the first honest discoverer give the word about, that Wood's halfpence have been offered, and caution the poor innocent people not to receive them.
modernized: Keep an eye on them at markets, fairs, and other public places. If someone discovers the counterfeit coins, let them speak out, and warn the innocent people not to accept them.

original: Therefore, as it was my lot to have been daily conversant with the persons then in power; never absent in times of business or conversation, until a few weeks before Her Majesty's death; and a witness of almost every step they made in the course of their administration; I must have been very unfortunate not to be better informed than those miserable pamphleteers, or their patrons, could pretend to.
modernized: Since I had regular interactions with those in power, was present for all important matters and discussions for nearly all the years before the Queen's death, I should have been surprisingly uninformed compared to contemporary writers, or their supporters, given my proximity and observance of the administration.

original: At the same time, I freely confess, it appeared necessary, as well as natural, upon such a mighty change as the death of a sovereign, that those who were to be in power upon the succession, and resolved to act in every part by a direct contrary system of politics, should load their predecessors with as much infamy as the most inveterate malice and envy could suggest, or the most stupid ignorance and credulity in their underlings could swallow.
modernized: Simultaneously, I acknowledge that it was not only plausible but also expected - following the death of a monarch - for those who would assume power upon succession and intended to adopt a completely opposing political strategy to smear their predecessors with as much scandal as extreme malice, profound envy, or outrageous blindness among their followers could concoct or swallow.

original: There have been, I believe, twenty acts of Parliament, in six or seven years of the late King, for mending long tracts of impassable ways in several counties of England, by erecting turnpikes, and receiving passage-money, in a manner that everybody knows.
modernized: For twenty acts of Parliament in six to seven years during the reign of the late king, England undertook improvements on various impassable roads in several counties, using turnpikes and collecting tolls. This is widely known.

original: If what I have advanced be true, it would be hard to give a reason against the same practice here; since the necessity is as great, the advantage, in proportion, perhaps much greater, the materials of stone and gravel as easy to be found, and the workmanship, at least, twice as cheap.
modernized: If my statements are accurate, there would be a strong case to adopt the same measures here, given the similar need, potential benefits that may surpass those in England, and cheaper labor for road construction.

original: Besides, the work may be done gradually, with allowances for the poverty of the nation, by so many perch a year; but with a special care to encourage skill and diligence, and to prevent fraud in the undertakers, to which we are too liable, and which are not always confined to those of the meaner sort: but against these, no doubt, the wisdom of the nation may and will provide.
modernized: Moreover, the road improvements could be carried out over time, taking the nation's poverty into account by assigning a specific number of perches per year. Additionally, efforts should be made to incentivize competence and diligence, and deter fraud, aspiring to minimize instances of malpractice, which are not limited to the less affluent contractors. Undoubtedly, the nation's wisdom will find effective solutions for these challenges.

original: All the acts for encouraging plantations of forest-trees are, I am told, extremely defective; which, with great submission, must have been owing to a defect of skill in the contrivers of them.
modernized: The acts for supporting tree plantations are widely believed to be flawed, which can likely be attributed to a lack of skill among those who drafted the laws.

original: In this climate, by the continual blowing of the west-south-west wind, hardly any tree of value will come to perfection that is not planted in groves, except very rarely, and where there is much land-shelter.
modernized: In this climate, only a few trees of value can reach maturity without being planted in groves, and even then, only in areas with substantial protection.

original: I have not, indeed, read all the acts; but, from enquiry, I cannot learn that the planting in groves is enjoined.
modernized: I haven't read all the laws, but I can't find anything indicating that trees should be planted in groups or groves.

original: And as to the effects of these laws, I have not seen the least, in many hundred miles riding, except about a very few gentlemen's houses, and even those with very little skill or success.
modernized: Regarding the effects of these laws, I've seen little improvement in the majority of my travels, with only a handful of wealthy homeowners experiencing any success.

original: In all the rest, the hedges generally miscarry, as well as the larger slender twigs planted upon the tops of ditches, merely for want of common skill and care.
modernized: Generally, the hedges and plantings along the tops of ditches tend to fail because of a lack of common skill and attention.

original: I can do no business, I fear, because Mr. Lewis, who has nothing or little to do here, sticks close to me.
modernized: I'm unable to conduct my business effectively as Mr. Lewis, who is idle here, constantly accompanies me.

original: I dined today with the gentlemen ushers, among scurvy company; but the Queen was hunting the stag till four this afternoon, and she drove in her chaise above forty miles, and it was five before we went to dinner.
modernized: I had dinner today with the gentlemen ushers, but the Queen was off hunting with her stag until 4 p.m. She covered over forty miles in her carriage, and it wasn't until 5 pm that we sat down to dine.

original: Here are fine walks about this town.
modernized: The town offers beautiful walking routes.

original: I sometimes walk up the avenue.
modernized: From time to time, I take strolls up the aven.

original: Whilst the congress at Utrecht remained in this inactive state, the Queen proceeded to perfect that important article for preventing the union of France and Spain.
modernized: During the inactivity of the Utrecht congress, the Queen worked on a crucial piece to prevent the union of France and Spain.

original: It was proposed and accepted, that Philip should renounce France, for himself and his posterity; and that the Most Christian King, and all the princes of his blood, should, in the like manner, renounce Spain.
modernized: It was agreed that Philip would renounce France for himself and his descendants, and the Most Christian King, along with all his royal family, would also renounce Spain.

original: And although we do not intend to expose our own persons by mentioning names, yet we are so far from requiring the same caution in our correspondents, that on the contrary, we expressly charge and command them, in all the facts they send us, to set down the names, titles, and places of abode at length; together with a very particular description of the persons, dresses, and dispositions of the several lords, ladies, squires, madams, lawyers, gamesters, toupees, sots, wits, rakes, and informers, whom they shall have occasion to mention; otherwise it will not be possible for us to adjust our style to the different qualities, and capacities of the persons concerned, and treat them with the respect or familiarity, that may be due to their stations and characters, which we are determined to observe with the utmost strictness, that none may have cause to complain.
modernized: We will not divulge our own identities by naming names, but we do not ask the same anonymity from our correspondents. On the contrary, we explicitly request that they provide full information, including names, titles, addresses, and detailed descriptions of the various nobles, ladies, squires, madams, lawyers, gamblers, wig-wearers, drunkards, intellectuals, rakes, and informants they mention. If they omit these details, it will be challenging for us to tailor our writing to match the diverse qualities and appropriateness for the individuals involved, to avoid causing any complaints.

original: Notwithstanding my resentment, which to be sure, he does not value, I would be sorry he should bring upon himself the resentment of those he has been so free with, and I cannot help advising him, to take all possible care, and use all effectual means, to conjure the printer, corrector, and publisher of this libel to secrecy; that however the author may be suspected, he may not be discovered.
modernized: Despite my displeasure, which he seems not to care about, I would be unhappy if the author gets in trouble because of his criticism, and I suggest he should take every precaution to ask the printer, editor, and publisher of this defamatory text to keep it secret, thus avoiding any potential exposure of the author's identity.

original: Upon the whole, is not this author, justly to be reputed a defamer, till he produces instances wherein the conforming nobility and gentry of Ireland, have shown their disaffection to the succession of the illustrious House of Hanover?
modernized: Overall, isn't the author rightly considered a slanderer until he can prove examples where the conforming Irish nobility and gentry have displayed their opposition to the Hanover dynasty's succession?

original: In that perplexed condition of the public debts, which I have already described, this minister was brought into the treasury and exchequer, and had the chief direction of affairs.
modernized: In the existing chaotic state of the national debt, previously explained, this minister was assigned to oversee the treasury and exchequer, and he took charge of the primary management of affairs.

original: His first regulation was that of exchequer bills, which, to the great discouragement of public credit, and scandal to the crown, were three per cent. less in value than the sums specified in them.
modernized: The first action he took was to address the devaluation of exchequer bills, causing distress to the nation's credit and embarrassment to the crown, as the bills were worth three percent less than the amounts specified.

original: The present treasurer, being then chancellor of the exchequer, procured an Act of Parliament, by which the Bank of England should be obliged, in consideration of forty-five thousand pounds, to accept and circulate those bills without any discount.
modernized: As chancellor of the exchequer at the time, the current treasurer obtained a parliamentary act mandating the Bank of England to accept and circulate these bills without discount, in exchange for a sum of forty-five thousand pounds.

original: He then proceeded to stop the depredations of those who dealt in remittances of money to the army, who, by unheard of exactions in that kind of traffic, had amassed prodigious wealth at the public cost, to which the Earl of Godolphin had given too much way, possibly by neglect; for I think he cannot be accused of corruption.
modernized: He then set out to halt the exploitation of individuals involved in sending money to the army, who were profiting through excessive fees in the process. Earl of Godolphin may have allowed for this activity, either through neglect or lacking evidence of corruption.

original: Had the farmers been confined to plough a certain quantity of land, with a penalty of ten pounds an acre for whatever they exceeded, and farther limited for the three or four last years of their leases, all this evil had been prevented; the nation would have saved a million of money, and been more populous by above two hundred thousand souls.
modernized: If farmers were restricted to plow a specific amount of land, with a ten-pound penalty for each additional acre, and were further limited during the last three or four years of their leases, these issues could have been avoided. The country would have saved a million pounds, and had an additional population of over 200,000 people.

original: The falsehood of this will readily appear upon perusal of the work.
modernized: The falsehood in this will be evident when you read the work.

original: This shows he knew the most secret springs of every movement in the whole complicated machine.
modernized: This indicates he had insider knowledge of every aspect of the complex system.

original: That he states facts, too well known to be contested, in elegant simplicity, and reasons upon them with the talents of the greatest historian.
modernized: He lays out facts, widely acknowledged and uncontestable, in a straightforward manner, using the skills of a top-tier historian.

original: And thus makes an History, composed rather of negotiations than actions, most entertaining, affecting, and interesting, instead of being, as might be expected, heavy, dull, and disagreeable.
modernized: As a result, this History, primarily about political dealings rather than actions, is engaging, emotional, and intriguing. Contrary to expectations, it is not dull, heavy, and disagreeable.

original: King Henry having now lost hope of issue by his new Queen, brought with him, on his return to England, his daughter Maud, who by the Emperor's death had been lately left a widow and childless; and in a Parliament or general assembly which he had summoned at Windsor, he caused the crown to be settled on her and her children, and made all his nobles take a solemn oath to defend her title.
modernized: On his return to England, King Henry brought along his daughter Maud and had a Parliament or general assembly summoned at Windsor. There, he established the crown in her and her children's names and made all his nobles vow to protect her claim to the throne. Out of all the nobles, Stephen Earl of Boulogne was the most diligent and passionate in this process.

original: This was performed by none with so much forwardness as Stephen Earl of Boulogne, who was observed to shew a more than ordinary zeal in the matter.
modernized: The King's nephew, Stephen Earl of Boulogne, unwaveringly showed exceptional zeal in securing Maud's claim to the throne.

original: This young lord was the King's nephew, being second son of the Earl of Blois by Adela the Conqueror's daughter: he was in high favour with the King his uncle, who had married him to the daughter and heiress of the Earl of Boulogne, given him great possessions in England, and made him indeed too powerful for a subject.
modernized: Stephen Earl of Boulogne was the second son of the Earl of Blois by Adela the Conqueror's daughter. He was very favored by the King, who had given him the Earl of Boulogne's daughter and heiress in marriage, granted him significant lands in England, and made him super powerful for a subject.

original: I find likewise that your printer has been so careless as to confound the times, and mistake the dates, of my several voyages and returns; neither assigning the true year, nor the true month, nor day of the month: and I hear the original manuscript is all destroyed since the publication of my book; neither have I any copy left: however, I have sent you some corrections, which you may insert, if ever there should be a second edition: and yet I cannot stand to them; but shall leave that matter to my judicious and candid readers to adjust it as they please.
modernized: I have noticed that the printer made mistakes with dates and journeys in my books, and I've heard my original manuscript has been destroyed since publication. I don't have a copy anymore but I have provided corrections for a potential second edition. Still, I am hesitant to implement them myself. Instead, I will leave it up to my fair and discerning readers to correct them as they see fit.

original: I have sometimes wondered, upon what motive the peerage of England were so desirous to determine our controversies; because I have been assured, and partly know, that the frequent appeals from hence, have been very irksome to that illustrious body; and whoever hath frequented the Painted Chamber, and Court of Requests, must have observed, that they are never so nobly filled, as when an Irish appeal is under debate.
modernized: I sometimes speculate about why the English nobility are eager to settle our disputes, since I've been told and can confirm that the frequent appeals to them have been quite inconvenient. Moreover, anyone who has visited the Painted Chamber or Court of Requests will have noticed that they are most grandly populated when an Irish appeal is being debated.

original: Mons. Buys seemed to know little of his masters' mind, and pretended he had no power to conclude upon any thing.
modernized: Monsieur Buys appeared uncertain about his masters' intentions and claimed he lacked the power to make any decisions.

original: Her Majesty's minister proposed to him an alliance between the two nations, to subsist after a peace.
modernized: The Queen's minister suggested a lasting alliance between the two nations following a peace agreement.

original: To this he hearkened very readily, and offered to take the matter ad referendum, having authority to do no more.
modernized: Monsieur Buys agreed to consider the proposal but claimed he had no authority to make decisions.

original: His intention was, that he might appear to negotiate, in order to gain time to pick out, if possible, the whole secret of the transactions between Britain and France; to disclose nothing himself, nor bind his masters to any conditions; to seek delays till the Parliament met, and then observe what turn it took, and what would be the issue of those frequent cabals between himself and some other foreign ministers, in conjunction with the chief leaders of the discontented faction.
modernized: Monsieur Buys's intention was to appear as if he were negotiating, in order to buy time to uncover as much information as possible about the interactions between Britain and France. He intended to reveal nothing himself and bind his masters to no specific conditions. He also planned to delay until the Parliament met and observe the outcome of frequent meetings between himself and other foreign ministers along with the leading members of the dissatisfied faction.

original: 5. I dined in the City to-day, and went from hence early to town, and visited the Duke of Ormond and Mr. Secretary.
modernized: 5. Today, I had lunch in the city and later went to visit the Duke of Ormond and the Secretary.

original: They say my Lord Treasurer has a dead warrant in his pocket; they mean a list of those who are to be turned out of employment; and we every day now expect those changes.
modernized: There are rumors that the Lord Treasurer has a list of people to be dismissed from their positions, and we are constantly expecting these changes.

original: I passed by the Treasury to-day, and saw vast crowds waiting to give Lord Treasurer petitions as he passes by.
modernized: I walked past the Treasury today and saw large groups of people waiting to present petitions to the Lord Treasurer.

original: He is now at the top of power and favour: he keeps no levees yet.
modernized: He is now in a powerful position and receives no visitors yet.

original: I am cruel thirsty this hot weather. -- I am just this minute going to swim.
modernized: I am extremely thirsty in this hot weather. -- I am about to go for a swim.

original: I take Patrick down with me, to hold my nightgown, shirt, and slippers, and borrow a napkin of my landlady for a cap.
modernized: I ask Patrick to accompany me in the pool to help me with my nightclothes, shirt, and slippers, and borrow a towel from my landlady as a makeshift cap.

original: So farewell till I come up; but there is no danger, don't be frighted. -- I have been swimming this half-hour and more; and when I was coming out I dived, to make my head and all through wet, like a cold bath; but, as I dived, the napkin fell off and is lost, and I have that to pay for.
modernized: Until I return, farewell; there is no need to worry. -- I have been swimming for a half-hour or more; when I emerged, I dove to submerge myself and cool off, but my towel fell off and is now lost, and I have to pay for it.

original: O, faith, the great stones were so sharp, I could hardly set my feet on them as I came out.
modernized: Oh, the large stones were so sharp, it was difficult for me to step on them as I got out.

original: It was pure and warm.
modernized: It was warm and comfortable.

original: I got to bed, and will now go sleep.
modernized: I have returned to bed and will now go to sleep.

original: About four hours after we began our journey, I awaked by a very ridiculous accident; for the carriage being stopped a while, to adjust something that was out of order, two or three of the young natives had the curiosity to see how I looked when I was asleep; they climbed up into the engine, and advancing very softly to my face, one of them, an officer in the guards, put the sharp end of his half-pike a good way up into my left nostril, which tickled my nose like a straw, and made me sneeze violently; whereupon they stole off unperceived, and it was three weeks before I knew the cause of my waking so suddenly.
modernized: Four hours after we started, I woke up due to a funny mishap; while the carriage paused momentarily to fix something, a few curious young locals peeked into the vehicle and one of them, an officer, stuck his half-pike up my left nostril, tickling it like a straw and causing me to sneeze violently. They left without me noticing until three weeks later.

original: We made a long march the remaining part of the day, and, rested at night with five hundred guards on each side of me, half with torches, and half with bows and arrows, ready to shoot me if I should offer to stir.
modernized: For the rest of the day, we continued our journey, stopping overnight with guards on both sides, armed with torches and bows, ensuring I didn't move. Half of them were stationed with torches and half with bows on standby, ready to shoot me if I stirred.

original: The next morning at sunrise we continued our march, and arrived within two hundred yards of the city gates about noon.
modernized: The following morning, the sun had risen and we begun moving again, reaching within 200 yards of the city gates by noon.

original: The emperor, and all his court, came out to meet us; but his great officers would by no means suffer his majesty to endanger his person by mounting on my body.
modernized: Upon our arrival, the emperor and his entire court appeared but his high officials refused to let him climb on me due to safety concerns.

original: The reformation of the stage is entirely in the power of the Queen, and in the consequences it hath upon the minds of the younger people, does very well deserve the strictest care.
modernized: The Queen has the sole power to reform the stage, and its impact on the younger generation warrants the utmost attention.

original: Besides the indecent and profane passages, besides the perpetual turning into ridicule the very function of the priesthood, with other irregularities, in most modern comedies, which have by others been objected to them, it is worth observing the distributive justice of the authors, which is constantly applied to the punishment of virtue, and the reward of vice, directly opposite to the rules of their best critics, as well as to the practice of dramatic poets, in all other ages and countries.
modernized: Despite the indecent and blasphemous passages, the continuous mockery of the priesthood, and other irregularities in modern comedies, it is notable that authors typically portray justice in an opposite manner to their best critics and the practices of dramatic poets in all other eras.

original: For example, a country squire, who is represented with no other vice but that of being a clown, and having the provincial accent upon his tongue, which is neither a fault, nor in his power to remedy, must be condemned to marry a cast wench, or a cracked chambermaid.
modernized: For instance, a simple-minded, unsophisticated country squire who is portrayed with only a provincial accent is forced to marry a wavering, immoral woman, be it a loose woman or a cranky maidservant.

original: On the other side, a rakehell of the town, whose character is set off with no other accomplishment, but excessive prodigality, profaneness, intemperance, and lust, is rewarded with a lady of great fortune to repair his own, which his vices had almost ruined.
modernized: On the contrary, a town playboy, displayed solely for his profligacy, profanity, drunkenness, and lechery, is rewarded with a woman of wealth to mend his own fate, which his vices nearly ruined.

original: And as in a tragedy, the hero is represented to have obtained many victories in order to raise his character in the minds of the spectators; so the hero of a comedy is represented to have been victorious in all his intrigues, for the same reason.
modernized: Similar to a tragedy hero who is portrayed as victorious to enhance his character in the eyes of the audience, a comedy hero is depicted as victorious in all his deceptive maneuvers, for the same reason.

original: I do not remember, that our English poets ever suffered a criminal amour to succeed upon the stage, till the reign of King Charles the Second.
modernized: I don't recall any English playwriters sanctioning successful criminal relationships onstage before the reign of King Charles the Second.

original: Ever since that time, the alderman is made a cuckold, the deluded virgin is debauched, and adultery and fornication are supposed to be committed behind the scenes, as part of the action.
modernized: Since that time, the alderman is presented as a cuckolded husband, virgins are deceived, and adultery and fornication are assumed to occur offstage as part of the play.

original: These and many more corruptions of the theatre, peculiar to our age and nation, need continue no longer, than while the court is content to connive at or neglect them.
modernized: These and many other improprieties unique to our modern theater should cease, as long as the court tolerates or overlooks them.

original: Surely a pension would not be ill employed on some men of wit, learning, and virtue, who might have power to strike out every offensive or unbecoming passage, from plays already written, as well as those that may be offered to the stage for the future.
modernized: Granting pensions to sharp, knowledgeable, and virtuous individuals could enable them to eliminate offensive or inappropriate lines from existing plays, as well as those yet to be presented on stage.

original: By which, and other wise regulations, the theatre might become a very innocent and useful diversion, instead of being a scandal and reproach to our religion and country.
modernized: Thus, by implementing such regulations, the theater could evolve into an innocent and beneficial pastime, rather than a disgrace to our religion and nation.

original: He had a tongue so musculous and subtile, that he could twist it up into his nose and deliver a strange kind of speech from thence.
modernized: He had such a muscular and eloquent tongue that he could speak from his nose in a peculiar manner.

original: He was also the first in these kingdoms who began to improve the Spanish accomplishment of braying; and having large ears perpetually exposed and erected, he carried his art to such a perfection, that it was a point of great difficulty to distinguish either by the view or the sound between the original and the copy.
modernized: He was the initial pioneer of enhancing the Spanish technique of the donkey bray in these kingdoms, becoming so skilled that he could not be differentiated from the original or the imitation by sight or sound.

original: This is an exact inventory of what we found about the body of the man-mountain, who used us with great civility and due respect to your majesty's commission.
modernized: A detailed account of the items found on the Man Mountain, who was very polite and respectful in accordance with your majesty's commission.

original: Signed and sealed, on the fourth day of the eighty-ninth moon of your majesty's auspicious reign.
modernized: Signed and notarized, on the 4th day of the 89th lunar cycle during your majesty's prosperous reign.

original: These things, my Lord, would seem strange in Westminster-hall, and would be severely noted in St. Stephen's Chapel.
modernized: These actions, my Lord, would seem unacceptable in Westminster-Hall and would be strongly criticized in St. Stephen's Chapel.

original: The honour of the Crown would be thought a very false as well as weak plea for such proceedings there, as indeed it is an infamous one everywhere, for 'tis a scandal upon a king, if he is represented in a court of justice, as if he were partially concerned or rather inclined to desire, that a party should be found guilty, than that he should be declared innocent.
modernized: The Crown's honor would be viewed as a weak and dishonest justification for such actions in these courts, because it reflects poorly on a king to appear biased towards unjustly convicting someone rather than declaring their innocence.

original: The King, in his return homeward, laid siege to Ludlow Castle, which had not been reduced with the rest: here Prince Henry of Scotland, boiling with youth and valour, and exposing his person upon all occasions, was lifted from his horse by an iron grapple let down from the wall, and would have been hoisted up into the castle, if the King had not immediately flown to his assistance, and brought him off with his own hands by main force from the enemy, whom he soon compelled to surrender the castle.
modernized: As he returned home, King Steven laid siege to Ludlow Castle, the only one remaining to be taken. At the castle, Prince Henry of Scotland, full of youth and bravery, frequently put himself in danger. He was grabbed from his horse by an iron hook dropped from the wall, but the King quickly came to save him from the enemy. The enemy was then forced to surrender the castle.

original: When this happy Art of polite Conversing shall be thoroughly improved, good Company will be no longer pestered with dull, dry, tedious Story-tellers, nor brangling Disputers: For, a right Scholar, of either Sex, in our Science, will perpetually interrupt them with some sudden surprising Piece of Wit, that shall engage all the Company in a loud Laugh; and, if after a Pause, the grave Companion resumes his Thread in the following Manner; Well, but to go on with my Story; new Interruptions come from the Left to the Right, till he is forced to give over.
modernized: If polite conversation is mastered proficiently, large groups will no longer be bothered by boring, pointless storytellers or endless debaters. Instead, a highly skilled conversationalist will continuously respond with brief, amusing witticisms to disrupt the conversation and elicit a loud laugh from the group. Following a pause, the original speaker may attempt to continue their story, but will instead be interrupted again until they eventually let the conversation drop.

original: I believe, sir, you are by this time heartily tired with this indigested letter, and are firmly persuaded of the truth of what I said in the beginning of it, that you had much better have imposed this task on some of our citizens of greater abilities.
modernized: I suspect, sir, you've grown tired and convinced of the truth in my initial comments, understanding that someone more skilled should have handled this letter.

original: But perhaps, sir, such a letter as this may be, for the singularity of it, entertaining to you, who correspond with the politest and most learned men in Europe.
modernized: However, sir, a letter like this might be unique and engaging to you, given your connections with the most sophisticated and intellectual figures in Europe.

original: But I am satisfied you will excuse its want of exactness and perspicuity, when you consider my education, my being unaccustomed to writings of this nature, and, above all, those calamitous objects which constantly surround us, sufficient to disturb the cleanest imagination, and the soundest judgment.
modernized: I assure you, considering my lack of formal education, my inexperience in writing, and the constant distress that surrounds me due to the ongoing calamities, you should forgive its inaccuracies and unclear nature.

original: Whereas the bearer served me the space of one year, during which time he was an idler and a drunkard, I then discharged him as such; but how far his having been five years at sea may have mended his manners, I leave to the penetration of those who may hereafter choose to employ him.
modernized: Since the bearer served me for a year but proved idle and intoxicated, I dismissed him, but I cannot predict if his previous time at sea has improved his behavior. Future employers must judge this for themselves.

original: Some time before Henry landed, the King had conceived a project to disappoint his designs, by confirming the crown upon himself and his own posterity.
modernized: Before Duke Henry arrived in England, the King had a plan to secure his own succession by being crowned king and his son, Eustace, being crowned king as well.

original: He sent for the Archbishop of Canterbury, with several other prelates, and proposed that his son Eustace should be crowned King with all the usual solemnity: but the bishops absolutely refused to perform the office, by express orders from the Pope, who was an enemy to Stephen, partly upon account of his unjust or declining cause, but chiefly for his strict alliance with the King of France, who was then engaged in a quarrel against that See, upon a very tender point relating to the revenues of vacant churches.
modernized: The King summoned the Archbishop of Canterbury and several other prelates, and proposed that Eustace should be officially crowned king, but the bishops refused as per the pope's orders, as the pope was against King Stephen due to his questionable rule and his alliance with the King of France, who was at odds with the church over the finances of vacant churches.

original: The King and his son were both enraged at the bishops' refusal, and kept them prisoners in the chamber where they assembled, with many threats to force them to a compliance, and some other circumstances of rigour; but all to no purpose, so that he was at length forced to desist.
modernized: The King and Eustace were furious with the bishops' refusal and kept them imprisoned in the room they were meeting in, making threats and using force to force compliance, but to no avail, so the King eventually stopped.

original: But the archbishop, to avoid further vexation, fled the realm.
modernized: The Archbishop, to avoid further trouble, left the realm.

original: In the year one thousand six hundred and ninety-seven, a general mortgage was made of certain revenues and taxes already settled, which amounted to near a million a year.
modernized: In 1697, a general mortgage was made on existing revenues and taxes, totaling almost a million pounds annually.

original: This mortgage was to continue till one thousand seven hundred and six, to be a fund for the payment of about five millions one hundred thousand pounds.
modernized: This mortgage was meant to last till 1706, serving as a fund to pay approximately five million one hundred thousand pounds.

original: In the first Parliament of the Queen, the said mortgage was continued till one thousand seven hundred and ten, to supply a deficiency of two millions three hundred thousand pounds, and interest of above a million; and in the intermediate years a great part of that fund was branched out into annuities for ninety-nine years; so that the late ministry raised all their money to one thousand seven hundred and ten, only by continuing funds which were already granted to their hands.
modernized: In the first Parliament of the reigning Queen, the mortgage was extended till 1710, providing for a shortfall of two million three hundred thousand pounds and over a million in interest, as well as extending a significant portion of the fund into annuities for 99 years, which allowed the late administration to secure all their funds up to 1710 by merely continuing already-granted funds.

original: This deceived the people in general, who were satisfied to continue the payments they had been accustomed to, and made the administration seem easy, since the war went on without any new taxes raised, except the very last year they were in power; not considering what a mighty fund was exhausted, and must be perpetuated, although extremely injurious to trade, and to the true interest of the nation.
modernized: This scheme tricked the general public, who continued making their regular payments and saw the administration as efficient because the war continued without new taxes except the last one before they lost power; however, they did not consider the massive fund that was being depleted and needed to be perpetuated, despite causing significant harm to trade and the nation's overall welfare.

original: Thus let every man look with a severe and impartial eye into all the distinct regions of the heart, and no doubt, several deformities and irregularities, that he never thought of, will open and disclose themselves upon so near a view; and rather make the man ashamed of himself, than proud.
modernized: Examine each compartment of the heart with an honest and unbiased gaze, and you will likely uncover faults and oddities you weren't previously aware of. This introspection is more likely to make you feel embarrassed about yourself rather than proud.

original: The next thing he demanded was one of the hollow iron pillars, by which he meant my pocket-pistols.
modernized: He asked for one of the metal tubes, hence referring to my hidden pocket pistols.

original: I drew it out, and at his desire, as well as I could, expressed to him the use of it; and charging it only with powder, which, by the closeness of my pouch, happened to escape wetting in the sea (an inconvenience against which all prudent mariners take special care to provide), I first cautioned the emperor not to be afraid, and then let it off in the air.
modernized: I handed it over to him while explaining its purpose, and loaded it with only dry gunpowder, which remained dry due to the compactness of my pouch (mariners often take precautions against this issue). Initially, I reassured the emperor not to fear, and then discharged it in the air.

original: I must beg leave to caution your lordships and worships in one particular.
modernized: Excuse me for interrupting, but I need to warn the noblemen and gentlemen about one thing.

original: Wood hath graciously promised to load us at present only with forty thousand pounds of his coin, till the exigences of the kingdom require the rest.
modernized: Mr. Wood has kindly agreed to distribute only 40,000 pounds of his coins for now, until the kingdom needs more. I kindly request that you don't allow Mr. Wood to decide what the kingdom needs.

original: I entreat you will never suffer Mr. Wood to be a judge of your exigences.
modernized: As long as there's even a single piece of silver or gold left in the kingdom, he'll call it an emergency. He'

original: While there is one piece of silver or gold remaining in the kingdom he will call it an exigency, he will double his present quantum by stealth as soon as he can, and will have the remainder still to the good.
modernized: He'll secretly increase the amount he's currently producing and keep the remaining coins for himself. He'll counterfeit his own coins and ones from France and Holland, and our local coiners will follow suit.

original: He will pour his own rapsand counterfeits upon us: France and Holland will do the same; nor will our own coiners at home be behind them: To confirm which I have now in my pocket a rap or counterfeit halfpenny in imitation of his, but so ill performed, that in my conscience I believe it is not of his coining.
modernized: To prove my point, I have a counterfeit halfpenny in my pocket, made to look like his, but I believe it's not genuinely his work because it's so poorly made.

original: He was, besides, a person of great design and improvement in affairs of devotion, having introduced a new deity, who has since met with a vast number of worshippers, by some called Babel, by others Chaos, who had an ancient temple of Gothic structure upon Salisbury plain, famous for its shrine and celebration by pilgrims.
modernized: In addition, this person was known for introducing a new god and making significant improvements in religious affairs. This deity, also referred to as Babel or Chaos, had a famous temple with a Gothic structure on Salisbury plain, attracting numerous pilgrims and worshippers.

original: By the ancient law of this realm, still in force, every parish is obliged to maintain its own poor, which although some may think to be not very equal, because many parishes are very rich, and have few poor among them, and others the contrary; yet, I think, may be justly defended: For as to remote country parishes in the desert part of the kingdom, the necessaries of life are there so cheap, that the infirm poor may be provided for with little burden to the inhabitants.
modernized: Under the ancient law of the realm, every parish is still obligated to provide for their own impoverished locals, though some may argue this isn't equitable due to disparities in wealth between parishes. For example, in isolated rural parts, the cost of essentials is low, making it easier to care for the needy.

original: But in what I am going to say, I shall confine myself only to this city, where we are overrun not only with our own poor, but with a far greater number from every part of the nation.
modernized: Moving forward, I will focus only on this city, which is swamped not just by its own poor, but by an even greater number from various regions of the nation.

original: Now, I say, this evil of being encumbered with so many foreign beggars, who have not the least title to our charity, and whom it is impossible for us to support, may be easily remedied, if the government of this city, in conjunction with the clergy and parish officers, would think it worth their care; and I am sure few things deserve it better.
modernized: I assert that this problem of numerous non-resident beggars, who have no right to our charity and cannot be supported by us, can be alleviated if the city government, along with the clergy and parish leaders, take action; I am confident that few things warrant attention more.

original: For, if every parish would take a list of those begging poor which properly belong to it, and compel each of them to wear a badge, marked and numbered, so as to be seen and known by all they meet, and confine them to beg within the limits of their own parish, severely punishing them when they offend, and driving out all interlopers from other parishes, we could then make a computation of their numbers; and the strollers from the country being driven away, the remainder would not be too many for the charity of those who pass by to maintain; neither would any beggar, although confined to his own parish, be hindered from receiving the charity of the whole town; because, in this case, those well-disposed persons who walk the streets will give their charity to such whom they think proper objects, wherever they meet them, provided they are found in their own parishes, and wearing their badges of distinction.
modernized: If every parish creates a list of its own eligible impoverished residents, requires them to wear identifying badges, and confines them to beg only within their own parish, while enforcing severe penalties for rule-breaking and expelling intruders from other parishes, we could estimate the number of recipients. This would also drive away rural wanderers, leaving a manageable number for the compassionate passerby to support. Indeed, well-intentioned individuals walking the streets could offer charity to deserving individuals found in their own parishes, as recognized by their badges.

original: And, as to those parishes which bordered upon the skirts and suburbs of the town, where country strollers are used to harbour themselves, they must be forced to go back to their homes, when they find nobody to relieve them, because they want that mark which only gives them licence to beg.
modernized: Regarding parishes on the outskirts of town where migrant beggars often reside, their return to their home territories should be enforced when they fail to find support. These individuals lack the necessary mark that authorizes begging.

original: Upon this point, it were to be wished, that inferior parish officers had better encouragement given them to perform their duty in driving away all beggars who do not belong to the parish, instead of conniving at them, as it is said they do for some small contribution: For the whole city would save much more by ridding themselves of many hundred beggars, than they would lose by giving parish officers a reasonable support.
modernized: It would be beneficial if lesser parish officials were incentivized to fulfill their duty of expelling unauthorized beggars, rather than allowing them to stay for a small fee; the entire city could financially benefit from this, as it would eliminate hundreds of beggars, while the cost of supporting parish officers would be minimal.

original: It is usual for clergymen who are taxed with this learned defect, to quote Dr. Tillotson, and other famous divines, in their defence; without considering the difference between elaborate discourses upon important occasions, delivered to princes or parliaments, written with a view of being made public, and a plain sermon intended for the middle or lower size of people.
modernized: Clergymen often defend themselves against being criticized for their learned language, by quoting Dr. Tillotson and other famous religious figures. However, they fail to recognize the difference between formal speeches for important events, written for publication, and sermons meant for everyday people.

original: Neither do they seem to remember the many alterations, additions, and expungings, made by great authors in those treatises which they prepare for the public.
modernized: Moreover, these clergymen neglect to recall all the changes, additions, and deletions made by distinguished authors in the works meant for public consumption.

original: Besides, that excellent prelate abovementioned, was known to preach after a much more popular manner in the city congregations: and if in those parts of his works he be any where too obscure for the understandings of many who may be supposed to have been his hearers, it ought to be numbered among his omissions.
modernized: Additionally, this esteemed prelate that was previously mentioned was known to preach in a more accessible manner in city congregations. If parts of his works are too obscure for those who are presumed to have been his congregants, these should be considered omissions.

original: In journeys, when I was weary of the coach, a servant on horseback would buckle on my box, and place it upon a cushion before him; and there I had a full prospect of the country on three sides from my three windows.
modernized: During travels, when I was tired of the coach, a servant rode alongside with my box attached, placing it on a cushioned stand for a wide viewing of the countryside from the three windows.

original: I had in this closet a field-bed, and a hammock hung from the ceiling, two chairs and a table, neatly screwed to the floor, to prevent being tossed about by the agitation of the horse or the coach.
modernized: In this travel-friendly closet, equipped with a bed, hammock, and secured chairs/table, I found refuge against the horse or coach's turbulent movement.

original: And having been long used to sea voyages, those motions, although sometimes very violent, did not much discompose me.
modernized: Having been accustomed to sea travel, the harsh motion, though often intense, didn't unsettle me much.

original: Meanwhile, those books that were advocates for the Moderns, chose out one from among them to make a progress through the whole library, examine the number and strength of their party, and concert their affairs.
modernized: In the meantime, books representing the Modern faction selected one to explore the entire library, assess their opposition, and organize their strategies.

original: This messenger performed all things very industriously, and brought back with him a list of their forces, in all, fifty thousand, consisting chiefly of light-horse, heavy-armed foot, and mercenaries; whereof the foot were in general but sorrily armed and worse clad; their horses large, but extremely out of case and heart; however, some few, by trading among the Ancients, had furnished themselves tolerably enough.
modernized: This emissary worked diligently, gathering a report of their total forces, approximately 50,000, primarily composed of cavalry, infantry, and mercenaries. The infantry were under-equipped and poorly dressed, while the horses were large but out of shape and low in spirits. However, some had managed to acquire decent supplies by trading with the Ancients.

original: When you invite the neighbouring Servants to junket with you at home in an Evening, teach them a peculiar way of tapping or scraping at the Kitchen Window, which you may hear, but not your Master or Lady, whom you must take Care not to disturb or frighten at such unseasonable Hours.
modernized: When hosting an informal gathering at home in the evening, instruct the nearby servants to knock or scratch on a specific Kitchen window to notify you, while ensuring your master and lady remain unaware and undisturbed during unusual hours.

original: By these means the poets, for many years past, were all overrun with pedantry.
modernized: In recent years, poets have been inundated with a display of pretentiousness.

original: For, as I take it, the word is not properly used; because pedantry is the too front or unseasonable obtruding our own knowledge in common discourse, and placing too great a value upon it; by which definition men of the court or the army may be as guilty of pedantry as a philosopher or a divine; and it is the same vice in women when they are over copious upon the subject of their petticoats, or their fans, or their china.
modernized: I believe the term 'pedantry' is misused because pedantry is the over-emphasis or inappropriate sharing of our own knowledge in casual conversation, and valuing it too highly; by this definition, individuals from court, the army, or the church may exhibit pedantry just as much as scholars or clergy; and it's the same flaw in women when they excessively discuss their fashion, accessories, or china.

original: For which reason, although it be a piece of prudence, as well as good manners, to put men upon talking on subjects they are best versed in, yet that is a liberty a wise man could hardly take; because, beside the imputation of pedantry, it is what he would never improve by.
modernized: For this reason, although it is wise and polite to prompt men to discuss topics they are most knowledgeable about, a wise man would find it difficult to exercise this freedom, as it may lead to the accusation of pedantry, and it is something he would never grow from.

original: First, That until some late proceedings are a little forgot, they would take care not to provoke, by any violence of tongue or pen, so great a majority, as there is now against them, nor keep up any longer that combination with their broken allies, but disperse themselves, and lie dormant against some better opportunity: I have shewn, they could have got no advantage if the late party had prevailed; and they will certainly lose none by its fall, unless through their own fault.
modernized: First, it's advisable for the Dissenters to temporarily suppress any provocative statements or actions towards the majority that currently opposes them, avoid prolonging their alliances with discredited groups, and instead bide their time for a more opportune moment. I've demonstrated that they wouldn't have benefited if the previous party had won, and they won't lose anything by its demise, unless due to their own mistakes.

original: They pretend a mighty veneration for the Queen; let them give proof of it, by quitting the ruined interest of those who have used her so ill; and by a due respect to the persons she is pleased to trust at present with her affairs: When they can no longer hope to govern, when struggling can do them no good, and may possibly hurt them, what is left but to be silent and passive?
modernized: The Dissenters claim to hold great respect for the Queen; they should demonstrate this by distancing themselves from the tarnished interests of those who have mistreated her, and by showing proper deference to the individuals she currently trusts with her affairs. Once their hopes of governing disappear, and struggling no longer benefits them but may potentially harm them, what is left but to remain quiet and compliant?

original: In this desolate condition I advanced forward, and soon got upon firm ground, where I sat down on a bank to rest myself, and consider what I had best do.
modernized: Moving forward in this desolate situation, I reached solid ground and sat down on a hillside to breathe and contemplate my next course.

original: When I was a little refreshed, I went up into the country, resolving to deliver myself to the first savages I should meet, and purchase my life from them by some bracelets, glass rings, and other toys, which sailors usually provide themselves with in those voyages, and whereof I had some about me.
modernized: Once rested, I headed towards the countryside, intending to approach the first humans I encounter, hoping to negotiate bartering trinkets for my freedom as sailors typically do on these voyages.

original: The land was divided by long rows of trees, not regularly planted, but naturally growing; there was great plenty of grass, and several fields of oats.
modernized: The land was divided by rows of naturally growing trees, there was much grass and fields of oats.

original: I walked very circumspectly, for fear of being surprised, or suddenly shot with an arrow from behind, or on either side.
modernized: I walked warily, suspecting ambush or sudden attack from hidden enemies.

original: I fell into a beaten road, where I saw many tracts of human feet, and some of cows, but most of horses.
modernized: I stumbled upon a path where human and animal footprints were clear, and there was evidence of horses more than cows.

original: At last I beheld several animals in a field, and one or two of the same kind sitting in trees.
modernized: At last, I saw several creatures in a field and a pair identical ones in trees.

original: Their shape was very singular and deformed, which a little discomposed me, so that I lay down behind a thicket to observe them better.
modernized: Their appearance was strange and unsettling, making me lie low to get a better look.

original: Some of them coming forward near the place where I lay, gave me an opportunity of distinctly marking their form.
modernized: Some of the creatures came near the hiding spot, allowing me to observe them carefully.

original: Their heads and breasts were covered with a thick hair, some frizzled, and others lank; they had beards like goats, and a long ridge of hair down their backs, and the fore parts of their legs and feet; but the rest of their bodies was bare, so that I might see their skins, which were of a brown buff colour.
modernized: They had thick hair on their heads, beards like goats, rows of hair on their backs, and hairs on their forefeet and faces. Their skin was brownish in color.

original: They had no tails, nor any hair at all on their buttocks, except about the anus, which, I presume, nature had placed there to defend them as they sat on the ground, for this posture they used, as well as lying down, and often stood on their hind feet.
modernized: They did not have tails; only hair around their anus. They sat and walked on their hind legs quite often, but could also lie down.

original: They climbed high trees as nimbly as a squirrel, for they had strong extended claws before and behind, terminating in sharp points, and hooked.
modernized: They could climb trees nimbly, having long sharp claws on their front and back paws.

original: They would often spring, and bound, and leap, with prodigious agility.
modernized: They often leaped, bounded, and jumped with incredible agility.

original: The females were not so large as the males; they had long lank hair on their heads, but none on their faces, nor any thing more than a sort of down on the rest of their bodies, except about the anus and pudenda.
modernized: The females were smaller than males, having long hair only on their heads, short downy hair elsewhere, and hair around their genital areas.

original: The dugs hung between their fore feet, and often reached almost to the ground as they walked.
modernized: The mammary glands hung between their front legs, nearly touching the ground.

original: The hair of both sexes was of several colours, brown, red, black, and yellow.
modernized: Both sexes had hair of various colors, from brown, red, black to yellow.

original: Upon the whole, I never beheld, in all my travels, so disagreeable an animal, or one against which I naturally conceived so strong an antipathy.
modernized: In summary, I had never beheld such a disagreeable animal, and I developed a strong natural dislike towards them.

original: So that, thinking I had seen enough, full of contempt and aversion, I got up, and pursued the beaten road, hoping it might direct me to the cabin of some Indian.
modernized: Convinced I had seen enough, full of contempt and aversion, I stood up and continued along the path, hoping it would lead me to an Indian settlement.

original: I had not got far, when I met one of these creatures full in my way, and coming up directly to me.
modernized: I had barely moved when I encountered one of these animals directly in my path, and it came straight towards me.

original: The ugly monster, when he saw me, distorted several ways, every feature of his visage, and stared, as at an object he had never seen before; then approaching nearer, lifted up his forepaw, whether out of curiosity or mischief I could not tell; but I drew my hanger, and gave him a good blow with the flat side of it, for I durst not strike with the edge, fearing the inhabitants might be provoked against me, if they should come to know that I had killed or maimed any of their cattle.
modernized: The hideous creature was startled when it saw me, contorting every facial feature as if it had never encountered such a sight. It approached closer, lifting its front paw as if curious or hostile. I drew my knife, cautiously striking it with the flat side, worried the inhabitants might become hostile if they knew I had injured their cattle.

original: When the beast felt the smart, he drew back, and roared so loud, that a herd of at least forty came flocking about me from the next field, howling and making odious faces; but I ran to the body of a tree, and leaning my back against it, kept them off by waving my hanger.
modernized: When the creature felt the blow, it retreated, roaring loudly enough to gather at least forty others from the surrounding field, who came howling and snarling. I ran to a tree for cover, using my knife to ward them off.

original: Several of this cursed brood, getting hold of the branches behind, leaped up into the tree, whence they began to discharge their excrements on my head; however, I escaped pretty well by sticking close to the stem of the tree, but was almost stifled with the filth, which fell about me on every side.
modernized: Some of these creatures leaped on branches behind me, raining excrement on my head. I managed to stay clear by staying close to the tree's trunk, but the filth fell on me everywhere.

original: I am now opening the book which I propose to examine.
modernized: I am about to open the book that I will be examining.

original: An employment, as it is entirely new to me, so it is that to which, of all others, I have naturally the greatest antipathy.
modernized: This job I am starting is entirely new to me, and of all others, I find it with the greatest natural aversion.

original: And, indeed, who can dwell upon a tedious piece of insipid thinking, and false reasoning, so long as I am likely to do, without sharing the infection?
modernized: Indeed, who could dwell on a tedious, insipid piece of thinking, and false reasoning, for as long as I might, without also becoming infected?

original: Besides all this, the army of the sciences hath been of late with a world of martial discipline drawn into its close order, so that a view or a muster may be taken of it with abundance of expedition.
modernized: Recent advancements in scientific discipline have organized the army of sciences in a well-disciplined manner, allowing for efficient and speedy observation and scrutiny.

original: For this great blessing we are wholly indebted to systems and abstracts, in which the modern fathers of learning, like prudent usurers, spent their sweat for the ease of us their children.
modernized: We owe this great convenience to the creation of systems and summarized knowledge by modern scholars, who have put in significant effort to facilitate understanding for the next generations.

original: For labour is the seed of idleness, and it is the peculiar happiness of our noble age to gather the fruit.
modernized: Labor paves the way for laziness, and it is a unique gift of our modern era to reap the rewards.

original: In order to reform the vices of this town, which, as we have said, hath so mighty an influence on the whole kingdom, it would be very instrumental to have a law made, that all taverns and alehouses should be obliged to dismiss their company at twelve at night, and shut up their doors, and that no woman should be suffered to enter any tavern or alehouse, upon any pretence whatsoever.
modernized: To reduce the vices of this significant city that has a great impact on the entire kingdom, it would be beneficial to pass a law requiring taverns and pubs to close at midnight, prohibiting women from entering these establishments for any reason.

original: It is easy to conceive what a number of ill consequences such a law would prevent, the mischiefs of quarrels, and lewdness, and thefts, and midnight brawls, the diseases of intemperance and venery, and a thousand other evils needless to mention.
modernized: This law would prevent numerous negative consequences, including disputes, improper behavior, theft, late-night fights, health issues related to excessive drinking and sexual activity, among other problems that do not need to be mentioned.

original: Nor would it be amiss, if the masters of those public-houses were obliged, upon the severest penalties, to give only a proportioned quantity of drink to every company, and when he found his guests disordered with excess, to refuse them any more.
modernized: Additionally, the managers of these public houses should be forced to provide only a reasonable amount of alcohol to patrons and refrain from serving them more if they are already drunk.

original: Another of his quarrels is against pluralities and non-residence: As to the former, it is a word of ill name, but not well understood.
