modernized: One of the issues Swift criticizes is pluralities and non-residence: While the term 'pluralities' is negative but not clearly defined, it refers to the practice of combining small vicarages to achievea

original: The clergy having been stripped of the greatest part of their revenues, the glebes being generally lost, the tithes in the hands of laymen, the churches demolished, and the country depopulated; in order to preserve a face of Christianity, it was necessary to unite small vicarages, sufficient to make a tolerable maintenance for a minister.
modernized: Since the clergy have been largely deprived of their revenue, lost glebes, parish tithes held by laymen, destroyed churches, and a dwindling population, it became necessary to merge small parishes in order to provide a reasonable living for a minister.

original: The profit of ten or a dozen of these unions, do seldom amount to above eighty or an hundred pounds a year: If there be a very few dignitaries, whose preferments are, perhaps, more liable to this accusation, it is to be supposed, they may be favourites of the time, or persons of superior merit, for whom there hath ever been some indulgence in all governments.
modernized: The income from ten to a dozen of these merged parishes rarely exceeds £80 to £100 per year; if there are a few high-ranking clergy who may be accused of holding multiple positions, it's likely they are favorites of the time or individuals of exceptional merit who have traditionally received special treatment in all governments.

original: As to the native poor of this city, there would be little or no damage in confining them to their several parishes.
modernized: Regarding the local poor of this city, it's unlikely that detaining them within their respective parishes would cause much harm.

original: For instance; a beggar of the parish of St. Warborough's, or any other parish here, if he be an object of compassion, hath an equal chance to receive his proportion of alms from every charitable hand; because the inhabitants, one or other, walk through every street in town, and give their alms, without considering the place, wherever they think it may be well disposed of: and these helps, added to what they get in eatables by going from house to house among the gentry and citizens, will, without being very burthensome, be sufficient to keep them alive.
modernized: For example, a beggar from any parish in this city, if they're considered deserving of help, has an equal chance to receive alms from any charitable individual; because the townspeople offer alms while strolling through the streets, not considering the specific parish, as long as they see it as a worthwhile cause. These donations, combined with food they receive by visiting local nobility and citizens, would be enough to sustain them without causing too much burden.

original: As to the House of Lords, the difficulty there is conceived at least as great as in ours.
modernized: Regarding the House of Lords, the perceived difficulty is at least equal to ours.

original: So many of our temporal peers live in England, that the bishops are generally pretty near a par of the House, and we reckon they will be all to a man against repealing the Test; and yet their lordships are generally thought as good Whigs upon our principles as any in the kingdom.
modernized: Since many of our hereditary peers reside in England, the bishops nearly make up half of the House, and we assume they will all oppose the repeal of the Test; however, their lords are generally considered as good Whigs according to our principles as those in the kingdom.

original: There are indeed a few lay lords who appear to have no great devotion for Episcopacy; and perhaps one or two more with whom certain powerful motives might be used for removing any difficulty whatsoever; but these are in no sort of a number to carry any point against the conjunction of the rest and the whole bench of bishops.
modernized: Additionally, a few secular lords seem to show little affection for the Episcopacy; and possibly a couple more might be convinced to remove any obstacles, but these are not numerous enough to push against the alliance of the rest and the entirety of the bishops.

original: I shall here take notice, that in the division of employments among the Presbyterians, after this approaching repeal of the Test Act, supposing them, in proper time, to have an equal share, I compute the odds will be three or four to one on their side, in any further scheme they may have towards making their religion national.
modernized: I'll point out that, when the Presbyterians take on equal duties after the possible repeal of the Test Act, I estimate their advantage in any future attempts to establish their religion nationally would be about 3:1. This is because all the Englishmen sent over, regardless of their professed religion or education, seem to align with that group, since going against the national flow is generally unwise for temporary residents, unless they have a specific purpose.

original: For I reckon, all those gentlemen sent over from England, whatever religion they profess, or have been educated in, to be of that party: Since it is no mark of prudence, for any persons to oppose the current of a nation, where they are in some sort only sojourners, unless they have it in direction.
modernized: I believe that all those gentlemen sent from England, regardless of their religion or education, are part of the group: It's not wise for individuals to oppose the national tide when they are just guests, unless they have a particular goal. In this instance, they're likely to follow the crowd.

original: When any Servant comes home drunk, and cannot appear, you must all join in telling your Master, that he is gone to Bed very sick; upon which your Lady will be so goodnatured, as to order some comfortable Thing for the poor Man, or Maid.
modernized: When a servant arrives home drunk and is unable to show up, everyone should collaborate in telling their master that the servant is gravely ill. As a result, the master's wife will show kindness by arranging for some comfort for the servant.

original: Seventh. That the said man-mountain shall at his times of leisure be aiding and assisting to our workmen, in helping to raise certain great stones, towards covering the wall of the principal park, and other our royal buildings.
modernized: During his free time, the man-mountain should assist our workers in constructing large stones to help cover the wall of the main park and other royal buildings.

original: If my lords, the bishops, who, I hear, are now employed in a scheme for regulating the conduct and maintenance of the inferior clergy, shall in their wisdom and piety, and love of the church, consent to this repeal of the Test, I have not the least doubt, that the whole reverend body will cheerfully submit to their spiritual fathers, of whose paternal tenderness for their welfare, they have already found so many amazing instances.
modernized: If the bishops, who I've heard are currently working on a plan to regulate and support the lower clergy, consent to repeal the Test in their wise, pious, and church-loving judgment, I am confident that the entire reverend body will happily comply with their spiritual leaders, whom they have already experienced showing extraordinary care for their welfare.

original: Great speakers in public are seldom agreeable in private conversation, whether their faculty be natural, or acquired by practice and often venturing.
modernized: Exceptional public speakers are rarely entertaining in casual conversation, regardless of whether their speaking ability is natural or due to practice and frequent opportunities.

original: Natural elocution, although it may seem a paradox, usually springeth from a barrenness of invention and of words, by which men who have only one stock of notions upon every subject, and one set of phrases to express them in, they swim upon the superficies, and offer themselves on every occasion; therefore, men of much learning, and who know the compass of a language, are generally the worst talkers on a sudden, until much practice hath inured and emboldened them; because they are confounded with plenty of matter, variety of notions, and of words, which they cannot readily choose, but are perplexed and entangled by too great a choice, which is no disadvantage in private conversation; where, on the other side, the talent of haranguing is, of all others, most insupportable.
modernized: While natural eloquence may appear to be a paradox, it often arises from a scarcity of ideas and words. People who limit their perspectives to a single set of beliefs and a single mode of expression tend to superficially navigate discussions, making themselves available at every opportunity. Consequently, individuals with a broad range of knowledge and an understanding of language are generally the worst at spontaneous conversation, until they have become accustomed to and emboldened by experience. They are often bewildered by the abundance of material, ideas, and words, which they find hard to choose, becoming perplexed and entangled among the many options. This navigational difficulty is not an issue in private conversations, as the talent of public speaking is, by comparison, the most oppressive.

original: I saw no inhabitants in the place where I landed, and being unarmed, I was afraid of venturing far into the country.
modernized: Upon landing, I discovered no people were present, and as I was unarmed, I was hesitant to explore the surroundings too far.

original: I found some shellfish on the shore, and ate them raw, not daring to kindle a fire, for fear of being discovered by the natives.
modernized: I found edible shellfish along the shoreline and ate them raw, reluctant to start a fire for fear of alerting the native inhabitants.

original: I continued three days feeding on oysters and limpets, to save my own provisions; and I fortunately found a brook of excellent water, which gave me great relief.
modernized: For three consecutive days, I survived primarily on oysters and limpets and managed to find a clean water stream that offered relief.

original: Another cause of our low condition is our great luxury, the chief support of which is the materials of it brought to the nation in exchange for the few valuable things left us, whereby so many thousand families want the very necessaries of life.
modernized: Another reason for our economic hardship is our excessive luxurious lifestyle, primarily supported by foreign goods, which are traded in exchange for our scarce valuable resources. Due to this, thousands of families lack even the basic necessities for living.

original: It is a practice I have generally followed, to converse in equal freedom with the deserving men of both parties; and it was never without some contempt, that I have observed persons wholly out of employment, affect to do otherwise: I doubted whether any man could owe so much to the side he was of, though he were retained by it; but without some great point of interest, either in possession or prospect, I thought it was the mark of a low and narrow spirit.
modernized: In general, I have always maintained equal freedom in my conversations with deserving individuals from both parties. It has often been met with contempt to see those out of work try to maintain an exclusive allegiance; I questioned if anyone could be loyal to a side without a significant stake, be it possession or prospects. I believed it indicated a restricted and small-minded spirit.

original: But to show how far the wicked spirit of envy, malice and resentment can hurry some men, my nameless old persecutor had provided me a monument at the stone-cutter's and would have erected it in the parish-church; and this piece of notorious and expensive villany had actually succeeded, had I not used my utmost interest with the vestry, where it was carried at last but by two voices, that I am still alive.
modernized: To demonstrate the extent of malicious envy, spite, and resentment, my anonymous tormentor had arranged for a monument in my honor and planned to place it in the church; however, thanks to my connections in the vestry, it was halted only by a close vote, and I still live.

original: That stratagem failing, out comes a long sable elegy, bedeck'd with hour-glasses, mattocks, sculls, spades, and skeletons, with an epitaph as confidently written to abuse me, and my profession, as if I had been under ground these twenty years.
modernized: When this scheme failed, a lengthy black elegiac poem appeared, adorned with symbols of death, including hourglasses, farming tools, skulls, shovels, and skeletons, along with a mocking epitaph, as if I had been dead for twenty years.

original: The discontented party in the House of Commons, finding the torrent against them not to be stemmed, suspended their opposition; by which means an address was voted, nemine contradicente, to acknowledge Her Majesty's condescension, to express their satisfaction in what she had already done, and to desire she would please to proceed with the present negotiations for obtaining a speedy peace.
modernized: The dissenting faction within the House of Commons, unable to halt the flow of events against them, chose to withdraw their opposition, which allowed for a motion to be passed, unanimously, expressing gratitude to the queen for her leniency, endorsing what she had already achieved, and requesting her to continue negotiating towards a swift peace settlement.

original: In these diversions he was interrupted by a noise at the closet door, as if somebody were opening it; whereupon he suddenly leaped up to the window, at which he had come in, and thence upon the leads and gutters walking upon three legs, and holding me in the fourth, till he clambered up to a roof that was next to ours.
modernized: During his playtime, a noise interrupted him as if someone was opening the closet door. He jumped up to the window he had entered, then moved along roof leads using three legs while carrying me in the fourth, until he reached a roof close to ours.

original: I heard Glumdalclitch give a shriek at the moment he was carrying me out.
modernized: I heard a scream from Glumdalclitch as the monkey carried me out.

original: The poor girl was almost distracted.
modernized: The poor girl was near panic.

original: That quarter of the palace was all in an uproar; the servants ran for ladders; the monkey was seen by hundreds in the court, sitting upon the ridge of a building, holding me like a baby in one of his forepaws: whereat many of the rabble below could not forbear laughing; neither do I think they justly ought to be blamed, for without question, the sight was ridiculous enough to everybody but myself.
modernized: The quarter of the palace was chaotic; servants fetched ladders, the monkey was seen by many in the court, seated on a building ridge while carrying me like a baby, causing many to laugh; I don't think they were to blame, as the sight would likely be amusing to everyone but myself.

original: Some of the people threw up stones, hoping to drive the monkey down; but this was strictly forbidden, or else very probably my brains had been dashed out.
modernized: Some people threw up stones in an attempt to make the monkey come down, but this was forbidden or else my head would likely have been hit

original: When you step but a few Doors off to tattle with a Wench, or take a running Pot of Ale, or to see a Brother Footman going to be hanged, leave the Street Door open, that you may not be forced to knock, and your Master discover you are gone out; for a Quarter of an Hour's Time can do his Service no Injury.
modernized: So when you step away to chat with a woman, go to the pub, or see a fellow footman being executed, leaving the front door ajar so you don't have to knock and your employer doesn't notice you've left, should only take 15 minutes and won't harm your employer's business.

original: Some time ago I was appointed one of a committee to inquire into the state of the workhouse; where we found that a charity was bestowed by a great person for a certain time, which in its consequences operated very much to the detriment of the house: for, when the time was elapsed, all those who were supported by that charity, continued on the same foot with the rest of the foundation; and being generally a pack of profligate vagabond wretches from several parts of the kingdom, corrupted all the rest; so partial, or treacherous, or interested, or ignorant, or mistaken are generally all recommenders, not only to employments, but even to charity itself.
modernized: In the past, I joined a committee to investigate the condition of a workhouse. Upon inspection, we discovered that a charity was given for a set duration which ultimately harmed the establishment: when the time expired, those reliant on the charity remained on the same level as the rest of the welfare system. The majority of these individuals were unproductive and unscrupulous vagabonds from various regions, who tainted the entire system, causing a disservice to the charity. Recommenders, often biased, untrustworthy, self-interested, or misinformed, are commonly those who grant not only employment but even charity.

original: I cannot here forbear reproving the folly and pedantry of some lawyers, whose opinions this poor creature blindly followeth, and rendereth yet more absurd by his comments.
modernized: I cannot help criticizing the ignorance and pretentiousness of some lawyers, whose opinions this humble individual blindly follows, and further complicates with his interpretations.

original: The knowledge of our constitution can be only attained by consulting the earliest English histories, of which those gentlemen seem utterly ignorant, further than a quotation or an index.
modernized: One can truly understand our government's history only by consulting the earliest English historical writings, which these men seem to be unaware of beyond a simple reference or index.

original: They would fain derive our government as now constituted, from antiquity: And, because they have seen Tacitus quoted for his majoribus omnes; and have read of the Goths' military institution in their progresses and conquests, they presently dream of a parliament.
modernized: These lawyers fantasize that our current system of governance was established in antiquity. They base this on instances where Tacitus is quoted and the progression and conquests of the Goths are detailed. Consequently, they imagine the existence of a parliament.

original: Had their reading reached so far, they might have deduced it much more fairly from Aristotle and Polybius, who both distinctly name the composition of rex, seniores, et populus; and the latter, as I remember particularly, with the highest approbation.
modernized: Had their knowledge delved deeper into history, they could have more legitimately deduced our government from Aristotle and Polybius, who both explicitly describe the composition of rex, seniores, et populus; and the latter, in particular, with high praise.

original: The princes, in the Saxon Heptarchy, did indeed call their nobles sometimes together upon weighty affairs, as most other princes of the world have done in all ages.
modernized: Princes in the Saxon Heptarchy would occasionally call their nobles together to discuss important matters, a practice similar to many other rulers throughout history.

original: But they made war and peace, and raised money by their own authority: They gave or mended laws by their charters, and they raised armies by their tenures.
modernized: However, these princes themselves made decisions on war, peace, and finance. They would amend or issue laws through charters, and they raised armies based on their holdings.

original: Besides, some of those kingdoms fell in by conquests, before England was reduced under one head, and therefore could pretend no rights, but by the concessions of the conqueror.
modernized: In addition, some of these kingdoms were conquered before England was united under one ruler, and thus could not claim any rights except through the concessions of the conqueror.

original: I must add one word more: I know it hath been the opinion of several of the learned, who think well enough of the true art of astrology, That the stars do only incline, and not force the actions or wills of men: And therefore, however I may proceed by right rules, yet I cannot in prudence so confidently assure the events will follow exactly as I predict them.
modernized: I must add one more word: Many scholars who value the science of astrology believe that stars only influence, and not compel, the actions and wills of people. Therefore, while I follow certain rules, I cannot guarantee with absolute certainty that the events will unfold precisely as I have predicted.

original: I have allowed some bishoprics of equal income to be of more or less value to the purchaser, according as they are circumstanced.
modernized: I have adjusted the value of certain bishoprics with equal income to match the unique circumstances of the buyer.

original: For instance, The lands of the primacy and some other sees, are let so low, that they hardly pay a fifth penny of the real value to the bishop, and there the fines are the greater.
modernized: For instance, Lands associated with the role of Archbishop and some other bishoprics are rented at such low prices that they barely pay a fifth of their true value to the bishop, with the fines being considerably higher in these cases.

original: On the contrary, the sees of Meath and Clonfert, consisting, as I am told, much of tithes, those tithes are annually let to the tenants without any fines.
modernized: On the other hand, the bishoprics of Meath and Clonfert, primarily consisting of tithes, are leased annually to the tenants without the payment of any fines.

original: So the see of Dublin is said to have many fee-farms which pay no fines, and some leases for lives which pay very little, and not so soon nor so duly.
modernized: It is said that the bishopric of Dublin features several 'freehold' properties which do not require fines, and some leases for life with a lower and delayed payment.

original: By means of this loadstone, the island is made to rise and fall, and move from one place to another.
modernized: This large loadstone allows the island to rise and fall and move from one location to another.

original: For, with respect to that part of the earth over which the monarch presides, the stone is endued at one of its sides with an attractive power, and at the other with a repulsive.
modernized: The powers of attraction and repulsion are located on opposite sides of the loadstone, depending on the part of the earth ruled by the monarch.

original: Upon placing the magnet erect, with its attracting end towards the earth, the island descends; but when the repelling extremity points downwards, the island mounts directly upwards.
modernized: Positioning the magnet upright with the attracting end towards the ground causes the island to sink, while pointing the repelling end downwards causes it to ascend straight up.

original: When the position of the stone is oblique, the motion of the island is so too: for in this magnet, the forces always act in lines parallel to its direction.
modernized: When the loadstone is set at an angle, the island's motion corresponds: the forces in this magnet always move parallel to its direction.

original: Of the other sort, are some clergymen born in this kingdom, who have most distinguished themselves by their warmth against Popery, their great indulgence to Dissenters, and all true loyal Protestants; by their zeal for the House of Hanover, abhorrence of the Pretender, and an implicit readiness to fall into any measures that will make the government easy to those who represent His Majesty's person.
modernized: These clergymen, born within the kingdom, have been highly recognized for their strong opposition to Popery, tolerant attitudes towards Dissenters and Protestants who uphold the truth, ardent support for the House of Hanover, abhorrence of the Pretender, and a unwavering willingness to take up any actions that facilitate a smoothly functioning government, as they serve those who represent the monarchy.

original: In choosing persons for all employments, they have more regard to good morals than to great abilities; for, since government is necessary to mankind, they believe that the common size of human understanding is fitted to some station or other, and that Providence never intended to make the management of public affairs a mystery, to be comprehended only by a few persons of sublime genius, of which there seldom are three born in an age; but they suppose truth, justice, temperance, and the like, to be in every man's power, the practice of which virtues, assisted by experience, and a good intention, would qualify any man for the service of his country, except where a course of study is required.
modernized: They prioritize good morals over great abilities for appointing individuals to all roles, believing that the average human understanding can fit a role and that Providence does not intend complex government matters to be understood by a small number of people with exceptional understanding. Instead, they believe that common virtues like honesty, justice, temperance, and the like can be practiced by everyone, given good intentions, experience, and the willingness to learn. However, they require education for positions that require specialized knowledge.

original: But they thought the want of moral virtues was so far from being supplied by superior endowments of the mind, that employments could never be put into such dangerous hands as those of persons so qualified; and at least, that the mistakes committed by ignorance, in a virtuous disposition, would never be of such fatal consequences to the public weal as the practices of a man whose inclinations led him to be corrupt, and who had great abilities to manage, to multiply, and defend his corruptions.
modernized: They believe that a lack of moral virtues is not compensated for by superior intelligence, as such positions could be placed in dangerous hands if held by individuals with such virtues. Mistakes made due to ignorance in a virtuous person might be detrimental but not as catastrophic as the actions of a person who is prone to corruption and has the ability to manage, multiply, and defend their corrupt deeds.

original: Most of the players, who had very little faith before, were now desirous of having as much as they could, and therefore embraced the Roman Catholic religion: the same thing was observed of some bawds, and ladies of pleasure.
modernized: Many actors, formerly with little or no faith, converted to Catholicism because they desired more faith. This behavior was also observed among some prostitutes and women working in pleasure establishments.

original: Mr. Masham sent this morning to desire I would ride out with him, the weather growing again very fine.
modernized: Mr. Masham asked me to go out this morning since the weather was nice again.

original: I was very busy, and sent my excuses; but desired he would provide me a dinner.
modernized: I couldn't join him as I was occupied; he promised to arrange a dinner for me instead.

original: I dined with him, his lady, and her sister, Mrs. Hill, who invites us tomorrow to dine with her, and we are to ride out in the morning.
modernized: So, I dined with Mr. Masham, his lady, and Mrs. Hill, who invited us for dinner tomorrow and we will ride together in the morning.

original: I sat with Lady Oglethorpe till eight this evening, then was going home to write; looked about for the woman that keeps the key of the house: she told me Patrick had it.
modernized: I stayed with Lady Oglethorpe until 8 in the evening, then went home to write; I asked for the house key and was informed Patrick had it.

original: I cooled my heels in the cloisters till nine, then went in to the music-meeting, where I had been often desired to go; but was weary in half an hour of their fine stuff, and stole out so privately that everybody saw me; and cooled my heels in the cloisters again till after ten: then came in Patrick.
modernized: Waiting for a while since I couldn't find the key keeper, I sat in the cloisters till 9, went to the music meeting as invited - but felt bored within half an hour and slipped out quietly; afterward, cooled my heels in the cloisters again until 10: then Patrick arrived.

original: I went up, shut the chamber door, and gave him two or three swinging cuffs on the ear, and I have strained the thumb of my left hand with pulling him, which I did not feel until he was gone.
modernized: Upon his arrival, I went to my chamber, shut the door, gave him a couple of sharp slaps on the ear, and strained my left thumb thumb in pulling him away. I only noticed the injury after he had left.

original: He was plaguily afraid and humbled.
modernized: Patrick looked frightened and contrite.

original: Soon after, I heard a general shout, with frequent repetitions of the words, Peplom selan, and I felt great numbers of people on my left side, relaxing the cords to such a degree, that I was able to turn upon my right, and to get a little ease.
modernized: Shortly afterwards, I heard loud exclamations with the repeated word Peplom selan, and I felt many people on my left side release the ropes. This allowed me to turn onto my right side and find some relief.

original: But, before this, they had daubed my face and both my hands with a sort of ointment very pleasant to the smell, which, in a few minutes, removed all the smart of their arrows.
modernized: Before this, they had applied a pleasant-smelling ointment to my face and hands that quickly healed the pain from the arrows lingering there.

original: These circumstances, added to the refreshment I had received by their victuals and drink, which were very nourishing, disposed me to sleep.
modernized: These events, along with the food and drink they provided for me, made me feel tired and prompted me to fall asleep.

original: I slept about eight hours, as I was afterwards assured; and it was no wonder, for the physicians, by the emperor's order, had mingled a sleepy potion in the hogsheads of wine.
modernized: After eight hours of rest, as I later learned, I fell into a deep sleep due to a sleep-inducing substance that had been mixed into the wine.

original: He is generally taxed by writers for discovering a contempt of religion in his common discourse and behaviour; which I take to have risen from the same fountain, being a point of art, and a known expedient, for men who cannot quit their immoralities, at least to banish all reflections that may disturb them in the enjoyment, which must be done either by not thinking of religion at all; or, if it will obtrude, by putting it out of countenance.
modernized: Writers often critique King John for indicating a disregard for religion in his conversations and actions, which might stem from a deliberate strategy to avoid any moral reflections that could disturb his pleasure-seeking lifestyle. He accomplishes this either by denying the existence of religion entirely or by making religion seem inappropriate.

original: First, Because there is no nation yet known, in either hemisphere, where the people of all conditions are more in want of some cordial to keep up their spirits, than in this of ours.
modernized: First, This nation, compared to others in the world, seems to have a particularly high demand for something to lift the spirits of its people, especially the common folk.

original: I am not in jest; and if the fact will not be allowed me, I shall not argue it.
modernized: I am not joking, and if my assertion is met with skepticism, I shall not try to defend it.

original: Secondly, It is too well and generally known, that this tax of forty shillings additional on every tun of wine, (which will be double, at least, to the home consumer) will increase equally every new session of Parliament, until, perhaps, it comes to twelve pounds.
modernized: Secondly, it's widely understood that an added forty shilling tax on every tun of wine (which will likely double the cost for domestic consumers) will gradually increase with each session of Parliament, potentially reaching up to twelve pounds.

original: I returned home, and consulting with the sorrel nag, we went into a copse at some distance, where I with my knife, and he with a sharp flint, fastened very artificially after their manner, to a wooden handle, cut down several oak wattles, about the thickness of a walking-staff, and some larger pieces.
modernized: Following my return home, I conferred with the sorrel nag and we ventured to a nearby grove to gather materials. I used my knife and he utilized a sharp flint attached to a wooden handle to cut down several thick wattles of oak. We also collected some larger pieces.

original: But I shall not trouble the reader with a particular description of my own mechanics; let it suffice to say, that in six weeks time with the help of the sorrel nag, who performed the parts that required most labour, I finished a sort of Indian canoe, but much larger, covering it with the skins of Yahoos, well stitched together with hempen threads of my own making.
modernized: In a span of six weeks, with assistance from the sorrel nag, who took care of the more taxing labor, I successfully constructed an oversized canoe, similar to an Indian design. Its exterior was covered with Yahoo hides that were well stitched together using hemp threads that I made myself.

original: My sail was likewise composed of the skins of the same animal; but I made use of the youngest I could get, the older being too tough and thick; and I likewise provided myself with four paddles.
modernized: The sail was constructed from more Yahoo hides, but I selected the youngest available as the older hides were too tough and thick. I also obtained four paddles for propulsion.

original: I laid in a stock of boiled flesh, of rabbits and fowls, and took with me two vessels, one filled with milk and the other with water.
modernized: To prepare for the journey, I stored provisions such as pre-cooked food from rabbits and birds, and filled containers with milk and water for consumption.

original: I have already computed the charge of nursing a beggar's child (in which list I reckon all cottagers, labourers, and four-fifths of the farmers) to be about two shillings per annum, rags included; and I believe no gentleman would repine to give ten shillings for the carcass of a good fat child, which, as I have said, will make four dishes of excellent nutritive meat, when he hath only some particular friend, or his own family to dine with him.
modernized: The cost of raising a beggar's child (including all cottagers, laborers, and four-fifths of farmers) has been computed to be about two shillings per year, including clothes; by contrast, a well-nourished child would be worth ten shillings to a gentleman, as it would provide four dishes of nutritious meat when entertaining friends or family.

original: Thus the squire will learn to be a good landlord, and grow popular among his tenants, the mother will have eight shillings neat profit, and be fit for work till she produces another child.
modernized: As a result, the squire will become a good landlord and gain popularity among his tenants, while the mother will earn eight shillings and be able to work again until she gives birth to another child.

original: To say the truth, the great neglect of education, in several noble families, whose sons are suffered to pass the most improvable seasons of their youth, in vice and idleness, have too much lessened their reputation; but even this misfortune we owe, among all the rest, to that Whiggish practice of reviling the Universities, under the pretence of their instilling pedantry, narrow principles, and high-church doctrines.
modernized: In truth, it's the neglect of education in many aristocratic families, where the sons are allowed to waste their formative years on vices and laziness, that has contributed to their diminished reputation. However, even this negative circumstance can be traced back to a Whig mentality of disregarding universities-their warning of pedantic, restrictive mindsets, and conservative beliefs being their reason for criticism.

original: Now if all this be true, upon which I could easily enlarge, I would be glad to know by what secret method it is that we grow a rich and flourishing people, without liberty, trade, manufactures, inhabitants, money, or the privilege of coining; without industry, labour or improvement of lands, and with more than half of the rent and profits of the whole Kingdom, annually exported, for which we receive not a single farthing: And to make up all this, nothing worth mentioning, except the linen of the North, a trade casual, corrupted, and at mercy, and some butter from Cork.
modernized: Given all these points, I'm curious to understand how we can prosper without liberties, trade, manufacturing, people, money, or the ability to coin currency; without work, improvement of lands, and exporting more than half of our kingdom's rental and profit income, without receiving any compensation in return, except for the northern linen trade, which is unreliable, and some butter from Cork.

original: If we do flourish, it must be against every law of Nature and Reason, like the thorn at Glastonbury, that blossoms in the midst of Winter.
modernized: If we're indeed thriving, it seems counterintuitive, going against the laws of nature and reason, like the winter-blooming thorn at Glastonbury.

original: There are computed to be one hundred pretty fellows in this town, that swear fifty oaths a head daily; some of them would think it hard to be stinted to an hundred: This very branch would produce a vast sum yearly.
modernized: In this town are approximately 100 men who swear an estimated 50 oaths a day each, some of whom would find it unfair to be limited to swearing only 100 oaths a day. This alone could generate a large amount of revenue annually.

original: I was reckoned to be as handsome as any in our neighbourhood, until I became pale and thin with grief and ill usage.
modernized: I was considered to be among the most attractive in our neighborhood, but I grew pale and thin due to grief and poor treatment.

original: I am still fair enough, and have, I think, no very ill feature about me.
modernized: I still appear to be reasonably attractive, and I don't have any significant flaws, in my opinion.

original: They that see me now will hardly allow me ever to have had any great share of beauty; for besides being so much altered, I go always mobbed and in an undress, as well out of neglect, as indeed for want of clothes to appear in.
modernized: Presently, people might question if I ever had real beauty, as I am noticeably altered and usually dressed in an untidy manner, due to disregard or a lack of appropriate clothing.

original: I might add to all this, that I was born to a good estate, although it now turneth to little account under the oppressions I endure, and hath been the true cause of all my misfortunes.
modernized: Additionally, I was born into a well-off family, though its benefits are no longer significant under the hardships I face, and it has actually led to most of my troubles.

original: The only Invention of late Years, which hath any way contributed towards Politeness in Discourse, is that of abbreviating or reducing Words of many Syllables into one, by lopping off the rest.
modernized: The only recent innovation that has contributed in some way to politeness in conversation is the abbreviation or shortening of words with many syllables into a single syllable, by removing the rest.

original: This Refinement, having begun about the Time of the Revolution, I had some Share in the Honour of promoting it, and I observe, to my great Satisfaction, that it makes daily Advancements, and I hope in Time will raise our Language to the utmost Perfection; although, I must confess, to avoid Obscurity, I have been very sparing of this Ornament in the following Dialogues.
modernized: This abbreviation trend, which started around the time of the Revolution, was partly my creation, and I'm pleased to note that it's gaining popularity every day. I hope it will eventually bring our language to its peak of perfection. However, to maintain clarity, I have been cautious with using this technique in the following dialogues.

original: Besides; all parties would be obliged to close with so good a work as this, for their own reputation: Neither is any expedient more likely to unite them.
modernized: All parties would be obliged to close with so good a work as this, for their own reputation.

original: For the most violent party men, I have ever observed, are such, as in the conduct of their lives have discovered least sense of religion or morality; and when all such are laid aside, at least those among them as shall be found incorrigible, it will be a matter perhaps of no great difficulty to reconcile the rest.
modernized: The most violent members of society, from my observations, seem to be those with the least sense of morality or religious values. When those with little religion or morality are removed from the group, it may be relatively easy to reconcile the remaining members.

original: We cannot but observe to your Grace, that, in the English act of the fourth year of Queen Anne, for the better collecting charity money on briefs by letters-patent, &c. the ministers are obliged only to read the briefs in their churches, without any particular exhortations; neither are they commanded to go from house to house with the churchwardens, nor to send the money collected to their respective chancellors, but pay it to the undertaker or agent of the sufferer.
modernized: In the English law of the fourth year of Queen Anne, when collecting charity money via letters-patent, the clergy are only required to publicly read the relevant documents in church without making any special appeals. They are not commanded to visit homes with the churchwardens, nor are they required to send money collected to their chancellors, but instead they are to give it to the agent or undertaker of the person seeking help.

original: So that, we humbly hope, the clergy of this kingdom shall not, without any law in being, be put to greater hardships in this case than their brethren in England, where the legislature, intending to prevent the abuses in collecting charity money on briefs, did not think fit to put the clergy under any of those difficulties we now complain of, in the present brief by letters patent, for the relief of Charles M'Carthy aforesaid.
modernized: We hope that the clergy of this kingdom will not face greater hardships than their counterparts in England, who are not subject to the same challenges we currently complain about in the modern brief issued via letters-patent for the benefit of Charles M'Carthy.

original: But, as to the formality of taking possession in my sovereign's name, it never came once into my thoughts; and if it had, yet, as my affairs then stood, I should perhaps, in point of prudence and self-preservation, have put it off to a better opportunity.
modernized: Regarding the formalities of claiming the land in the name of my sovereign, it wasn't a consideration I had in mind initially. If it had been, given my circumstances at the time, I might have deferred the action until a more opportune moment for my safety and self-preservation.

original: There is generally a vagabond spirit in beggars, which ought to be discouraged and severely punished.
modernized: The habitual laziness, drunkenness, and impulsive marriages without a means to support their families are prevalent among beggars, and such behavior is

original: It is owing to the same causes that drove them into poverty; I mean, idleness, drunkenness, and rash marriages without the least prospect of supporting a family by honest endeavours, which never came into their thoughts.
modernized: The reasons that led beggars into poverty are generally absent-mindedness, alcoholism, and hasty marriages without any thought of supporting a family through honest work.

original: It is observed, that hardly one beggar in twenty looks upon himself to be relieved by receiving bread or other food; and they have in this town been frequently seen to pour out of their pitcher good broth that hath been given them, into the kennel; neither do they much regard clothes, unless to sell them; for their rags are part of their tools with which they work: they want only ale, brandy, and other strong liquors, which cannot be had without money; and, money as they conceive, always abounds in the metropolis.
modernized: It has been noted that only one in twenty beggars considers themselves in need of food handouts; in fact, they have been spotted pouring out food they've been given into the trash, and they pay little attention to clothes unless it's for resale. Their rags, however, serve as work tools for them. Alcohol, specifically ale, brandy, and strong liquors, is what they truly crave, as they believe such items are abundant in major cities.

original: As for the few following predictions I now offer the world, I forbore to publish them till I had perused the several almanacks for the year we are now enter'd on.
modernized: I will only provide a few upcoming predictions I'm presenting to the world, as I have recently reviewed several almanacs for the current year.

original: I find them in all the usual strain, and I beg the reader will compare their manner with mine: And here I make bold to tell the world, that I lay the whole credit of my art upon the truth of these predictions; and I will be content, that Partridge, and the rest of his clan, may hoot me for a cheat and impostor, if I fail in any singular particular of moment.
modernized: My work's validity depends entirely on the accuracy of these predictions, and I am prepared for criticisms if I fail in any significant prediction. I invite readers to compare my method with that of common almanac writers.

original: I believe, any man who reads this paper, will look upon me to be at least a person of as much honesty and understanding, as a common maker of almanacks.
modernized: I hope my readers will perceive me as a person of honesty and intelligence, at least as much as someone who makes typical almanacs.

original: I do not lurk in the dark; I am not wholly unknown in the world; I have set my name at length, to be a mark of infamy to mankind, if they shall find I deceive them.
modernized: I do not hide my identity, working in secrecy; I am known to many, and I've openly signed my name on my predictions to take responsibility.

original: If two-thirds of any kingdom's revenue be exported to another country, without one farthing of value in return; and if the said kingdom be forbidden the most profitable branches of trade wherein to employ the other third, and only allowed to traffic in importing those commodities which are most ruinous to itself; how shall that kingdom stand?
modernized: If a country exports two-thirds of its revenue to another country without receiving any valuable return, and is banned from participating in profitable industries while only allowed to import commodities that are harmful to itself, how will the country manage?

original: The King, having stayed a while to settle the state of Normandy, returned with his brother into England, whom he sent prisoner to Cardiff Castle, with orders that he should be favourably used, which, for some time, were duly observed; until being accused of attempting to make his escape (whether it were real or feigned) he had his eyes put out with a burning basin, by the King's express commands; in which miserable condition he lived for six-and-twenty years.
modernized: After addressing Normandy's affairs, the King returned to England with his brother, who was imprisoned at Cardiff Castle under the King's instructions for kind treatment. However, the brother was accused of planning an escape (whether genuine or not), leading the King to order his blinding with a hot basin. The brother lived on for six-and-twenty years in this pitiful condition.

original: Besides the large box in which I was usually carried, the queen ordered a smaller one to be made for me, of about twelve feet square and ten high, for the convenience of travelling, because the other was somewhat too large for Glumdalclitch's lap, and cumbersome in the coach.
modernized: In addition to the large carriage I was typically carried in, the queen commissioned a smaller one to be built for me. This compact one, measuring approximately twelve feet square by ten feet high, was designed for traveling convenience, as the larger one was bigger than Glumdalclitch's lap and unwieldy in the coach. The same craftsman who made my original carriage constructed this portable chamber.

original: It was made by the same artist, whom I directed in the whole contrivance.
modernized: I gave directions to the craftsman about the entire design of this portable chamber.

original: This travelling closet was an exact square, with a window in the middle of three of the squares, and each window was latticed with iron wire on the outside, to prevent accidents in long journeys.
modernized: This portable chamber was a perfect square, with one window in the center of three sides, guarded by iron wire mesh on the outside to prevent accidents during long journeys.

original: On the fourth side, which had no window, two strong staples were fixed, through which the person who carried me, when I had a mind to be on horseback, put a leathern belt, and buckled it about his waist.
modernized: On the fourth side without a window, two strong hooks were attached, through which a carrier could secure a leather belt to their waist when I desired to travel by horseback. This was always the duty of a serious, trustworthy servant I trusted.

original: This was always the office of some grave, trusty servant, in whom I could confide, whether I attended the king and queen in their progresses, or were disposed to see the gardens, or pay a visit to some great lady or minister of state in the court; for I soon began to be known and esteemed among the greatest officers, I suppose more on account of their majesties' favor than any merit of my own.
modernized: This servant was responsible for accompanying me during the king and queen's travels, visiting gardens, or meeting influential people in the court. It seemed that I was well-respected among the highest officers, more due to the royal family's favor than my own merits.

original: It is the part of wise men to conceal their passions, when they are not in circumstances of exerting them to purpose: the arts of getting power, and preserving indulgence, are very different.
modernized: It's wise for people to hide their emotions when they can't take action on them, as acquiring power and maintaining leniency are two different strategies.

original: For the former, the reasonable hopes of the Dissenters, seem to be at an end; their comrades, the Whigs and Freethinkers, are just in a condition proper to be forsaken; and the Parliament, as well as the body of the people, will be deluded no longer.
modernized: The Dissenters' reasonable expectations are now lost; their allies, the Whigs and Freethinkers, have reached a point where they can be abandoned; and neither the Parliament nor the general public will be deceived any longer.

original: Besides, it sometimes happens for a cause to be exhausted and worn out, as that of the Whigs in general, seems at present to be: the nation has had enough of it.
modernized: Occasionally, a cause can become exhausted and used up, like the Whigs appear to be at present.

original: It is as vain to hope restoring that decayed interest, as for a man of sixty to talk of entering on a new scene of life, that is only proper for youth and vigour.
modernized: It's futile to attempt reviving a fading interest, just as it would be for an elderly person to start a new life meant for the young.

original: New circumstances and new men must arise, as well as new occasions, which are not like to happen in our time.
modernized: New situations, people, and opportunities need to occur, which don't seem likely to happen in our current time.

original: So that the Dissenters have no game left, at present, but to secure their indulgence: in order to which, I will be so bold to offer them some advice.
modernized: Given the lack of other options, the Dissenters are left only with securing their indulgence. To do so, I'd be audacious enough to offer them some guidance.

original: Having already written three letters upon so disagreeable a subject as Mr. Wood and his halfpence; I conceived my task was at an end: But I find, that cordials must be frequently applied to weak constitutions, political as well as natural.
modernized: In the past, I had written three letters about the controversial topic of Mr. Wood's halfpence. I thought my task was complete, but later I discovered that constant encouragement is necessary for weak constitutions, both political and personal.

original: A people long used to hardships, lose by degrees the very notions of liberty, they look upon themselves as creatures at mercy, and that all impositions laid on them by a stronger hand, are, in the phrase of the Report, legal and obligatory.
modernized: A people who have long endured hardships gradually lose the concept of freedom. They come to see themselves as subjects at the mercy of a stronger authority, and any restrictions placed upon them are considered lawful and obligatory according to the language used in the Report.

original: Hence proceeds that poverty and lowness of spirit, to which a kingdom may be subject as well as a particular person.
modernized: This leads to a state of poverty and despair, which can affect not only an individual but also an entire nation.

original: And when Esau came fainting from the field at the point to die, it is no wonder that he sold his birthright for a mess of pottage.
modernized: When Esau was nearly dying from exhaustion while in the field, it is unsurprising that he gave away his birthright in exchange for a simple meal.

original: The divine authority of Holy Writ, the precepts of philosophers, the lashes and ridicule of satirical poets, have been all employed in exploding this insatiable thirst of money, and all equally controlled by the daily practice of mankind.
modernized: Religious texts, philosophical teachings, and satirical poetry have all been used to critique greed, but their impact has been outweighed by human behavior.

original: Nothing new remains to be said upon the occasion, and if there did, I must remember my character, that I am an Examiner only, and not a Reformer.
modernized: There is nothing new to say on this topic, and if there were, I must remember that I'm an analyst, not a reformer.

original: However, although virtue and innocence are no infallible defence against perjury, malice, and subornation, yet they are great supports for enabling us to bear those evils with temper and resignation; and it is an unspeakable comfort to a good man under the malignity of evil mercenary tongues, that a few years will carry his appeal to an higher tribunal, where false witnesses, instead of daring to bring accusations before an all-seeing Judge, will call for mountains to cover them.
modernized: Even though virtue and innocence may not be an infallible shield against lies, slander, and bribery, they can help us endure such evils with patience and acceptance. It's a remarkable comfort for a righteous person to face unjust accusations that their case ultimately goes to a higher court, where false witnesses will plead for mountains to hide from an all-seeing Judge.

original: As for earthly judges, they seldom have it in their power; and, God knows, whether they have it in their will, to mingle mercy with justice; they are so far from knowing the hearts of the accuser or the accused, that they cannot know their own; and their understanding is frequently biassed, although their intentions be just.
modernized: Earthly judges usually lack the power to intervene, and it's unclear whether they even want to impart justice mercy. They often have limited understanding and are frequently biased towards certain cases, parties, or individuals due to human nature, even if they aren't fully aware of their biases.

original: They are often prejudiced to causes, parties, and persons, through the infirmity of human nature, without being sensible themselves that they are so: And therefore, although God may pardon their errors here, he certainly will not ratify their sentences hereafter.
modernized: Judges can easily be prejudiced against cases, groups, or individuals without realizing it, and God may forgive their errors in the present, but He won't endorse their rulings in the future.

original: It will sometimes happen, I know not how in the course of human affairs, that a man shall be made liable to legal animadversions, where he has nothing to answer for, either to God or his country; and condemned at Westminster-hall for what he will never be charged with at the Day of Judgment.
modernized: A situation might arise in the natural flow of events that a person may be held accountable for issues without deserve, neither to God nor their country, and be found guilty at Westminster-hall for matters not brought up in the Judgment Day.

original: Some of the former kind are such as are said to have enjoyed tolerable preferments in England; and it is therefore much to their commendation that they have condescended to leave their native country, and come over hither to be bishops, merely to promote Christianity among us; and therefore in my opinion, both their lordships, and the many defenders they bring over, may justly claim the merit of missionaries sent to convert a nation from heresy and heathenism.
modernized: These clergy members from England, who are now bishops in Ireland, are commended for leaving their home country to promote Christianity here. Consequently, I believe both they and their followers should be recognized as missionaries working to convert a nation from heresy and heathenism.

original: I must repeat, that what I am to say upon this subject, is intended only for the conviction of those among our own party, who are true lovers of the Church, and would be glad it should continue in a tolerable degree of prosperity to the end of the world.
modernized: I need to reiterate that my statements on this matter are meant solely to convince those within our party who genuinely love the Church and would like it to maintain a reasonable level of success until the end of time.

original: As to the improvement of land, those few who attempt that or planting, through covetousness, or want of skill, generally leave things worse than they were; neither succeeding in trees nor hedges; and, by running into the fancy of grazing, after the manner of the Scythians, are every day depopulating the country.
modernized: As for efforts to enhance the land, only a small number of individuals make attempts due to greed or incompetence, often leaving things in worse condition than before; this is true of both trees and hedges. Additionally, an increasing number of people are abandoning rural areas and depopulating the country by focusing on agriculture similar to the Scythians.

original: This prince was the youngest son of William the Conqueror, and bred to more learning than was usual in that age, or to his rank, which got him the surname of Beauclerk; the reputation whereof, together with his being born in England, and born son of a king, although of little weight in themselves, did very much strengthen his pretensions with the people.
modernized: Henry the Young King, the youngest son of William the Conqueror, had great favoritism among the people due to his education and English birth. These factors, although insignificant on their own, significantly bolstered his claims to power.

original: Besides, he had the same advantage of his brother Robert's absence, which had proved before so successful to Rufus, whose treasures he likewise seized on immediately at his death, after the same manner, and for the same end, as Rufus did those of his father the Conqueror.
modernized: Having his brother Robert away in the Holy War, Henry seized the opportunity, much like his late brother Rufus, taking control of his treasures after their father's death.

original: Robert had been now five years absent in the Holy War, where he acquitted himself with great glory; and although he was now in Apulia, upon his return homeward, yet the nobles pretending not to know what was become of him, and others giving out that he had been elected King of Jerusalem, Henry laid hold of the occasion, and calling together an assembly of the clergy, nobles, and people of the realm at London, upon his promises to restore King Edward's laws, and redress the grievances which had been introduced by his father and brother, they consented to elect him king.
modernized: When Robert returned home, having gained great respect and victory in the Holy War, the nobles pretended not to know of his whereabouts. They spread rumors of his election as King of Jerusalem. Seizing this opportunity, Henry summoned the clergy, nobles, and people for a meeting in London, promoting himself as being committed to restoring King Edward's laws and addressing the grievances under the reign of his father and brother. The attendees consented to elect Henry as king.

original: Immediately after his coronation, he proceeded upon reforming the abuses of the late reign: he banished dissolute persons from the court, who had long infested it under the protection and example of Rufus: he restored the people to the use of lights in the night, which the Conqueror had forbidden, after a certain hour, by the ringing of a bell.
modernized: Following his coronation, Henry immediately worked on reforming the misrule of his predecessors: he banished undesirable court associates who had plagued the court since the time of Rufus; he restored the privilege of lighting homes at night, as the Conqueror had prohibited it past a certain hour, by ringing a bell.

original: Then he published his charter, and ordered a copy thereof to be taken for every county in England.
modernized: He then published a charter and organized copies to be sent to each county in England.

original: This charter was in substance; The freedom of Mother Church from former oppressions; leave to the heirs of nobles to succeed in the possession of their lands, without being obliged to redeem them, only paying to the king a moderate relief; abolition of fines for licence of marriage to their heiresses; a promise of not refusing such licence unless the match proposed be with the king's enemy, &c.; the next of kin to be guardians of the lands of orphans; punishments for coiners of false money; a confirmation of St. Edward's laws; and a general amnesty.
modernized: The charter, in essence, granted Mother Church immunity from previous oppressions; allowed the heirs of nobles to inherit land without payment unless a small relief was due; forbade fines for marriage licenses of heiresses unless it would jeopardize the king's interests; made the next of kin responsible for orphaned land; imposed penalties for counterfeit money; reinforced St. Edward's laws; and extended a general amnesty.

original: Sir Andrew Fountaine has been very ill this week; and sent to me early this morning to have prayers, which you know is the last thing.
modernized: Sir Andrew Fountaine has been seriously ill the past week and asked for prayers, which is normally a final request.

original: I found the doctors and all in despair about him.
modernized: Upon checking on Sir Andrew Fountaine, I found the doctors and everyone p

original: I read prayers to him, found he had settled all things; and, when I came out, the nurse asked me whether I thought it possible he could live; for the doctors thought not.
modernized: I prayed with him and discovered he had settled his affairs. The nurse questioned me about his chances of surviving, as the doctors were not optimistic.

original: I said, I believed he would live; for I found the seeds of life in him, which I observe seldom fail (and I found them in poor, dearest Stella, when she was ill many years ago); and tonight I was with him again, and he was mightily recovered, and I hope he will do well, and the doctor approved my reasons; but, if he should die, I should come off scurvily.
modernized: I told her I believed he would survive as I could sense vitality within him, a sign that he often failed to in the past (I also observed this in dear Stella when she was gravely ill years ago). Tonight I visited him again, and I am hopeful he will recover, and the doctor agreed with my assessment, but if he does not make it, I will appear foolish.

original: The Secretary of State (Mr. St. John) sent to me to dine with him; Mr. Harley and Lord Peterborow dined there too; and at night came Lord Rivers.
modernized: Lord St. John (the Secretary of State) invited me to dine with him. Mr. Harley and Lord Peterborough also dined there, and later came Lord Rivers.

original: Lord Peterborow goes to Vienna in a day or two: he has promised to make me write to him.
modernized: Lord Peterborough plans to travel to Vienna soon and promised to write to me.

original: Mr. Harley went away at six; but we stayed till seven.
modernized: Mr. Harley left at six, but we remained till seven

original: I took the Secretary aside, and complained to him of Mr. Harley, that he had got the Queen to grant the First-Fruits, promised to bring me to her, and get her letter to the bishops of Ireland; but the last part he had not done in six weeks, and I was in danger to lose reputation, etc. He took the matter right, desired me to be with him on Sunday morning, and promises me to finish the affair in four days; so I shall know in a little time what I have to trust to. -- It is nine o'clock, and I must go study, you little rogues; and so goodnight, etc.
modernized: I spoke privately with the Secretary and expressed my frustration with Mr. Harley, as he obtained a favor from the Queen but did not fulfill his promise to introduce me. I fear my reputation could suffer. He acknowledged the issue and promised to resolve the matter within a few days, so I will soon know my standing.

original: I dined with a cousin in the City, and poor Pat Rolt was there.
modernized: I had dinner with a relative in the city, and Pat Rolt was also present.

original: I have got her rogue of a husband leave to come to England from Port-Mahon.
modernized: I managed to convince her husband to return to England from Port Mahon.

original: The Whigs are much down; but I reckon they have some scheme in agitation.
modernized: The Whigs are struggling in the political scene, but I assume they have some plans in motion.

original: This Parliament-time hinders our Court meetings on Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays.
modernized: This session of parliament is disrupting our scheduled court meetings on Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays.

original: I had a great deal of business tonight, which gave me a temptation to be idle, and I lost a dozen shillings at ombre, with Dr. Pratt and another.
modernized: I had a lot of work to complete tonight, which made me consider being unproductive, and I ended up losing a dozen shillings playing ombre with Dr. Pratt and someone else.

original: I have been to see t'other day the Bishop of Clogher and lady, but did not see Miss.
modernized: I recently visited the Bishop of Clogher and his wife, but I did not get a chance to see Miss.

original: It rains every day, and yet we are all over dust.
modernized: It seems to be raining every day, but we're still covered in dust.

original: Lady Masham's eldest boy is very ill: I doubt he will not live, and she stays at Kensington to nurse him, which vexes us all.
modernized: Lady Masham's eldest son is critically ill, and she's staying at Kensington to care for him, which is frustrating for everyone.

original: She is so excessively fond, it makes me mad.
modernized: Her excessive affection is infuriating me.

original: She should never leave the Queen, but leave everything, to stick to what is so much the interest of the public, as well as her own.
modernized: She should prioritize staying with the queen over everything else, as it serves the greater good for both the public and herself.

original: This I tell her; but talk to the winds.
