original: By these marks you will easily distinguish a truly moderate man from those who are commonly, but very falsely, so called; and while persons thus qualified are so numerous and so noisy, so full of zeal and industry to gain proselytes, and spread their opinions among the people, it cannot be wondered at that there should be so little brotherly love left among us.
modernized: Using these traits, you can easily identify a genuine moderate person from those frequently mislabeled as such. With so many vocal and passionate people spreading their divisive beliefs, it's no surprise that there is a lack of brotherly love among us.

original: A rainy, wretched, scurvy day from morning till night: and my neighbour Vanhomrigh invited me to dine with them and this evening I passed at Mr. Prior's with Dr. Freind; and 'tis now past twelve, so I must go sleep.
modernized: Yesterday was a dreary, dismal, unhealthy day, from morning till night. My neighbor Vanhomrigh invited me for dinner today, and this evening I spent some time at Mr. Prior's with Dr. Freind. It's now past midnight, so I need to go to bed.

original: When you are ordered to open or lock any Door, Trunk or Cabinet, and miss the proper Key, or cannot distinguish it in the Bunch; try the first Key that you can thrust in, and turn it with all your Strength till you open the Lock, or break the Key; for your Lady will reckon you a Fool to come back and do nothing.
modernized: If you are instructed to open or lock any door, cabinet, or chest and are unable to find or identify the correct key, attempt to insert the first key you see and turn it with as much force as possible until you unlock it or break the key, as your employer will consider it foolish to return empty-handed.

original: This is the Work, which I have been so hardy to attempt, and without the least mercenary View.
modernized: I have dared to attempt this work, and with no greedy intentions.

original: Neither do I doubt of succeeding to my full Wish, except among the Tories and their Abettors; who being all Jacobites, and, consequently Papists in their Hearts, from a Want of true Taste, or by strong Affectation, may perhaps resolve not to read my Book; chusing rather to deny themselves the Pleasure and Honour of shining in polite Company among the principal Genius's of both Sexes throughout the Kingdom, than adorn their Minds with this noble Art; and probably apprehending (as, I confess nothing is more likely to happen) that a true Spirit of Loyalty to the Protestant Succession should steal in along with it.
modernized: I believe I will achieve my full ambition, except among Tories and their accomplices, who are all Jacobites, and as such, Roman Catholics in their hearts. Lacking a genuine appreciation for aesthetics, or perhaps out of affected disdain, they may choose not to read my book, preferring to forego the pleasure and honor of associating with the leading creative minds of both sexes throughout the kingdom, rather than enrich their minds with this noble art. They may even fear (I must admit, it is not an unlikely scenario) that a true sense of loyalty to the Protestant succession might unintentionally be instilled within them.

original: I should likewise not be sorry, if the names of some bishops' sees were so much obliged to the alphabet, that upon pronouncing them we might contract some veneration for the order and persons of those reverend peers, which the gross ideas sometimes joined to their titles are very unjustly apt to diminish.
modernized: I would also appreciate it if the names of some bishops' sees were properly aligned with the alphabet, as it could instill a sense of respect for their order and themselves. Unfortunately, the crude connotations sometimes associated with their titles unjustly minimize their significance.

original: In 1713, he arrived at the deanery of St. Patrick, where he found the rage of party so prevalent, that the common people considered him as a Jacobite, and threw stones at him as he walked.
modernized: In 1713, Swift arrived at the deanery of St. Patrick in Ireland. He found intense political divisions so prevalent that the common people misperceived him as a supporter of the Jacobites, and even pelted him with stones as he walked.

original: To organise his reverend brethren of the chapter into some system, and to calm that Irish rabble who detested, and not long afterwards adored him, was, to his genius and humour, neither a tedious nor laborious task; for when he returned to London in the next year, he left behind him a name equally beloved and venerated.
modernized: Swift endeavored to organize his clerical colleagues into a cohesive system and to calm the volatile Irish crowd who both detested and later admired him. He found this task neither tiresome nor burdensome, as it aligned with his intellect and humor. When he returned to London the following year, he was recognized as equally respected and venerated.

original: It has rained all day with a continuendo, and I went in a chair to dine with Mrs. Van; always there in a very rainy day.
modernized: It's been raining continuously all day, and I went for a ride in a carriage to dine with Mrs. Van. I often go to dine there on rainy days.

original: But I made a shift to come back afoot.
modernized: I managed to walk back home after dinner.

original: I live a very retired life, pay very few visits, and keep but very little company; I read no newspapers.
modernized: I lead a very solitary life, make few social visits, and maintain only a small circle of friends; I don't read any newspapers.

original: I am sorry I sent you the Examiner, for the printer is going to print them in a small volume: it seems the author is too proud to have them printed by subscription, though his friends offered, they say, to make it worth five hundred pounds to him.
modernized: I regret sending you the Examiner as the printer is going to print them in a small volume. It seems the author is too proud to have them published by subscription, though it's reported his friends offered 500 pounds for the privilege.

original: The Spectators are likewise printing in a larger and a smaller volume, so I believe they are going to leave them off, and indeed people grow weary of them, though they are often prettily written.
modernized: The Spectator articles are also being published in both larger and smaller volumes. I believe they may soon stop publishing them altogether as some people seem to be growing weary of them, despite their charming writing.

original: We have had no news for me to send you now towards the end of my letter.
modernized: There hasn't been any news for me to share with you towards the end of this letter.

original: The Queen has the gout a little: I hoped the Lord Treasurer would have had it too, but Radcliffe told me yesterday it was the rheumatism in his knee and foot; however, he mends, and I hope will be abroad in a short time.
modernized: The Queen has a bit of gout, but I've been told the Lord Treasurer has rheumatism in his knee and foot. However, he's feeling better and I hope he'll be able to travel soon.

original: I am told they design giving away several employments before the Parliament sits, which will be the thirteenth instant.
modernized: It's rumored they'll distribute several positions before the Parliament convenes, which will take place on the 13th.

original: I either do not like, or not understand this policy; and if Lord Treasurer does not mend soon, they must give them just before the session.
modernized: I'm not sure I agree with this approach, and if the Lord Treasurer doesn't recover quickly, they'll have to make these appointments just before the parliamentary session.

original: But he is the greatest procrastinator in the world.
modernized: The Lord Treasurer is an extreme procrastinator.

original: Hence are derived those exorbitant interests and annuities; hence those large discounts for advances and prompt payment; hence public credit is shaken, and hence great numbers find their profit in prolonging the war.
modernized: The high interests and annuities, large discounts for early payments, and shaken public credit, as well as the profit for many, stem from prolonging the war.

original: I observed among them a Dutchman, who seemed to be of some authority, though he was not commander of either ship.
modernized: I noticed a Dutchman who appeared to have authority, but was not a commander of either ship.

original: He knew us by our countenances to be Englishmen, and jabbering to us in his own language, swore we should be tied back to back and thrown into the sea.
modernized: He identified us as Englishmen and threatened to tie us back-to-back and throw us into the sea in his own language.

original: I spoken Dutch tolerably well; I told him who we were, and begged him, in consideration of our being Christians and Protestants, of neighbouring countries in strict alliance, that he would move the captains to take some pity on us.
modernized: I spoke Dutch fairly well; I told him who we were, and begged for mercy due to us being Christians and Protestants from neighboring countries with close ties.

original: This inflamed his rage; he repeated his threatenings, and turning to his companions, spoke with great vehemence in the Japanese language, as I suppose, often using the word Christianos.
modernized: This angered him; he continued to threaten and spoke vehemently to his companions in Japanese, using the word 'Christians' repeatedly.

original: That farmers should be limited in ploughing is very reasonable, and practised in England, and might have easily been done here by penal clauses in their leases; but to deprive them, in a manner, altogether from tilling their lands, was a most stupid want of thinking.
modernized: Limiting farmers from over-plowing their lands is a reasonable measure, as it's already practiced in England. Adding penalties for excessive plowing in lease arrangements could have prevented the issue, but depriving farmers of the ability to till their lands altogether was a thoughtless approach.

original: When the King, who was then a prisoner in the Isle of Wight, had made his last concessions for a peace to the Commissioners of the Parliament, who attended him there; upon their return to London, they reported his Majesty's answer to the House.
modernized: When the imprisoned King had reached his final concessions for a peace with the Parliament Commissioners in the Isle of Wight, upon their return to London, they reported the King's answer to Parliament.

original: Whereupon, a number of moderate members, who, as Ludlow says, had secured their own terms with his Majesty, managed with so much art, as to obtain a majority, in a thin house, for passing a vote, that the King's concessions were a ground for future settlement.
modernized: Moderate members, who, according to Ludlow, had secured private terms with the King, skillfully managed to gain a majority in the sparsely populated House, passing a vote that the King's concessions provided a foundation for future negotiations.

original: But the great officers of the army, joining with the discontented members, came to a resolution, of excluding all those who had consented to that vote; which they executed in a military way.
modernized: The army's top officers, along with the disgruntled members, decided to banish everyone who supported that vote, executing their plan in a military fashion.

original: Ireton told Fairfax the General, a rigid Presbyterian, of this resolution; who thereupon issued his orders for drawing out the army the next morning, and placing guards in Westminster-hall, the Court of Requests, and the lobby; who, in obedience to the General, in conjunction with those members who opposed the vote, would let no member enter the House, except those of their own party.
modernized: Ireton informed Fairfax, the rigorous Presbyterian General, about this decision. As a result, Fairfax issued orders for the assembly to evacuate the following morning, posted guards in Westminster-hall, the Court of Requests, and the lobby, allowing no member to enter the House except those from their own faction.

original: Upon which, the question for bringing the King to justice, was immediately put and carried without opposition, that I can find.
modernized: As a response, the question to prosecute the King was approved without opposition, as per the information I can find.

original: Then, an order was made for his trial; the time and place appointed; the judges named; of whom Fairfax himself was one; although by the advice or threats of his wife, he declined sitting among them.
modernized: An order was immediately issued for the King's trial, specifying the time, place, and judges involved; Fairfax was among the judges named, but he declined sitting with them due to his wife's advice or threats.

original: However, by fresh orders under his own hand, which I have seen in print, he appointed guards to attend the judges at the trial, and to keep the city in quiet; as he did likewise to prevent any opposition from the people, upon the day of execution.
modernized: Despite this, Fairfax later appointed guards utilizing his own authority to safeguard the judges during the trial and maintain order in the city on the day of execution.

original: Coxe endeavors to exonerate Walpole from the disgrace attached to this business, by expatiating on Carteret's opposition to Walpole, an opposition which went so far as to attempt to injure the financial minister's reputation by fomenting jealousies and using the Wood patent agitation to arouse against him the popular indignation; but this does not explain away the fact itself.
modernized: Coxe tries to clear Walpole's name by focusing on Carteret's opposition, which attempt to tarnish Walpole's reputation by stirring up jealousy and using the Wood patent controversy to foment public outrage; however, this does not justify the questionable actions.

original: He lays some blame for the agitation on Wood's indiscretion in flaunting his rights and publicly boasting of what the great minister would do for him.
modernized: He partly blames Wood for the uproar due to his unwise display of his privileges and boasting about what the powerful minister would do for him.

original: At the same time he takes care to censure the government for its misconduct in not consulting with the Lord Lieutenant and his Privy Council before granting the patent.
modernized: At the same time, he criticizes the government for their poor decision-making by not conferring with the Lord Lieutenant and his advisors before awarding the patent.

original: His censure, however, is founded on the consideration that this want of attention was injudicious and was the cause of the spread of exaggerated rumours of the patent's evil tendency.
modernized: His criticism, however, is based on the understanding that their lack of consultation led to the spread of overblown rumors about the patent's negative impact.

original: He has nothing to say of the rights and liberties of a people which had thereby been infringed and ignored.
modernized: He remains silent on the rights and freedoms of the people, which were compromised through these questionable actions.

original: Morning. It is now seven, and I have got a fire, but am writing abed in my bedchamber. 'Tis not shaving-day, so I shall be ready early to go before church to Mr. St. John; and tomorrow I will answer our MD's letter.
modernized: At morning, it's now 7 o'clock, and I have a fire but continue writing in bed. It is not shaving day, so I will be ready early to leave for church to see Mr. St. John. Tomorrow, I plan to respond to our MD's letter.

original: If swearing and profaneness, scandalous and avowed lewdness, excessive gaming and intemperance, were a little discountenanced in the army, I cannot readily see what ill consequences could be apprehended; if gentlemen of that profession were at least obliged to some external decorum in their conduct; or even if a profligate life and character were not a means of advancement, and the appearance of piety a most infallible hindrance, it is impossible the corruptions there should be so universal and exorbitant.
modernized: If swearing, lewdness, excessive gambling, and drunkenness were discouraged in the military, I cannot think of any negative consequences. If military leaders were at least expected to maintain a certain level of decorum, and if a profligate lifestyle was not a pathway to success and a pious appearance was a guaranteed hindrance, it's impossible for such behaviors to be so widespread.

original: I have been assured by several great officers, that no troops abroad are so ill disciplined as the English; which cannot well be otherwise, while the common soldiers have perpetually before their eyes the vicious example of their leaders; and it is hardly possible for those to commit any crime, whereof these are not infinitely more guilty, and with less temptation.
modernized: I've been told by many senior officers that the English troops overseas are very poorly disciplined, which is likely because the common soldiers are continuously exposed to the poor examples set by their leaders. These leaders are often much more guilty of these behaviors and they have less incentive to change.

original: These preparations were public enough, and the ministers had sufficient time to arm themselves; but they seem to have acted, in this juncture, like men who trusted to the goodness of their cause, and the general inclinations of the kingdom, rather than to those arts which our corruptions have too often made necessary.
modernized: The preparations were quite obvious, but the ministers seemed to rely on public opinion and the strength of their cause rather than on tactics, which have often been necessary due to corruption.

original: Calculations were indeed taken, by which it was computed, that there would be a majority of ten upon the side of the court.
modernized: Calculations were made predicting a majority of 10 in favor of the court.

original: I remember to have told my Lord Harcourt and Mr. Prior, that a majority of ten was only a majority of five, because if their adversaries could bring off five, the number would be equal: and so it happened to prove; for the mistake lay in counting upon the bare promises of those who were wholly in the interest of the old ministry, and were only kept in awe by the fear of offending the crown, and losing their subsistence, wherein the Duke of Somerset had given them full satisfaction.
modernized: I told Lord Harcourt and Mr. Prior that a majority of 10 was actually a majority of 5, as if five more votes could be secured, the number would be even; and this ended up being the case, as they overestimated the support of those who supported the old ministry due to fear of the monarch and loss of income, as they were satisfied with Duke of Somerset's terms.

original: Whatever might have been the method of electing bishops, in the more primitive ages, it seems plain to me that in these times, and somewhat before, although the election was made per clerum et populum, yet the king always nominated at first, or approved afterwards, and generally both, as may be seen by the style in which their elections ran, as well as by the persons chosen, who were usually Churchmen of the court, or in some employment near the King.
modernized: the election was made by the clergy and the people, but the king always nominated at the outset or approved afterwards, and generally both. Although this selection process might have been a gradual encroachment of royal power on the Church, I prefer to leave such debates to scholars.

original: But whether this were a gradual encroachment of the regal upon the spiritual power, I had rather leave others to dispute.
modernized: But whether this was a gradual encroachment of royal power on the Church remains a matter of scholarly debate.

original: But fortune disposed otherwise of me.
modernized: Fortune put me in a different situation.

original: When the people observed I was quiet, they discharged no more arrows: but, by the noise I heard, I knew their numbers increased; and about four yards from me, over against my right ear, I heard a knocking for above an hour, like that of people at work; when, turning my head that way, as well as the pegs and strings would permit me, I saw a stage erected, about a foot and a half from the ground, capable of holding four of the inhabitants, with two or three ladders to mount it; from whence one of them, who seemed to be a person of quality, made me a long speech, whereof I understood not one syllable.
modernized: When the people saw that I was still, they stopped shooting arrows at me. However, the noise I heard suggested that more of them had gathered nearby. About four yards from me and to my right, I heard a sound similar to people working for an hour. as I turned my head to listen, I observed a small stage being set up, about 1.5 feet from the ground and capable of holding four of the creatures. From the stage, a person who seemed to be important made a lengthy speech, although I didn't understand a single word of it.

original: Upon these faithful informations, and advices from your Commons, we assure ourselves your Majesty, in your great goodness to your people, will rescue them from those evils, which the private counsels of ill-designing men have exposed them to; and that in your great wisdom you will find some means for the explaining, and amending, the several articles of this treaty, so as that they may consist with the interest of Great Britain, and with real and lasting friendship between your Majesty and the States General.
modernized: With the reliable information and advice from your commons, we are confident that your Majesty, for the well-being of your people, will protect them from the harms intentionally set upon them by unscrupulous individuals. We believe that you will employ wisdom to clarify and revise the various terms of this treaty, ensuring its alignment with Great Britain's best interests and maintaining genuine, lasting friendship between your Majesty and the States General.

original: In this incident there seems to have been an union of events, that will probably never happen again to the end of the world, or at least like the grand conjunction in the heavens, which I think they say can arrive but once in twenty thousand years.
modernized: This incident was a highly unlikely sequence of events, much like a rare astronomical event that only occurs once every 20,000 years.

original: For instance, nothing is more generally exploded than the folly of talking too much; yet I rarely remember to have seen five people together where some one among them hath not been predominant in that kind, to the great constraint and disgust of all the rest.
modernized: For example, it's commonly considered a bad thing to talk excessively, but I seldom see a group of five people where someone isn't dominating conversations, causing discomfort to others.

original: But among such as deal in multitudes of words, none are comparable to the sober deliberate talker, who proceedeth with much thought and caution, maketh his preface, brancheth out into several digressions, findeth a hint that putteth him in mind of another story, which he promiseth to tell you when this is done; cometh back regularly to his subject, cannot readily call to mind some person's name, holdeth his head, complaineth of his memory; the whole company all this while in suspense; at length, says he, it is no matter, and so goes on.
modernized: However, among those who talk a lot, no one compares to the thoughtful, cautious speaker who takes time to think, starts with a preface, has multiple digressions, recalls a hint leading to another story, promises to finish the story later, returns to the subject, struggles to remember names, holds his head, and complains of his memory; the whole group is held in suspense for a while until he says it doesn't matter and continues.

original: And, to crown the business, it perhaps proveth at last a story the company hath heard fifty times before; or, at best, some insipid adventure of the relater.
modernized: In the end, it often turns out to be a story the group has heard many times before, or, at best, an insipid personal adventure.

original: But an incident soon offered, which gave King Henry a pretext for retaliating almost in the same manner: for it happened that upon some offence taken against his nephew Theobald Count of Blois by the French King, Louis in great rage sent an army to invade and ravage the earl's territories.
modernized: A conflict soon arose, which provided King Henry with an excuse to retaliate. The French King, angered by an offense against his nephew Theobald Count of Blois, dispatched an army to invade and pillage Theobald's territories.

original: Theobald defended himself for a while with much valour; but at length in danger to be overpowered, requested aid of his uncle the King of England, who supported him so effectually with men and money, that he was able not only to defend his own country, but very much to infest and annoy his enemy.
modernized: Theobald initially defended himself valiantly, but as defeat seemed imminent he sought the aid of his uncle, King Henry. King Henry came to his nephew's assistance with men and funds, enabling Theobald to both defend his own lands and harass the enemy.

original: Thus a war was kindled between the two kings; Louis now openly asserted the title of William the son of Robert, and entering into an alliance with the Earls of Flanders and Anjou, began to concert measures for driving King Henry out of Normandy.
modernized: This conflict escalated into a war between the two kings. Louis publicly supported William the son of Robert's claim and formed alliances with the Earls of Flanders and Anjou, plotting to unseat King Henry from Normandy.

original: The payment of tithes in this kingdom, is subject to so many frauds, brangles, and other difficulties, not only from Papists and Dissenters, but even from those who profess themselves Protestants; that by the expense, the trouble, and vexation of collecting, or bargaining for them, they are, of all other rents, the most precarious, uncertain, and ill paid.
modernized: Payment of tithes in the kingdom is fraught with numerous scams, quarrels, and other complications, not only by Catholics and dissenters, but even by those who claim to be Protestants; making it the most uncertain, unpredictable, and underpaid form of rent. As a result, the process of collections or negotiations for them is confusing, costly, and troublesome.

original: It is true, the Clergy of this kingdom, who are promoted to bishoprics, have always some great advantages; either that of rich deaneries, opulent and multiplied rectories and dignities, strong alliances by birth or marriage, fortified by a superlative degree of zeal and loyalty; but, however, they were all at first no more than young beginners; and before their great promotion, were known by their plain Christian names, among their old companions, the middling rate of clergymen; nor could, therefore, be strangers to their condition, or with any good grace, forget it so soon as it hath sometimes happened.
modernized: The clergy who ascend to the rank of bishop in this kingdom have substantial advantages, such as rich deaneries, abundant rectories, and dignities; powerful family ties by birth or marriage, boosted by exceptional devotion and loyalty. However, even though they became bishops, they were initially just starting out in their career; and before their promotion, they were known by their given names among their peers, the average clergy. Given this, they should not forget their prior circumstances so easily, as it has happened on occasion.

original: Here the author being seized with a fit of dulness, to which he is very subject, after having read a poetical epistle addressed to . . . it entirely composed his senses, so that he has not writ a line since.
modernized: The author suffered a sudden bout of writer's block, a condition he often experiences, following the reading of a poetic letter. Consequently, he has not been able to write any new material since.

original: Secondly, The Dissenters are now tolerated by law; neither do we observe any murmurs at present from that quarter, except those reasonable complaints they make of persecution, because they are excluded from civil employments; but their number being very small in either House of Parliament, they are not yet in a situation to erect a party: Because, however indifferent men may be with regard to religion, they are now grown wise enough to know, that if such a latitude were allowed to Dissenters; the few small employments left us in cities and corporations, would find other hands to lay hold on them.
modernized: Secondly, Dissenters are legally tolerated, yet they still complain about being excluded from civil roles. However, their numbers are too small in Parliament to form a party. Although people may be indifferent about religion, they understand that allowing more leeway to Dissenters could lead to others seizing the few remaining job opportunities in cities and corporations.

original: I received from you, some weeks ago, the honour of my freedom, in a silver box, by the hands of Mr. Stannard; but it was not delivered to me in as many weeks more; because, I suppose, he was too full of more important business.
modernized: I received the honor of my freedom, in a silver box, from you several weeks ago, but it was not delivered to me for several more weeks, likely due to Mr. Stannard being occupied with more urgent matters.

original: Since that time, I have been wholly confined by sickness, so that I was not able to return you my acknowledgment; and it is with much difficulty I do it now, my head continuing in great disorder.
modernized: I have been confined to bed due to illness since then and have struggled to respond earlier, as my head is still disordered.

original: Mr. Faulkner will be the bearer of my letter, who sets out this morning for Cork.
modernized: Mr. Faulkner will be delivering my letter today, as he departs for Cork this morning.

original: But although our arguments are not suffered to be printed in England, yet the consequence will be of little moment.
modernized: Despite our arguments not being allowed to be published in England, the impact will not be significant.

original: Let Wood endeavour to persuade the people there that we ought to receive his coin, and let me convince our people here that they ought to reject it under pain of our utter undoing.
modernized: Wood should attempt to convince the English people to accept his coin, while I aim to persuade our citizens to refuse it to prevent our downfall.

original: And then let him do his best and his worst.
modernized: Let him continue to do his best and worst.

original: But when this expedient of anticipations and mortgages was first put in practice, artful men, in office and credit, began to consider what uses it might be applied to; and soon found it was likely to prove the most fruitful seminary, not only to establish a faction they intended to set up for their own support, but likewise to raise vast wealth for themselves in particular, who were to be the managers and directors in it.
modernized: Initial attempts to develop anticipations and mortgages revealed opportunities for influential individuals to wield power and amass wealth. The plotters saw potential for establishing a faction in their favor and amassing personal wealth for themselves, as managers and directors of the scheme.

original: It was manifest, that nothing could promote these two designs so much, as burthening the nation with debts, and giving encouragement to lenders: for, as to the first, it was not to be doubted, that moneyed men would be always firm to the party of those who advised the borrowing upon such good security, and with such exorbitant premiums and interest; and every new sum that was lent, took away as much power from the landed men, as it added to theirs: so that the deeper the kingdom was engaged, it was still the better for them.
modernized: The primary way to foster these objectives was by burdening the nation with debts and fostering lending. Moneyed men would remain loyal to those who advocated borrowing with excellent security and high premiums/interest. As more money was lent, the power shifted from landowners to the new lenders, ultimately favoring the latter.

original: Thus a new estate and property sprung up in the hands of mortgagees, to whom every house and foot of land in England paid a rent-charge, free of all taxes and defalcations, and purchased at less than half value.
modernized: As a result, a new class of wealthy mortgagees emerged. They collected rent-charges from every house and inch of land in England, exempt from all taxes and deficiencies, and acquired these properties at less than half the market value.

original: So that the gentlemen of estates were, in effect, but tenants to these new landlords; many of whom were able, in time, to force the election of boroughs out of the hands of those who had been the old proprietors and inhabitants.
modernized: This left the landed gentry as mere tenants to these new landlords, many of whom eventually seized control of boroughs from the original proprietors and inhabitants.

original: This was arrived at such a height, that a very few years more of war and funds would have clearly cast the balance on the moneyed side.
modernized: The situation escalated to a critical point where only a few more years of war and debt would have significantly tipped the balance in favor of the moneyed class.

original: In another paragraph of the patent your Majesty has covenanted and granted unto the said William Wood, his executors, &c.
modernized: In another paragraph of the patent, your Majesty has promised and agreed to the said William Wood, his executors, and so forth.

original: That upon performance of covenants, on his and their parts, he and they shall peaceably, and quietly, have, hold, and enjoy all the powers, authorities, privileges, licences, profits, advantages, and all other matters and things thereby granted, without any let, suit, trouble, molestation or denial of your Majesty, your heirs or successors, or of or by any of your or their officers or ministers, or any person or persons, &c.
modernized: Upon fulfillment of the promises and agreements on both sides, William Wood and his associates should peacefully and quietly have, possess, and use all the granted powers, authorities, privileges, licenses, profits, advantages, and all other matters without hindrance from your Majesty, your heirs, or successors, or any of your officers, ministers, or other individuals.

original: This being so expressly granted and covenanted by your Majesty, and there appearing no failure, non-performance, or breach of covenants, on the part of the patentee, the Lords of the Committee cannot advise your Majesty to give directions to the officers of the revenue, not to receive or utter any of the said copper halfpence or farthings as has been desired.
modernized: Since the promises and agreements between your Majesty and the patentee have been explicitly made and no failures, non-performance, or breaches have been found, the Lords of the Committee advise against instructing the revenue officers not to accept or circulate the copper halfpence or farthings as was requested.

original: When the matron Houyhnhnms have produced one of each sex, they no longer accompany with their consorts, except they lose one of their issue by some casualty, which very seldom happens; but in such a case they meet again; or when the like accident befalls a person whose wife is past bearing, some other couple bestow on him one of their own colts, and then go together again until the mother is pregnant.
modernized: When a matron Houyhnhnm has given birth to one of each sex, they cease to mate with their partners, unless they suffer a loss within their family, which is rare. However, if such a loss occurs, they reunite, or if a person's partner is unable to conceive, another couple gives one of their own offspring to him, and they reunite until the mother becomes pregnant again. This practice is necessary to avoid overpopulation.

original: This caution is necessary, to prevent the country from being overburdened with numbers.

original: Now suppose, that, instead of the public coinage, a patent had been granted to some private, obscure person, for coining a proportionable quantity of copper in that kingdom, to what Mr. Wood is preparing in this; and all of it at least five times below the intrinsic value: The current money of England is reckoned to be twenty millions; and ours under five hundred thousand pounds: By this computation, as Mr. Wood hath power to give us 108,000 pound; so the patentee in England, by the same proportion, might circulate four millions three hundred and twenty thousand pounds; besides as much more by stealth and counterfeits: I desire to know from you, whether the Parliament might not have addressed upon such an occasion; what success they probably would have had; and how many Drapiers would have risen to pester the world with pamphlets: Yet that kingdom would not be so great a sufferer as ours in the like case; because their cash would not be conveyed into foreign countries, but lie hid in the chests of cautious, thrifty men, until better times.
modernized: Let's imagine a situation where a private individual was granted a patent to produce five times as much copper in England, as Mr. Wood is producing here, with each piece being worth less than the copper's actual worth. The money supply in England is valued at £20 million, and ours at around £500,000. If Mr. Wood can distribute £108,000 here, a patentee in England might circulate £4,320,000, in addition to an unknown amount through stealth or fraud. I'd like to know: would the British Parliament have acted in such a case? How many Drapiers would have emerged to spread pamphlets? However, even if England suffered, their cash wouldn't be taken to foreign countries. Instead, it would be hoarded by careful, thrifty individuals until better times.

original: Then I desire, for the satisfaction of the public, that you will please to inform me why this country is treated in so very different a manner, in a point of such high importance; whether it be on account of Poining's act; of subordination; dependence; or any other term of art; which I shall not contest, but am too dull to understand.
modernized: I want to know, for the public's sake, why this country is being treated so differently in matters of great importance, when compared to England. Is it due to Poining's Act, subordination, or some legal term I'm unfamiliar with? I won't argue against these terms, but I'm too dull to understand.

original: If there be any true reasoning in what I have laid down, it should seem, that the project now in agitation for repealing the Test Act, and yet leaving the name of an establishment to the present national church, is altogether inconsistent, and may admit of consequences, which those, who are the most indifferent to any religion at all, are possibly not aware of.
modernized: If the arguments I presented are sound, it appears that the current proposal to repeal the Test Act while preserving the established church's name is contradictory and could have unforeseen consequences, even for those who claim to be indifferent to religion.

original: However, since the Drapier is but one man, I shall think I do a public service, by asserting that the rest of my countrymen are wholly free from learning out of his pamphlets to reflect on the King or his ministers, to breed sedition.
modernized: Since the Drapier is just one individual, I believe it's my duty to assert that the rest of my fellow citizens have not been influenced by his writings to question the King or his officials, and are not promoting sedition in any way.

original: First: It would be well, if people would not lay so much weight on their own reason in matters of religion, as to think everything impossible and absurd which they cannot conceive.
modernized: It would be beneficial for people to not rely excessively on their personal judgment when it comes to religious matters, considering everything implausible or absurd that they struggle to comprehend.

original: How often do we contradict the right rules of reason in the whole course of our lives!
modernized: We frequently disregard the correct principles of reason during the entirety of our lives.

original: Reason itself is true and just, but the reason of every particular man is weak and wavering, perpetually swayed and turned by his interests, his passions, and his vices.
modernized: Although reason is valid and just, the reason of any individual is fragile and inconsistent, often swayed by personal interests, emotions, and vices.

original: Let any man but consider, when he hath a controversy with another, although his cause be ever so unjust, although the world be against him, how blinded he is by the love of himself, to believe that right is wrong, and wrong is right, when it maketh for his own advantage.
modernized: Any man should reflect, in instances of contention with another, even if his claim is unjust and the world opposes him, how blinded he becomes by self-love, believing right to be wrong, and wrong to be right, when it benefits him personally.

original: Where is then the right use of his reason, which he so much boasts of, and which he would blasphemously set up to control the commands of the Almighty?
modernized: In what way is his reason, which he praises so much, serving a rightful purpose when he arrogantly attempts to challenge the commands of the Almighty?

original: I come now to a most important Part of your Oeconomy, the bottling of a Hogshead of Wine, wherein I recommend three Virtues, Cleanliness, Frugality, and brotherly Love.
modernized: In discussing your household economy, I want to focus on wine bottling and the virtues of cleanliness, frugality, and brotherly love. For the corks, I advise choosing the longest available ones to conserve wine in each bottle. You should also opt for b

original: Let your Corks be of the longest Kind you can get; which will save some Wine in the Neck of every Bottle: As to your Bottles chuse the smallest you can find, which will increase the Number of Dozens, and please your Master; for a Bottle of Wine is always a Bottle of Wine, whether it hold more or less; and if your Master hath his proper Number of Dozens, he cannot complain.
modernized: Select smaller bottles to increase the number of dozen bottles and please your master. Understand that a bottle of wine remains a bottle of wine, regardless of its volume, and if your master owns the proper number of dozen bottles, he will not complain.

original: When the Lord Raby was first sent to The Hague, the Duke of Marlborough, and Lord Townshend, had, for very obvious reasons, used their utmost endeavours to involve him in as many difficulties as they could; upon which, and other accounts, needless to mention, it was thought proper, that his Grace, then in Flanders, should not be let into the secret of this affair.
modernized: The Duke of Marlborough and Lord Townshend actively worked to ensnare Lord Raby when he was first sent to The Hague for complex reasons. Consequently, it was considered necessary to keep him unaware of the matters at hand, and he was then in Flanders.

original: Thirdly, Nothing is more dangerous to idle young fellows, than the company of those odious common whores we frequent, and of which this town is full: These wretches put us upon all mischief to feed their lusts and extravagancies: They are ten times more bloody and cruel than men; their advice is always not to spare if we are pursued; they get drunk with us, and are common to us all; and yet, if they can get anything by it, are sure to be our betrayers.
modernized: Thirdly, the association of idle young men with offensive common prostitutes, who are prevalent in this town, poses great danger. These women lead us into mischief to satisfy their desires and indulgences. Ten times more cruel and violent than men, they always encourage us not to hold back if we are pursued. They get drunk with us and share their affections indiscriminately among us. Despite that, if they see a chance to profit, they are certain to betray us.

original: The Blefuscudians, who had not the least imagination of what I intended, were at first confounded with astonishment.
modernized: The Blefuscudians, initially lacking any idea of my plan, were overwhelmed with bewilderment.

original: They had seen me cut the cables, and thought my design was only to let the ships run adrift, or fall foul on each other: but when they perceived the whole fleet moving in order, and saw me pulling at the end, they set up such a scream of grief and despair as it is almost impossible to describe or conceive.
modernized: Having witnessed me cut the ship's cables, the Blefuscudians initially presumed I intended to let the ships drift or collide: but when they noticed the entire fleet moving coordinated and observing me pulling the end, they let out a lamentable outcry of sorrow that was hard to put into words.

original: When I had got out of danger, I stopped awhile to pick out the arrows that stuck in my hands and face: and rubbed on some of the same ointment that was given me at my first arrival, as I have formerly mentioned.
modernized: Once I was out of harm's way, I paused to remove the arrows embedded in my hands and face and apply the ointment I had got upon arriving, as I had previously noted.

original: I then took off my spectacles, and waiting about an hour, till the tide was a little fallen, I waded through the middle with my cargo, and arrived safe at the royal port of Lilliput.
modernized: After that, I took off my spectacles, waited an hour for the tide to recede slightly, and waded through with my cargo, ultimately reaching the royal port of Lilliput safely.

original: The reasons for this unusual proceeding, which made a mighty noise, were of sufficient weight to justify it; for, pursuant to the agreement made between us and France, a courier was then dispatched from Fontainebleau to Madrid, with the offer of an alternative to Philip, either of resigning Spain immediately to the Duke of Savoy, upon the hopes of succeeding to France, and some present advantage, which, not having been accepted, is needless to dilate on; or of adhering to Spain, and renouncing all future claim to France for himself and his posterity.
modernized: The Queen offered Philip a choice: either hand over Spain immediately to the Duke of Savoy with hopes of succeeding to the French throne, with some immediate benefits, but which was not accepted and is unnecessary to elaborate on; or stay with Spain and renounce any future claim to France for himself and his descendants. This unusual action, causing a significant stir, was justified due to a prior agreement with France. A messenger was sent from Fontainebleau to Madrid with this proposition. Nevertheless, the Queen held off from taking control of Dunkirk or declaring an armistice until she knew which option Philip would choose. Unfortunately, should an opportunity to engage in battle arise, Prince Eugene would be eager to exploit it to satisfy his own ambition, anger his new Dutch masters, and disrupt the peace.

original: I am persuaded that foreigners, as well as those at home, who live too remote from the scene of business to be rightly informed, will not be displeased with this account of a person, who in the space of two years, hath been so highly instrumental in changing the face of affairs in Europe, and hath deserved so well of his own Prince and country.
modernized: I believe that people, both from foreign lands and from home who are not closely involved in the politics, will appreciate hearing about this individual who has significantly impacted the political landscape of Europe over a period of two years and has served his country and monarch admirably.

original: About two or three days before I was set at liberty, as I was entertaining the court with feats of this kind, there arrived an express to inform his majesty that some of his subjects riding near the place where I was first taken up, had seen a great black substance lying on the ground, very oddly shaped, extending its edges round as wide as his majesty's bedchamber, and rising up in the middle as high as a man; that it was no living creature, as they had at first apprehended, for it lay on the grass without motion; and some of them had walked round it several times; that, by mounting upon each other's shoulders, they had got to the top, which was flat and even, and, stamping upon it, they found it was hollow within; that they humbly conceived it might be something belonging to the man-mountain; and if his majesty pleased, they would undertake to bring it with only five horses.
modernized: Three or four days before my release, while performing equestrian and military feats for the court, an express arrived reporting that some of the king's subjects had found a large, oddly shaped, black object on the ground near where I was initially captured. It was as wide as the king's bedchamber and stood as tall as a man. They initially believed it was a living creature, but it was motionless on the grass. They walked around it several times and, by standing on each other's shoulders, reached the top. They found it was flat, hollow, and seemed to belong to the man-mountain. They proposed to bring it to the king with just five horses.

original: If a private gentleman's income be sunk irretrievably for ever from a hundred pounds to fifty, and that he hath no other method to supply the deficiency, I desire to know, my Lord, whether such a person hath any other course to take than to sink half his expenses in every article of economy, to save himself from ruin and the gaol.
modernized: If a wealthy person's income were to drop from £100 to £50 and they had no other way to make up the difference, I would like to know, my Lord, if this person would have any other choice except to cut expenses in half for every expense category, in order to avoid bankruptcy and jail.

original: Is not this more than doubly the case of Ireland, where the want of money, the irrecoverable ruin of trade, with the other evils above mentioned, and many more too well known and felt, and too numerous or invidious to relate, have been gradually sinking us for above a dozen years past, to a degree that we are at least by two thirds in a worse condition than was ever known since the Revolution?
modernized: Isn't this situation even more extreme in Ireland, where a lack of resources, the irreversible collapse of trade, along with other issues mentioned and many more that are known, felt, and too numerous or inappropriate to discuss have been gradually causing us to worsen for over a dozen years, to a point that we are at least two-thirds worse off than at any time since the Revolution?

original: Therefore instead of dreams and projects for the advancing of trade, we have nothing left but to find out some expedient whereby we may reduce our expenses to our incomes.
modernized: Therefore, instead of grandiose plans to boost trade, we are left with no choice but to figure out some way to lower our expenses to match our income.

original: How Jack and Martin, being parted, set up each for himself.
modernized: After parting ways, Jack and Martin each forged their own paths.

original: How they travelled over hills and dales, met many disasters, suffered much from the good cause, and struggled with difficulties and wants, not having where to lay their head; by all which they afterwards proved themselves to be right father's sons, and Peter to be spurious.
modernized: They journeyed through rugged terrains, faced numerous difficulties, struggled with lack and hardship, and eventually proved themselves true sons of their father, with Peter reveling as a fraud.

original: Finding no shelter near Peter's habitation, Martin travelled northwards, and finding the Thuringians, a neighbouring people, disposed to change, he set up his stage first among them, where, making it his business to cry down Peter's powders, plasters, salves, and drugs, which he had sold a long time at a dear rate, allowing Martin none of the profit, though he had been often employed in recommending and putting them off, the good people, willing to save their pence, began to hearken to Martin's speeches.
modernized: Unable to find shelter near Peter's residence, Martin traveled northwards, discovering a group of Thuringians nomadic people, who were willing to change their ways. There, Martin set up shop as a critic of Peter's overpriced remedies and medicines, claiming their profits for himself.

original: How several great lords took the hint, and on the same account declared for Martin; particularly one who, not having had enough of one wife, wanted to marry a second, and knowing Peter used not to grant such licenses but at a swingeing price, he struck up a bargain with Martin, whom he found more tractable, and who assured him he had the same power to allow such things.
modernized: Several powerful lords followed Martin's lead, including one who wanted to marry a second wife but knew Peter wouldn't grant it except for a high price. This individual found Martin more compliant and promised him the same ability to grant such licenses.

original: How most of the other Northern lords, for their own private ends, withdrew themselves and their dependants from Peter's authority, and closed in with Martin.
modernized: Many other Northern lords, seeking to serve their own interests, abandoned their allegiance to Peter and sided with Martin.

original: How Peter, enraged at the loss of such large territories, and consequently of so much revenue, thundered against Martin, and sent out the strongest and most terrible of his bulls to devour him; but this having no effect, and Martin defending himself boldly and dexterously, Peter at last put forth proclamations declaring Martin and all his adherents rebels and traitors, ordaining and requiring all his loving subjects to take up arms, and to kill, burn, and destroy all and every one of them, promising large rewards, &c., upon which ensued bloody wars and desolation.
modernized: Furious over losing significant territories and revenue, Peter denounced Martin with threating proclamations, ordering his subjects to rise against Martin, promising large rewards. This sparked bloody wars and destruction throughout the land. Martin defended himself bravely and cunningly.

original: I am therefore of opinion, that a real undefalcated revenue of six hundred pounds a year, is a sufficient income for a country dean in this kingdom; and since the rents consist wholly of tithes, two parishes, to the amount of that value, should be united, and the dean reside as minister in that of Down, and the remaining parishes be divided among worthy clergymen, to about 300l. a year to each.
modernized: I believe that, for a country dean in this kingdom, a genuine, unembezzled income of 600 pounds a year is sufficient. Since the income originates solely from tithes, two parishes worth that total amount should be merged. The dean should serve as a minister in one of these parishes, and the remaining parishes should be distributed among deserving clergy, providing an income of approximately 300 pounds a year to each.

original: The deanery of Derry, which is a large city, might be left worth 800l. a year, and Rapho according as it shall be thought proper.
modernized: The deanery of Derry, a large city, could be valued at 800 pounds a year, and Rapho, according to what seems fitting.

original: These three are the only opulent deaneries in the whole kingdom, and, as I am informed, consist all of tithes, which was an unhappy expedient in the Church, occasioned by the sacrilegious robberies during the several times of confusion and war; insomuch that at this day there is hardly any remainder left of dean and chapter lands in Ireland, that delicious morsel swallowed so greedily in England, under the fanatic usurpations.
modernized: The three wealthiest deaneries in the kingdom are the only ones I've learned about, and they consist entirely of tithes. This was an unfortunate practice in the church, caused by the sacrilegious thefts during times of disarray and war. As a result, there is now hardly any dean and chapter land left in Ireland, a valuable treat relished excessively in England, under the fanatical usurpations.

original: This was the sum of my speech, delivered with great improprieties and hesitation; the latter part was altogether framed in the style peculiar to that people, whereof I learned some phrases from Glumdalclitch, while she was carrying me to court.
modernized: I explained to the queen that my speech was fraught with awkwardness and stumbling, particularly the latter part which I learned from the people there, as Glumdalclitch helped me on my journey to the court.

original: About two or three days before I was set at liberty, as I was entertaining the court with this kind of feat, there arrived an express to inform his majesty, that some of his subjects, riding near the place where I was first taken up, had seen a great black substance lying on the around, very oddly shaped, extending its edges round, as wide as his majesty's bedchamber, and rising up in the middle as high as a man; that it was no living creature, as they at first apprehended, for it lay on the grass without motion; and some of them had walked round it several times; that, by mounting upon each other's shoulders, they had got to the top, which was flat and even, and, stamping upon it, they found that it was hollow within; that they humbly conceived it might be something belonging to the man-mountain; and if his majesty pleased, they would undertake to bring it with only five horses.
modernized: After about two or three days, an express arrived with news that some of the emperor's subjects had seen a large black object near where I was first captured. This oddly shaped object extended its edges as wide as the emperor's bedchamber and stood up as tall as a man, and it appeared to be inanimate as it lay still on the grass. Some people climbed on each other's shoulders to get to the top and found it to be hollow. They believed it might belong to the Man Mountain, and if the emperor wished, they would retrieve it using only five horses.

original: I presently knew what they meant, and was glad at heart to receive this intelligence.
modernized: Upon hearing this, I realized what they were talking about and felt relieved to receive this information.

original: It seems, upon my first reaching the shore after our shipwreck, I was in such confusion, that before I came to the place where I went to sleep, my hat, which I had fastened with a string to my head while I was rowing, and had stuck on all the time I was swimming, fell off after I came to land; the string, as I conjecture, breaking by some accident, which I never observed, but thought my hat had been lost at sea.
modernized: Upon reaching the shore after our shipwreck, I was so confused that I lost my hat before I reached the place where I eventually fell asleep. The string holding my hat to my head likely broke, causing the hat to fall off and be lost at sea. I didn't notice this accident occur, but I later learned that it was lost.

original: I entreated his imperial majesty to give orders it might be brought to me as soon as possible, describing to him the use and the nature of it: and the next day the waggoners arrived with it, but not in a very good condition; they had bored two holes in the brim, within an inch and half of the edge, and fastened two hooks in the holes; these hooks were tied by a long cord to the harness, and thus my hat was dragged along for above half an English mile; but, the ground in that country being extremely smooth and level, it received less damage than I expected.
modernized: I asked the emperor to have my missing hat retrieved as soon as possible and described its use and purpose to him. The following day, the waggoners returned with the hat, but it was in a damaged condition. They bored two holes in the brim and attached hooks to drag the hat using a long cord attached to the harness. The hat was dragged for more than half a mile, but due to the smooth and level ground, it sustained less damage than I expected.

original: This is the utmost I am authorised to say upon so ungrateful and melancholy a subject, because we are extremely unwilling to inflame a controversy whose continuance may be so fatal to the interests of us all, desiring much rather that things be amicably composed; and we shall so far advance on our side as to be ready to receive the two prodigals with open arms whenever they shall think fit to return from their husks and their harlots, which I think, from the present course of their studies , they most properly may be said to be engaged in, and, like an indulgent parent, continue to them our affection and our blessing.
modernized: I am only authorized to speak about this very unfortunate and sad topic, as we are extremely reluctant to escalate a controversy that could potentially be disastrous for everyone involved. Instead, we strongly advocate for reconciliation. We are willing to accept the prodigal authors back with open arms whenever they decide to leave their questionable lifestyle, which based on their current studies, seems appropriate, and we will continue to offer them our support and encouragement.

original: There is one advantage greater than any of the foregoing, proposed by the abolishing of Christianity: that it will utterly extinguish parties among us, by removing those factious distinctions of High and Low Church, of Whig and Tory, Presbyterian and Church of England, which are now so many mutual clogs upon public proceedings, and are apt to prefer the gratifying themselves, or depressing their adversaries, before the most important interest of the state.
modernized: One significant advantage of eliminating Christianity is that it would eliminate division among us by removing the differences between High Church and Low Church, Whigs and Tories, Presbyterians and Church of England. These differences currently hinder progress on national matters, and are often prioritized over the state's best interests.

original: I allow that the thrown and raw silk is less pernicious, because we have some share in the manufacture: but we are not now in circumstances to trifle.
modernized: I acknowledge that raw and imported silk is less harmful to some extent, as we have some control over its production. However, under current circumstances, we cannot afford to be frivolous. It costs us approximately forty-th加

original: It costs us above forty thousand pounds a-year; and if the ladies, till better times, will not be content to go in their own country shifts, I wish they may go in rags.
modernized: If the ladies continue to refuse wearing domestic clothing until better times, I sincerely hope they will settle for wearing rags instead.

original: The Marquis de Torcy, secretary to the Most Christian King, was the minister with whom the Duke was to treat, as having been the first who moved his master to apply to the Queen for a peace, in opposition to a violent faction in that kingdom, who were as eagerly bent to continue the war, as any other could be either here or in Holland.
modernized: The Marquis de Torcy, serving as the secretary to the Most Christian King, was the principal minister with whom the Duke was to negotiate, as he had initially appealed to the Queen for peace against a powerful faction within his kingdom who were intent on prolonging the war, similar to those who would advocate for it here or in the Netherlands.

original: These were chocolate houses of the time, supported mainly by the aristocracy and the gamblers.
modernized: In the past, two social clubs known as chocolate houses were prevalent. They were primarily backed by the aristocracy and gamblers.

original: White's is still in existence, and has had the honour of having had a special history written about it.
modernized: White's still exists today and has been the subject of a written historical account.

original: Tom's was in Russell Street, and so-called after its landlord, Tom West.
modernized: Tom's was located on Russell Street and was named for its proprietor, Tom West.

original: The Kit-Cat Club was the resort of the Whig wits of the day, and the Hanover Club of those who favoured the Hanover succession.
modernized: The Kit-Cat Club was a gathering place for the Whig intellectuals of the time, while the Hanover Club consisted of those supporting the Hanover line of succession.

original: What a mixed multitude of ballad-writers, ode-makers, translators, farce-compounders, opera-mongers, biographers, pamphleteers, and journalists, would appear crowding to the hospital; not unlike the brutes resorting to the ark before the deluge!
modernized: A diverse assortment of songwriters, poet-writers, translators, comedy-writers, opera composers, biographers, essay-writers, and journalists would crowd toward the hospital, much like animals gathering near the ark before the flood.

original: And what an universal satisfaction would such a sight afford to all, except pastry-cooks, grocers, chandlers, and tobacco-retailers, to whom alone the writings of those incurables were anyway profitable!
modernized: Such a sight would bring an overwhelming sense of fulfillment to nearly everyone, with the exceptions being pastry-chefs, grocery store owners, hardware store proprietors, and tobacco sellers, as they were the only ones who profited from the works of these incurable writers.

original: But, as to monarchs; who must be supposed well to study and understand their own interest; they will best consider, whether those people, who in all their actions, preachings, and writings, have openly declared themselves against regal power, are to be safely placed in an equal degree of favour and trust with those who have been always found the true and only friends to the English establishment.
modernized: They should carefully assess whether people who publicly oppose monarchy should have the same level of support and trust as those who have consistently supported the English establishment, as this is in the best interest of the ruling monarchs.

original: From which consideration, I could have added one more article to my new test, if I had thought it worth my time.
modernized: I would have added another article to my new test if I found it important enough.

original: When dinner was done my master went out to his labors, and, as I could discover by his voice and gestures, gave his wife a strict charge to take care of me.
modernized: Shortly after dinner, hearing his voice and movements from outside, I inferred that my master had left for work and his wife had been given strict orders to look after me.

original: I was very much tired and disposed to sleep, which, my mistress perceiving, she put me on her own bed, and covered me with a clean white handkerchief, but larger and coarser than the mainsail of a man-of-war.
modernized: Feeling exhausted and ready for sleep, my mistress placed me on her bed, and she covered me with a bulky, rough white cloth, so great that it resembled the sails of a large ship.

original: I take it for granted, that you intend to pursue the beaten track, and are already desirous to be seen in a pulpit, only I hope you will think it proper to pass your quarantine among some of the desolate churches five miles round this town, where you may at least learn to read and to speak before you venture to expose your parts in a city congregation; not that these are better judges, but because, if a man must needs expose his folly, it is more safe and discreet to do so before few witnesses, and in a scattered neighbourhood.
modernized: You likely plan to follow the customary path, and already desire to preach in a pulpit. I hope you'll consider taking some time to practice in more remote churches located around this town, so you can at least learn to read and speak before stepping into a city congregation, as it's safer to make mistakes among fewer people and in a less conspicuous setting.

original: And you will do well if you can prevail upon some intimate and judicious friend to be your constant hearer, and allow him with the utmost freedom to give you notice of whatever he shall find amiss either in your voice or gesture; for want of which early warning, many clergymen continue defective, and sometimes ridiculous, to the end of their lives; neither is it rare to observe among excellent and learned divines, a certain ungracious manner, or an unhappy tone of voice, which they never have been able to shake off.
modernized: It would be beneficial if you could find a close and discerning friend to regularly listen to your sermons, allowing them to openly point out any issues in your voice or delivery. Too many clergymen continue with flaws, sometimes even becoming ridiculous, throughout their lives. It's worth noting that even among highly accomplished and learned religious leaders, an unpleasant demeanor or unmelodic tone can linger, and often goes unshaken.

original: The Duke of Shrewsbury executed this important commission with that speed and success, which could only be expected from an able minister.
modernized: The Duke of Shrewsbury promptly carried out his important task with the expected precision from a capable minister.

original: The French King immediately yielded to the whole scheme Her Majesty proposed; whereupon directions were sent to the lord privy seal, and the Earl of Strafford, to sign a peace between Great Britain and France, without delay.
modernized: Upon receiving the proposed plan, the French King quickly agreed, and directions were instantly sent to the Lord Privy Seal and the Earl of Strafford to sign a peace treaty between Great Britain and France without further delay.

original: This being the day the Parliament was to meet, and the great question to be determined, I went with Dr. Freind to dine in the City, on purpose to be out of the way, and we sent our printer to see what was our fate; but he gave us a most melancholy account of things.
modernized: Today, the Parliament meeting day, I dined in the city with Dr. Freind, to keep a low profile, but received disheartening news from our printer about the debate.

original: The Earl of Nottingham began, and spoke against a peace, and desired that in their address they might put in a clause to advise the Queen not to make a peace without Spain; which was debated, and carried by the Whigs by about six voices: and this has happened entirely by my Lord Treasurer's neglect, who did not take timely care to make up all his strength, although every one of us gave him caution enough.
modernized: Earl of Nottingham proposed against a peace and advocated for an advice clause for the Queen not to make a peace without Spain, which the Whigs passed by about six votes, caused by my Lord Treasurer's inattention.

original: Nottingham has certainly been bribed.
modernized: Nottingham has evidently been bribed.

original: The question is yet only carried in the Committee of the whole House, and we hope when it is reported to the House tomorrow, we shall have a majority, by some Scotch lords coming to town.
modernized: The majority depends on some Scottish Lords joining us when the issue will be reported to the whole House tomorrow.

original: However, it is a mighty blow and loss of reputation to Lord Treasurer, and may end in his ruin.
modernized: It is a significant blow to Lord Treasurer's reputation, which may potentially lead to his downfall.

original: I hear the thing only as the printer brought it, who was at the debate; but how the Ministry take it, or what their hopes and fears are, I cannot tell until I see them.
modernized: I only have the printer's account of the debate outcome, but the Ministry's attitude remains unclear until I speak to them.

original: I shall be early with the Secretary tomorrow, and then I will tell you more, and shall write a full account to the Bishop of Clogher tomorrow, and to the Archbishop of Dublin, if I have time.
modernized: I will meet the Secretary tomorrow and share further details, and write a detailed report to the Bishop of Clogher and Archbishop of Dublin if I find the time.

original: I am horribly down at present.
modernized: I feel quite down today.

original: I long to know how Lord Treasurer bears this, and what remedy he has.
modernized: I'm eager to learn how Lord Treasurer reacts to this and his plans to remedy the situation.

original: The Duke of Ormond came this day to town, and was there.
modernized: The Duke of Ormond arrived in town today.

original: I do therefore humbly offer it to publick consideration, that of the hundred and twenty thousand children, already computed, twenty thousand may be reserved for breed, whereof only one fourth part to be males; which is more than we allow to sheep, black cattle, or swine, and my reason is, that these children are seldom the fruits of marriage, a circumstance not much regarded by our savages, therefore, one male will be sufficient to serve four females.
modernized: I propose humbly that 20,000 of the 120,000 children calculated could be set aside for breeding. A fourth of these should be males, which is more than we often allow for livestock, considering that these children rarely result from marriage in our society. This is because, in our society, marriage isn't considered important by many. One male could serve four females, therefore.

original: That the remaining hundred thousand may, at a year old, be offered in sale to the persons of quality and fortune, through the kingdom, always advising the mother to let them suck plentifully in the last month, so as to render them plump, and fat for a good table.
modernized: After the remaining 100,000 children reach one year, they could be put up for sale to well-off individuals throughout the kingdom, with the mother encouraged to let the child nurse robustly in the last month to ensure they are well-fed. This would make them plump and suitable for consumption.

original: A child will make two dishes at an entertainment for friends, and when the family dines alone, the fore or hind quarter will make a reasonable dish, and seasoned with a little pepper or salt, will be very good boiled on the fourth day, especially in winter.
modernized: At a gathering, two children could provide four main dishes. For a family meal, the fore or hind leg would make a decent portion, and seasoned with salt and pepper, it would be very tasty when boiled for four days, especially in winter.

original: From what I have already deduced, it appears manifest, that the differences between those two sects, Presbyterian and Independent, did not then amount to half so much as what there is between a Whig and Tory at present among us.
modernized: The differences between Presbyterians and Independents in the past were smaller compared to the differences between Whigs and Tories at present.

original: The design of utterly extirpating monarchy and episcopacy, was equally the same in both; evidently the consequence of the very same principles, upon which the Presbyterians alone began, continued, and would have ended in the same events; if towards the conclusion, they had not been bearded by that new party, with whom they could not agree about dividing the spoil.
modernized: Both Presbyterians and Independents aimed to eliminate monarchy and episcopacy, with their goals being the inevitable result of the same principles. However, Independents couldn't agree with Presbyterians on dividing the power, but they did hold civil and military positions throughout the period of usurpation.

original: However, they held a good share of civil and military employments during the whole time of the usurpation; whose names, and actions, and preferments, are frequent in the accounts of those times.
modernized: Presbyterians, who were prudent, conformed to the system in appropriate times and managed to secure positions during usurpation, some of which they kept until the restoration.

original: For I make no doubt, that all the prudent Presbyterians complied in proper seasons, falling in with the stream; and thereby got that share in employments, which many of them held to the Restoration; and perhaps too many of them after.
modernized: Similarly, wise Tories made attempts for several years to regain their lost power by conforming to the new measures after the Queen's death and were successful in recovering according to their respective abilities.

original: In the same manner, we find our wisest Tories, in both kingdoms, upon the change of hands and measures at the Queen's death, have endeavoured for several years, by due compliances, to recover the time they had lost by a temporary obstinacy; wherein they have well succeeded, according to their degrees of merit.
modernized: If I were to name the wise Tories who achieved this in both kingdoms, I would, but I am afraid it may offend their modesty. Their names, actions, and achievements are frequently mentioned in accounts from that time.

original: Of whose names I could here make honourable mention, if I did not fear it might offend their modesty.
modernized: I could give honourable mentions to many wise Tories if modesty were not a concern.

original: Before he quitted Redriff, he left the custody of the following papers in my hands, with the liberty to dispose of them as I should think fit.
modernized: Before leaving Redriff, Mr. Gulliver entrusted these documents to me, allowing me to handle them as I saw fit.

original: I have carefully perused them three times.
modernized: I have taken the time to read these documents three times.

original: The style is very plain and simple; and the only fault I find is, that the author, after the manner of travellers, is a little too circumstantial.
modernized: The writing style is very plain and straightforward, but the author occasionally provides too many details, a common habit among travel writers.

original: There is an air of truth apparent through the whole; and indeed the author was so distinguished for his veracity, that it became a sort of proverb among his neighbours at Redriff, when any one affirmed a thing, to say, it was as true as if Mr. Gulliver had spoken it.
modernized: These documents exude a sense of truth throughout. In fact, the author's honesty was so well-regarded by those in Redriff that it became a well-known saying: 'If it's as true as if Mr. Gulliver had said it.'

original: The month of April will be observable for the death of many great persons.
modernized: April will be noticeable for the deaths of several influential people.
