original: On the 4th will die the Cardinal de Noailles, Archbishop of Paris: On the 11th the young Prince of Asturias, son to the Duke of Anjou: On the 14th a great peer of this realm will die at his country-house: On the 19th an old layman of great fame for learning: and on the 23rd an eminent goldsmith in Lombard-Street.
modernized: On April 4th, Cardinal de Noailles, Archbishop of Paris, will pass away, followed on April 11th by the young Prince of Asturias, son of the Duke of Anjou. On April 14th, a prominent peer in this country will die at their countryside home, and on April 19th, a highly learned layperson will die. On April 23rd, an prominent goldsmith in Lombard Street will also die.

original: I could mention others, both at home and abroad, if I did not consider it is of very little use or instruction to the reader, or to the world.
modernized: I could provide more names of such individuals, both here and abroad, but I believe it would provide little value or insight for the reader or the world.

original: I answer, thirdly, that freethinkers are the most virtuous persons in the world; for all freethinkers must certainly differ from the priests, and from nine hundred ninety-nine of a thousand of those among whom they live; and are therefore virtuous of course, because everybody hates them.
modernized: I assert that, in the third place, freethinkers are the most morally upstanding individuals. Since freethinkers stand apart from religious leaders and a vast majority of their peers, they are likely to be virtuous simply through this difference in perspective. Furthermore, they are commonly maligned, which further highlights the integrity of their character.

original: 4thly, Avoid, as much as possible, the conversation of those people, who are given to talk of public persons and affairs, especially of those whose opinions in such matters are different from yours.
modernized: Avoid conversations with people who frequently discuss public figures and their opinions, particularly those whose views differ from yours.

original: I never once knew any disputes of this kind managed with tolerable temper; but on both sides they only agree as much as possible to provoke the passions of each other, indeed with this disadvantage, that he who argueth on the side of power may speak securely the utmost his malice can invent; while the other lieth every moment at the mercy of an informer; and the law, in these cases, will give no allowance at all for passion, inadvertency, or the highest provocation.
modernized: In my experience, debates of this nature are rarely conducted with reasonable restraint. Instead, both parties provoke each other, often without provocation. Anyone arguing in favor of power can say whatever they want, while the other party is always at risk of being denounced by informants. The law does not provide any leniency in these situations for emotions, mistakes, or even extreme provocation.

original: In the nurseries of females of the meaner sort, the children are instructed in all kinds of works proper for their sex and their several degrees; those intended for apprentices are dismissed at seven years old, the rest are kept to eleven.
modernized: In the schools for lesser families' daughters, the children are taught tasks fitting their gender and social status. The ones bound for apprenticeship are dismissed at age 7, while the others remain until age 11.

original: I am very much at a loss how to proceed upon the subject intended in this paper, which a new incident has led me to engage in: The subject I mean, is that of soldiers and the army; but being a matter wholly out of my trade, I shall handle it in as cautious a manner as I am able.
modernized: I'm struggling to figure out how to approach the topic in this paper, as a recent event has prompted me to delve into it: The subject I'm referring to is soldiers and the army, but since it's not my expertise, I'll handle it as carefully as I can.

original: However we may dislike the causes; yet this effect of begetting an universal concord among us in all national debates, as well as in cities, corporations, and country neighbourhoods, may keep us at least alive, and in a condition to eat the little bread allowed us in peace and amity.
modernized: Despite our disagreements regarding the causes, the effect of fostering a nationwide unity within all debates can ensure our survival with minimal resources. This may enable us to peacefully sustain our lives as we await fresh reasons for disagreement, as was illustrated in a tavern where a quarrel subsided when no one could identify the dispute.

original: I have heard of a quarrel in a tavern, where all were at daggers-drawing, till one of the company cried out, desiring to know the subject of the quarrel; which, when none of them could tell, they put up their swords, sat down, and passed the rest of the evening in quiet.
modernized: In the past, we have experienced discord similar to a tavern brawl, but once questioned about the cause of the conflict, the parties settled down and spent the rest of the evening peacefully. I hope that we can do the same now, putting aside our differences until there is a valid reason to disagree; just as a group of goslings instinctively stick together in the presence of danger.

original: The former part hath been our case; I hope the latter will be so too; that we shall sit down amicably together, at least until we have something that may give us a title to fall out; since nature hath instructed even a brood of goslings to stick together while the kite is hovering over their heads.
modernized: In the past, we have been divided and contentious, but I hope we can now find unity and sit together amicably, at least until there is a new issue to argue about; since nature has taught even young goslings to remain together when danger approaches.

original: Thus we see the public is many times, as it were, at the mercy of the meanest instrument, who can be wicked enough to watch opportunities of doing it mischief, upon the principles of avarice or malice, which I am afraid are deeply rooted in too many breasts, and against which there can be no defence, but a firm resolution in all honest men, to be closely united and active in showing their love to their country, by preferring the public interest to their present private advantage.
modernized: The public is often at the mercy of even the smallest people with malicious intent, who find opportunities to cause harm for personal gain or ill-will. This seems to be widespread, and the only defense is a strong resolve by honest individuals to unite and act in the interest of their country, prioritizing the public good over their current private interests.

original: If a passenger, in a great storm at sea, should hide his goods, that they might not be thrown overboard to lighten the ship, what would be the consequence?
modernized: If a passenger, in a great storm at sea, were to conceal his possessions, not allowing them to be discarded to save the ship, what would be the outcome?

original: The ship is cast away, and he loses his life and goods together.
modernized: The ship would sink, and the passenger would lose both his life and possessions.

original: Among all the schemes offered to the public in this projecting age, I have observed with some displeasure, that there have never been any for the improvement of religion and morals; which beside the piety of the design from the consequence of such a reformation in a future life, would be the best natural means for advancing the public felicity of the state, as well as the present happiness of every individual.
modernized: In this age of excessive projecting, I've noticed with displeasure that no plans have been proposed to improve religion and morals. Such plans, apart from the spiritual rewards in the afterlife, would be the most natural means to enhance the nation's overall happiness and the well-being of all individuals.

original: For, as much as faith and morality are declined among us, I am altogether confident, they might in a short time, and with no very great trouble, be raised to as high a perfection as numbers are capable of receiving.
modernized: Given the declining state of faith and morality among us, I am fully confident that they could be brought back to nearly perfect levels with relatively little effort.

original: Indeed, the method is so easy and obvious, and some present opportunities so good, that, in order to have this project reduced to practice, there seems to want nothing more than to put those in mind, who by their honour, duty, and interest, are chiefly concerned.
modernized: The method to implement this plan is simple and obvious, and there are good opportunities currently available. All that seems to be missing is reminding those who have a personal stake in the issue, namely those bound by honor, duty, and personal interest, to take action.

original: I have hitherto confined myself to those endeavours for the good of the Church, which were common to all the leaders and principal men of our party; but if my paper were not drawing towards an end, I could produce several instances of particular persons, who by their exemplary lives and actions have confirmed the character so justly due to the whole body.
modernized: So far, I have only focused on the efforts for the betterment of the Church that were shared by all the high-ranking individuals in our faction. If I had more space, I could provide many instances of individual persons whose virtuous actions and lives have strengthened the Church's positive image. However, due to space constraints, I will only mention two such examples, and provide evidence to support their merits.

original: I shall at present mention only two, and illustrate the merits of each by a matter of fact.
modernized: Now, I will only discuss two of these individuals, highlighting the exceptional qualities of each using actual events as examples.

original: Morning. I am going this morning to see Prior, who dines with me at Mr. Harley's; so I can't stay fiddling and talking with dear little brats in a morning, and 'tis still terribly cold. -- I wish my cold hand was in the warmest place about you, young women, I'd give ten guineas upon that account with all my heart, faith; oh, it starves my thigh; so I'll rise and bid you good-morrow, my ladies both, good-morrow.
modernized: Good morning, I'm heading to see Prior who is dining with me at Mr. Harley's. I can't linger and chat with the children in the morning as it's cold. I wish my cold hand could be near you, young ladies, I'd gladly give ten guineas for that warmth. Alas, it makes my leg quite uncomfortable. I shall rise now and take my leave, good-day, my dear ladies, good-day.

original: Come, stand away, let me rise: Patrick, take away the candle.
modernized: Patrick, could you kindly move aside and let me stand up? Please extinguish the candle.

original: Is there a good fire? -- So -- up-a-dazy. -- At night.
modernized: Is the fire well-lit? It's getting late and this highburner seems suitable.良

original: Mr. Harley did not sit down till six, and I stayed till eleven; henceforth I will choose to visit him in the evenings, and dine with him no more if I can help it.
modernized: Mr. Harley didn't settle till 6 pm, and I stayed until 11 pm. From now on, I'll prefer to visit him in the evenings and refuse to dine with him if possible.

original: It breaks all my measures, and hurts my health; my head is disorderly, but not ill, and I hope it will mend.
modernized: My health is unsettled, and my head is not unwell, but I hope it will recover.

original: Princes usually make wiser choices than the servants whom they trust for the disposal of places: I have known a prince, more than once, choose an able Minister, but I never observed that Minister to use his credit in the disposal of an employment to a person whom he thought the fittest for it.
modernized: Princes tend to make more informed decisions about appointments than their advisors, as I have observed that a capable Minister rarely chooses the most qualified individual for a task.

original: One of the greatest in this age owned and excused the matter from the violence of parties and the unreasonableness of friends.
modernized: One of the great leaders of this era acknowledged and justified the issue due to the influence of political factions and unreasonable allies.

original: He, in the meantime, had wandered long in search of some enterprise, till at length he arrived at a small rivulet that issued from a fountain hard by, called, in the language of mortal men, Helicon.
modernized: He eventually found himself wandering for a long time in search of some adventure, until he eventually arrived at a small river that flowed out from a nearby fountain, which was called Helicon by mortal men.

original: Here he stopped, and, parched with thirst, resolved to allay it in this limpid stream.
modernized: He stopped and, being very thirsty, decided to quench his thirst in this clear stream.

original: Thrice with profane hands he essayed to raise the water to his lips, and thrice it slipped all through his fingers.
modernized: He tried three times with unclean hands to lift the water to his mouth, but it slipped through his fingers every time.

original: Then he stopped prone on his breast, but, ere his mouth had kissed the liquid crystal, Apollo came, and in the channel held his shield betwixt the Modern and the fountain, so that he drew up nothing but mud.
modernized: He then lay down on his chest, but before his mouth could touch the crystal-clear water, Apollo appeared, and held his shield between the man and the fountain, so that all he managed to draw up was mud.

original: For, although no fountain on earth can compare with the clearness of Helicon, yet there lies at bottom a thick sediment of slime and mud; for so Apollo begged of Jupiter, as a punishment to those who durst attempt to taste it with unhallowed lips, and for a lesson to all not to draw too deep or far from the spring.
modernized: Although no fountain on earth compares to the clarity of Helicon, there is a thick layer of muck and sludge at the bottom; this is why Apollo asked Jupiter to punish those who dared to drink from it with unholy lips, as a lesson to all not to reach too deep or too far from the spring.

original: Here I found, to my great surprise, that although they all entered upon occasion into particular descriptions of the true critic, according as they were governed by their fears or their hopes, yet whatever they touched of that kind was with abundance of caution, adventuring no further than mythology and hieroglyphic.
modernized: To my shock, I discovered that all the ancient writers briefly described the true critic but only did so with caution; they never provided explicit definitions, instead resorting to mythology and symbolism.

original: This, I suppose, gave ground to superficial readers for urging the silence of authors against the antiquity of the true critic, though the types are so apposite, and the applications so necessary and natural, that it is not easy to conceive how any reader of modern eye and taste could overlook them.
modernized: This has led shallow readers to argue that ancient authors have never spoken about the true critic, but their symbolic clues are so relevant and clear that it is hard to imagine any knowledgeable and discerning reader could overlook them.

original: I shall venture from a great number to produce a few which I am very confident will put this question beyond doubt.
modernized: I will confidently present a select few examples that will provide indisputable proof regarding the true critic.

original: I began my discourse by informing his majesty that our dominions consisted of two islands, which composed three mighty kingdoms, under one sovereign, besides our plantations in America.
modernized: I began my discussion by explaining to the king that our dominions consist of two islands that make up three powerful kingdoms, ruled by a single monarch, in addition to our colonies in America.

original: I dwelt long upon the fertility of our soil and the temperature of our climate.
modernized: I focused on the richness of our soil and the pleasantness of our climate.

original: I then spoke at large upon the constitution of an English parliament, partly made up of an illustrious body, called the House of Peers, persons of the noblest blood and of the most ancient and ample patrimonies.
modernized: I then went into detail about the composition of the English parliament, which includes a prestigious group called the House of Lords, composed of individuals with noble ancestry and substantial family estates.

original: I described that extraordinary care always taken of their education in arts and arms, to qualify them for being counsellors both to the king and kingdom; to have a share in the legislature; to be members of the highest court of judicature, from whence there could be no appeal; and to be champions always ready for the defence of their prince and country, by their valor, conduct, and fidelity.
modernized: I elaborated on the care taken to educate them in art, military, and other relevant skills to serve as advisors to both the king and the nation, participate in the legislation, preside over the highest courts of justice, and protect the kingdom by their bravery, excellent judgment, and loyalty.

original: That these were the ornament and bulwark of the kingdom, worthy followers of their most renowned ancestors, whose honor had been the reward of their virtue, from which their posterity were never once known to degenerate.
modernized: These are the ornaments and protectors of the kingdom, worthy emulators of their most illustrious ancestors, who were recognized for their virtues and valor.

original: To these were joined several holy persons, as part of that assembly, under the title of bishops, whose peculiar business it is to take care of religion, and those who instruct the people therein.
modernized: In addition to them, there were several religious figures as part of that assembly, known as bishops, tasked with ensuring the spiritual welfare of the people and guiding them on religious matters.

original: These were searched and sought out through the whole nation, by the prince and his wisest counsellors, among such of the priesthood as were most deservedly distinguished by the sanctity of their lives and the depth of their erudition, who were indeed the spiritual fathers of the clergy and the people.
modernized: These individuals were carefully chosen through the country by the king and his wisest advisors, based on their exemplary conduct, profound knowledge, and piety. They effectively served as spiritual guides for both the clergy and the people.

original: But my heart is too heavy to continue this journey longer, for it is manifest that whatever stranger took such a journey, would be apt to think himself travelling in Lapland or Ysland, rather than in a country so favoured by Nature as ours, both in fruitfulness of soil, and temperature of climate.
modernized: I find it too hard-hearted to continue this journey any longer, because anyone coming here from a foreign region would likely believe they're in a harsh place like Lapland or Iceland instead of a country as blessed by Nature as ours, considering both its fertile soil and moderate climate.

original: The miserable dress, and diet, and dwelling of the people.
modernized: The clothing, nutrition, and shelter of the people are miserable.

original: The general desolation in most parts of the Kingdom.
modernized: There's widespread destruction across most parts of the country.

original: The old seats of the nobility and gentry all in ruins, and no new ones in their stead.
modernized: The old homes of the nobility and gentry have all fallen into disrepair, and there are no new homes in their places.

original: The families of farmers who pay great rents, living in filth and nastiness upon butter-milk and potatoes, without a shoe or stocking to their feet, or a house so convenient as an English hog-sty to receive them.
modernized: Farmers' families are living in squalor, scraping by on butter-milk and potatoes, and lack even shoes or decent housing, such as an English hog-sty.

original: These indeed may be comfortable sights to an English spectator, who comes for a short time only to learn the language, and returns back to his own country, whither he finds all our wealth transmitted.
modernized: These dire conditions would likely seem comforting to an English visitor who's only here for a short time to learn the language and then returns to their own country, where they'll find all our wealth has been transferred.

original: The meaner families who have children at these nurseries, are obliged, besides their annual pension, which is as low as possible, to return to the steward of the nursery a small monthly share of their gettings, to be a portion for the child; and therefore all parents are limited in their expenses by the law.
modernized: Poorer families with children at the nurseries must give a portion of their income to the nursery each month, which limits their expenses, as it is required by law.

original: For the Lilliputians think nothing can be more unjust, than for people, in subservience to their own appetites, to bring children into the world, and leave the burthen of supporting them on the public.
modernized: The Lilliputians believe it's grossly unfair for people who cater to their own desires to have children without taking responsibility for their care and support.

original: As to persons of quality, they give security to appropriate a certain sum for each child, suitable to their condition; and these funds are always managed with good husbandry and the most exact justice.
modernized: For those of high social standing, they provide a set amount of funds for each child according to their status, and these funds are managed diligently and with the greatest accuracy.

original: Although reason were intended by Providence to govern our passions, yet it seems that, in two points of the greatest moment to the being and continuance of the world, God hath intended our passions to prevail over reason.
modernized: Reason is meant to govern our emotions, yet it seems absurd that in two critical aspects of our existence, our passions are purposely allowed to override reason by divine design.

original: The first is, the propagation of our species, since no wise man ever married from the dictates of reason.
modernized: The first of these instances is the reproduction of our species, as no sensible person ever makes the decision to marry based on reason alone.

original: The other is, the love of life, which, from the dictates of reason, every man would despise, and wish it at an end, or that it never had a beginning.
modernized: The second instance is our instinctive desire to live, which, according to reason, every person would prefer never to have begun or to end.

original: From the universities, the young nobility, and others of great fortunes, are sent for early up to town, for fear of contracting any airs of pedantry, by a college education.
modernized: The youth from universities, nobility, and others of privilege head off to the city early to avoid educational snobbery.

original: Many of the younger gentry retire to the Inns of Court, where they are wholly left to their own discretion.
modernized: Many younger aristocrats withdraw to the Inns of Court, where they are given complete autonomy.

original: And the consequence of this remissness in education appears, by observing that nine in ten of those, who rise in the church or the court, the law, or the army, are younger brothers, or new men, whose narrow fortunes have forced them upon industry and application.
modernized: The results of lax education reveal themselves in observing that a majority of individuals who rise in the church, court, law, or army are younger brothers or incoming individuals, driven by lack of resources to apply themselves industriously.

original: Since I writ these last lines, I have perused the whole pamphlet (which I had only dipped in before) and found I have been hunting upon a wrong scent; for the author hath in several parts of his piece, discovered the true motives which put him upon sending it abroad at this juncture; I shall therefore consider them as they come in my way.
modernized: Since reading these recent lines, I have thoroughly reviewed the entire pamphlet (which I had only briefly skimmed previously), and discovered that I was on the wrong track. The author has revealed his motivations for distributing the pamphlet at this specific time in various parts of his work. I will now delve deeper into those reasons as I encounter them.

original: It plainly appears, from what hath been said, that no one human creature is more worthy than another in the sight of God, further than according to the goodness or holiness of their lives; and that power, wealth, and the like outward advantages, are so far from being the marks of God's approving or preferring those on whom they are bestowed, that, on the contrary, He is pleased to suffer them to be almost engrossed by those who have least title to His favour.
modernized: Every person's worth before God is determined by their goodness or holiness, not their power, wealth, or other external advantages, as God often favors those who least deserve it. Apparently, power is not a sign of God's approval or preference.

original: Now, according to this equality wherein God hath placed all mankind with relation to Himself, you will observe that in all the relations between man and man there is a mutual dependence, whereby the one cannot subsist without the other.
modernized: Given how God has placed all humankind equally in His sight, it's clear that in every human relationship, there is a mutual dependence, making it impossible for one to exist without the other.

original: Thus no man can be a prince without subjects, nor a master without servants, nor a father without children.
modernized: Consequently, no one can be a ruler without followers, an employer without employees, or a parent without children.

original: And this both explains and confirms the doctrine of the text; for where there is a mutual dependence there must be a mutual duty, and consequently a mutual subjection.
modernized: This doctrine unveils the essence of the taught principle; where mutual dependence exists, mutual duty and thus subjection follows accordingly.

original: For instance, the subject must obey his prince, because God commands it, human laws require it, and the safety of the public makes it necessary; for the same reasons we must obey all that are in authority, and submit ourselves not only to the good and gentle, but also to the froward, whether they rule according to our liking or not.
modernized: To illustrate, subjects must obey their rulers because God commands it, the law requires it, and the safety of the community depends on it; for similar reasons, we must all obey those in authority, serving the good and kind, as well as the rude, whether they lead according to our liking or not.

original: On the other side, in those countries that pretend to freedom, princes are subject to those laws which their people have chosen; they are bound to protect their subjects in liberty, property, and religion, to receive their petitions and redress their grievances, so that the best prince is, in the opinion of wise men, only the greatest servant of the nation - not only a servant to the public in general, but in some sort to every man in it.
modernized: In countries claiming freedom, rulers are subject to the laws chosen by the people; they are obliged to protect their subjects' rights, properties, and beliefs, hearing their complaints and addressing their grievances, making an excellent leader, in the eyes of wise people, more a servant to the people than their master.

original: In the like manner a servant owes obedience, and diligence, and faithfulness to his master, from whom, at the same time, he hath a just demand for protection, and maintenance, and gentle treatment.
modernized: A servant must afford obedience, diligence, and fidelity to their master, while receiving protection, support, and kindness in return.

original: Nay, even the poor beggar hath a just demand of an alms from the rich man, who is guilty of fraud, injustice, and oppression if he does not afford relief according to his abilities.
modernized: Even the lowest beggar is entitled to receive help from the wealthy, who are guilty of dishonesty, injustice, and cruelty if they don't aid according to their capabilities.

original: This I speak with the utmost respect to the person and dignity of his Excellency the Lord Carteret, whose character hath been given me by a gentleman that hath known him from his first appearance in the world: That gentleman describes him as a young nobleman of great accomplishments, excellent learning, regular in his life, and of much spirit and vivacity.
modernized: I express this with the utmost respect towards Lord Carteret, whose character I was told about by a man who has known him since his beginnings in life. This man portrays him as a young nobleman possessing great abilities, extensive knowledge, leading a virtuous life, and full of spirit and energy.

original: He hath since, as I have heard, been employed abroad, was principal secretary of state, and is now about the 37th year of his age appointed Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.
modernized: Since then, I've been informed that he was employed outside the country, served as the principal secretary of state, and is currently about 37 years old and has been appointed Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.

original: From such a governor this kingdom may reasonably hope for as much prosperity as, under so many discouragements, it can be capable of receiving.
modernized: Given the caliber of governor we have, it is reasonable to expect this kingdom will experience as much prosperity as it can possibly achieve, despite numerous obstacles.

original: During these transactions at home, the Duke of Ormonde was in a very uneasy situation at the army, employed in practising those arts which perhaps are fitter for a subtle negotiator than a great commander.
modernized: During these domestic negotiations, the Duke of Ormonde faced a challenging situation commanding the army, as he focused on deft political strategies instead of military tactics. However, due to his loyalty, he continued to manage the troops, even though this was against his nature, for the sake of Queen's

original: But as he had always proved his obedience, where courage or conduct could be of use; so the duty he professed to his prince, made him submit to continue in a state of inactivity at the head of his troops, however contrary to his nature, if it were for Her Majesty's service.
modernized: As he had consistently shown obedience when courage or skills were crucial, the duty he felt towards his prince led him to endure an inactive role leading the troops, despite it going against his nature, for the Queen's service.

original: He had sent early notice to the ministers, that he could not depend upon the foreign forces in the Queen's pay, and he now found some attempts were already begun to seduce them.
modernized: The Duke had warned the ministers that he couldn't rely on foreign forces under the Queen's banner, and now he discovered that attempts were already being made to lure them away.

original: My first prediction is but a trifle, yet I will mention it, to show how ignorant those sottish pretenders to astrology are in their own concerns: It relates to Partridge the almanack-maker; I have consulted the stars of his nativity by my own rules, and find he will infallibly die upon the 29th of March next, about eleven at night, of a raging fever; therefore I advise him to consider of it, and settle his affairs in time.
modernized: I'll share one minor prediction to demonstrate the lack of knowledge among astrologers regarding their own lives: It pertains to Partridge, the almanac maker. I've analyzed his birth chart according to my own methods, and predict with certainty that he will die on the 29th of March at around 11:00 PM due to a severe fever. Given this forecast, I recommend Partridge to address his affairs promptly.

original: Stephen, upon his return to England, met with an account of new troubles from the north; for the King of Scots, under pretence of observing his oath of fealty to the Empress, infested the Borders, and frequently making cruel inroads, plundered and laid waste all before him.
modernized: Upon returning to England, Stephen learned of new troubles in the north. The King of Scots, under the guise of honoring his oath of loyalty to the Empress, raided the borders and regularly committed cruel attacks, leaving destruction in his wake.

original: Fourthly, The practice of this duty of being subject to one another would make us rest contented in the several stations of life wherein God hath thought fit to place us, because it would, in the best and easiest manner, bring us back, as it were, to that early state of the Gospel when Christians had all things in common.
modernized: Practicing submission to one another would help us accept the various roles God has given us, as it would, in the most natural and easiest way, bring us back to the early state of the Gospel where believers shared all their possessions.

original: For if the poor found the rich disposed to supply their want, if the ignorant found the wise ready to instruct and direct them, or if the weak might always find protection from the mighty, they could none of them, with the least pretence of justice, lament their own condition.
modernized: If the wealthy provided for the needs of the poor, the wise assisted the ignorant, and the weak received protection from the powerful, no one would have any reason to complain about their station in life.

original: Some persons of a desponding spirit are in great concern about that vast number of poor people, who are aged, diseased, or maimed; and I have been desired to employ my thoughts what course may be taken, to ease the nation of so grievous an incumbrance.
modernized: Some people with a depressed outlook are extremely worried about the large number of poor people who are old, ill, or disabled. They have asked me to consider what can be done to alleviate this heavy burden on the nation.

original: But I am not in the least pain upon that matter, because it is very well known, that they are every day dying, and rotting, by cold and famine, and filth, and vermin, as fast as can be reasonably expected.
modernized: However, I personally am not worried about this issue because it is well-known that they are dying every day from cold, famine, filth, and vermin at a rate that is fast yet reasonable.

original: And as to the young labourers, they are now in almost as hopeful a condition.
modernized: As for the young laborers, they are currently in an almost as likely optimistic condition.

original: They cannot get work, and consequently pine away from want of nourishment, to a degree, that if at any time they are accidentally hired to common labour, they have not strength to perform it, and thus the country and themselves are happily delivered from the evils to come.
modernized: They cannot find jobs and as a result starve from a lack of sustenance to a point where they do not have the strength to perform any work if they are ever hired. Consequently, the country and themselves are fortunate to be freed from the misfortunes to come.

original: The Quakers were more likely to admit this relaxation of their peculiar tenets, as, upon their first appearance as a sect, they did not by any means profess the principle of non-resistance, which they afterwards adopted.
modernized: The Quakers initially didn't advocate for non-resistance, a principle they later adopted. This suggests they might be more open to loosening their unique beliefs.

original: If your Master calls you by Name, and you happen to answer at the fourth Call, you need not hurry yourself, and if you be chidden for staying, you may lawfully say, you came no sooner, because you did not know what you were called for.
modernized: A servant, if called by name by their master and they take time to respond at the fourth call, should not rush and may explain that they didn't know what they were being summoned for. If reprimanded for late response, the servant can legitimately state that they came as soon as they could, because they were uncertain of the purpose of the call.

original: The learned Æolists maintain the original cause of all things to be wind, from which principle this whole universe was at first produced, and into which it must at last be resolved, that the same breath which had kindled and blew up the flame of Nature should one day blow it out.
modernized: The learned scholars argue that the origin of all things stems from wind, the fundamental force that gave rise to this universe and to which it shall eventually return. The same breath that ignited the fire of nature will one day extinguish it. --

original: If Mr. Partridge had followed this example in the controversy between us, he might have spared me the trouble of justifying myself in so publick a manner.
modernized: If Mr. Partridge had acted under the same principles in our disagreement, he could have saved me from having to publicly justify myself.

original: I believe few men are readier to own their errors than I, or more thankful to those who will please to inform me of them.
modernized: I believe very few people are as willing to admit their mistakes as I am, or as grateful to those who point out such mistakes.

original: But it seems this gentleman, instead of encouraging the progress of his own art, is pleased to look upon all attempts of that kind as an invasion of his province.
modernized: It appears this gentleman doesn't appreciate the advancements in his field, but instead views other attempts as an infringement upon his own territory.

original: He has been indeed so wise to make no objection against the truth of my predictions, except in one single point, relating to himself: And to demonstrate how much men are blinded by their own partiality, I do solemnly assure the reader, that he is the only person from whom I ever heard that objection offered; which consideration alone, I think, will take off all its weight.
modernized: He is the only person who has raised objections to the truthfulness of my predictions regarding him. By focusing on just him, I think it takes away from the full weight of the objection because he is the only one who has brought it up.

original: If an humble Companion, a Chaplain, a Tutor, or a dependent Cousin happen to be at Table, whom you find to be little regarded by the Master, and the Company which nobody is readier to discover and observe than we Servants, it must be the Business of you and the Footman, to follow the Example of your Betters, by treating him many degrees worse than any of the rest, and you cannot please your Master better, or at least your Lady.
modernized: If a less important guest, such as a chaplain, tutor, or dependent cousin is present at the table and appears to be unimportant to the master and the entire company, it falls on you and the footman to treat this guest significantly worse than the others, as this will please the master or at least the lady.

original: The master horse ordered a sorrel nag, one of his servants, to untie the largest of these animals, and take him into the yard.
modernized: The master horse ordered one of his servants to release the largest Yahoo-like creature and lead it into the courtyard.

original: The beast and I were brought close together, and by our countenances diligently compared both by master and servant, who thereupon repeated several times the word Yahoo.
modernized: The creature and I were scrutinized carefully by both the master and the servant, who repeatedly said the word 'Yahoo'.

original: My horror and astonishment are not to be described, when I observed in this abominable animal, a perfect human figure: the face of it indeed was flat and broad, the nose depressed, the lips large, and the mouth wide; but these differences are common to all savage nations, where the lineaments of the countenance are distorted, by the natives suffering their infants to lie grovelling on the earth, or by carrying them on their backs, nuzzling with their face against the mothers' shoulders.
modernized: I was utterly horrified and astounded as I observed a clear human form in this repugnant creature. The shape of its face was broad and flat, the nose flattened, the lips large, and the mouth wide; such features are common in less developed societies due to the practice of babies lying on the ground and being carried on the backs of mothers.

original: The forefeet of the Yahoo differed from my hands in nothing else but the length of the nails, the coarseness and brownness of the palms, and the hairiness on the backs.
modernized: The Yahoo's front feet resembled human hands, except for their length of nails, the coarseness of the palms, and hairiness on the backs.

original: There was the same resemblance between our feet, with the same differences; which I knew very well, though the horses did not, because of my shoes and stockings; the same in every part of our bodies except as to hairiness and colour, which I have already described.
modernized: Our feet shared a great resemblance, with the same differences; I was familiar with these differences, since I wore shoes and stockings, but the horses were not.

original: I could have wished, as I am a private man, that, in the instrument of my freedom, you had pleased to assign your reasons for making choice of me.
modernized: As a private individual, I would have preferred if you had explained your reasons for granting me the instrument of my freedom.

original: I know it is a usual compliment to bestow the freedom of the city on an archbishop, or lord-chancellor, and other persons of great titles, merely on account of their stations or power: but a private man, and a perfect stranger, without power or grandeur, may justly expect to find the motives assigned in the instrument of his freedom, on what account he is thus distinguished.
modernized: It's typical to bestow the freedom of a city upon high-ranking individuals because of their titles or influence. However, a private individual with no power or status might reasonably expect to learn the motives for such an honor stated in the instrument of freedom. But I couldn't find any reasons mentioned on the parchment.

original: And yet I cannot discover, in the whole parchment scrip, any one reason offered.
modernized: Moreover, I am puzzled as to why no reason was given for the freedom gifted.

original: Next, as to the silver box, there is not so much as my name upon it, nor any one syllable to show it was a present from your city.
modernized: Surprisingly, the silver box does not have any markings indicating it's a gift from the city.

original: Therefore I have, by the advice of friends, agreeable with my opinion, sent back the box and instrument of freedom by Mr. Faulkner, to be returned to you; leaving to your choice whether to insert the reasons for which you were pleased to give me my freedom, or bestow the box upon some more worthy person whom you may have an intention to honour, because it will equally fit everybody.
modernized: With advice from friends, in agreement with my beliefs, I have returned the box and the instrument of freedom to you. I leave it to you to decide whether to specify the reasons for granting me my freedom or to give the box to someone more deserving, as it suits everyone equally.

original: In the paper above mentioned, which I left with my friend, I have also set down the names of several gentlemen who have been robbed in Dublin streets for three years past: I have told the circumstances of those robberies; and shewn plainly that nothing but the want of common courage was the cause of their misfortunes.
modernized: In the paper I left with my friend, I have also included the names of several noblemen who experienced robberies in the streets of Dublin for the past three years. I've detailed the circumstances of these robberies and emphasized that the lack of common courage was the primary cause of their misfortunes.

original: I have therefore desired my friend, that whenever any gentlemen happens to be robbed in the streets, he will get that relation printed and published with the first letters of those gentlemen's names, who by their own want of bravery are likely to be the cause of all the mischief of that kind, which may happen for the future.
modernized: I have instructed my friend to print and distribute the release detailing these incidents whenever a gentleman is robbed in the streets. This will be done with the initial letters of the cowardly gentlemen involved marked, indicating that their timidity may cause future incidents of this nature.

original: The Marquis de Torcy had likewise the same sentiments, of what mighty consequence those few British battalions were to the confederate army; since he advised his master to deliver up Dunkirk, although the Queen could not perform the condition understood, which was a cessation of arms of all the foreign forces in her pay.
modernized: The Marquis de Torcy shared the same opinion regarding the importance of the British forces to the confederate army. He suggested to his master that they should surrender Dunkirk, but only if the Queen could cease all hostilities from foreign forces she employed.

original: Let me put another case.
modernized: Let me present a hypothetical case.

original: Suppose a gentleman's estate of two hundred pounds a year should sink to one hundred, by some accident, whether by an earthquake, or inundation, it matters not: and suppose the said gentleman utterly hopeless and unqualified ever to retrieve the loss; how is he otherwise to proceed in his future economy, than by reducing it on every article to one half less, unless he will be content to fly his country, or rot in jail?
modernized: Imagine a gentleman's annual income reduces to half due to unforeseen circumstances such as natural disasters, and he's unable to return it to its original state. Under those circumstances, what options does the gentleman have apart from leaving the country or living in poverty?

original: This is a representation of Ireland's condition; only with one fault, that it is a little too favourable.
modernized: Ireland's situation is exhibited here, but with one exception: the depiction is overly favorable.

original: Neither am I able to propose a full remedy for this, that shall ever be granted, but only a small prolongation of life, until God shall miraculously dispose the hearts of our neighbours, our kinsmen, our fellow-protestants, fellow-subjects, and fellow rational creatures, to permit us to starve without running further in debt.
modernized: I cannot offer a definitive solution to this issue, but only a temporary respite, hoping for a miracle that will change the minds of our neighbors, kin, fellow Protestants, fellow subjects, and fellow rational beings, allowing us to survive without incurring further debt.

original: I am informed that our national debt (and God knows how we wretches came by that fashionable thing a national debt) is about two hundred and fifty thousand pounds; which is at least one-third of the whole kingdom's rents, after our absentees and other foreign drains are paid, and about fifty thousand pounds more than all the cash.
modernized: Our national debt stand at approximately 250,000 pounds (the amount we somehow acquired), which amounts to at least a third of the entire kingdom's rental income, excluding revenue drained overseas, and is around 50,000 pounds more than the total cash available.

original: I remember about thirty Years ago, there was a Bohemian Woman, of that Species commonly known by the name of Gypsies, who came over hither from France, and generally attended Isaac the Dancing-Master when he was teaching his Art to Misses of Quality; and while the young Ladies were thus employed, the Bohemian, standing at some distance, but full in their Sight, acted before them all proper Airs, and turnings of the Head, and motions of the Hands, and twistings of the Body; whereof you may still observe the good Effects in several of our elder Ladies.
modernized: Thirty years ago, there was a Gypsy woman who often accompanied a dance instructor in teaching young noble ladies. While the women were learning, the Gypsy, standing off to the side but within their view, demonstrated proper gestures, postures, and movements, which some of our older ladies still exhibit today.

original: Neither had the primitive fathers any great or good opinion of the heathen philosophy, as is manifest from several passages in their writings; so that this vein of affecting to raise the reputation of those sages so high Is a mode and a vice but of yesterday, assumed chiefly, as I have said, to disparage revealed knowledge and the consequences of it among us.
modernized: The early Christian scholars did not hold the heathen philosophy in high esteem, as made clear through various passages in their writings. This tendency to exaggerate the wisdom of ancient philosophers appears to be a recent phenomenon, mainly used to discredit divine knowledge and its impact within our society.

original: I have already told the reader that there were two strong staples fixed upon that side of my box which had no window, and into which the servant, who used to carry me on horseback, would put a leathern belt, and buckle it about his waist.
modernized: I've already informed the reader that two strong staples were attached to the side of my box with no windows. A leather belt would be fastened there by the servant who carried me on a horse, secured around his waist.

original: Being in this disconsolate state, I heard, or at least thought I heard, some kind of grating noise on that side of my box where the staples were fixed; and soon after I began to fancy that the box was pulled or towed along the sea; for I now and then felt a sort of tugging, which made the waves rise near the tops of my windows, leaving me almost in the dark.
modernized: In my desolate state, I thought I heard a grating noise coming from the side of the box with the staples. It seemed to me that the box was being dragged or towed across the sea. Every so often, I felt a tugging, which made the waves crash near the top of my windows and left me in semi-darkness.

original: This gave me some faint hopes of relief, although I was not able to imagine how it could be brought about.
modernized: This gave me some glimmers of hope, but I wasn't sure how it could happen.

original: I ventured to unscrew one of my chairs, which were always fastened to the floor; and having made a hard shift to screw it down again, directly under the slipping-board that I had lately opened, I mounted on the chair, and putting my mouth as near as I could to the hole, I called for help in a loud voice, and in all the languages I understood.
modernized: I risked unscrewing one of the chairs attached to the floor, moved it into position beneath the opening I made in the cover, then stood on the chair and shouted for help in all the languages I knew.

original: I then fastened my handkerchief to a stick I usually carried, and thrusting it up the hole, waved it several times in the air, that if any boat or ship were near, the seamen might conjecture some unhappy mortal to be shut up in the box.
modernized: I secured my handkerchief to a stick I carried and threw it up the hole, waving it back and forth to signal for help from any boats or ships nearby.

original: By the like methods, a stop might be put to that ruinous practice of deep gaming; and the reason why it prevails so much is, because a treatment, directly opposite in every point, is made use of to promote it; by which means, the laws enacted against this abuse are wholly eluded.
modernized: A stop could be made to the destructive habit of excessive gambling, as it is encouraged instead of being discouraged through opposite methods. This enables the laws made to combat this issue to be completely avoided.

original: There is no way of judging how far we may depend upon the actions of men, otherwise than by knowing the motives, and grounds, and causes of them; and, if the motives of our actions be not resolved and determined into the law of God, they will be precarious and uncertain, and liable to perpetual changes.
modernized: To judge the reliability of people's actions, we need to understand their motivations, reasons, and causes. If these motivations are not grounded in the law of God, the actions will be unstable and subject to constant change.

original: I will shew you what I mean, by an example: Suppose a man thinks it his duty to obey his parents, because reason tells him so, because he is obliged by gratitude, and because the laws of his country command him to do so; but, if he stops here, his parents can have no lasting security; for an occasion may happen, wherein it may be extremely his interest to be disobedient, and where the laws of the land can lay no hold upon him: therefore, before such a man can safely be trusted, he must proceed farther, and consider, that his reason is the gift of God; that God commanded him to be obedient to the laws, and did moreover in a particular manner enjoin him to be dutiful to his parents; after which, if he lays due weight upon those considerations, he will probably continue in his duty to the end of his life: Because no earthly interest can ever come in competition to balance the danger of offending his Creator, or the happiness of pleasing him.
modernized: Let me show you by example: If a man believes it is his duty to obey his parents due to reason, gratitude, or country's laws but stops there, they will have no lasting security because an opportunity may arise where it's in his interest to disobey and the laws of the land cannot stop him. To trust such a man, he should consider that his reason is a gift from God; that God commanded him to obey the laws and also specifically directed him to be dutiful to his parents. If he gives these matters proper weight, he will likely continue his duty for the rest of his life, because no earthly interest will ever outweigh the risk of offending his Creator or the happiness of pleasing him.

original: And of all this his conscience will certainly inform him, if he hath any regard to religion.
modernized: And if he holds any regard for religion, his conscience will tell him these matters without a doubt.

original: From this summary of Whig-principles and dispositions, we find what a prince may reasonably fear and hope from that party.
modernized: We can summarize the principles and attitudes of the Whig party that a prince might expect based on their ideologies.

original: Let us now very briefly consider, the doctrines of the Tories, which their adversaries will not dispute.
modernized: Now, let's quickly examine the beliefs of the Tory party, which their opponents won't contest.

original: As they prefer a well-regulated monarchy before all other forms of government; so they think it next to impossible to alter that institution here, without involving our whole island in blood and desolation.
modernized: They favor a properly regulated monarchy over any other type of government and think it almost impossible to change our monarchy without causing widespread bloodshed and destruction.

original: They believe, that the prerogative of a sovereign ought, at least, to be held as sacred and inviolable as the rights of his people, if only for this reason, because without a due share of power, he will not be able to protect them.
modernized: They believe that a ruler's authority should be considered as sacred and inviolable as that of the people, for the reason that without a fair share of power, the ruler won't be able to safeguard them.

original: They think, that by many known laws of this realm, both statute and common, neither the person, nor lawful authority of the prince, ought, upon any pretence whatsoever, to be resisted or disobeyed.
modernized: In their view, according to well-established laws in this realm, neither the person nor the legitimate power of the ruler should be disobeyed or resisted under any circumstances.

original: Their sentiments, in relation to the Church, are known enough, and will not be controverted, being just the reverse to what I have delivered as the doctrine and practice of the Whigs upon that article.
modernized: Regarding the Church, their views are widely known and won't be disputed, as they're the opposite of what I've stated as the thoughts and practices of the Whigs on that topic.

original: But the King of France was in great discontent at this match: he easily foresaw the dismal consequences to himself and his successors from such an increase of dominion united to the crown of England: he knew what impressions might be made in future times to the shaking of his throne by an aspiring and warlike king, if they should happen in a weak reign, or upon any great discontents in that kingdom.
modernized: The King of France was upset about this marriage. He anticipated dire consequences for himself and his heirs if England and France's unified dominion grew too powerful. A potential threat could arise from a dominant and warlike king, especially during a weak reign or a time of significant internal conflict in France.

original: Which conjectures being highly reasonable (and since often verified by events) he cast about to find some way of driving the King of England entirely out of France; but having neither pretext nor stomach in the midst of a peace to begin an open and formal quarrel, there fell out an accident which gave him plausible occasion of pursuing his design.
modernized: Since this scenario was highly likely (and later proven true), the King of France sought means to eliminate England from France without starting an open war during peace. Lacking a legitimate pretext and unwilling to openly challenge England, he found an accidental opportunity to further his goal of expelling the English.

original: Give me leave to compute, wholly at random, what charge the kingdom will be at, by the loss of intrinsic value in the coinage of 10,000l. in copper, under the management of such a society of gentlemen.
modernized: I'd like to estimate, at random, what cost the kingdom will incur due to the devaluation of intrinsic worth in minting 10,000 pounds in copper, under the supervision of such a group of gentlemen.

original: Many dignities in this kingdom are the poorest kind of benefices; and it should seem hard to put poor dignitaries under the necessity either of making greater contributions than they can afford, or of exposing themselves to the censure of wanting charity, by making their contributions public.
modernized: Many dignitaries in this kingdom have the poorest income from their positions; it appears unfair to require them to contribute more money than they can afford or face criticism for not being charitable, especially when their contributions are made public.

original: By what I have gathered out of ancient records, I find the compass of their doctrine took in two-and-thirty points, wherein it would be tedious to be very particular.
modernized: Based on my research, their teachings encompassed 23 points, and I won't go into great detail about each point. However, it's important to highlight their most significant principles.

original: However, a few of their most important precepts deducible from it are by no means to be omitted; among which, the following maxim was of much weight: That since wind had the master share as well as operation in every compound, by consequence those beings must be of chief excellence wherein that primordium appears most prominently to abound, and therefore man is in highest perfection of all created things, as having, by the great bounty of philosophers, been endued with three distinct animas or winds, to which the sage AEolists, with much liberality, have added a fourth, of equal necessity as well as ornament with the other three, by this quartum principium taking in the four corners of the world.
modernized: One influential principle was that since wind played a major role in all compounds, entities that exhibit wind most prominently are of the highest rank. In this way, humans, who are said to have three distinct 'winds' and a fourth, according to these philosophers, have the highest status among all creations, as they fill the four corners of the world.

original: Which gave occasion to that renowned cabalist Bombastus of placing the body of man in due position to the four cardinal points.
modernized: This belief led the famed scholar Bombastus to suggest that man's physical body should align with the four cardinal points.

original: For instance: How many lawyers, attorneys, solicitors, under-sheriffs, intriguing chambermaids, and counter-officers, are continually guilty of extortion, bribery, oppression, and many other profitable knaveries, to drain the purses of those with whom they are any way concerned!
modernized: For example: What number of lawyers, legal representatives, solicitors, deputy sheriffs, manipulative chambermaids, and junior officers often commit extortion, bribery, oppression, and various other financial scams to empty the wallets of those they interact with, while they are still involved with them.

original: And yet, all these different expedients to raise a fortune, pass generally under the milder names of fees, perquisites, vails, presents, gratuities, and such like; although, in strictness of speech, they should be called robbery, and consequently be rewarded with a gibbet.
modernized: These various ways of amassing wealth and fortune, however, are commonly referred to by milder terms such as fees, perquisites, kickbacks, gifts, and gratuities; nonetheless, they should more accurately be named robbery, in which case they would deserve the death sentence.

original: The landlords and farmers by this scheme can find no profit, but will certainly be losers; for instance, if the large northern livings be split into a dozen parishes, or more, it will be very necessary for the little threadbare gownman, with his wife, his proctor and every child who can crawl, to watch the fields at harvest time, for fear of losing a single sheaf, which he could not afford under peril of a day's starving; for according to the Scotch proverb, a hungry louse bites sore.
modernized: This proposed scheme will cause landlords and farmers to suffer financially, as if large northern living establishments are split into many smaller ones, the clergymen will be forced to closely monitor their fields to prevent small losses during harvest time, and according to a Scottish proverb, a hungry louse bites painfully.

original: This would of necessity, breed an infinite number of brangles and litigious suits in the spiritual courts, and put the wretched pastor at perpetual variance with his whole parish.
modernized: Such constant monitoring and protection will inevitably lead to numerous disputes and legal battles in the church courts, placing the clergy in permanent conflict with their entire parishes.

original: But, as they have hitherto stood, a clergyman established in a competent living is not under the necessity of being so sharp, vigilant, and exacting.
modernized: Currently, a clergyman securely established in a suitable living does not need to be as acutely vigilant and meticulous.

original: On the contrary, it is well known and allowed, that the Clergy round the kingdom think themselves well treated, if they lose only one single third of their legal demands.
modernized: The clergy across the kingdom are content with the current treatment they receive, acknowledging they can tolerate even losing a third of their legal claims.

original: My Lord; I freely own it a wild imagination that any words will cure the sottishness of men, or the vanity of women, but the Kingdom is in a fair way of producing the most effectual remedy, when there will not be money left for the common course of buying and selling the very necessaries of life in our markets, unless we absolutely change the whole method of our proceedings.
modernized: My Lord, I admit it's a radical idea, but words alone won't solve the problem of male foolishness or female vanity. However, the kingdom may be on its way to finding a truly effective solution when people won't have money left to buy essential goods in our markets unless we drastically change our current methods.

original: I observed there was the flesh of several animals, but could not distinguish them by the taste.
modernized: I observed some meat from various animals, but I couldn't tell what kind it was based on the taste.

original: There were shoulders, legs, and loins, shaped like those of mutton, and very well dressed, but smaller than the wings of a lark.
modernized: There were parts like shoulder, leg, and loin, similar to mutton, and well-prepared, but smaller than a lark's wing.

original: I ate them by two or three at a mouthful, and took three loaves at a time, about the bigness of musket bullets.
modernized: I consumed a few pieces at a bite and three loaves at a time, about the size of a musket bullet.

original: They supplied me as they could, showing a thousand marks of wonder and astonishment at my bulk and appetite.
modernized: The inhabitants provided as much as they could, showing great amazement and surprise at my size and appetite.

original: I then made another sign that I wanted drink.
modernized: I then made another sign that I needed water to drink.

original: I slept about two hours, and dreamt I was at home with my wife and children, which aggravated my sorrows when I awaked, and found myself alone in a vast room, between two and three hundred feet wide, and above two hundred high, lying in a bed twenty yards wide.
modernized: I slept for about two hours and had a dream where I was at home with my family, but waking up found myself alone in a massive room with a large bed.

original: My mistress was gone about her household affairs, and had locked me in.
modernized: My mistress left to attend to household chores and locked me inside the room.

original: The bed was eight yards from the floor.
modernized: The bed was far from the floor, approximately eight yards.

original: Some natural necessities required me to get down; I durst not presume to call; and if I had, it would have been in vain, with such a voice as mine, at so great a distance from the room where I lay to the kitchen where the family kept.
modernized: I had to relieve myself, but was too afraid to call, unable to reach them even if I did because my weak voice wouldn't carry that far.

original: While I was under these circumstances, two rats crept up the curtains, and ran smelling backwards and forwards on the bed.
modernized: While I was in this predicament, two rats climbed up the curtains and scurried around on the bed.

original: One of them came up almost to my face, whereupon I rose in a fright, and drew out my hanger to defend myself.
modernized: One of the rats came near my face, scaring me, so I got up and grabbed my sword to defend myself.

original: These horrible animals had the boldness to attack me on both sides, and one of them held his forefeet at my collar; but I had the good fortune to rip up his belly before he could do me any mischief.
modernized: The rats dared to attack me on both sides, and one of them held onto my collar, but I managed to slice open its belly before it could harm me.

original: He fell down at my feet; and the other, seeing the fate of his comrade, made his escape, but not without one good wound on the back, which I gave him as he fled, and made the blood run trickling from him.
modernized: The injured rat fell at my feet, and the other, seeing its companion's fate, ran away with a wound on its back.

original: After this exploit, I walked gently to and fro on the bed, to recover my breath and loss of spirits.
modernized: After dealing with the rats, I walked along the bed to catch my breath and calm myself.

original: These creatures were of the size of a large mastiff, but infinitely more nimble and fierce; so that if I had taken off my belt before I went to sleep, I must have infallibly been torn to pieces and devoured.
modernized: The rats were as big as large dogs but were shockingly agile and fierce. If I hadn't kept my belt when I went to sleep, I would have been ripped apart and killed.

original: I measured the tail of the dead rat, and found it to be two yards long, wanting an inch; but it went against my stomach to drag the carcass off the bed, where it lay still bleeding; I observed it had yet some life, but with a strong slash across the neck, I thoroughly despatched it.
modernized: I measured the tail of the dead rat, and it was about two yards long, missing just an inch. Leaving the carcass on the bed made me uncomfortable, but I killed it for good by making a deep cut across its neck.

original: There is nothing wherein the Skill of a Butler more appears, than in the Management of Candles, whereof, although some Part may fall to the Share of the other Servants, yet you being the principal Person concerned, I shall direct my Instructions upon this Article to you only, leaving to your Fellow-servants to apply them upon Occasion.
modernized: The skill of a butler is particularly demonstrated through candle management, a task primarily entrusted to the head servant. Therefore, I will focus my instructions on candle management specifically, allowing other servants to apply these tips as needed.

original: I will employ this present paper upon a subject, which of late hath very much affected me, which I have considered with a good deal of application, and made several enquiries about, among those persons who I thought were best able to inform me; and if I deliver my sentiments with some freedom, I hope it will be forgiven, while I accompany it with that tenderness which so nice a point requires.
modernized: In this essay, I plan to explore a topic that has recently become significant to me, which I have given considerable thought and sought opinions from knowledgeable individuals. I ask for understanding if I express candidly my opinions, as I will balance them with compassion, which such delicate matters require.

original: Endowed with all these accomplishments, we leave him in the full career of success, mounting fast toward the top of the Ladder Ecclesiastical, which he hath a fair probability to reach; without the merit of one single virtue, moderately stocked with the least valuable parts of erudition, utterly devoid of all taste, judgment, or genius; and, in his grandeur, naturally choosing to haul up others after him, whose accomplishments most resemble his own, except his beloved sons, nephews, or other kindred, be in competition; or, lastly, except his inclinations be diverted by those who have power to mortify, or further advance him.
modernized: He possesses these impressive achievements and continues to climb the Church hierarchy quickly, without doing even one good deed, merely having some minimal academic knowledge, lacking taste, wisdom, or creativity. He tries to pull others up after him, unless his favored relatives are competing or his intentions are influenced by those who can help him advance.}

original: About this time died Archbishop Lanfranc; by whose death the King, loosed from that awe and constraint he was under, soon began to discover those irregularities of his nature, which till then he had suppressed and disguised, falling into those acts of oppression and extortion that have made his name and memory infamous.
modernized: Around this period, Archbishop Lanfranc passed away, which allowed the King to reveal his unscrupulous behaviors that had previously been hidden. He indulged in repressive and corrupt practices, actions that have left a negative impact on his legacy.

original: He kept the see of Canterbury four years vacant, and converted the revenues to his own use, together with those of several other bishoprics and abbeys, and disposed all church preferments to the highest bidder.
modernized: The King left the see of Canterbury empty for four years, appropriating the earnings for his personal gain, along with those of multiple other bishoprics and abbeys. He sold every church appointment to the highest bidder.

original: Nor were his exactions less upon the laity, from whom he continually extorted exorbitant fines for pretended transgression of certain penal laws, and entertained informers to observe men's actions and bring him intelligence.
modernized: Furthermore, he imposed excessive fines on the laity, accusing them of infractions to certain laws, all while employing informants to gather information about their activities.

original: This prince, whose dominions confined on France and Normandy, was usually courted for an ally by both Kings in their several quarrels; but having little faith or honour, he never scrupled to change sides as often as he saw or conceived it for his advantage.
modernized: This prince with territories bordering France and Normandy was often courted as an ally during conflicts by both Kings, but his lack of loyalty and dishonor led him to switch sides whenever it served his interest.

original: After the great victory over the French, he closed in with King Henry, and gave his daughter to the young prince William; yet at the same time, by the private encouragement of Louis, he prevailed on the King of England to be easy in the conditions of a peace.
modernized: Following the significant victory over the French, he aligned himself with King Henry and gave his daughter to the young Prince William. Meanwhile, with Louis' private support, he pressureed King Henry to be lenient with the peace terms.

original: Upon the unfortunate loss of the prince, and the troubles in Normandy thereupon, he fell again from the King, gave his other daughter to William the son of Robert, and struck up with France to take that prince again into protection.
modernized: Unfortunately, the loss of the Prince and troubles in Normandy caused him to abandon King Henry again. He then gave his other daughter to William, son of Robert, and formed an alliance with France to protect the same prince once more.

original: But dying soon after, and leaving his son Geoffrey to succeed in that earldom, the King was of opinion he could not anywhere bestow his daughter with more advantage, both for the security and enlargement of his dominions, than by giving her to this earl; by which marriage Anjou would become an acquisition to Normandy, and this be a more equal match to so formidable a neighbour as France.
modernized: With the prince's death and Geoffrey set to succeed, the King believed he couldn't make a better match for his daughter, as the marriage with this Earl would strengthen and expand their dominions and provide a more equal match against France.

original: In a short time the marriage was concluded; and this Earl Geoffrey had the honour to introduce into the royal family of England the surname of Plantagenet, borne by so many succeeding Kings, which began with Henry II. who was the eldest son of this marriage.
modernized: The marriage soon took place, and Earl Geoffrey had the honor of introducing the Plantagenet surname into the royal family of England, a name that would be carried by many future kings. This lineage started with Henry II, the eldest son of this marriage.

original: In the same Manner, if you are allowed a large Silver Spoon for the Kitchen, let half the Bole of it be worn out with continual scraping and stirring and often say merrily, This Spoon owes my Master no Service.
modernized: In the same way, if you are given a large silver spoon for kitchen use, allow half of it to wear out from constant scraping and stirring, while cheerfully saying, 'This spoon doesn't owe my master any service.'

original: Why should I go upon farther particulars, which might fill a volume with the just eulogies of my contemporary brethren?
modernized: Why bother discussing further details, as they would likely fill a book with the praises of my contemporary peers?

original: I shall bequeath this piece of justice to a larger work, wherein I intend to write a character of the present set of wits in our nation; their persons I shall describe particularly and at length, their genius and understandings in miniature.
modernized: I will save this piece of criticism for a larger work, where I plan to write a profile of the current group of wits in our country; I will describe the individuals with detail and depth, and outline their intellect and talents in brief.

original: I complied at last, finding I could not do better.
modernized: I conceded eventually, realizing there was no better option.

original: I left Lisbon the 24th day of November, in an English merchantman, but who was the master I never inquired.
modernized: I departed from Lisbon on November 24th in an English trading ship, but I never asked for the captain's name.

original: Don Pedro accompanied me to the ship, and lent me twenty pounds.
modernized: Don Pedro escorted me to the boat and lent me twenty pounds.

original: He took kind leave of me, and embraced me at parting, which I bore as well as I could.
modernized: He bid me farewell, gave me a warm embrace, and I managed to endure it as best as I could.

original: During this last voyage I had no commerce with the master or any of his men; but, pretending I was sick, kept close in my cabin.
modernized: For the duration of this last journey, I avoided contact with the crew as they did not visit the cabin where I feigned illness.

original: On the fifth of December, 1715, we cast anchor in the Downs, about nine in the morning, and at three in the afternoon I got safe to my house at Rotherhith.
modernized: On the 5th of December 1715, we dropped anchor in the Downs around 9 a.m., and at 3 p.m. I arrived safely at my home in Rotherhith.

original: I have long sought after this opportunity of doing justice to a society of men for whom I have a peculiar honour, and whose opinions as well as practices have been extremely misrepresented and traduced by the malice or ignorance of their adversaries.
modernized: I've spent a long time trying to find a chance to defend a group of people who I greatly respect and whose views and actions have been unfairly stereotyped and criticized by their opponents.

original: For I think it one of the greatest and best of human actions to remove prejudices and place things in their truest and fairest light, which I therefore boldly undertake, without any regards of my own beside the conscience, the honour, and the thanks.
modernized: I believe it is one of humanity's greatest and most noble actions to challenge prejudices and present things in their most accurate and truthful light, which I am confident in doing without any concern for my own gains, only guided by my conscience, honor, and gratitude.
