original: The land rents of Ireland are computed to about two millions, whereof one-tenth amounts to two hundred thousand pounds.
modernized: The total rent for land in Ireland is estimated to be about two million pounds, with one-tenth amount adjudged to be two hundred thousand pounds.

original: The benefited clergymen, excluding those of this city, are not reckoned to be above five hundred; by which computation, they should each of them possess two hundred pounds a year, if those tithes were equally divided, although in well cultivated corn countries it ought to be more; whereas they hardly receive one half of that sum; with great defalcations, and in very bad payments.
modernized: Without counting the clergy in the city, it's suspected there are approximately 500 benefited clergymen, with a calculation that each would receive 200 pounds annually if tithes were evenly distributed, but they barely receive half that amount and suffer from deficiencies and poor payments.

original: There are indeed, a few glebes in the north pretty considerable, but if these and all the rest were in like manner equally divided, they would not add five pounds a year to every clergyman.
modernized: Although there are a few notable glebes in the north, if all were evenly distributed among the clergy, it wouldn't add even five pounds to the annual income of every clergyman.

original: Therefore, whether the condition of the Clergy in general among us be justly liable to envy, or able to bear a heavy burden, which neither the nobility, nor gentry, nor tradesmen, nor farmers, will touch with one of their fingers; this, I say, is submitted to the honourable House.
modernized: I submit the question of whether the Clergy's general condition among us is deserving of envy or laboring under a heavy burden, one that neither the nobility, gentry, tradesmen, nor farmers would take on the slightest; this matter is placed before the honorable House.

original: But to return, Louis the Gross King of France, a valiant and active prince, in the flower of his age, succeeding to that crown that Robert was deprived of, Normandy, grew jealous of the neighbourhood and power of King Henry, and begun early to entertain designs either of subduing that duchy to himself, or at least of making a considerable party against the King in favour of William son of Robert, whom for that end he had taken into his protection.
modernized: Louis the Gross, the powerful and active King of France, who took over the crown previously held by Robert, felt threatened by Henry's dominion and began planning strategies to either take control of Normandy or create a strong opposition against Henry by supporting Robert's son, William. Louis took him under his protection for this purpose.

original: Pursuant to these intentions, he soon found an occasion for a quarrel: expostulating with Henry, that he had broken his promise by not doing homage for the Duchy of Normandy, as well as by neglecting to raze the castle of Gisors, which was built on the French side of the river Epte, the common boundary between both dominions.
modernized: To further his plans, Louis quickly found a reason for a dispute: he accused Henry of breaking his promise by failing to pledge allegiance for Normandy and by neglecting to destroy the castle of Gisors, which was located on the French side of the Epte river, the shared border between the two domains.

original: Guiscard died this morning at two; and the coroner's inquest have found that he was killed by bruises received from a messenger, so to clear the Cabinet Councillors from whom he received his wounds.
modernized: This morning, Guiscard died at 2 o'clock. The inquest found he was killed by injuries sustained from a messenger to protect the Cabinet Council members who inflicted those wounds.

original: I had a letter from Raymond, who cannot hear of your box; but I hope you have it before this comes to your hands.
modernized: I received a letter from Raymond who is unable to get your package; but I hope you've received it before this letter reaches you.

original: I dined to-day with Mr. Lewis of the Secretary's office.
modernized: Today, I had lunch with Mr. Lewis, who works in the Secretary's office.

original: Mr. Harley has abundance of extravasated blood comes from his breast out of his wound, and will not be well so soon as we expected.
modernized: Mr. Harley has an excess of blood leaking from his breast wound, and it will take longer than anticipated for him to recover.

original: I had something to say, but cannot call it to mind.
modernized: I had something to share, but I can't remember now.

original: To-day I went to Lewis at the Secretary's office; where I saw and spoke to Mr. Harley, who promised, in a few days, to finish the rest of my business.
modernized: Today I met with Lewis at his workplace, the Secretary's office. I had a conversation with Mr. Harley there, who assured me he would complete the remaining tasks within a few days.

original: I reproached him for putting me on the necessity of minding him of it, and rallied him, etc., which he took very well.
modernized: I criticized him for needing me to remind him of the tasks, and joked around a bit, which he accepted graciously.

original: I dined to-day with one Mr. Gore, elder brother to a young merchant of my acquaintance; and Stratford and my other friend merchants dined with us, where I stayed late, drinking claret and burgundy; and am just got to bed, and will say no more, but that it now begins to be time to have a letter from my own little MD; for the last I had above a fortnight ago, and the date was old too.
modernized: I had dinner today with a man named Mr. Gore, an elder brother to one of my acquaintances. Stratford and my other merchant friends were also present. We stayed late, drinking wine, and I just returned to bed. I'm starting to miss a letter from my dear MD as the last one I received was a fortnight ago, and the date is outdated.

original: I could force nothing on him but a footman's tooth, which I observed him to examine with great curiosity, and found he had a fancy for it.
modernized: I could only convince him to accept a soldier's tooth, which he seemed very interested in.

original: He received it with abundance of thanks, more than such a trifle could deserve.
modernized: He thanked me profusely, even though the tooth was just a trinket.

original: It was drawn by an unskilful surgeon, in a mistake, from one of Glumdalclitch's men, who was afflicted with the toothache, but it was as sound as any in his head.
modernized: The tooth was removed mistakenly by an inexperienced doctor from one of Glumdalclitch's men, who had a toothache, but it was in excellent condition.

original: I got it cleaned, and put it into my cabinet.
modernized: I cleaned the tooth and stored it in my cabinet.

original: It was about a foot long, and four inches in diameter.
modernized: It was approximately one foot long and four inches wide.

original: Minutius Felix seems to be a true modern latitudinarian, freethinking Christian; for he is against altars, churches, public preaching, and public assemblies; and likewise against priests; for, he says, there were several great flourishing empires before there were any orders of priests in the world.
modernized: Minutius Felix appears to be a modern latitudinarian, a Christian with progressive views, as he criticizes altars, churches, public sermons, assemblies, and the priesthood. He claims that prosperous empires existed before the establishment of religious orders.

original: Our truest and best ally, the Most Christian King, hath obtained his Majesty's licence, pursuant to law, to export from hence some thousand bodies of healthy, young, living men, to supply his Irish regiments.
modernized: Our most loyal and beneficial ally, the King of France, has been granted permission by law to export a thousand fit young men from here to relieve his Irish regiments.

original: The King of Spain, as you assert yourself, hath desired the same civility, and seemeth to have at least as good a claim.
modernized: According to yourself, the King of Spain has expressed a similar request, and appears to have a worthy claim.

original: Supposing then that these two potentates will only desire leave to carry off six thousand men between them to France and Spain; then, by computing the maintenance of a tall, hungry Irishman, in food and clothes, to be only at five pounds a head, here will be thirty thousand pounds per annum saved clear to the nation; for they can find no other employment at home, beside begging, robbing, or stealing.
modernized: Suppose then that these two rulers seek permission to send 6,000 men to France and Spain; by estimating the yearly cost of feeding an Irishman, which we suggest to be £5, the savings to the nation would be £30,000. As these men have no other means of work but begging, stealing, or robbing, sending them away would significantly benefit the country.

original: But, if thirty, forty, or fifty thousand (which we could gladly spare) were sent on the same errand, what an immense benefit must it be to us!
modernized: However, if 30, 40, or 50,000 men (which we can easily spare) were sent, this would generate an enormous benefit for us.

original: And if the two princes, in whose service they were, should happen to be at war with each other, how soon would those recruits be destroyed!
modernized: If the two rulers, whose armies these men would serve, were to engage in conflict, the recruits would likely be quickly eliminated.

original: Then what a number of friends would the Pretender lose, and what a number of Popish enemies all true Protestants get rid of!
modernized: In that scenario, a significant number of allies for the Pretender would disperse, while a substantial group of Popish enemies against true Protestants would be removed.

original: Add to this, that then, by such a practice, the lands of Ireland, that want hands for tillage, must be employed in grazing, which would sink the price of wool, raw hides, butter, and tallow, so that the English might have them at their own rates, and in return send us wheat to make our bread, barley to brew our drink, and oats for our houses, without any labour of our own.
modernized: Additionally, such practices would result in the lands that lack hands for agriculture in Ireland switching to grazing. This would lower the prices of wool, raw hides, butter, and tallow for the English, who could then send us wheat for bread, barley for brewing, and oats for homes, all without requiring any labor from us.

original: Besides, the politics of the French ran at this time very opposite to those of Britain: They thought the ministers here durst not meet the Parliament without a peace; and that, therefore, Her Majesty would either force the States to comply with France, by delivering up Tournay, which was the principal point in dispute, or would finish her own peace with France and Spain, leaving a fixed time for Holland to refuse or accept the terms imposed on them.
modernized: Moreover, the French government was opposing British politics at this time. They believed the English ministers wouldn't confront the Parliament without a peace, so they assumed Queen would either force the Dutch to comply with France by surrendering Tournay, the main point of contention, or make peace with France and Spain, giving the Dutch a set time to refuse or accept the imposed terms. However, the Queen believed the demand for Tournay by the Dutch was important and just, and was resolved to insist on it and openly declare against France, if necessary, rather than allow her ally to be without a fortification helpful for their defense.

original: But the Queen, who thought the demand of Tournay by the States to be very necessary and just, was determined to insist upon it, and to declare openly against France, rather than suffer her ally to want a place so useful for their barrier.
modernized: The Queen, however, saw the demand for Tournay by the States as critical and fundamental. She decided to assert her stance on it and to openly oppose France, rather than see her ally without a crucial stronghold essential for their defense.

original: And Mr. Prior was ordered to signify this resolution of Her Majesty to Mons. de Torcy, in case that minister could not be otherwise prevailed on.
modernized: In such a situation, Mr. Prior was instructed to communicate the Queen's firm resolution to Mons. de Torcy if the latter couldn't be persuaded otherwise.

original: I was debating with myself, whether this hint of producing a small pamphlet to give notice of a large folio, was not borrowed from the ceremonial in Spanish romances, where a dwarf is sent out upon the battlements to signify to all passengers, what a mighty giant there is in the castle; or whether the Bishop copied this proceeding from the fanfarronade of Monsieur Boufflers, when the Earl of Portland and that general had an interview.
modernized: I was considering whether the Bishop's announcement of a small pamphlet to preview a large book was copied from the tradition in Spanish stories, where a dwarf signals from the castle's walls about a giant inside, or if he copied it from the elaborate festival of Monsieur Boufflers when the Earl of Portland and that general met. Men were stationed at specific intervals to rush towards the English camp and shout, 'The Lord is coming, The Lord is coming'. Smaller groups followed with the same speed and cry, maintaining this display for many hours until the Marshal arrived.

original: Several men were appointed at certain periods to ride in great haste toward the English camp, and cry out, Monseigneur vient, Monseigneur vient: Then, small parties advanced with the same speed and the same cry, and this foppery held for many hours, until the mareschal himself arrived.
modernized: Here, several men were scheduled to race quickly towards the English camp at certain times, shouting 'The Lord is coming, The Lord is coming'. Then, small groups followed with the same speed and call, keeping up this extravagant display for many hours until the Marshal himself arrived.

original: So here, the Bishop (as we find by his dedication to Mr. Churchill the bookseller) has for a long time sent warning of his arrival by advertisements in Gazettes, and now his Introduction advances to tell us again, Monseigneur vient: In the mean time, we must gape and wait and gaze the Lord knows how long, and keep our spirits in some reasonable agitation, until his Lordship's real self shall think fit to appear in the habit of a folio.
modernized: Back in England, the Bishop (as shown by his dedication to Mr. Churchill the bookseller) has been advertising his arrival in Gazettes for a long time. Now his Introduction comes again to tell us that he's finally here, although we're left wandering how long we must wait for his grand appearance in his large book.

original: Japan was at that time a limited monarchy, which some authors are of opinion was introduced there by a detachment from the numerous army of Brennus, who ravaged a great part of Asia; and, those of them who fixed in Japan, left behind them that kind of military institution, which the northern people, in ensuing ages, carried through most parts of Europe; the generals becoming kings, the great officers a senate of nobles, with a representative from every centenary of private soldiers; and, in the assent of the majority in these two bodies, confirmed by the general, the legislature consisted.
modernized: During that period, Japan was a limited monarchy that some scholars speculate was established by a detachment of Brennus's large army, which ravaged a significant portion of Asia. The soldiers who settled in Japan are believed to have left behind a military institution that later spread throughout much of Europe, where generals became kings, high officials became a senate of nobles, and there was a representative from every hundred common soldiers. The legislature was formed as a result of the majority's agreement in these two bodies and the general's confirmation.

original: The Christian religion, in the most early times, was proposed to the Jews and heathens without the article of Christ's divinity; which, I remember, Erasmus accounts for, by its being too strong a meat for babes.
modernized: The Christian religion was originally introduced to non-Christians without the requirement of believing in the divinity of Christ, as recalled by Erasmus since he found it too complex for new converts.

original: Perhaps, if it were now softened by the Chinese missionaries, the conversion of those infidels would be less difficult: And we find by the Alcoran, it is the great stumbling-block of the Mahometans.
modernized: With the aid of the Chinese missionaries, the conversion of non-believers might be more feasible if the teachings about Christ's divinity were made more accessible. It is stated in the Quran that this belief is a significant stumbling block for Muslims.

original: But, in a country already Christian, to bring so fundamental a point of faith into debate, can have no consequences that are not pernicious to morals and public peace.
modernized: In a nation where Christianity has already been established, raising fundamental questions about faith can only lead to negative consequences for morals and social peace.

original: This volume would have been at least twice as large, if I had not made bold to strike out innumerable passages relating to the winds and tides, as well as to the variations and bearings in the several voyages, together with the minute descriptions of the management of the ship in storms, in the style of sailors; likewise the account of longitudes and latitudes; wherein I have reason to apprehend, that Mr. Gulliver may be a little dissatisfied.
modernized: I left out several detailed descriptions of the seas and the ship's maintenance during storms, as well as explaining navigation systems like latitudes and longitudes, because I thought they would be too technical for most readers. Mr. Gulliver might not be pleased with some of these omissions.

original: But I was resolved to fit the work as much as possible to the general capacity of readers.
modernized: I adjusted the work to be accessible to a broad audience.

original: However, if my own ignorance in sea affairs shall have led me to commit some mistakes, I alone am answerable for them.
modernized: If I made any mistakes related to sea navigation in the work due to my lack of knowledge, I shall take full responsibility for them.

original: And if any traveller hath a curiosity to see the whole work at large, as it came from the hands of the author, I will be ready to gratify him.
modernized: If any traveler wanted to see the entire, original work as it was first written by the author, I would willingly provide it to them.

original: In those hospitals which have good foundations and rents to support them, whereof, to the scandal of Christianity, there are very few in this kingdom; I say, in such hospitals, the children maintained ought to be only of decayed citizens, and freemen, and be bred up to good trades.
modernized: The children in the hospitals with stable funding and assets should only be from decrepit citizens and freemen, and taught skillful trades. However, there are very few such hospitals in the kingdom, which is a scandal for Christianity.

original: But in these small-parish charity-schools which have no support, but the casual goodwill of charitable people, I do altogether disapprove the custom of putting the children 'prentice, except to the very meanest trades; otherwise the poor honest citizen, who is just able to bring up his child, and pay a small sum of money with him to a good master, is wholly defeated, and the bastard issue, perhaps, of some beggar preferred before him.
modernized: In the small parish charity-schools that lack support apart from charitable individuals, I completely oppose the practice of apprenticing children, except to the most basic trades. This prevents a capable citizen from raising and training his child, while potentially favoring a child born of a beggar over him.

original: And hence we come to be so overstocked with 'prentices and journeymen, more than our discouraged country can employ; and, I fear, the greatest part of our thieves, pickpockets, and other vagabonds are of this number.
modernized: As a result, we end up having an excess of apprentices and journeymen beyond what our underdeveloped country can employ. I am concerned that most of our thieves, pickpockets, and vagabonds come from this group.

original: It is likewise true, nor will it be denied; that when the King was possessed of the English crown; and the remainder of the quarrel was left to be decided in this kingdom; the Presbyterians wisely chose to join with the Protestant army, rather than with that of King James their old friend, whose affairs were then in a manner desperate.
modernized: When the English King was in power and the remaining quarrel was left to be resolved within the kingdom, the Presbyterians decided to join the Protestant army instead of supporting King James, as he was in a desperate situation.

original: They were wise enough to know, that this kingdom, divided against itself, could never prevail against the united power of England.
modernized: The Presbyterians knew that a divided kingdom could not win against the combined power of England.

original: They fought pro aris et focis; for their estates and religion; which latter will never suffer so much by the Church of England as by that of Rome, where they are counted heretics as well as we: and consequently they have no other game to play.
modernized: Presbyterians fought for their properties and religion, which they believed were threatened more by the Church of Rome than by the Church of England, where they were considered heretics as well.

original: But, what merit they can build upon having joined with a Protestant army, under a King they acknowledged, to defend their own liberties and properties against a Popish enemy under an abdicated King; is, I confess to me absolutely inconceivable; and I believe will equally be so for ever, to any reasonable man.
modernized: Joining the Protestant army to defend their rights against a Popish enemy, under an abdicated King, while acknowledging the current King, was something I could not fathom as a means to gain merit and seems unlikely to a reasonable person forever.

original: He had before served me a scurvy trick, which set the queen a-laughing, although, at the same time she was heartily vexed, and would have immediately cashiered him, if I had not been so generous as to intercede.
modernized: Before, he played a mean trick on me, causing the queen to laugh while also being angry at him. If I hadn't intervened, he would've been fired immediately. However, because I was generous, I defended him and pleaded his case.

original: Her majesty had taken a marrow-bone upon her plate and, after knocking out the marrow, placed the bone on the dish erect, as it stood before.
modernized: The queen picked up a marrow bone from her plate, removed the marrow, and placed the bone, upright, on the dish.

original: The dwarf watching his opportunity, while Glumdalclitch was gone to the sideboard, mounted upon the stool she stood on to take care of me at meals, took me up in both hands, and, squeezing my legs together, wedged them into the marrow-bone above my waist, where I stuck for some time, and made a very ridiculous figure, I believe it was near a minute before any one knew what was became of me; for I thought it below me to cry out.
modernized: While Glumdalclitch was absent, the dwarf climbed onto the stool she stood on, took me up in both hands, and wedged me into the marrow bone above my waist, leaving me stuck there, looking quite silly, for about a minute before anyone realized what happened; I didn't want to cry out because I thought it unseemly.

original: But, as princes seldom get their meat hot, my legs were not scalded, only my stockings and breeches in a sad condition.
modernized: Since princes seldom eat food that's hot, I didn't get burned, but my clothes did get damaged.

original: The dwarf, at my entreaty, had no other punishment than a sound whipping.
modernized: At my request, the dwarf's punishment was only a sound whipping.

original: King James the First, who deserves more of the Church of Ireland than all other princes put together, having the forfeitures of vast tracts of land in the northern parts (I think commonly called the escheated counties), having granted some hundred thousand acres of these lands to certain Scotch and English favourites, was prevailed on by some great prelates to grant to some sees in the north, and to many parishes there, certain parcels of land for the augmentation of poor bishoprics, did likewise endow many parishes with glebes for the incumbents, whereof a good number escaped the depredations of 1641 and 1688.
modernized: King James I generously granted land in the northern parts (commonly known as the escheated counties) to Scottish and English favorites, and with support from some high-ranking clergy, provided land to several northern dioceses and parishes for the improvement of impoverished bishoprics. Many of these grants also included parcels of land for incumbents with glebes that survived the 1641 and 1688 depredations.

original: These lands, when they were granted by King James, consisted mostly of woody ground, wherewith those parts of this island were then overrun.
modernized: When James I granted these lands, they were primarily covered in forest thus overrunning those areas of the island.

original: This is well known, universally allowed, and by some in part remembered; the rest being, in some places, not stubbed out to this day.
modernized: Common knowledge, generally accepted, and partially recalled prove that the value of the lands was insignificant until Scottish colonies settled in large numbers to make the land more inhabitable.

original: And the value of the lands was consequently very inconsiderable, till Scotch colonies came over in swarms upon great encouragement to make them habitable; at least for such a race of strong-bodied people, who came hither from their own bleak barren highlands, as it were into a paradise; who soon were able to get straw for their bedding, instead of a bundle of heath spread on the ground, and sprinkled with water.
modernized: These strong-bodied people found their way to Ireland from their highlands and managed to get better bedding with straw and cleaner accommodations with water, which enabled them to become more civilized and thrive.

original: Here, by degrees, they acquired some degree of politeness and civility, from such neighbouring Irish as were still left after Tyrone's last rebellion, and are since grown almost entirely possessors of the north.
modernized: Over time, they assimilated politeness and civility from nearby Irish who survived the last rebellion and since possess the majority of the northern territories.

original: Thus, at length, the woods being rooted up, the land was brought in, and tilled, and the glebes which could not before yield twopence an acre, are equal to the best, sometimes affording the minister a good demesne, and some land to let.
modernized: As the forest was gradually cleared, the land was cultivated, and the previously unproductive glebes now match the best, sometimes providing the minister with a large farm and some property to rent.

original: I shall mention but one ill consequence more, which attends our want of brotherly love; that it hath put an end to all hospitality and friendship, all good correspondence and commerce between mankind.
modernized: I want to bring up another negative outcome resulting from our absence of brotherly love - it has eliminated all hospitality and friendship, mutual correspondence, and peace among people.

original: There are indeed such things as leagues and confederacies among those of the same party; but surely God never intended that men should be so limited in the choice of their friends: However, so it is in town and country, in every parish and street; the pastor is divided from his flock, the father from his son, and the house often divided against itself.
modernized: While there are groups united among the same party, it seems God didn't intend for our friendships to be so restricted. However, in towns and countryside, many parishes and neighborhoods, pastors and families are divided, and even houses are often split apart.

original: Men's very natures are soured, and their passions inflamed, when they meet in party clubs, and spend their time in nothing else but railing at the opposite side; thus every man alive among us is encompassed with a million of enemies of his own country, among which his oldest acquaintance and friends, and kindred themselves, are often of the number; neither can people of different parties mix together without constraint, suspicion, or jealousy, watching every word they speak, for fear of giving offence, or else falling into rudeness and reproaches, and so leaving themselves open to the malice and corruption of informers, who were never more numerous or expert in their trade.
modernized: People's innate behaviors become bitter and passions are fueled when they gather in party gatherings, spending only time badmouthing the opposition. As a result, each person alive in our society is surrounded by countless enemies who are often close friends, relatives, and acquaintances. People from different political groups can't mingle freely without tension, suspicion, or nervousness, constantly monitoring their words to avoid offense or falling into rude insults, making themselves vulnerable to malicious informants who are more plentiful and skilled than ever.

original: And as a further addition to this evil, those very few, who, by the goodness and generosity of their nature, do in their own hearts despise this narrow principle of confining their friendship and esteem, their charity and good offices, to those of their own party, yet dare not discover their good inclinations, for fear of losing their favour and interest.
modernized: Furthermore, those hard-hearted few who, through kindness and generosity, secretly condemn this narrow principle of only valuing friendships and affection within one's own party, still dare not express their goodwill for fear of losing their influence and support.

original: And others again, whom God had formed with mild and gentle dispositions, think it necessary to put a force upon their own tempers, by acting a noisy, violent, malicious part, as a means to be distinguished.
modernized: On the other hand, there are those with gentle and mild dispositions who feel the need to outwardly express aggression and malice in order to stand out from the crowd.

original: Thus hath party got the better of the very genius and constitution of our people; so that whoever reads the character of the English in former ages, will hardly believe their present posterity to be of the same nation or climate.
modernized: By doing this, parties have dominated the basic nature and makeup of our people, making it hard to recognize the English of earlier centuries in their modern counterparts.

original: For my own part, I must confess, the difficulties appeared so great to me, from such a noise and shew of opposition, that I thought nothing but the absolute necessity of affairs, could ever justify so daring an attempt.
modernized: I personally find the obstacles seemed insurmountable to me due to loud opposition and an unnecessary show, leading me to believe only the urgent necessity of matters themselves could justify such an audacious move.

original: But, a wise and good prince, at the head of an able ministry, and of a senate freely chosen; all united to pursue the true interest of their country, is a power, against which, the little inferior politics of any faction, will be able to make no long resistance.
modernized: However, a wise, virtuous, and honest monarch serving with an efficient ministry, alongside a senate freely elected, all working towards the nation's best interest, is a force that even the petty politics of any faction will struggle to resist for a prolonged period.

original: To this we may add one additional strength, which in the opinion of our adversaries, is the greatest and justest of any; I mean the vox populi, so indisputably declarative on the same side.
modernized: To further support this, I believe the 'voice of the people' - unquestionably echoing the same view - adds another powerful asset to our side.

original: I am apt to think, when these discarded politicians begin seriously to consider all this, they will think it proper to give out, and reserve their wisdom for some more convenient juncture.
modernized: I think that once these ousted politicians have fully considered all of these factors, they will realize it's prudent to stay quiet and wait for a more opportune moment to share their wisdom.

original: It would be tedious to trouble the reader with relating what vast numbers of illustrious persons were called up to gratify that insatiable desire I had to see the world in every period of antiquity placed before me.
modernized: It would be lengthy and perhaps boring to describe in detail the multitude of famous individuals who appeared to satisfy my curiosity to witness the world in all its historical periods.

original: I chiefly fed mine eyes with beholding the destroyers of tyrants and usurpers, and the restorers of liberty to oppressed and injured nations.
modernized: Mostly, I focused on observing those who overthrew tyrants and usurpers and restored freedom to oppressed and harmed nations.

original: But it is impossible to express the satisfaction I received in my own mind, after such a manner as to make it a suitable entertainment to the reader.
modernized: However, I cannot adequately convey the personal satisfaction I felt as a result, in a way that would make it enjoyable for the reader.

original: Thirdly, Since it is observed of armies, that in the present age they are brought to some degree of humanity, and a more regular demeanour to each other and to the world, than in former times; it is certainly a good maxim to endeavour preserving this temper among them, without which they would soon degenerate into savages.
modernized: Thirdly, armies in the current age are generally more civilized and behave more decently towards each other and the world compared to previous times. It is wise to maintain this civility among them, as they would quickly devolve into savagery without it.

original: To this end, it would be prudent among other things, to forbid that detestable custom of drinking to the damnation or confusion of any person whatsoever.
modernized: In order to achieve this, it is advisable to prohibit the disgraceful practice of toasting to the ruin of any individual whatsoever.

original: And here I must take leave to tell you, although you cannot but have perceived it from what I have already said, and shall be still more amply convinced by what is to follow; that freethinking signifies nothing, without freespeaking and freewriting.
modernized: In order to clearly convey what I've already mentioned and to further confirm my points, it's important to emphasize that simply freethinking is not enough; one must also openly express and write their thoughts. Freethinking implies a duty to try to convince everyone to think as one does, with the goal of encouraging freethinking in others.

original: It is the indispensable duty of a freethinker, to endeavour forcing all the world to think as he does, and by that means make them freethinkers too.
modernized: Moreover, I consider it essential for a freethinker to question and challenge established religious beliefs, rather than limiting their freethinking to minor variations from these beliefs.

original: You are also to understand, that I allow no man to be a freethinker, any further than as he differs from the received doctrines of religion.
modernized: It's important to understand that, for me, a person is only considered a freethinker to the extent that they deviate from generally accepted religious doctrines.

original: Where a man falls in, though by perfect chance, with what is generally believed, he is in that point a confined and limited thinker; and you shall see by and by, that I celebrate those for the noblest freethinkers in every age, who differed from the religion of their countries in the most fundamental points, and especially in those which bear any analogy to the chief fundamentals of religion among us.
modernized: When a person agrees with established beliefs by coincidence, they are narrow-minded in that particular belief. I admire those who have been the most notable freethinkers throughout history, as they disagreed with their countries' religious beliefs in the most fundamental points and especially in those aspects that resonate with the core beliefs of our own religion.

original: As to Savoy, that the Queen expected the States would concur with her in making good the advantages stipulated for that duke, and in prevailing with the Emperor to consent to an absolute neutrality in Italy, until the peace should be concluded.
modernized: The Queen hopes that the States will agree with her to uphold the agreed-upon benefits for the Duke of Savoy and to persuade the Emperor to maintain a complete neutrality in Italy until the peace treaty is finalized.

original: He bore a strange kind of appetite to snap-dragon and to the livid snuffs of a burning candle , which he would catch and swallow with an agility wonderful to conceive; and by this procedure maintained a perpetual flame in his belly, which issuing in a glowing steam from both his eyes, as well as his nostrils and his mouth, made his head appear in a dark night like the skull of an ass wherein a roguish boy hath conveyed a farthing-candle, to the terror of his Majesty's liege subjects.
modernized: Swift's character had a peculiar fondness for the game snap-dragon and the pungent smoke of a burning candle. He would catch and swallow them with remarkable speed, keeping a constant internal fire that emitted steam through his eyes, nose, and mouth, making him seem like a glow-in-the-dark donkey skull on a dark night, causing fear among King's subjects.

original: Therefore he made use of no other expedient to light himself home, but was wont to say that a wise man was his own lanthorn.
modernized: Swift's character preferred to use no other light source for navigation at home and would often say that a sensible person has his own source of light.

original: The learning of this people is very defective, consisting only in morality, history, poetry, and mathematics, wherein they must be allowed to excel.
modernized: The education of this society is quite inadequate, focusing on ethics, history, poetry, and mathematics, where they are undoubtedly excellent. However, practical knowledge is the only application of their mathematical prow

original: But the last of these is wholly applied to what may be useful in life, to the improvement of agriculture, and all mechanical arts; so that among us, it would be little esteemed.
modernized: Yet, their practical application of knowledge is exclusively limited to improving agriculture and all manual arts, and such work would be poorly regarded.

original: And as to ideas, entities, abstractions, and transcendentals, I could never drive the least conception into their heads.
modernized: Alas, the concepts of abstract ideas, entities, abstractions, and transcendentals remain beyond their comprehension.

original: The Church is supposed to last for ever, both in its discipline and doctrine; which is a privilege common to every petty corporation, who must likewise observe the laws of their foundation.
modernized: The Church is expected to endure forever, in terms of both its rules and beliefs. This is a privilege shared by all small organizations, who must also adhere to the regulations established by their founding charter.

original: If a gentleman's estate which now yields him a thousand pounds a year, had been set for ever at the highest value, even in the flourishing days of King Charles the Second, would it now amount to above four or five hundred at most?
modernized: If a gentleman's estate, which currently generates a thousand pounds annually, had always been set at its highest possible value, even during the prosperous era of King Charles II, would it now be worth more than 4 or 5 hundred pounds at most?

original: What if this had happened two or three hundred years ago; would the reserved rent at this day be any more than a small chiefry?
modernized: What if these circumstances had occurred two or three hundred years ago; would the current revenue be any greater than a small town's?

original: Suppose the revenues of a bishop to have been under the same circumstances; could he now be able to perform works of hospitality and charity?
modernized: Suppose a bishop's income was under the same circumstances; could they now afford to engage in charitable and hospitable acts?

original: Thus, if the revenues of a bishop be limited to a thousand pounds a year; how will his successor be in a condition to support his station with decency, when the same denomination of money shall not answer an half, a quarter, or an eighth part of that sum?
modernized: Therefore, if a bishop's income is capped at a thousand pounds each year, how will their successor be able to maintain their status with dignity, when the same unit of money will no longer be equivalent to half, a quarter, or an eighth of the initial amount?

original: Which must unavoidably be the consequence of any bill to elude the limiting act, whereby the Church was preserved from utter ruin.
modernized: This situation would inevitably occur if a bill were passed to bypass the limiting act, which had previously prevented the Church from going bankrupt.

original: And although this doctrine of subjecting ourselves to one another may seem to grate upon the pride and vanity of mankind, and may therefore be hard to be digested by those who value themselves upon their greatness or their wealth, yet it is really no more than what most men practise upon other occasions.
modernized: Firstly, the idea of humbling ourselves before each other, though it may clash with human pride and arrogance, is actually just a deliberate application of what many people regularly do in their daily lives.

original: For if our neighbour, who is our inferior, comes to see us, we rise to receive him; we place him above us, and respect him as if he were better than ourselves; and this is thought both decent and necessary, and is usually called good manners.
modernized: In everyday life, when our lesser-ranked peers visit us, we stand up to greet them and make them feel superior. Such behavior is considered both courteous and necessary, and is commonly referred to as good manners.

original: Now the duty required by the Apostle is only that we should enlarge our minds, and that what we thus practise in the common course of life we should imitate in all our actions and proceedings whatsoever; since our Saviour tells us that every man is our neighbour, and since we are so ready, in point of civility, to yield to others in our own houses, where only we have any title to govern.
modernized: The Apostle's teaching simply asks us to extend this practice of humility to every area of our lives. Since our Savior emphasizes that everyone around us is our neighbor, and since we readily defer to others in our homes, where we have a right to govern, we should continue to embrace this attitude towards others in all situations.

original: The army of the Ancients was much fewer in number; Homer led the horse, and Pindar the light-horse; Euclid was chief engineer; Plato and Aristotle commanded the bowmen; Herodotus and Livy the foot; Hippocrates, the dragoons; the allies, led by Vossius and Temple, brought up the rear.
modernized: In the Ancient army, the horse was led by Homer, while Pindar led the light-horse. Euclid served as the chief engineer, with Plato and Aristotle commanding the archers, and Herodotus and Livy leading the infantry. Hippocrates oversaw the dragoons, and allies led by Vossius and Temple brought up the rear.

original: It appeared that he understood me well enough, for he shook his head by way of disapprobation, and held his hand in a posture to show that I must be carried as a prisoner.
modernized: He made it clear that I was to be captured, as he disapproved of what I was doing and signaled that I should be taken away.

original: However, he made other signs, to let me understand that I should have meat and drink enough, and very good treatment.
modernized: He signaled that I would be given plentiful food and drink, and that my treatment would be good.

original: Whereupon I once more thought of attempting to break my bonds; but again, when I felt the smart of their arrows upon my face and hands, which were all in blisters, and many of the darts still sticking in them, and observing, likewise, that the number of my enemies increased, I gave tokens to let them know, that they might do with me what they pleased.
modernized: I thought of attempting to break free again, but when I felt the pain of their arrows on my face and hands, which were covered in blisters, and noticed that more of my enemies were present, I let them know they could do as they pleased.

original: Upon this the hurgo and his train withdrew, with much civility, and cheerful countenances.
modernized: The hurgo and his party withdrew, doing so politely and with cheerful expressions.

original: If we examine what societies of men are in closest union among themselves, we shall find them either to be those who are engaged in some evil design, or who labour under one common misfortune: Thus the troops of banditti in several countries abroad, the knots of highwaymen in our own nation, the several tribes of sharpers, thieves and pickpockets, with many others, are so firmly knit together, that nothing is more difficult than to break or dissolve their several gangs.
modernized: If we analyze societies of people who are most united, we find they are either working together for some harmful goal or facing a shared misfortune. For example, gangs of thieves, highwaymen, con artists, and so forth are tightly knit groups whose bonds are difficult to break. Similarly, people who share a misfortune - whether it's real or perceived - often form a close bond. This can be seen in the Catholic population of this kingdom, bearing the legitimate hardships they face, and in various sects that split off due to modern persecution, as they are called 'want of power'.

original: So likewise those who are fellow-sufferers under any misfortune, whether it be in reality or opinion, are usually contracted into a very strict union; as we may observe in the Papists throughout this kingdom, under those real difficulties which are justly put on them; and in the several schisms of Presbyterians, and other sects, under that grievous persecution of the modern kind, called want of power.
modernized: These tight-knit groups form because they share a common purpose and the interests of individual members don't conflict with those of the group as a whole. It's clear why such alliances remain strong and inviolable.

original: And the reason why such confederacies, are kept so sacred and inviolable, is very plain, because in each of those cases I have mentioned, the whole body is moved by one common spirit, in pursuit of one general end, and the interest of individuals is not crossed by each other, or by the whole.
modernized: Now, both these motivating factors unite the high-profile Whigs currently: they have been working toward a harmful goal for some time, and more recently, they're growing even tighter due to the unfortunate loss of power. So, it is right to be wary of any secret plots these nefarious groups may concoct.

original: In vain would his excusers endeavour to palliate his enormities, by imputing them to madness: Because, it is well known, that madness only operates by inflaming and enlarging the good or evil dispositions of the mind: For the curators of Bedlam assure us, that some lunatics are persons of honour, truth, benevolence, and many other virtues, which appear in their highest ravings, although after a wild incoherent manner; while others on the contrary, discover in every word and action the utmost baseness and depravity of human minds; which infallibly they possessed in the same degree, although perhaps under a better regulation, before their entrance into that academy.
modernized: Attempts to excuse his wrongdoings by attributing them to madness are futile, as madness only amplifies the good or bad tendencies of the mind. It's well documented that some patients at Bedlam, a mental hospital, exhibit noble qualities like honor, truth, and benevolence even during their erratic behavior. On the other hand, there are those who display the basest human traits during their time at Bedlam, and it can be inferred that they possessed these traits to the same extent before their admission into the institution.

original: Seneca was a great freethinker, and had a noble notion of the worship of the gods, for which our priests would call any man an atheist: He laughs at morning devotions, or worshipping upon Sabbath-days; he says God has no need of ministers and servants, because he himself serves mankind.
modernized: Seneca was a prominent freethinker known for questioning conventional religious practices. He found mockery in daily religious rituals like morning devotions and worship on Sundays. Seneca believed that God requires no intermediaries to serve humanity.

original: This religious man, like his religious brethren the Stoics, denies the immortality of the soul, and says, all that is feigned to be so terrible in hell, is but a fable: Death puts an end to all our misery, &c.
modernized: This religious figure, like the Stoics, didn't believe in the immortality of the soul. He considered the perceived horrors of hell to be mere myths, stating that death brings an end to all suffering.

original: Yet the priests were anciently so fond of Seneca, that they forged a correspondence of letters between him and St. Paul.
modernized: Despite his unorthodox beliefs, the priests in ancient times had a fondness for Seneca, fabricating a correspondence between him and St. Paul.

original: I have known, indeed, a few exceptions to some parts of these observations.
modernized: I've encountered a few exceptions to some of my observations.

original: I have seen some of the dullest men alive aiming at wit, and others, with as little pretensions, affecting politeness in manners and discourse: But never being able to persuade the world of their guilt, they grew into considerable stations, upon the firm assurance which all people had of their discretion, because they were of a size too low to deceive the world to their own disadvantage.
modernized: I've witnessed some of the least intelligent individuals striving for wit, and others attempting to project politeness in their manners and speech; however, they couldn't convince the world of their inappropriate behavior, and they managed to attain significant positions due to their reputations for being discreet, even though their deceitful nature was evident to those who paid close attention.

original: But this, I confess, is a trial too dangerous often to engage in.
modernized: However, I must admit that constantly testing the boundaries in this manner is risky.

original: But while these debates and differences continued at the congress, the Queen resolved to put a speedy end to her part in the war; she therefore sent orders to the lord privy seal, and the Earl of Stafford, to prepare every thing necessary for signing her own treaty with France.
modernized: During the ongoing discussions and disagreements at the congress, the Queen decided to quickly conclude her involvement in the war and initiated an order for the Lord Privy Seal and the Earl of Stafford to prepare for signing a treaty with France.

original: This she hoped might be done against the meeting of her Parliament, now prorogued to the third of February; in which time, those among the allies, who were really inclined towards a peace, might settle their several interests by the assistance and support of Her Majesty's plenipotentiaries; and as for the rest, who would either refuse to comply, or endeavour to protract the negotiation, the heads of their respective demands, which France had yielded by Her Majesty's intervention, and agreeable to the plan laid down in her speech, should be mentioned in the treaty, and a time limited for the several powers concerned to receive or reject them.
modernized: The Queen hoped this could be accomplished before the meeting of her Parliament, rescheduled to the third of February. In this timeframe, those who genuinely wished for peace could settle their individual interests with the assistance of Her Majesty's representatives. For the others who either refused to cooperate or wished to drag out the negotiation, the key points of their demands, which France agreed upon due to Her Majesty's intervention in line with her stated plan, would be included in the treaty, and a specified timeframe would be allowed for the concerned powers to either accept or reject them.

original: On the other hand, he extols the ministers, and minions of the Queen, in the highest terms; and while he robs their antagonists of every good quality, generally gives those wisdom and every virtue that can adorn human nature.
modernized: In contrast, he praises the ministers and supporters of the Queen extremely highly, while discrediting those who oppose her, crediting them with very little wisdom or virtue.

original: But leaving the care of informing posterity to better pens, I shall with due regard to truth, discretion, and the safety of my person from the men of the newfangled moderation, continue to take all proper opportunities of letting the misled part of the people see how grossly they have been abused, and in what particulars: I shall also endeavour to convince them, that the present course we are in, is the most probable means, with the blessing of God, to extricate ourselves out of all our difficulties.
modernized: I will leave it to more capable writers to educate future generations about the state of affairs. However, I will truthfully present my thoughts with caution, avoiding any potential harm to myself, regarding those responsible for misleading the public. I will provide specific examples of the corruption and detail why our current course, through divine intervention, might free us from our predicament.

original: As to our City of Dublin, shambles may be appointed for this purpose, in the most convenient parts of it, and butchers we may be assured will not be wanting; although I rather recommend buying the children alive, and dressing them hot from the knife, as we do roasting pigs.
modernized: In our City of Dublin, it would be beneficial to establish places for such a purpose in the most convenient locations. These areas would ensure the presence of butchers, who would gladly take part. Although I suggest buying the children alive and preparing them immediately, just like freshly roasted pigs.

original: Herein I resolved to exceed the Advice of Horace, a Roman Poet, (which I have read in Mr.Creech's admirable Translation) That an Author should keep his Works Nine Years in his Closet, before he ventured to publish them; and finding that I still received some additional Flowers of Wit and Language, although in a very small Number, I determined to defer the Publication, to pursue my Design, and exhaust, if possible, the whole Subject, that I might present a complete System to the World: For, I am convinced by long Experience, that the Critics will be as severe as their old Envy against me can make them: I foretel, they will object, that I have inserted many Answers and Replies which are neither witty, humorous, polite, or authentic; and have omitted others, that would have been highly useful, as well as entertaining: But let them come to Particulars, and I will boldly engage to confute their Malice.
modernized: I made a decision to surpass the recommendation of Horace, a famous Roman poet (from Creech's excellent translation), which advises an author to keep their work in a private space for nine years before publishing it. I found that I was still gaining additional bits of wit and expressive language, albeit in small numbers, so I chose to postpone publication to continue my work and explore every aspect of my topic, to present a comprehensive system to the world. I believe, based on my extensive experience, that critics will be as harsh as their age-old prejudice allows, and they will argue that I've included many unamusing answers and responses that are not witty, humorous, polite, or authentic; while also missing out on others that would have been both useful and entertaining. However, if they focus on specifics, I am confident I can refute their criticisms.

original: The French army acts now wholly on the defensive, strongly fortify'd in their trenches; and the young French King sends overtures for a treaty of peace by the Duke of Mantua; which, because it is a matter of state that concerns us here at home, I shall speak no farther of it.
modernized: The French army is currently taking a defensive stance, heavily fortified in their trenches. The young French king presents proposals for a peace treaty via the Duke of Mantua; however, as it concerns domestic politics, I won't discuss it further.

original: If your Butter, when it is melted, tastes of Brass, it is your Master's Fault, who will not allow you a Silver Saucepan; besides, the less of it will go further, and new tinning is very chargeable: If you have a Silver Saucepan, and the Butter smells of Smoak, lay the Fault upon the Coals.
modernized: If the melted butter tastes like brass, it's because your master doesn't provide a silver saucepan; additionally, less butter will stretch further, and re-tinning costs a lot. However, if you do have a silver saucepan but the butter smells of smoke, blame the coals.

original: When you take away the remaining Pieces of Bread after Dinner, put them on foul Plates, and press them down with other Plates over them, so as nobody can touch them; and so, they will be a good Perquisite to the Blackguard Boy in ordinary.
modernized: If leftover bread from dinner remains, place it on dirty plates and press them down with other plates. No one can take the bread, and it becomes a personal prize for the dishonest boy who frequently helps serve meals.

original: We have heard of men, who, through greediness of gain, have brought infected goods into a nation, which bred a plague, whereof the owners and their families perished first.
modernized: Hear of people who, driven by greed, introduced tainted goods into a country, leading to a plague that initially killed the owners and their families.

original: Let those among us consider this and tremble, whose houses are privately stored with those materials of beggary and desolation, lately brought over to be scattered like a pestilence among their countrymen, which may probably first seize upon themselves and their families, until their houses shall be made a dunghill.
modernized: Let's reflect upon this and shiver, considering those among us who secretly hoard detrimental items imported recently, meant to spread like a contagion among fellow citizens. These items may first affect the hoarders and their families, eventually turning their homes into a dumping ground.

original: We left Lord Peter in open rupture with his two brethren, both for ever discarded from his house, and resigned to the wide world with little or nothing to trust to.
modernized: Lord Peter was left in a severe disagreement with his two brothers, who were expelled from his home and left with very little to rely on.

original: Which are circumstances that render them proper subjects for the charity of a writer's pen to work on, scenes of misery ever affording the fairest harvest for great adventures.
modernized: These unfortunate circumstances make them suitable subjects for the aid of a writer, as such situations are often the springboard for great adventures.

original: And in this the world may perceive the difference between the integrity of a generous Author and that of a common friend.
modernized: This highlights the distinction between the honesty of a compassionate author and that of a casual friend.

original: The latter is observed to adhere close in prosperity, but on the decline of fortune to drop suddenly off; whereas the generous author, just on the contrary, finds his hero on the dunghill, from thence, by gradual steps, raises him to a throne, and then immediately withdraws, expecting not so much as thanks for his pains; in imitation of which example I have placed Lord Peter in a noble house, given him a title to wear and money to spend.
modernized: A casual friend typically remains supportive during prosperous times but quickly abandons during hardship, whereas a compassionate author seeks to uplift their hero from a lowly state, guide them to a position of power, and then retreat without expectations of gratitude. In this story, I have placed Lord Peter in a grand household, provided him with a title and wealth.

original: There I shall leave him for some time, returning, where common charity directs me, to the assistance of his two brothers at their lowest ebb.
modernized: At this point, I will leave Lord Peter for some time before returning to aid his two brothers in their desperate situation.

original: However, I shall by no means forget my character of a historian, to follow the truth step by step whatever happens, or wherever it may lead me.
modernized: Although I am also a historian, I will not abandon my pursuit of truth, no matter where it takes me.

original: But, because I altogether contemn the displeasure and resentment of highfliers, Tories, and Jacobites, whom I look upon to be worse even than professed Papists, I do here declare, that those evils which I am going to mention, were all brought in upon us in the worst of times, under the late Earl of Oxford's administration, during the four last years of Queen Anne's reign.
modernized: I disregard and condemn the displeasure and resentment of the upper class, Tories, and Jacobites, who I believe are even worse than open Papists. I declare that all the evils I'll mention were introduced during the worst of times, under the late Earl of Oxford's administration, during the last four years of Queen Anne's reign.

original: That wicked minister was universally known to be a Papist in his heart.
modernized: The corrupt minister was generally known to secretly be a Papist.

original: He was of a most avaricious nature, and is said to have died worth four millions, sterl. besides his vast expenses in building, statues, gold plate, jewels, and other costly rarities.
modernized: He was extremely greedy and is rumored to have died worth four million pounds, in addition to the massive expenditures on construction, statues, gold plate, jewels, and other luxury items.

original: He was of a mean obscure birth, from the very dregs of the people, and so illiterate, that he could hardly read a paper at the council table.
modernized: He came from a humble, low-class background and was so illiterate that he struggled to read a paper at the council table.

original: I forbear to touch at his open, profane, profligate life; because I desire not to rake into the ashes of the dead, and therefore I shall observe this wise maxim: De mortuis nil nisi bonum.
modernized: I choose not to discuss his promiscuous and scandalous actions while he was alive, as I prefer not to dig up the past, and will therefore follow this wise advice: Speak nothing but good of the dead.

original: The spirit of war and contention, which had for a long time possessed the nation, became so effectually laid during the last year of King Stephen's reign, that no alteration or disturbance ensued upon his death, although the new King, after he had received intelligence of it, was detained six weeks by contrary winds: besides, the opinion of this prince's power and virtues, had already begotten so great an awe and reverence for him among the people, that upon his arrival he found the whole kingdom in a profound peace.
modernized: The destructive spirit of conflict and discord, which had persisted for a long time in the country, remained dormant during the last year of King Stephen's reign. When he passed away, there was no discord or turmoil happening, even though the new King was delayed for six weeks due to contrary winds receiving news of his death. The people held such a great respect for this new King that they welcomed him with the kingdom already in a deep peace. This King landed at Hostreham around the beginning of December.

original: He landed at Hostreham, about the beginning of December, was received at Winchester by a great number of the nobility, who came there to attend and swear fealty to him, and three weeks after was crowned at Westminster, about the twenty-third year of his age.
modernized: Upon his arrival at Winchester, he was greeted by numerous Nobles who came to pledge allegiance to him, and he was crowned three weeks later at Westminster, around his twenty-third year of age.

original: When your Lady is ill, and after a very bad Night, is getting a little Nap in the Morning, if a Footman comes with a Message to enquire how she doth, do not let the Compliment be lost, but shake her gently until she wakes; then deliver the Message, receive her Answer, and leave her to sleep.
modernized: When your Lady is feeling unwell, especially after a difficult night, if a Footman comes with a question about her condition during her brief morning rest, do not overlook the polite gesture, but carefully awaken her and deliver the message. After obtaining her response, allow her to rest again.

original: Perhaps I have been too tedious; but there would never be an end, if I attempted to say all that this melancholy subject will bear.
modernized: I may have been overly lengthy, but I can't exhaust all that this topic can cover. I'll now humbly suggest one idea that could quickly bring an end to this catastrophic plan.

original: I will conclude with humbly offering one proposal, which, if it were put in practice, would blow up this destructive project at once.
modernized: I propose we put this idea into action; if it's taken seriously, it would instantaneously tackle and resolve this detrimental scheme.

original: Let some skilful judicious pen draw up an advertisement to the following purpose.
modernized: A capable and sensible writer should draft an advertisement suggesting the following.}

original: It would be endless to relate, or rather indeed impossible to discover, the several arts which curious men have found out to enrich themselves, by defrauding the public, in defiance of the law.
modernized: It is beyond possibility to explain or even discover the various schemes that crafty individuals have devised to accumulate wealth by defrauding the public in violation of the law.

original: The military men, both by sea and land, have equally cultivated this most useful science: neither hath it been altogether neglected by the other sex; of which, on the contrary, I could produce an instance, that would make ours blush to be so far outdone.
modernized: The military personnel, both in the navy and the army, have equally perfected this beneficial skill. Women have also not been completely indifferent to this practice; in fact, I could provide an example that would make us look uneducated in comparison.

original: And here, I cannot conceal, without Ingratitude, the great Assistance I have received from those two illustrious Writers, Mr. Ozel, and Captain Stevens.
modernized: I am grateful for the significant help I've received from the two well-known authors, Mr. Ozel and Captain Stevens.

original: These, and some others, of distinguished Eminence, in whose Company I have passed so many agreeable Hours, as they have been the great Refiners of our Language; so, it hath been my chief Ambition to imitate them.
modernized: Many distinguished individuals, with whom I've spent pleasant hours, have significantly influenced our language; my main goal has been to emulate them.

original: Let the Popes, the Gays, the Arbuthnots, the Youngs, and the rest of that snarling Brood burst with Envy at the Praises we receive from the Court and Kingdom.
modernized: Let popes, gays, Arbuthnots, Youngs, and the rest of that snarling group rejoice in envy at the accolades we receive from the court and kingdom.

original: In the trial of persons accused for crimes against the state, the method is much more short and commendable: the judge first sends to sound the disposition of those in power, after which he can easily hang or save a criminal, strictly preserving all due forms of law.
modernized: In the trial of those accused of crimes against the state, the method is more efficient and noteworthy. The judge first checks the intentions of those in power and can then easily convict or acquit a criminal, maintaining all aspects of due process of law.

original: If the censure of the Yahoos could any way affect me, I should have great reason to complain, that some of them are so bold as to think my book of travels a mere fiction out of mine own brain, and have gone so far as to drop hints, that the Houyhnhnms and Yahoos have no more existence than the inhabitants of Utopia.
modernized: If criticism from the Yahoos could in any way affect me, I would have a legitimate reason to complain, as some of them are audacious enough to believe that my travel book is a work of fiction created solely by my imagination, and they have hinted that the Houyhnhnms and Yahoos may not even exist, similar to the people of Utopia.

original: If an additional excise upon ale, or a duty upon flesh and bread, were to be enacted, neither the victualler, butcher, or baker would bear any more of the charge than for what themselves consumed; but it would be an equal general tax through the whole kingdom: Whereas, by this Bill, the Clergy alone are avowedly condemned to be deprived of their ancient, inherent, undisputed rights, in order to encourage a manufacture by which all the rest of the kingdom are supposed to be gainers.
modernized: If an additional tax on ale or duty on food products like meat and bread was imposed, no restaurant owner, butcher, or baker would shoulder any more of the cost than what they consume themselves; it would be a uniform tax across the entire kingdom. However, this bill specifically targets the clergy, stripping them of their ancient, inherited, undisputed rights, supposedly to benefit the rest of the country by increasing a particular industry.

original: I am ready enough to grant, that the oppression of landlords, the utter ruin of trade, with its necessary consequence the want of money, half the revenues of the kingdom spent abroad, the continued dearth of three years, and the strong delusion in your people by false allurement from America, may be the chief motives of their eagerness after such an expedition.
modernized: The main reasons for the Irish going on such an expedition could be the oppressive behavior of landlords, the collapse of trade, the scarcity of money, half of the kingdom's revenue being spent overseas, three years of famine, and the false temptation to emigrate to America.

original: [But there is likewise another temptation, which is not of inconsiderable weight; which is their itch of living in a country where their sect is predominant, and where their eyes and consciences would not be offended by the stumbling-block of ceremonies, habits, and spiritual titles.]
modernized: [However, there is another reason that shouldn't be overlooked, namely their desire to live in a country where their particular religious sect is the majority, and where they won't be disturbed by religious ceremonies, habits, and spiritual titles.]

original: I have gone as far as I am able in qualifying myself to be such a moderator: I believe I am no bigot in religion, and I am sure I am none in government.
modernized: I have done as much as I can to prepare myself to act as a neutral party; I do not have strong religious biases, and I have no allegiances to any political party.

original: I converse in full freedom with many considerable men of both parties, and if not in equal number, it is purely accidental and personal, as happening to be near the court, and to have made acquaintance there, more under one ministry than another.
modernized: I speak openly and readily with many influential individuals from both parties, though I may have more acquaintances with those closer to the court and under one ministry more than the other.

original: Then, I am not under the necessity of declaring myself by the prospect of an employment.
modernized: I am not obligated to take a side because of the prospects of a job.

original: And lastly, if all this be not sufficient, I industriously conceal my name, which wholly exempts me from any hopes and fears in delivering my opinion.
modernized: Furthermore, I keep my true identity hidden, which protects me from any advantage or disadvantage in expressing my opinion.

original: But I had another reason, which made me less forward to enlarge his majesty's dominions by my discoveries.
modernized: I had another reason that made me hesitant to increase the size of the king's domain with my discoveries.

original: To say the truth, I had conceived a few scruples with relation to the distributive justice of princes upon those occasions.
modernized: Thinking honestly, I had some doubts about the fairness of kings in such situations.

original: For instance, a crew of pirates are driven by a storm they know not whither; at length a boy discovers land from the topmast; they go on shore to rob and plunder, they see a harmless people, are entertained with kindness; they give the country a new name; they take formal possession of it for their king; they set up a rotten plank, or a stone, for a memorial; they murder two or three dozen of the natives, bring away a couple more, by force, for a sample; return home, and get their pardon.
modernized: For example, a band of pirates are swept by a storm to unknown shores; a boy spots land from the mast; they go ashore to loot and pillage, encounter peaceful people, receive hospitality; they name the land for their king, claim it under his sovereignty, set up a wooden plank or stone as a symbol; they kill dozens of natives, kidnap a few more, return home, and are pardoned.

original: Here commences a new dominion acquired with a title by divine right.
modernized: This begins a new dominant territory established with a claim by divine right.

original: Ships are sent with the first opportunity; the natives driven out or destroyed; their princes tortured to discover their gold; a free license given to all acts of inhumanity and lust, the earth reeking with the blood of its inhabitants: and this execrable crew of butchers, employed in so pious an expedition, is a modern colony, sent to convert and civilize an idolatrous and barbarous people!
modernized: Ships are sent with the earliest opportunity; the natives are either driven out or slaughtered; their leaders are tortured for gold; the inhabitants are given free rein to commit atrocities and acts of depravity, the land soaked with blood of its residents: these lawless killers, who take part in such so-called pious expeditions, represent a modern colony sent to convert and civilize what they consider barbaric and idolatrous people.

original: Whosoever hath examined the conduct and proceedings of both parties for some years past, whether in or out of power, cannot well conceive it possible to go far towards the extremes of either, without offering some violence to his integrity or understanding.
modernized: Anyone who has carefully examined the actions of both political parties for a number of years, regardless of whether they are in power or not, cannot reasonably imagine going to the furthest extremes of either party without causing harm to their own principles or intellect.

original: A wise and a good man may indeed be sometimes induced to comply with a number whose opinion he generally approves, though it be perhaps against his own.
modernized: A wise and fair-minded individual may be forced to agree with a group whose views they generally support, even if it means going against their own personal beliefs.

original: But this liberty should be made use of upon very few occasions, and those of small importance, and then only with a view of bringing over his own side another time to something of greater and more public moment.
modernized: This agreement should be made in very rare circumstances, and only in situations of minor importance, with the aim of eventually winning over their own side to a greater and more publicly significant issue.

original: But to sacrifice the innocency of a friend, the good of our country, or our own conscience to the humour, or passion, or interest of a party, plainly shews that either our heads or our hearts are not as they should be: Yet this very practice is the fundamental law of each faction among us, as may be obvious to any who will impartially, and without engagement, be at the pains to examine their actions, which however is not so easy a task: For it seems a principle in human nature, to incline one way more than another, even in matters where we are wholly unconcerned.
modernized: However, to compromise the innocence of a friend, the good of the nation, or one's own conscience for the sake of a political party, clearly indicates that one's morals and judgment are not what they should be. This behavior is the core principle of every political faction, and can be seen when one carefully and objectively evaluates their actions. However, it is not an easy task to take an unbiased look at the actions of others.

original: And it is a common observation, that in reading a history of facts done a thousand years ago, or standing by at play among those who are perfect strangers to us, we are apt to find our hopes and wishes engaged on a sudden in favour of one side more than another.
modernized: It is also common observation that when reading accounts of events that took place centuries ago or watching a game between strangers, one's sympathies and desires can suddenly be engaged in favor of one side over another.

original: No wonder then, we are all so ready to interest ourselves in the course of public affairs, where the most inconsiderable have some real share, and by the wonderful importance which every man is of to himself, a very great imaginary one.
modernized: Unsurprisingly, it is easy for us to take an interest in public affairs, as even the most insignificant individuals have a real stake in them, and each person places an exaggerated importance on themselves.
