original: There were no leaders at the time who could see this, and seeing it, enforce its truth on the dull English mind to move it to saner methods of dealing with this people.
modernized: During that time, there was a lack of leaders who understood the situation and took action to advocate for fairer treatment of the Irish people.

original: Nor were there any who could order the resentment into battalions of fighting men to give point to the demands for equal rights with their English fellow-subjects.
modernized: Furthermore, no one stepped up to organize the growing sense of injustice and lead peaceful protests to demand equal rights with the English.

original: How Jack, having got rid of the old landlord, set up another to his mind, quarrelled with Martin, and turned him out of doors.
modernized: How Jack, after discarding the previous landlord, appointed a new one to his liking, argued with Martin and evicted him.

original: How he pillaged all his shops, and abolished his whole dispensatory.
modernized: He plundered all his shops and dismantled his entire pharmacy.

original: How the new landlord laid about him, mauled Peter, worried Martin, and made the whole neighbourhood tremble.
modernized: The new landlord initiated physical altercations, harassed Peter, irritated Martin, and instilled fear throughout the neighborhood.

original: How Jack's friends fell out among themselves, split into a thousand parties, turned all things topsyturvy, till everybody grew weary of them; and at last, the blustering landlord dying, Jack was kicked out of doors, a new landlord brought in, and Martin re-established.
modernized: Jack's friends disagreed amidst chaos, splintered into numerous factions, caused confusion, and eventually everyone grew tired of the chaos; with the loud landlord passing away, Jack was ultimately evicted, a new landlord arrived, and Martin was reinstated.

original: How this new landlord let Martin do what he pleased, and Martin agreed to everything his pious landlord desired, provided Jack might be kept low.
modernized: This new landlord allowed Martin to do as he pleased and Martin agreed to everything his devout landlord desired, as long as Jack remained subdued.

original: Of several efforts Jack made to raise up his head, but all in vain; till at last the landlord died, and was succeeded by one who was a great friend to Peter, who, to humble Martin, gave Jack some liberty.
modernized: Jack made several attempts to regain his position, but all failed; it wasn't until the landlord passed away that a new landlord arrived who was friendly with Peter, giving Jack some liberties.

original: How Martin grew enraged at this, called in a foreigner and turned out the landlord; in which Jack concurred with Martin, because this landlord was entirely devoted to Peter, into whose arms he threw himself, and left his country.
modernized: Martin became enraged by this, hired a foreigner to evict the landlord, and did so - Jack collaborated with Martin because this landlord was heavily devoted to Peter, who he then joined and left his country.

original: How the new landlord secured Martin in the full possession of his former rights, but would not allow him to destroy Jack, who had always been his friend.
modernized: The new landlord guaranteed Martin's possession of his former rights, but refused to let him harm Jack, who had always been an ally.

original: How Jack got up his head in the North, and put himself in possession of a whole canton, to the great discontent of Martin, who finding also that some of Jack's friends were allowed to live and get their bread in the south parts of the country, grew highly discontented with the new landlord he had called in to his assistance.
modernized: Jack successfully asserted his position in the North, took control of an entire territory, causing dissatisfaction among Martin, who also noticed that some of Jack's allies were allowed to live and earn a living in the southern parts of the county, sparking discontent with the new landlord he had summoned to assist him.

original: How this landlord kept Martin in order, upon which he fell into a raging fever, and swore he would hang himself or join in with Peter, unless Jack's children were all turned out to starve.
modernized: This landlord kept Martin under control, causing Martin to fall into a severe fever and threaten to commit suicide or join forces with Peter, unless Jack's children were evicted and left to starve.

original: Of several attempts to cure Martin, and make peace between him and Jack, that they might unite against Peter; but all made ineffectual by the great address of a number of Peter's friends, that herded among Martin's, and appeared the most zealous for his interest.
modernized: Various attempts were made to heal Martin and reconcile him with Jack, so they could unite against Peter; however, these efforts were ineffective due to the persuasive tactics of multiple Peter's allies residing within Martin's circle.

original: How Martin, getting abroad in this mad fit, looked so like Peter in his air and dress, and talked so like him, that many of the neighbours could not distinguish the one from the other; especially when Martin went up and down strutting in Peter's armour, which he had borrowed to fight Jack.
modernized: As Martin ventured out in this fits of madness, he resembled Peter in his demeanor and mannerisms, and even spoke like him; this led many neighbors to confuse Martin with Peter, especially when Martin wandered around decked out in Peter's armor, borrowed to fight Jack.

original: What remedies were used to cure Martin's distemper . . .
modernized: Different treatments were employed to cure Martin, but his illness persisted.

original: And we do beg leave to represent it to Your Majesty, as the humble opinion and advice of this House, that no peace can be safe or honourable to Great Britain and Europe, if Spain and the West Indies are to be allotted to any branch of the house of Bourbon.
modernized: We would like to humbly advise Your Majesty that a peace considered safe and honorable for Great Britain and Europe cannot be achieved if Spain and the West Indies are given to any branch of the House of Bourbon.

original: Second place: To inquire into the grounds and reasons of this ignorance, and to shew whence it comes to pass that man, the only creature in the world that can reflect and look into himself, should know so little of what passes within him, and be so very much unacquainted even with the standing dispositions and complexion of his own heart.
modernized: To investigate the causes and reasons behind this ignorance and explain why man, who can think and introspect, still knows so little about what goes on within himself, even the fundamental characteristics of his own heart.

original: The prime reason of it is, because we so very seldom converse with ourselves, and take so little notice of what passes within us: For a man can no more know his own heart than he can know his own face, any other way than by reflection: He may as well tell over every feature of the smaller portions of his face without the help of a looking-glass, as he can tell all the inward bents and tendencies of his soul, those standing features and lineaments of the inward man, and know all the various changes that this is liable to from custom, from passion, and from opinion, without a very frequent use of looking within himself.
modernized: The main reason is that we rarely reflect on our thoughts and pay little attention to what happens inside: A person cannot understand their own heart any better than they can see their own face without looking in a mirror. They can't tell all the hidden and constant feelings of their soul, the permanent characteristics, like the face's basic features, or the varying changes due to habit, emotion and opinion, without frequently observing themselves from within.

original: It was the want of assigning some happiness proportioned to the soul of man that caused many of them, either on the one hand, to be sour and morose, supercilious and untreatable, or, on the other, to fall into the vulgar pursuits of common men, to hunt after greatness and riches, to make their court and to serve occasions, as Plato did to the younger Dionysius, and Aristotle to Alexander the Great.
modernized: The lack of a promised happiness tied to the soul led several of them to be either bitter, arrogant, and hard to get along with, or to pursue worldly pleasures like wealth, honor, and power, such as Plato serving the younger Dionysius and Aristotle serving Alexander the Great.

original: So impossible it is for a man who looks no further than the present world to fix himself long in a contemplation where the present world has no part; he has no sure hold, no firm footing; he can never expect to remove the earth he rests upon while he has no support besides for his feet, but wants, like Archimedes, some other place whereon to stand.
modernized: A person who focuses only on this world cannot maintain deep contemplation when this world is not involved; they have no stable foundation; they cannot expect to move the ground they stand on without additional support, like Archimedes needing another place to stand.

original: To talk of bearing pain and grief without any sort of present or future hope cannot be purely greatness of spirit; there must be a mixture in it of affectation and an alloy of pride, or perhaps is wholly counterfeit.
modernized: Purely enduring pain and sorrow without any present or future hope is difficult to interpret as true greatness of spirit; it may contain elements of disingenuousness and self-importance, or may be entirely insincere.

original: And therefore I, the author of this miraculous treatise, having hitherto, beyond expectation, maintained by the aforesaid handle a firm hold upon my gentle readers, it is with great reluctance that I am at length compelled to remit my grasp, leaving them in the perusal of what remains to that natural oscitancy inherent in the tribe.
modernized: So, as the author of this incredible booklet, I've managed to keep readers engaged by using a specific tactic for quite some time. Now, it's with great reluctance that I must release my grip on them, because they're left to wander in the rest of it, at the mercy of their own distractions.

original: I can only assure thee, courteous reader, for both our comforts, that my concern is altogether equal to thine, for my unhappiness in losing or mislaying among my papers the remaining part of these memoirs, which consisted of accidents, turns, and adventures, both new, agreeable, and surprising, and therefore calculated in all due points to the delicate taste of this our noble age.
modernized: I sincerely sympathize with you, dear reader, because I deeply regret losing the rest of these memoirs-which included amusing, curious, and unexpected events-since it was meant to cater to this sophisticated age.

original: But alas! with my utmost endeavours I have been able only to retain a few of the heads.
modernized: However, I can only remember a few details from what I had intended to include.

original: Under which there was a full account how Peter got a protection out of the King's Bench, and of a reconcilement between Jack and him, upon a design they had in a certain rainy night to trepan brother Martin into a spunging-house, and there strip him to the skin.
modernized: There was a detailed account of how Peter acquired protection from the King's Bench, along with a reconciliation between Jack and him, part of a plot they had concocted on a rainy evening to lock Martin in a spa, strip him, and humiliate him.

original: How Martin, with much ado, showed them both a fair pair of heels.
modernized: Martin struggled mightily, managing to escape from both of them.

original: How a new warrant came out against Peter, upon which Jack left him in the lurch, stole his protection, and made use of it himself.
modernized: Soon after, a warrant was issued for Peter, causing Jack to leave him to his own devices. Jack then used Peter's protection and took advantage of it for himself.

original: How Jack's tatters came into fashion in court and city; how he got upon a great horse and ate custard.
modernized: Jack's peculiar fashion choices became popular in court and the city, eventually getting him on a great horse and allowing him to eat custard.

original: But the particulars of all these, with several others which have now slid out of my memory, are lost beyond all hopes of recovery.
modernized: Unfortunately, those specific details, along with other incidents that are now fading from my memory, are gone forever.

original: For which misfortune, leaving my readers to condole with each other as far as they shall find it to agree with their several constitutions, but conjuring them by all the friendship that has passed between us, from the title-page to this, not to proceed so far as to injure their healths for an accident past remedy, I now go on to the ceremonial part of an accomplished writer, and therefore by a courtly modern least of all others to be omitted.
modernized: For this unfortunate setback, I urge my readers to commiserate with one another, acknowledging that their experiences may differ. I implore them, given our previous bond, not to read too much, for fear of harming their health, due to an unavoidable accident.

original: One thing I might add, as another acknowledged maxim in that party, and in my opinion, as dangerous to the constitution as any I have mentioned; I mean, that of preferring, on all occasions, the moneyed interest before the landed; which they were so far from denying, that they would gravely debate the reasonableness and justice of it; and at the rate they went on, might in a little time have found a majority of representatives, fitly qualified to lay those heavy burthens on the rest of the nation, which themselves would not touch with one of their fingers.
modernized: One point I would emphasize, as a widely accepted principle within their party, and in my view, potentially harmful to the constitution: their tendency to always prioritize the financial interests over the landowning class. Not only do they openly discuss the legitimacy of this approach, but they were progressing towards having a majority of influential representatives who could impose excessive taxes on the rest of the nation, despite avoiding such taxes themselves.

original: When your Linen is pinned on the Line, or on a Hedge, and it rains, whip it off, although you tear it, &c.
modernized: Remove dripping clothes from the line or hedge when it rains, even if they get torn in the process.

original: But the Place for hanging them, is on young Fruit Trees, especially in Blossom; the Linen cannot be torn, and the Trees give them a fine Smell.
modernized: The best location to hang clothes is on young fruit trees, especially during blossom; the trees provide a pleasant scent and the clothes won't get torn.

original: If your Master or Mistress happens to walk the Streets, keep on one Side and as much on the Level with them as you can, which People observing, will either think you do not belong to them, or that you are one of their Companions; but, if either of them happen to turn back and speak to you, so that you are under the Necessity to take off your Hat, use but your Thumb and one Finger, and scratch your Head with the rest.
modernized: When your employer happens to take a walk outside, walk alongside them at a similar height. Onlookers will assume either you aren't their servant or you're a companion. However, if your employer turns back and addresses you directly, removing your hat, simply use your thumb and index finger to scratch your head with the rest of your fingers.

original: But in the mean time the Queen was firmly resolved, that the interests of her own kingdoms should not be neglected at this juncture, as they had formerly twice been, while the Dutch were principal managers of a negotiation with France.
modernized: During this time, the Queen insisted on prioritizing the interests of her own kingdoms during negotiations with France, as they had been previously overlooked when the Dutch were in charge.

original: Her Majesty had given frequent and early notice to the States, of the general disposition of her people towards a peace, of her own inability to continue the war upon the old foot, under the disadvantage of unequal quotas, and the universal backwardness of her allies.
modernized: The Queen frequently communicated her subjects' desire for peace, and her difficulties in continuing the war under the disadvantage of unequal contributions and resistance from allies.

original: She had likewise informed them of several advances made to her on the side of France, which she had refused to hearken to, till she had consulted with those, her good friends and confederates, and heard their opinion on that subject: but the Dutch, who apprehended nothing more than to see Britain at the head of a treaty, were backward and sullen, disliked all proposals by the Queen's intervention, and said it was a piece of artifice of France to divide the allies; besides, they knew the ministry was young, and the opposite faction had given them assurances, that the people of England would never endure a peace without Spain, nor the men in power dare to attempt it, after the resolutions of one House of Parliament to the contrary.
modernized: She also informed the allies of various overtures made by France that she declined to accept, until she consulted with her allies for their opinion on the matter. However, the Dutch, fearing a treaty led by Britain, were reluctant and resentful about the Queen's involvement and believed France was attempting to divide the allies. Additionally, they knew the English government was new, and had been assured the people would not tolerate a peace without Spain.

original: But, in the midst of this unwillingness to receive any overtures from France by the Queen's hands, the Dutch ministers were actually engaged in a correspondence with that court, where they urged our inability to begin a treaty, by reason of those factions which themselves had inflamed, and were ready to commence a negotiation upon much easier terms than what they supposed we demanded.
modernized: In spite of their resistance, the Dutch ministers were secretly negotiating with France, suggesting that Britain's inability to initiate a treaty was due to internal conflicts, and they were prepared to start negotiations on more favorable terms than they anticipated.

original: For not to mention the Duke of Lorraine's interposition in behalf of Holland, which France absolutely refused to accept; the letters sent from the Dutch to that court, were shewn some months after to a British minister there, which gave much weight to Monsieur de Torcy's insinuations; that he knew where to meet with more compliance, if the necessity of affairs should force him to it, by our refusal.
modernized: This correspondence, however, was rejected by France, and letters from the Dutch to that court were shown to a British minister later on, which supported Monsieur de Torcy's claims that he could find more willingness to agree if Britain refused.

original: And the violence of the States against our entertaining of that correspondence, was only because they knew theirs would never be accepted, at least till ours were thrown off.
modernized: The Dutch's hostility towards our engagement in this correspondence was because they believed their own would not be accepted, until Britain's was rejected first.

original: Neither shall I mingle panegyric or satire with an history intended to inform posterity, as well as to instruct those of the present age, who may be ignorant or misled; since facts, truly related, are the best applauses, or most lasting reproaches.
modernized: A Clear and Unbiased History: I will ensure that this account of relevant domestic affairs, during the last session of Parliament, as well as our foreign peace negotiations, will be presented without the addition of praise or criticism. The truth of each event, as it truly occurred, serves as the most effective form of commendation or severe criticism.

original: These foreigners, generally called Flemings by the writers of the English story, were a sort of vagabond soldiers of fortune, who in those ages, under several denominations, infested other parts of Europe as well as England: they were a mixed people, natives of Arragon, Navarre, Biscay, Brabant, and other parts of Spain and Flanders.
modernized: In England, these foreign mercenaries, often referred to as Flemish in English historical texts, were a mixed group of wandering soldiers from various parts of Spain and Flanders, such as Arragon, Navarre, Biscay, and Brabant.

original: They were ready to be hired to whatever prince thought fit to employ them, but always upon condition to have full liberty of plunder and spoil.
modernized: These foreign mercenaries could be hired by any prince, but always demanded complete freedom to loot and pillage.

original: Nor was it an easy matter to get rid of them, when there was no further need of their service.
modernized: Removing these foreign mercenaries was difficult once they were no longer needed.

original: In England they were always hated by the people, and by this prince in particular, whose continual enemies they had been.
modernized: In England, the general population and this specific prince have strongly disliked the foreigners, as they have been their consistent adversaries.

original: To supply the want of such a law, several pious persons, in many parts of this kingdom, have been prevailed on, by the great endeavours and good example set them by the clergy, to erect charity-schools in several parishes, to which very often the richest parishioners contribute the least.
modernized: In order to compensate for the lack of legislation, numerous compassionate individuals, in various regions of this kingdom, have been persuaded by the significant efforts and positive influence of the clergy to establish charity schools in numerous parishes. Oftentimes, the wealthiest parishioners contribute minimally.

original: In those schools, children are, or ought to be, trained up to read and write, and cast accounts; and these children should, if possible, be of honest parents, gone to decay through age, sickness, or other unavoidable calamity, by the hand of God; not the brood of wicked strollers; for it is by no means reasonable, that the charity of well-inclined people should be applied to encourage the lewdness of those profligate, abandoned women, who crowd our streets with their borrowed or spurious issue.
modernized: In these schools, children are, or should be, educated to read, write, and perform basic mathematics. Ideally, these children should, when possible, be of law-abiding parents who have fallen on hard times due to age, illness, or unavoidable misfortune. They should not be the children of wandering, immoral women who fill our streets with their illegitimate offspring. It is unreasonable for charitable donors' funds to encourage the licentious behavior of these abandoned, profligate women.

original: We have heard of men, who, through greediness of gain, have brought infected goods into a nation; which bred a plague, whereof the owners and their families perished first.
modernized: We have heard of individuals, motivated by greed, who smuggled poor quality goods into a country, causing a plague that affected the owners and their families first.

original: Let those among us consider this and tremble, whose houses are privately stored with those materials of beggary and desolation, lately brought over to be scattered like a pestilence among their countrymen, which may probably first seize upon themselves and their families, until their houses shall be made a dunghill.
modernized: Anyone who stores products that could lead to poverty and destruction, secretly brought in recently to spread such effects among their fellow citizens, should reflect upon this and be fearful. These materials may first impact them and their families until their homes become uninhabitable.

original: It is certain, that a firm union in any country, where every man wishes the same thing with relation to the public, may, in several points of the greatest importance, in some measure, supply the defect of power; and even of those rights which are the natural and undoubted inheritance of mankind.
modernized: A national agreement, where everyone desires the same public outcome, can, in crucial aspects, offset the power deficit and even some of the rights that are mankind's natural inheritance.

original: If the universal wish of the nation upon any point, were declared by the unanimous vote of the House of Commons, and a reasonable number of Lords; I should think myself obliged in conscience to act in my sphere according to that vote; because, in all free nations, I take the proper definition of law to be the will of the majority of those who have the property in land; which, if there be a monarchy, is to be confirmed by the royal assent.
modernized: If the nation's consensus on any issue is expressed by the unanimous vote of the House of Commons, and a suitable number of Lords, I would feel personally obligated to follow this consensus in my role, because in free countries, I consider the law to be the majority's will among landed property owners, which needs the king's approval if there is a monarchy.

original: And, although such votes or declarations have not received such a confirmation, for certain accidental reasons; yet I think they ought to be of much weight with the subject; provided they neither oppose the King's prerogative, endanger the peace of the nation, nor infringe any law already in force; none of which, however, can reasonably be supposed.
modernized: Although such consensus declarations haven't received the king's approval for some accidental reasons, I believe they should carry significant weight among the subjects, as long as they don't conflict with the king's rights, jeopardize the country's peace, or breach existing laws, which should not be expected to occur.

original: Thus, for instance, if nine in ten of the House of Commons, and a reasonable number of native temporal peers, should declare, that whoever received or uttered brass coin, except under certain limitations and securities, should be deemed as enemies to the King and the nation; I should think it a heinous sin in myself to act contrary to such a vote: And, if the same power should declare the same censure against those who wore Indian stuffs and calicoes, or woollen manufactures imported from abroad, whereby this nation is reduced to the lowest ebb of misery; I should readily, heartily, and cheerfully pay obedience; and to my utmost power persuade others to do the like: Because, there is no law of this land obliging us either to receive such coin, or to wear such foreign manufactures.
modernized: For example, if nine out of ten members of the House of Commons and a reasonable number of native temporal peers were to declare that any individual receiving or uttering brass coins, without certain conditions and guarantees, would be considered enemies of the king and the nation, I would consider it a grave sin not to comply with such a declaration: Similarly, if the same power were to censure people wearing imported Indian cloth, calicoes, or foreign woollen manufactures, which have led our country to extreme poverty, I would willingly and resolutely obey; and I'd do my best to persuade others to do the same, as no law in our land forces us to use such coins or foreign goods.

original: The Parliament sat as long as the approaching festival would allow; and upon the twenty-second, the land-tax and occasional bills having received the royal assent, the House of Commons adjourned to the fourteenth of January following: but the adjournment of the Lords was only to the second, the prevailing party there being in haste to pursue the consequences of the Earl of Nottingham's clause, which they hoped would end in the ruin of the treasurer, and overthrow the ministry; and therefore took the advantage of this interval, that they might not be disturbed by the Commons.
modernized: The Parliament remained in session until permitted by the upcoming holiday, and on the 22nd, with the royal approval, the land tax and temporary church bills were passed. In response, the House of Commons adjourned until the 14th of January. However, the Lords adjourned only until the 2nd, as the majority party there was eager to act on the Earl of Nottingham's clause, hoping it would destabilize the treasurer and bring down the government. They seized this gap to avoid interference from the House of Commons.

original: For if we only consider how this kingdom swarms with quadrille-tables, and gaming-houses, both public and private; and also how each of those houses, as well as Westminster-Hall aforesaid, swarms with knaves who are anxious to win, or fools who have anything to lose; we may be soon convinced how necessary it will be to limit the number of incurables, comprehended under these titles, lest the foundation should prove insufficient to maintain any others besides them.
modernized: Considering the abundance of places to play quadrille and gamble in this kingdom, both publicly and privately, as well as the large number of dishonest individuals at these establishments, including Westminster-Hall, it might be crucial to limit the number of people considered 'incurables' in order to maintain a sufficient number of beds in the hospital for others who may require care.

original: It is to be observed, that these ambassadors spoke to me by an interpreter, the languages of both empires differing as much from each other as any two in Europe, and each nation priding itself upon the antiquity, beauty, and energy of its own tongue, with an avowed contempt for that of its neighbor; yet our emperor, standing upon the advantage he had got by the seizure of their fleet, obliged them to deliver their credentials, and make their speech in the Lilliputian tongue.
modernized: It should be noted that the ambassadors spoke to me through a translator, as the languages of both empires were quite distinct. Each nation boasted of the antiquity, beauty, and power of its own language, with a clear disdain for the other. Nevertheless, our emperor, using the advantage he gained from capturing their fleet, demanded that they present their credentials and address him in the Lilliputian language.

original: Soon after the restoration of King Charles the Second, the parliament taking into consideration the miserable estate of the Church, certain lands, by way of augmentation, were granted to eight bishops in the act of settlement, and confirmed in the act of explanation; of which bounty, as I remember, three sees were, in a great measure, defeated; but by what accidents, it is not here of any importance to relate.
modernized: After the return of King Charles II to the throne, the parliament, considering the poor state of the Church, offered eight bishops some land as an improvement, and this offer was confirmed in legislation. It is recalled that three sees did not benefit much from this act, but the specific circumstances are not relevant here.

original: Lastly, I observe that the author of the paper called The Englishman, hath run into the same cant, gravely advising the whole body of the clergy not to bring in Popery, because that will put them under a necessity of parting with their wives, or losing their livings.
modernized: Lastly, I notice that the author of 'The Englishman' paper advises all clergy members against adopting Papistry, as they would risk losing their wives or their jobs as a result.

original: Infant's flesh will be in season throughout the year, but more plentiful in March, and a little before and after; for we are told by a grave author, an eminent French physician, that fish being a prolifick dyet, there are more children born in Roman Catholick countries about nine months after Lent, the markets will be more glutted than usual, because the number of Popish infants, is at least three to one in this kingdom, and therefore it will have one other collateral advantage, by lessening the number of Papists among us.
modernized: Infant's meat will be available year-round, but will be more abundant in March and around that time. According to a renowned French physician, fish is a fertility-inducing diet, resulting in more births in Catholic nations nine months after Lent. As a result, there will be an increased supply in these regions, specifically since the ratio of Catholic infants to the rest of the kingdom is at least 3:1. This will also have a secondary benefit of reducing the number of Catholics among us.

original: Whereas had but any other person entered with us into a vow so solemn, that he had taken the Holy Sacrament upon it, I believe had he but once deceived us by breaking in upon the vow, we should hardly ever after be prevailed upon to trust that man again, though we still continue to trust our own fears, against reason and against experience.
modernized: If any other person were to make such a serious promise to us, especially involving the Holy Sacrament, and then break it, we would find it difficult to trust them again, even if we still harbor doubts and act against reason and prior experience.

original: It is clear, from present experience, that the bare example of the best prince will not have any mighty influence, where the age is very corrupt.
modernized: From what we've seen, the influence of even the best ruler is insignificant when dealing with a highly corrupt society.

original: For, when was there ever a better prince on the throne than the present Queen?
modernized: Has there ever been a better ruler on the throne than the current queen?

original: I do not talk of her talent for government, her love of the people, or any other qualities that are purely regal; but her piety, charity, temperance, conjugal love, and whatever other virtues do best adorn a private life; wherein, without question or flattery, she hath no superior: yet, neither will it be satire or peevish invective to affirm, that infidelity and vice are not much diminished since her coming to the crown, nor will, in all probability, till some more effectual remedies be provided.
modernized: I'm not discussing her governing skills or affection for the people, but rather her personal virtues like piety, charity, temperance, and conjugal love, which, without a doubt or flattery, she excels in. However, it should not be seen as criticism or petty complaining to say that infidelity and vice have not decreased since her ascension to the throne, and probably won't until more effective solutions are implemented.

original: This Passion Week, people are so demure, especially this last day, that I told Dilly, who called here, that I would dine with him, and so I did, faith; and had a small shoulder of mutton of my own bespeaking.
modernized: During the Holy Week, particularly today, people have been very reserved. I told Dilly, who visited me, that I would dine with him, and I did. I also had a small shoulder of mutton prepared in advance.

original: It rained all day. I came home at seven, and have never stirred out, but have been reading Sacheverell's long dull sermon, which he sent me.
modernized: It has rained all day. When I returned home at 7 o'clock, I haven't left since then, spending the time reading Sacheverell's lengthy and dull sermon that he sent me.

original: It is the first sermon since his suspension is expired; but not a word in it upon the occasion, except two or three remote hints.
modernized: This is the first sermon since the suspension ended, but there's no mention of the occasion except for a couple of subtle hints.

original: The Bishop of Clogher has been sadly bit by Tom Ashe, who sent him a pun, which the Bishop had made, and designed to send to him, but delayed it; and Lord Pembroke and I made Sir Andrew Fountaine write it to Tom.
modernized: The Bishop of Clogher received a joke from Tom Ashe, which the Bishop had create but delayed sending. Lord Pembroke and I had Sir Andrew Fountaine write it to Tom.

original: I believe I told you of it in my last; it succeeded right, and the Bishop was wondering to Lord Pembroke how he and his brother could hit on the same thing.
modernized: I mentioned this to you in my previous letter; it was successful, and the Bishop was surprised to Lord Pembroke about how both brothers came up with the same humor.

original: I'll go to bed soon, for I must be at church by eight tomorrow, Easter Day.
modernized: I will go to bed soon, as I need to be at church by 8:00 AM tomorrow, Easter Day.

original: If so wretched a state of things would allow it, methinks I could have a malicious pleasure, after all the warning I have in vain given the public, at my own peril, for several years past, to see the consequences and events answering in every particular.
modernized: If the current situation allowed it, I'd secretly take pleasure to see the disastrous consequences and outcomes of my repeated warnings to the public, despite putting myself at risk for several years.

original: I pretend to no sagacity: what I writ was little more than what I had discoursed to several persons, who were generally of my opinion; and it was obvious to every common understanding, that such effects must needs follow from such causes; -- a fair issue of things begun upon party rage, while some sacrificed the public to fury, and others to ambition: while a spirit of faction and oppression reigned in every part of the country, where gentlemen, instead of consulting the ease of their tenants, or cultivating their lands, were worrying one another upon points of Whig and Tory, of High Church and Low Church; which no more concerned them than the long and famous controversy of strops for razors: while agriculture was wholly discouraged, and consequently half the farmers and labourers, and poorer tradesmen, forced to beggary or banishment.
modernized: What I wrote was merely a reflection of conversations I had with several people, who generally shared my opinion. It was obvious to any common sense that such results had to occur due to the causes at hand: a chain of events initiated by political strife, where some sacrificed the public interest for personal anger, and others for ambition; a widespread atmosphere of faction and oppression invaded every region of the country, where landowners prioritized squabbles over political affiliations over the welfare of their tenants, their lands, and agriculture; agricultural practices were neglected, leading to many farmers, laborers, and small tradesmen being forced into poverty or exile.

original: Wisdom crieth in the streets: Because I have called on ye; I have stretched out my hand, and no man regarded; but ye have set at nought all my counsels, and would none of my reproof; I also will laugh at your calamity, and mock when your fear cometh.
modernized: Wisdom cries out in the streets: I called on you; I extended my hand, but no one listened; yet you rejected all my advice and ignored my warnings. I will laugh at your misfortune and mock when your fear comes.

original: It were endless to recount the several methods of tyranny and destruction which your governor is pleased to practise upon this occasion.
modernized: The governor's practices of tyranny and destruction on this particular occasion are countless.

original: His inveterate malice is such to the writings of our age, that, of several thousands produced yearly from this renowned city, before the next revolution of the sun there is not one to be heard of.
modernized: Many of the writings from our city, produced annually, disappear without a trace as a result of the governor's malice. His hostility towards the writings of the age makes countless works vanish before they become known.

original: Unhappy infants! many of them barbarously destroyed before they have so much as learnt their mother-tongue to beg for pity.
modernized: Unfortunate infants! Many are destroyed cruelly before they even learn their mother tongue, begging for sympathy.

original: Some he stifles in their cradles, others he frights into convulsions, whereof they suddenly die, some he flays alive, others he tears limb from limb, great numbers are offered to Moloch, and the rest, tainted by his breath, die of a languishing consumption.
modernized: Some infants he smothers in their cradles, while others suffer convulsions from fright, leading to their sudden death. Some he flays alive, others he tears apart limb by limb. A large number are sacrificed to Moloch, while the rest die of a slow, lingering consumption attributed to the governor's harmful breath.

original: Upon this occasion I cannot but take notice, that of all the heresies in politics, profusely scattered by the partisans of the late administration, none ever displeased me more, or seemed to have more dangerous consequences to monarchy, than that pernicious talent so much affected, of discovering a contempt for birth, family, and ancient nobility.
modernized: In this situation, I cannot help but notice that among all the political heresies spread by the supporters of the previous administration, none have displeased me more or seemed to pose more dangerous consequences for monarchy than the recurring disrespect for ancestors, noble families, and established nobility.

original: All the threadbare topics of poets and orators were displayed to discover to us, that merit and virtue were the only nobility; and that the advantages of blood, could not make a knave or a fool either honest or wise.
modernized: Poets and orators have repeatedly showed us that only merit and virtue are the source of nobility, and that family lineage or heritage cannot transform a dishonest or foolish individual into an honest or wise person.

original: Most popular commotions we read of in histories of Greece and Rome, took their rise from unjust quarrels to the nobles; and in the latter, the plebeians' encroachments on the patricians, were the first cause of their ruin.
modernized: Throughout history, popular uprisings originated from unjust disputes with the nobility, and in Rome, the plebeians' power grabs contributed to the downfall of the patricians.

original: That true Merit, was the son of Virtue and Honour; but that there was likewise a spurious child who usurped the name, and whose parents were Vanity and Impudence.
modernized: Merit is the product of Virtue and Honor, but there is also a counterfeit version created by Vanity and Arrogance.

original: That, at a distance, there was a great resemblance between them, and they were often mistaken for each other.
modernized: From afar, the two look quite similar and are often mistaken for each other.

original: That the bastard issue had a loud shrill voice, which was perpetually employed in cravings and complaints; while the other never spoke louder than a whisper, and was often so bashful that he could not speak at all.
modernized: The counterfeit Merit has a loud, shrill voice that constantly demands and complains, whereas the true Merit rarely speaks and sometimes appears shy.

original: That in all great assemblies, the false Merit would step before the true, and stand just in his way; was constantly at court, or great men's levees, or whispering in some minister's ear.
modernized: In important gatherings, the fake Merit steps in front of the true Merit, often attempting to gain the attention of high-ranking officials.

original: That the more you fed him, the more hungry and importunate he grew.
modernized: The more one feeds the fake Merit, the more demanding and insistent it becomes.

original: That he often passed for the true son of Virtue and Honour, and the genuine for an impostor.
modernized: People often mistake the fake Merit for the genuine one, while the true Merit is mistaken for a fraud.

original: That he was born distorted and a dwarf, but by force of art appeared of a handsome shape, and taller than the usual size; and that none but those who were wise and good, as well as vigilant, could discover his littleness or deformity.
modernized: Although the true Merit may appear normal at first glance, it is only due to artifices; only those who are wise, good, and vigilant can see its flaws and deformities.

original: That the true Merit had been often forced to the indignity of applying to the false, for his credit with those in power, and to keep himself from starving.
modernized: The true Merit is often forced to appeal to the fake Merit to gain recognition and prevent itself from starving.

original: That he filled the antechambers with a crew of his dependants and creatures, such as projectors, schematises, occasional converts to a party, prostitute flatterers, starveling writers, buffoons, shallow politicians, empty orators, and the like, who all owned him for their patron, and grew discontented if they were not immediately fed.
modernized: The fake Merit surrounds itself with followers who are projectors, schematizers, opportunists, flatterers, struggling writers, buffoons, shallow politicians, empty speakers, and the like. These individuals are unhappy if they are not quickly rewarded.

original: I forgot to tell you that Lord Treasurer forced me to dine with him yesterday as usual, with his Saturday company; which I did after frequent refusals.
modernized: Yesterday, Lord Treasurer insisted that I have dinner with him and his usual Saturday company, despite my repeated refusals.

original: To-day I dined with a private friend, and was not at Court.
modernized: Today, I dined with a private friend and did not attend Court.

original: After dinner Mr. Lewis sent me a note, that the Queen stayed till she knew whether the Duke of Ormond approved of Sterne for Bishop.
modernized: In the evening, Mr. Lewis informed me that the Queen waited to learn if the Duke of Ormond approved of Sterne for Bishop.

original: I went this evening, and found the Duke of Ormond at the Cockpit, and told him, and desired he would go to the Queen, and approve of Sterne.
modernized: I went to the Cockpit and told the Duke of Ormond to speak with the Queen in support of Sterne's nomination for Bishop.

original: He made objections, desired I would name any other deanery, for he did not like Sterne; that Sterne never went to see him; that he was influenced by the Archbishop of Dublin, etc.; so all now is broken again.
modernized: The Duke of Ormond raised objections, expressing his displeasure with Sterne, stating that Sterne never visited him, and that he was influenced by the Archbishop of Dublin, causing the whole plan to fall apart.

original: I sent out for Lord Treasurer, and told him this.
modernized: I sent for Lord Treasurer and shared the details of this development with

original: He says all will do well; but I value not what he says.
modernized: He assures me everything will be fine, but I do not put much faith in his words.

original: This suspense vexes me worse than anything else.
modernized: This prolonged uncertainty bothers me more than anything else.

original: Besides the large box in which I was usually carried, the queen ordered a smaller one to be made for me, of about twelve feet square, and ten high, for the convenience of travelling; because the other was somewhat too large for Glumdalclitch's lap, and cumbersome in the coach; it was made by the same artist, whom I directed in the whole contrivance.
modernized: The queen requested a travel-friendly, smaller box for me, approximately 12 feet by 10 feet, due to my previous box being too large for my nurse, Glumdalclitch, and inconvenient in the coach. The same craftsman from before was tasked to create this new box, following my instructions for the overall design.

original: This travelling-closet was an exact square, with a window in the middle of three of the squares, and each window was latticed with iron wire on the outside, to prevent accidents in long journeys.
modernized: This travel-closet had three walls with windows, with iron bars on the outside for safety during long trips.

original: On the fourth side, which had no window, two strong staples were fixed, through which the person that carried me, when I had a mind to be on horseback, put a leathern belt, and buckled it about his waist.
modernized: On the fourth side, devoid of a window, there were two strong staples for attaching a leather belt, which a trustworthy servant would wear around their waist, allowing me to be carried on horseback.

original: This was always the office of some grave trusty servant, in whom I could confide, whether I attended the king and queen in their progresses, or were disposed to see the gardens, or pay a visit to some great lady or minister of state in the court, when Glumdalclitch happened to be out of order; for I soon began to be known and esteemed among the greatest officers, I suppose more upon account of their majesties' favour, than any merit of my own.
modernized: This servant was always responsible for me, assisting me in attending the king and queen during their travels, visiting gardens, or meeting important individuals in the court, when my nurse was unavailable. I gained respect among high-ranking officials, perhaps more due to the influence of the royal family rather than any personal merits.

original: In journeys, when I was weary of the coach, a servant on horseback would buckle on my box, and place it upon a cushion before him; and there I had a full prospect of the country on three sides, from my three windows.
modernized: When I grew tired during travel by coach, a servant on horseback would attach my box to a cushion in front of them, allowing me to view the surrounding countryside from three sides through the windows.

original: I had, in this closet, a field-bed and a hammock, hung from the ceiling, two chairs and a table, neatly screwed to the floor, to prevent being tossed about by the agitation of the horse or the coach.
modernized: In this box, I had a foldable bed, a hammock hanging from the ceiling, along with two chairs and a table, securely fastened to the floor to prevent movement during the rocking of the horse or coach.

original: And having been long used to sea-voyages, those motions, although sometimes very violent, did not much discompose me.
modernized: Having spent much time on sea-voyages, the motions, despite occasionally being very intense, did not causing me significant discomfort.

original: The humour of exploding many things under the name of trifles, fopperies, and only imaginary goods, is a very false proof either of wisdom or magnanimity, and a great check to virtuous actions.
modernized: Treating insignificant objects and possessions as important matters discourages wise and virtuous actions.

original: For instance, with regard to fame, there is in most people a reluctance and unwillingness to be forgotten.
modernized: People generally have a resistance and reluctance towards being forgotten, even among common folks.

original: We observe, even among the vulgar, how fond they are to have an inscription over their grave.
modernized: There is a strong desire, even among uneducated individuals, to have a memorial inscription on their grave.

original: It requires but little philosophy to discover and observe that there is no intrinsic value in all this; however, if it be founded in our nature as an incitement to virtue, it ought not to be ridiculed.
modernized: It takes little wisdom to perceive that there is no real value in such exhibitions; but if it motivates virtuous actions, it should not be dismissed as trivial.

original: His death was violent and unexpected, the effect of casualty; although this perhaps is the only misfortune of life to which the person of a prince is generally less subject than that of other men.
modernized: The King's death was violent and unexpected, and it's rare for a monarch to face such misfortunes less frequently than common people.

original: Being at his beloved exercise of hunting in the New Forest in Hampshire, a large stag crossed the way before him, the King hot on his game, cried out in haste to Walter Tyrrel, a knight of his attendants, to shoot; Tyrrel, immediately let fly his arrow, which glancing against a tree, struck the King through the heart, who fell dead to the ground without speaking a word.
modernized: While the King was hunting in the New Forest, a large stag appeared before him. In his excitement, he commanded knight Walter Tyrrel to shoot, and Tyrrel's arrow inadvertently struck the King through the heart, causing his immediate death.

original: Upon the surprise of this accident, all his attendants, and Tyrrel among the rest, fled different ways; until the fright being a little over, some of them returned, and causing the body to be laid in a collier's cart, for want of other conveniency, conveyed it in a very unbecoming contemptuous manner to Winchester, where it was buried the next day without solemnity, and which is worse, without grief.
modernized: In shock, all the attendants, including Tyrrel, ran away in different directions. After some time, they brought the body to a cart for lack of other means, and they conveyed the King's remains disrespectfully to Winchester, where he was buried the following day without proper ceremony or mourning.

original: About the same time he performed two acts of justice, which, by gratifying the revenge and the love of the people, gained very much upon their affections to his person: the first was, to imprison Ralph Bishop of Durham, who having been raised by the late king from a mean and sordid birth to be his prime confidant and minister, became the chief instrument, as well as contriver, of all his oppressions: the second was, in recalling and restoring Archbishop Anselm, who having been forced by the continual persecutions of the same prince, to leave England, had lived ever since in banishment, and deprived of all his revenues.
modernized: During the same time period, King Henry III did two just acts that strongly appealed to the people's revenge and affection towards him. Firstly: he imprisoned Bishop Ralph of Durham, who, elevated from a lowly background by the previous king and became his chief advisor, was involved in many of his oppressions. Secondly: he recalled and restored Archbishop Anselm, who had been forced into exile due to the constant persecutions of the same king, and had been living without any revenues since.

original: To conclude, whatever some may think of the great advantages to trade by this favourite scheme, I do very much apprehend that in six months' time after the Act is passed for the extirpation of the Gospel, the Bank and East India stock may fall at least one per cent.
modernized: When this scheme is enacted to eliminate Christianity, I fear the Bank and East India stock might drop by at least 1% within six months.

original: And since that is fifty times more than ever the wisdom of our age thought fit to venture for the preservation of Christianity, there is no reason we should be at so great a loss merely for the sake of destroying it.
modernized: This is fifty times less than what our society has ever been willing to risk to preserve Christianity, thus there's no justification for such a huge loss for the sole purpose of its annihilation.

original: The author sent for to court.
modernized: The author is summoned to the court.

original: The queen buys him of his master the farmer, and presents him to the king.
modernized: The queen buys the author from his farmer master and introduces him to the king.

original: He disputes with his majesty's great scholars.
modernized: The author debates with the king's learned scholars.

original: An apartment at court provided for the author.
modernized: The author is assigned living quarters at court.

original: He is in high favour with the queen.
modernized: The author enjoys favor with the queen.

original: He stands up for the honour of his own country.
modernized: The author defends the honor of his own country.

original: His quarrels with the queen's dwarf.
modernized: The author has conflicts with the queen's dwarf.

original: What people then, are these in a corner, to whom the constitution must truckle?
modernized: Who are these individuals, hidden in the corner, that the constitution must appease?

original: If the whole nation's credit cannot supply funds for the war, without humble application from the entire legislature to a few retailers of money, it is high time we should sue for a peace.
modernized: If the entire nation's credit is insufficient to fund the war, and the legislature must humbly approach a few lenders for funds, it's past time to seek peace.

original: What new maxims are these, which neither we nor our forefathers ever heard of before, and which no wise institution would ever allow?
modernized: What are these unheard-of rules that neither our ancestors nor we have known, and that no prudent institution would tolerate?

original: Must our laws from henceforward pass the Bank and East India Company, or have their royal assent before they are in force?
modernized: From now on, will our laws need to be approved by the Bank and East India Company, or receive the monarch's consent before they become law?

original: But this is beside my present design, which was only to show what degree of reformation is in the power of the Queen, without the interposition of the legislature, and which her Majesty is, without question, obliged in conscience to endeavour by her authority, as much as she does by her practice.
modernized: My current goal is to demonstrate the extent of reform the Queen can achieve without involving the legislature, and how she, morally, should try to do so using her authority. According to her actions, she is already doing this to some degree.

original: For my own part, I am already resolved what to do; I have a pretty good shop of Irish stuffs and silks, and instead of taking Mr. Wood's bad copper, I intend to truck with my neighbours the butchers, and bakers, and brewers, and the rest, goods for goods, and the little gold and silver I have, I will keep by me like my heart's blood till better times, or till I am just ready to starve, and then I will buy Mr. Wood's money as my father did the brass money in K. James's time, who could buy ten pound of it with a guinea, and I hope to get as much for a pistole, and so purchase bread from those who will be such fools as to sell it me.
modernized: For my own part, I've made up my mind about what to do. I have a decent store of Irish goods and silks, and instead of accepting Mr. Wood's poor copper coins, I intend to trade with my local neighbors - the butchers, bakers, brewers, and others - by exchanging goods for goods. The small amount of gold and silver I have, I plan to keep as if it were my lifeblood until better times or until I'm on the verge of starvation. Then, I'll buy Mr. Wood's coins like my father did during King James's time when he could exchange ten pounds for a guinea, and I hope I can get as much for a pistole. With this, I can buy food from those foolish enough to sell it to me.

original: I must caution you particularly against my Lord's eldest Son: If you are dextrous enough, it is odds that you may draw him in to marry you, and make you a Lady: If he be a common Rake, (and he must be one or t'other) avoid him like Satan; for he stands less in Awe of a Mother, than my Lord doth of a Wife; and, after ten thousand Promises, you will get nothing from him, but a big Belly or a Clap, and probably both together.
modernized: I strongly advise you to be cautious about my Lord's eldest son. If you manage well, you might convince him to marry you, potentially making you a lady. However, if he is a womanizer (as he probably is), stay away from him as you would Satan, because he respects his mother less than his wife, and after numerous promises, he may only lead to heartache or pregnancy. Specifically, he could cause both unwanted situations.

original: When I attempted to catch any of these birds they would boldly turn against me, endeavoring to pick my fingers, which I durst not venture within their reach; and then they would hop back unconcerned to hunt for worms and snails as they did before.
modernized: Upon trying to catch these birds, they aggressively turned on me, attempting to peck my fingers. I didn't dare approach closely as they retreated unconcerned to search for worms and snails as they had done earlier.

original: But one day I took a thick cudgel, and threw it with all my strength so luckily at a linnet that I knocked him down, and seizing him by the neck with both my hands ran with him in triumph to my nurse.
modernized: Feeling triumphant, I once picked up a thick club and hurled it with great force at a linnet, knocking it down. I then approached it, grabbing it by the neck and ran off with it to my nurse.

original: However, the bird, who had only been stunned, recovering himself, gave me so many boxes with his wings on both sides of my head and body, though I held him at arm's length and was out of the reach of his claws, that I was twenty times thinking of letting him go.
modernized: However, the stunned bird, recovering, started attacking me with its wings, giving me 20 moments of hesitation as I considered letting it go. Despite being out of reach of its claws, I was still hit repeatedly by its wings.

original: But I was soon relieved by one of our servants, who wrung off the bird's neck, and I had him next day for dinner by the queen's command.
modernized: Luckily, a servant stepped in and broke the bird's neck, after which I ate it for dinner, as per the queen's command.

original: This linnet, as near as I can remember, seemed to be somewhat larger than an English swan.
modernized: This linnet appeared to be significantly larger than an English swan.

original: By these descriptions of Whig and Tory, I am sensible those names are given to several persons very undeservedly; and that many a man is called by one or the other, who has not the least title to the blame or praise I have bestowed on each of them throughout my papers.
modernized: I acknowledge that the labels of Whig and Tory have been mistakenly applied to numerous individuals, and many persons who do not deserve my criticism or praise have been identified as such in my previous writings.

original: The farmer will find no relief by this Modus, because, when his present lease shall expire, his landlord will infallibly raise the rent in an equal proportion, upon every part of land where flax is sown, and have so much a better security for payment at the expense of the Clergy.
modernized: The farmer won't escape higher rent when his lease ends, as landlords will increase rent proportionally on all lands cultivated with flax, drawing more security for payments at the Clergy's expense.

original: Her Majesty likewise pressed France by the same dispatches, to send full instructions to their plenipotentiaries, empowering them to offer to the allies such a plan of peace, as might give reasonable satisfaction to all her allies.
modernized: The Queen also requested France, through the same messengers, to instruct their representatives to propose a peace plan to the allies that would be satisfactory to all of her allies.

original: Therefore concluding myself to be thus far upon a safe and sure foot; I shall continue, upon any proper occasion, as God enables me, to revive and preserve that spirit raised in the nation, (whether the real author were a real Drapier or no is little to the purpose) against this horrid design of Mr. Wood; at the same time carefully watching every stroke of my pen, and venturing only to incur the public censure of the world as a writer; not of my Lord Chief Justice Whitshed, as a criminal.
modernized: Thus assured of this, I will persist, whenever possible, in upholding and maintaining the national spirit aroused (regardless of whether the true Drapier is real or not) against Mr. Wood's nefarious scheme. Simultaneously, I will be cautious about everything I write and will accept only public criticism as a writer, not judgments that label me a criminal, such as my Lord Chief Justice Whitshed.

original: Whenever an order shall come out by authority, forbidding all men upon the highest penalties, to offer anything in writing or discourse against Mr. Wood's halfpence; I shall certainly submit.
modernized: If an order arrives, authorized by power, forbidding everyone on the highest penalties from expressing written or verbal opposition to Mr. Wood's halfpence, I will conform.

original: However, if that should happen, I am determined to be somewhat more than the last man in the kingdom to receive them; because I will never receive them at all: For, although I know how to be silent; I have not yet learned to pay active obedience against my conscience, and the public safety.
modernized: However, if such an order arises, I resolve to be the last person in the country to accept these coins because I refuse them outright. But I understand the art of remaining silent better than learning to actively obey against my conscience and the public good.

original: And again, Whereas our Presbyterian brethren in many of their pamphlets, take much offence, that the great rebellion in England, the murder of the King, with the entire change of religion and government, are perpetually objected against them both in and out of season, by our common enemy, the present conformists: We do declare in the defence of our said brethren, that the reproach aforesaid is an old worn-out threadbare cant, which they always disdained to answer: And I very well remember, that, having once told a certain conformist, how much I wondered to hear him and his tribe, dwelling perpetually on so beaten a subject; he was pleased to divert the discourse with a foolish story, which I cannot forbear telling to his disgrace.
modernized: In response to numerous pamphlets written by our Presbyterian brethren, they are often offended by the persistent accusation of their role in the English rebellion, the King's murder, and the change of religion and government. We publicly defend our brethren who have long ignored this reproach as an outdated cliché. I vividly recall discussing this with a certain conformist. I expressed my surprise at their constant focus on this well-known topic, to which he replied with a foolish story that discredits him. He told me about a clergyman in Yorkshire who, for fifteen years, preached every Sunday against drunkenness. The parishioners, upset by his sermons, complained to the archbishop. Upon summoning the clergyman, the archbishop reprimanded him severely. The clergyman admitted to the accusation and added that all the parishioners were drunkards. He wanted to address their alcohol problem first before moving on to other issues but since they continued to be as drunk as ever, he decided to continue preaching, unless the archbishop stopped him.

original: He said, there was a clergyman in Yorkshire, who for fifteen years together preached every Sunday against drunkenness: Whereat the parishioners being much offended, complained to the archbishop; who having sent for the clergyman, and severely reprimanded him, the minister had no better an answer, than by confessing the fact; adding, that all the parish were drunkards; that he desired to reclaim them from one vice before he would begin upon another; and, since they still continued to be as great drunkards as before, he resolved to go on, except his Grace would please to forbid him.
modernized: The clergyman said there was a clergyman in Yorkshire who, for fifteen years, preached every Sunday against drunkenness. At this, the parishioners became offended and brought their complaint to the archbishop. When summoned, the clergyman admitted the fact and added that the entire parish was drunk. He wished to reform them first before focusing on other vices, but since the parishioners continued to drink excessively, he vowed to keep preaching, unless the archbishop forbade him.

original: It is certain, the faith of princes is so frequently subservient to their ambition, that renunciations have little validity, otherwise than from the powers and parties whose interest it is to support them.
modernized: Generally speaking, the faith of princes is often used to serve their ambitions, so renunciations rarely hold any weight unless they are supported by those whose interests are at stake.

original: But this renunciation, which the Queen hath exacted from the French King and his grandson, I take to be armed with all the essential circumstances that can fortify such an act.
modernized: The renunciation that the Queen has insisted upon from the French King and his grandson appears to have all necessary elements to strengthen its impact.

original: For as it is necessary, for the security of every prince in Europe, that those two great kingdoms should never be united; so the chief among them will readily consent to be guarantees for preventing such a misfortune.
modernized: It is crucial for the security of every European monarch that these two powerful kingdoms should never come under one rule. Therefore, the leading monarchs would be more than willing to act as guarantors to prevent such an unfortunate union.

original: While Grace is saying after Meat, do you and your Brethren take the Chairs from behind the Company, so that when they go to it again, they may fall backwards, which will make them all merry; but be you so discreet as to hold your Laughter till you get to the Kitchen, and then divert your Fellow-servants.
modernized: After meals, you and the other servants should move the chairs from behind the dining guests in such a way that when they return, they might accidentally fall back. This would amuse everyone, but you should keep your laughter to yourself until you reach the kitchen. Once there, feel free to entertain your fellow servants.

original: This perhaps may appear too great a paradox even for our wise and paxodoxical age to endure; therefore I shall handle it with all tenderness, and with the utmost deference to that great and profound majority which is of another sentiment.
modernized: This statement might seem too extreme, even for our modern, skeptical age, but I will approach it tactfully, with great respect to the vast majority that hold a contrary opinion.

original: From this brief survey of the falling state of ears in the last age, and the small care had to advance their ancient growth in the present, it is manifest how little reason we can have to rely upon a hold so short, so weak, and so slippery; and that whoever desires to catch mankind fast must have recourse to some other methods.
modernized: From this overview, we can see how little trust we can put in the weak and unreliable grasp of ears in today's society, and that other methods must be employed to capture people's interest.

original: Now he that will examine human nature with circumspection enough may discover several handles, whereof the six senses afford one apiece, beside a great number that are screwed to the passions, and some few riveted to the intellect.
modernized: By carefully studying human nature, one can identify several means to engage people, with the six senses offering one means apiece, while passions and intellect provide additional ways.

original: Among these last, curiosity is one, and of all others affords the firmest grasp; curiosity, that spur in the side, that bridle in the mouth, that ring in the nose of a lazy, an impatient, and a grunting reader.
modernized: In particular, curiosity holds the strongest grip, acting as a spur, a bridle, or a ring, driving a lazy, impatient, and grumbling reader to be captivated by an author.

original: By this handle it is that an author should seize upon his readers; which as soon as he hath once compassed, all resistance and struggling are in vain, and they become his prisoners as close as he pleases, till weariness or dulness force him to let go his grip.
modernized: Once an author has command of his reader's curiosity, any resistance and struggle are futile, and the reader is firmly held as a captive until weariness or dullness compels the author to release their grip.

original: During the dominion of the late men in power, addresses had been procured from both Houses to the Queen, representing their opinion, that no peace could be secure for Britain, while Spain or the West Indies remained in the possession of the Bourbon family.
modernized: During the governance of the late individuals in power, both Houses had provided addresses to the Queen expressing their concern that no peace could be secure for Britain as long as Spain or the West Indies were held by the Bourbon family.

original: But Her Majesty having, for reasons which have been often told to the world, and which will not soon be forgotten, called a new Parliament, and chose a new set of servants, began to view things and persons in another light.
modernized: However, due to reasons frequently recounted, the Queen called a new Parliament and chose new officials, leading her to see things and people differently.

original: She considered the necessities of her people, the distant prospect of a peace upon such an improbable condition, which was never mentioned or understood in the grand alliance; the unequal burthen she bore in the war, by the practices of the allies upon the corruption of some whom she most trusted, or perhaps by the practices of these upon the allies; and, lastly, by the changes which death had brought about in the Austrian and Bourbon families.
modernized: The Queen considered the needs of her subjects, the distant possibility of peace under such improbable terms, which were never discussed or comprehended in the grand alliance; the disproportionate burden she bore in the war, resulting from the practices of the allies exploiting the corruption of some she trusted, or perhaps the practices of these against the allies; and lastly, the changes resulting from the deaths in the Austrian and Bourbon families.

original: Upon all which motives she was prevailed upon to receive some overtures from France, in behalf of herself and the whole confederacy.
modernized: With these reasons, the Queen was persuaded to consider proposals from France on behalf of herself and the entire coalition.

original: The several steps of this negotiation, from its first rise to the time I am now writing, shall be related in another part of this History.
modernized: I will provide further details in another part of this history about the progress of these negotiations since they began up to this point.

original: Let it suffice for the present to say, that such proposals were received from France as were thought sufficient by our court whereupon to appoint time and place for a general treaty; and soon after the opening of the session, the Bishop of Bristol, lord privy seal, was dispatched to Utrecht, where he and the Earl of Strafford were appointed plenipotentiaries for the Queen of Great Britain.
modernized: For now, it is enough to say that the proposals received from France were deemed acceptable by the court and a time and place were set for a general treaty; and soon after the start of this session, the Bishop of Bristol, who held the position of Lord Privy Seal, was sent to Utrecht to serve as one of the Queen's representatives.

original: Therefore to conclude: It plainly appears, that unless men are guided by the advice and judgment of a conscience founded on religion, they can give no security that they will be either good subjects, faithful servants of the public, or honest in their mutual dealings; since there is no other tie through which the pride, or lust, or avarice, or ambition of mankind will not certainly break one time or other.
modernized: It is clear that without religion guiding one's morals, individuals cannot guarantee they will be honest, faithful to the public, or trustworthy among others. This is because people's ambition, pride, greed, or desire will inevitably lead them to act unethically at some point, as there are no other restraining factors.

original: Among those kingdoms and states which first embraced the Reformation, England appears to have received it in the most regular way; where it was introduced in a peaceable manner, by the supreme power of a King, and the three estates in Parliament; to which, as the highest legislative authority, all subjects are bound passively to submit.
modernized: Among the first kingdoms and countries that accepted the Reformation, England seems to have adopted it in the most formal manner, as it was legally established by the King and the three branches of Parliament, to which the general population is obligated to submit.

original: Neither was there much blood shed on so great a change of religion.
modernized: There was minimal violence involved in the religious change.

original: But a considerable number of lords, and other persons of quality through the kingdom still continued in their old faith, and were, notwithstanding their difference in religion, employed in offices civil as well as military, more or less in every reign, until the Test Act in the time of King Charles II.
modernized: Although many lords and influential people remained followers of the old faith, they continued to hold positions in the civil and military sectors of the kingdom until the Test Act during the reign of King Charles II.

original: However, from the time of the Reformation, the number of Catholics gradually and considerably lessened.
modernized: Since the Reformation, the number of Catholics in England gradually decreased.

original: So that in the reign of King Charles I. England became, in a great degree, a Protestant Kingdom, without taking the sectaries into the number; the legality whereof, with respect to human laws, the Catholics never disputed: But the Puritans, and other schismatics, without the least pretence to any such authority, by an open rebellion, destroyed that legal Reformation, as we observed before, murdered their King, and changed the monarchy into a republic.
modernized: By the time of King Charles I, England had become predominantly Protestant, excluding sectarian groups. The legitimacy of this change, as per human laws, was not disputed by Catholics; however, the Puritans and other dissident groups, without any legitimate authority, overthrew the legal Reformation through open rebellion, leading to the murder of their King and the transition from monarchy to republic.

original: It is therefore not to be wondered at, if the Catholics, in such a Babel of religions, chose to adhere to their own faith left to them by their ancestors, rather than seek for a better among a rabble of hypocritical, rebellious, deluding knaves, or deluded enthusiasts.
modernized: Given the chaotic variety of religions, it's not surprising that Catholics chose to stick with the faith passed down to them by their ancestors rather than search for a better option among a group of dishonest, rebellious, and easily deceived individuals.
