original: Their inclinations to the Church were soon discovered, when King James the Second succeeded to the crown, with whom they unanimously joined in its ruin, to revenge themselves for that restraint they had most justly suffered in the foregoing reign; not from the persecuting temper of the clergy, as their clamours would suggest, but the prudence and caution of the legislature.
modernized: Their animosity towards the Church became clear when King James the Second ascended the throne. They joined forces with him, intent on the Church's destruction, seeking revenge for the restrictions they had faced under the previous reign. This was not due to any persecutory nature of the clergy, as their complaints might suggest, but rather the wise and cautious manner of the lawmakers.

original: The same indulgence against law, was made use of by them and the Papists, and they amicably employed their power, as in defence of one common interest.
modernized: The same tolerance of the law was utilized by them and the Catholics, and they collaborated in the defense of a common purpose.

original: The progress of our endeavours will of necessity be very much interrupted, except the learned world will please to send their lists to the Chamber of Fame with all expedition.
modernized: To make progress with our initiatives, the learned community must promptly send their records to the Hall of Fame.

original: There is nothing can so much contribute to create a noble emulation in our youth, as the honourable mention of such whose actions have outlived the injuries of time, and recommended themselves so far to the world, that it is become learning to know the least circumstance of their affairs.
modernized: The recognition of outstanding individuals, whose actions have withstood the test of time, greatly encourages young people to excel, leading to the widespread desire to learn even the smallest details about their lives.

original: It is a great incentive to see, that some men have raised themselves so highly above their fellow-creatures; that the lives of ordinary men are spent in inquiries after the particular actions of the most illustrious.
modernized: It is motivating to observe that some individuals have risen above their peers; ordinary lives are filled with curiosity about the specific achievements of highly esteemed individuals.

original: True it is, that without this impulse to fame and reputation, our industry would stagnate, and that lively desire of pleasing each other die away.
modernized: It's a fact that without this thirst for fame and recognition, our efforts would slow, and the enthusiasm to please each other would vanish.

original: This opinion was so established in the heathen world, that their sense of living appeared insipid, except their being was enlivened with a consciousness, that they were esteemed by the rest of the world.
modernized: In the ancient world, the feeling of existence was unfulfilled unless it was rooted in the knowledge that they were respected by the broader society.

original: However I was so mortified, that I resolved for the future to sit quietly in my shop, and deal in common goods like the rest of my brethren; till it happened some months ago considering with myself that the lower and poorer sort of people wanted a plain strong coarse stuff to defend them against cold easterly winds, which then blew very fierce and blasting for a long time together, I contrived one on purpose, which sold very well all over the kingdom, and preserved many thousands from agues I then made a second and a third kind of stuffs for the gentry with the same success, insomuch that an ague hath hardly been heard of for some time.
modernized: I was so embarrassed that I decided to focus on selling ordinary goods in my shop, like others in my profession. A few months ago, I realized that the lower and poorer class of people needed a durable, heavy fabric to protect themselves from the fierce cold, easterly winds. I created such a fabric and it was successful throughout the kingdom, helping many avoid catching colds. After this, I made similar fabrics for the upper class and these were also successful, to the point that cases of colds have significantly decreased.

original: The fable in Ovid of Arachne and Pallas, is to this purpose.
modernized: The story of Arachne and Pallas from Ovid, serves as an analogy.

original: The goddess had heard of one Arachne a young virgin, very famous for spinning and weaving.
modernized: The goddess learned of Arachne, a young lady famed for her exceptional sewing and weaving skills.

original: They both met upon a trial of skill; and Pallas finding herself almost equalled in her own art, stung with rage and envy, knocked her rival down, turned her into a spider, enjoining her to spin and weave for ever, out of her own bowels, and in a very narrow compass.
modernized: They encountered each other in a contest of their craftsmanship. When Pallas noticed Arachne matching her abilities in her own art, jealousy surged, causing her to strike and transform Arachne into a spider, demanding she weave forever within tight boundaries from her own body.

original: I confess, that from a boy, I always pitied poor Arachne, and could never heartily love the goddess on account of so cruel and unjust a sentence; which however is fully executed upon us by England, with further additions of rigour and severity.
modernized: From an early age, I have felt sympathy for poor Arachne, and could never truly admire the goddess because of such a harsh and unjust punishment; yet England has imposed a similar treatment on us, adding further severity.

original: For the greatest part of our bowels and vitals are extracted, without allowing us the liberty of spinning and weaving them.
modernized: The majority of our internal organs and essentials are removed, without permitting us to weave and produce them ourselves.

original: First, One great advantage proposed by the abolishing of Christianity is, that it would very much enlarge and establish liberty of conscience, that great bulwark of our nation, and of the Protestant Religion, which is still too much limited by priestcraft, notwithstanding all the good intentions of the legislature, as we have lately found by a severe instance.
modernized: First, One significant advantage of abolishing Christianity is the potential increase and solidification of liberty of conscience, a crucial shield for our nation and Protestant Religion, which continues to be narrowed by the influence of the clergy, despite the good intentions of the government, as recently demonstrated by a severe instance.

original: For it is confidently reported, that two young gentlemen of real hopes, bright wit, and profound judgment, who upon a thorough examination of causes and effects, and by the mere force of natural abilities, without the least tincture of learning, having made a discovery, that there was no God, and generously communicating their thoughts for the good of the public, were some time ago, by an unparalleled severity, and upon I know not what obsolete law, broke for blasphemy.
modernized: It is confirmed that two young men with genuine promise, sharp intellect, and deep wisdom, who meticulously considered reasons and effects, using their innate abilities alone without any formal education and concluded that there is no God, shared their findings for public benefit. However, they were allegedly harshly punished for blasphemy through unprecedented severity and some obscure, outdated law.

original: And as it hath been wisely observed, if persecution once begins, no man alive knows how far it may reach, or where it will end.
modernized: Moreover, it has been prudently pointed out that once persecution starts, no one knows how it could intensify or where it could end.

original: To conclude, Whereas the last quoted author complains very heavily and frequently of a brand that lies upon them, it is a great mistake: For the first original brand hath been long taken off.
modernized: However, the original problem the author repeatedly mentions has been resolved. In fact, the initial issue has been gone a long time.

original: Only we confess, the scar will probably remain and be visible for ever to those who know the principles by which they acted, and until those principles shall be openly renounced; else it must continue to all generations, like the mark set upon Cain, which some authors say descended to all his posterity: Or like the Roman nose and Austrian lip, or like the long bag of flesh hanging down from the gills of the people in Piedmont.
modernized: Nevertheless, we admit the scar of our actions might persist, visible to those who understand our motives, unless we publicly abandon the beliefs that caused it; otherwise, it will pass down through generations like the mark on Cain, some authors believe was inherited by his descendants, or like the physical features of the people in Piedmont such as the Roman nose, Austrian lip, or the flabby necks hanging from their gills.

original: But as for any brands fixed on schismatics for several years past, they have been all made with cold iron; like thieves, who by the benefit of the clergy are condemned to be only burned in the hand; but escape the pain and the mark, by being in fee with the jailor.
modernized: However, any labels placed on the dissenters in the past have been imposed with cold coercion, similar to a thief getting a hand-burning sentence by benefit of the clergy, but avoiding the punishment and mark by being aligned with the jailor.

original: Which advantage the schismatical teachers will never want, who, as we are assured, and of which there is a very fresh instance, have the souls, and bodies, and purses of the people a hundred times more at their mercy, than the Catholic priests could ever pretend to.

Spitting on your hand and squeezing the wax until it goes out is another method. The cook can put out the candle by placing it in a bowl of flour, oats, hay, or litter. The housemaid can extinguish her candle by running it against a mirror, which is an effective way to clean the mirror. However, blowing out the candle with your breath is the quickest and most effective method, leaving the candle clean and ready to be relit.

modernized: He acquired the throne with a legitimate claim, supported by the nobles' approval and his own personal merits.

original: He had no disturbance for some time, which he might easily have employed in settling the kingdom, and acquiring the love of his people.
modernized: He initially faced no significant challenges, which he could have used to stabilize the kingdom and earn the affection of his subjects.

original: He had treasure enough to raise and pay armies, without burthening the subject.
modernized: He possessed enough wealth to raise and fund armies without overburdening the population.

original: His competitor was a woman, whose sex was the least of her infirmities, and with whom he had already compounded for his quiet by a considerable pension: yet with all these advantages he seldom was master of above half the kingdom at once, and that by the force of perpetual struggling, and with frequent danger of losing the whole.
modernized: Despite numerous advantages, he often controlled only half the kingdom and faced a constant risk of losing it all due to persistent conflicts and struggles. His main competitor was a woman with various infirmities, with whom existing agreements purchased her loyalty.

original: The principal difficulties he had to encounter, appear to have been manifest consequences of several most imprudent steps in his conduct, whereof many instances have been produced in the history of his reign; such as, the unlimited permission of building castles; his raising the siege of a weak place where the Empress was shut up, and must, in a few days, have fallen into his hands; his employing the Flemings in his wars, and favouring them above his own subjects; and lastly, that abortive project of crowning his son, which procured him at once the hatred and contempt of the clergy, by discovering an inclination to violence and injustice that he durst not pursue: whereas, it was nothing else but an effect of that hasty and sudden disposition usually ascribed to those of his country, and in a peculiar manner charged to this prince: for authors give it as a part of his character, to be hot and violent in the beginning of an enterprise, but to slacken and grow cold in the prosecution.
modernized: The primary challenges he faced seemed to be the result of numerous thoughtless actions in his leadership, including the careless permission of building castles, prematurely lifting sieges, favoring foreign troops over domestic ones, and attempting, albeit unsuccessfully, to crown his son, which earned him condemnation from the clergy for his hasty and impulsive behavior in the initial stages of an endeavor but eventual complacency and hesitation in its prosecution rather than the loyalty to violence and injustice suggested by some authors.

original: The greatest blow given of late to this kingdom, was by the dishonesty of a few manufacturers; by imposing bad wares at foreign markets, in almost the only traffic permitted to us, did half ruin that trade; by which this poor unhappy kingdom still suffers in the midst of sufferings.
modernized: Recently, the dishonesty of a few manufacturers caused significant damage to this kingdom. By selling poor-quality goods abroad in almost the only permitted trade, they nearly ruined that trade, and the kingdom is still struggling to recover.

original: I speak not here of persons in high stations who ought to be free from all reflection, and are supposed always to intend the welfare of the community: but we now find by experience, that the meanest instrument may, by the concurrence of accidents, have it in his power to bring a whole kingdom to the very brink of destruction, and is at this present endeavouring to finish his work; and hath agents among ourselves who are contented to see their own country undone, to be small sharers in that iniquitous gain, which at last must end in their own ruin, as well as ours.
modernized: I'm not referring to those in high positions who are expected to promote the welfare of the community. Instead, we've seen that even the most ordinary individuals, through the combination of unfortunate circumstances, can bring a nation to the brink of collapse and are working to complete their harmful actions. They have co-conspirators in our midst who are willing to watch their own country crumble, settling for a small share of the unjust gain, which ultimately leads to their own downfall, as well as ours.

original: I confess it was chiefly the consideration of that great danger we are in, which engaged me to discourse to you on this subject, to exhort you to a love of your country, and a public spirit, when all you have is at stake; to prefer the interest of your prince and your fellow-subjects, before that of one destructive impostor, and a few of his adherents.
modernized: I feel compelled to speak about this issue due to the grave danger we are currently facing. I urge you to love your country and have a strong sense of public duty when all you own is at risk. Put the interest of your leader and your fellow citizens before that of a destructive fraudster and his followers.

original: Of such mighty importance every man is to himself, and ready to think he is so to others, without once making this easy and obvious reflection, that his affairs can have no more weight with other men than theirs have with him; and how little that is he is sensible enough.
modernized: Everyone consider themselves extremely important, and often assume this is also true for others, without realizing that their concerns carry the same weight to others as their concerns weigh to them.

original: I can faithfully assure the Reader, that there is not one single witty Phrase in this whole Collection, which hath not received the Stamp and Approbation of at least one hundred Years, and how much longer, it is hard to determine; he may therefore be secure to find them all genuine, sterling, and authentic.
modernized: The reader can trust that every witty expression in this entire compilation has been accepted and approved for at least a hundred years, and it's hard to determine how much longer they've been in use. Readers can therefore feel confident that they will find all of them to be genuine, reliable, and authentic.

original: First: I shall therefore shew, first, that the poor (in the sense I understand the word) do enjoy many temporal blessings, which are not common to the rich and great; and likewise, that the rich and great are subject to many temporal evils, which are not common to the poor.
modernized: I will initially demonstrate that the individuals I consider 'poor' (as opposed to the more common usage) actually experience various temporal benefits which are not typically enjoyed by the wealthy and powerful; and additionally, that the wealthy and powerful experience various temporal hardships which are rare among the 'poor'.

original: I did indeed observe that the Yahoos were the only animals in this country subject to any diseases; which, however, were much fewer than horses have among us, and contracted, not by any ill-treatment they meet with, but by the nastiness and greediness of that sordid brute.
modernized: I observed that the Yahoos are the only animals in this country prone to diseases, and these are fewer than those among horses. The reason for their diseases is not due to ill-treatment, but the Yahoos' own filthiness and greed.

original: Neither has their language any more than a general appellation for those maladies, which is borrowed from the name of the beast, and called hnea-yahoo, or Yahoo's evil; and the cure prescribed is a mixture of their own dung and urine, forcibly put down the Yahoo's throat.
modernized: The Yahoo language contains only a general term for diseases, which is derived from the Yahoo name and is called 'Yahoo's sickness'. The treatment for this includes mixing their own feces and urine and forcing it down the Yahoo's throat as a cure.

original: This I have since often known to have been taken with success, and do here freely recommend it to my countrymen for the public good, as an admirable specific against all diseases produced by repletion.
modernized: I have personally witnessed the success of this treatment, and I strongly suggest it to my fellow countrymen for use against diseases caused by overeating.

original: The office of Recorder to this city being vacant by the death of a very worthy gentleman, it is said, that five or six persons are soliciting to succeed him in the employment.
modernized: Five or six individuals are reportedly vying for the vacant position of Recorder for this city, following the death of a very respected gentleman.

original: I am a stranger to all their persons, and to most of their characters; which latter, I hope, will at this time be canvassed with more decency than it sometimes happeneth upon the like occasions.
modernized: Since I'm not familiar with any of these candidates' personal backgrounds, I hope that the selection process at this time will display a higher level of decorum compared to past occasions.

original: Therefore, as I am wholly impartial, I can with more freedom deliver my thoughts how the several persons and parties concerned ought to proceed in electing a Recorder for this great and ancient city.
modernized: Given my impartial perspective, I can express my thoughts more freely about the appropriate steps that should be taken by the people and parties involved in electing a Recorder for this grand, historical city.

original: Having thus declared what sort of persons I have always meant, under the denomination of Whigs, it will be easy to shew whom I understand by Tories.
modernized: Now that I've explained who I refer to as Whigs, it's straightforward to identify who I mean by Tories.

original: Such whose principles in Church and State, are what I have above related; whose actions are derived from thence, and who have no attachment to any set of ministers, further than as these are friends to the constitution in all its parts, but will do their utmost to save their prince and country, whoever be at the helm.
modernized: Those whose religious and political beliefs match those I've articulated earlier, whose actions stem from these beliefs, have no loyalty to any particular government officials, but will work tirelessly to protect the country and the monarch, no matter who is in power.

original: I may add, that absurd practice of cutting turf, without any regularity; whereby great quantities of restorable land are made utterly desperate, many thousands of cattle destroyed, the turf more difficult to come at, and carry home, and less fit for burning; the air made unwholesome by stagnating pools and marshes; and the very sight of such places offensive to those who ride by.
modernized: The practice of haphazardly cutting turf causes the devastation of fertile land, the death of many cattle, the difficulty in collecting and using the turf, and the production of unhealthy air due to stagnant pools and marshes. It also makes these areas unpleasant for those who pass by.

original: Neither should that odious custom be allowed, of cutting scraws, (as they call them) which is flaying off the green surface of the ground, to cover their cabins; or make up their ditches; sometimes in shallow soils, where all is gravel within a few inches; and sometimes in low ground, with a thin greensward, and sloughy underneath; which last turns all into bog, by this mismanagement.
modernized: The practice of scraping off the green surface of the ground (referred to as 'scraws') is odious and should be prohibited. This process is used to cover cabins or make ditches, often in shallow soil or low ground with thin grass and soggy undergrowth which turns into bog due to negligent management.

original: And, I have heard from very skilful countrymen, that by these two practices in turf and scraws, the kingdom loseth some hundreds of acres of profitable land every year; besides the irreparable loss of many skirts of bogs, which have a green coat of grass, and yet are mangled for turf; and, besides the want of canals, by regular cutting, which would not only be a great convenience for bringing their turf home at an easy rate; but likewise render even the larger bogs more dry and safe, for summer pasture.
modernized: According to knowledgeable rural people, the twin practices of haphazard turf cutting and 'scraws' result in the loss of several hundred acres of productive land each year. Furthermore, they also cause the destruction of numerous bogs with visible grass cover that are still used for turf extraction. Additionally, the lack of canals for regular cutting makes it difficult to transport turf while also increasing the risk of the larger bogs becoming boggy and unsafe for use as summer pasture.

original: This accident absolutely determined Glumdalclitch never to trust me abroad for the future out of her sight.
modernized: The incident made Glumdalclitch vow never to let me out of her sight again.

original: I had been long afraid of this resolution, and therefore concealed from her some little unlucky adventures, that happened in those times when I was left by myself.
modernized: I was afraid she would never let me outside because of past incidents that I hid from her when she was gone.

original: Once a kite, hovering over the garden, made a stoop at me, and if I had not resolutely drawn my hanger, and run under a thick espalier, he would have certainly carried me away in his talons.
modernized: A kite once swooped down on me in the garden, but I managed to avoid it by drawing my sword and running under an espalier.

original: Another time, walking to the top of a fresh mole-hill, I fell to my neck in the hole, through which that animal had cast up the earth, and coined some lie, not worth remembering, to excuse myself for spoiling my clothes.
modernized: Another time, I fell into a hole created by a mole, and had to make up a story to excuse my ruined clothes when I returned.

original: I likewise broke my right shin against the shell of a snail, which I happened to stumble over, as I was walking alone and thinking on poor England.
modernized: I injured my leg on a snail's shell while thinking about poor England, alone and off by myself.

original: However, to make a further inquiry into the truth of this observation, I doubt not but there is reason to think that a great many of those encomiums given to ancient philosophers are taken upon trust, and by a sort of men who are not very likely to be at the pains of an inquiry that would employ so much time and thinking.
modernized: It's possible that many of the compliments bestowed upon ancient philosophers are simply accepted without question, in part because of those who put forth these compliments seem unlikely to engage in thorough investigation that requires significant time and effort.

original: For the usual ends why men affect this kind of discourse appear generally to be either out of ostentation, that they may pass upon the world for persons of great knowledge and observation, or, what is worse, there are some who highly exalt the wisdom of those Gentile sages, thereby obliquely to glance at and traduce Divine revelation, and more especially that of the Gospel; for the consequence they would have us draw is this: that since those ancient philosophers rose to a greater pitch of wisdom and virtue than was ever known among Christians, and all this purely upon the strength of their own reason and liberty of thinking; therefore it must follow that either all revelation is false, or, what is worse, that it has depraved the nature of man, and left him worse than it found him.
modernized: Individuals typically engage in such intellectually-focused discourse for various reasons, often to appear knowledgeable or to pass themselves off as having keen insights. Worse still, some individuals elevate the wisdom of the ancient sages in subtle attempts to undermine Divine revelation, particularly that of the Gospel. Their implication is that the ancient philosophers attained a higher level of wisdom and virtue than has ever been seen among Christians. This, they suggest, implies either that all revelation is false or that it has corrupted the human nature and left individuals in a worse state than before.

original: About the same time, likewise, the House of Commons advanced one considerable step towards securing us against farther impositions from our allies, resolving that the additional forces should be continued; but with a condition, that the Dutch should make good their proportion of three-fifths to two-fifths, which those confederates had so long, and in so great degree, neglected.
modernized: During the same period, the House of Commons made progress in securing us against further financial burdens from our allies. They resolved to continue the additional forces, but only if the Dutch fulfilled their three-fifths to two-fifths obligation, which they had long been neglecting.

original: The Duke of Marlborough's deduction of two and a half per cent., from the pay of the foreign troops, was also applied for carrying on the war.
modernized: The Duke of Marlborough was also given the authority to reduce pay for foreign troops by two and a half percent in order to fund the war.

original: Her majesty agreed to my petition, and easily got the farmer's consent, who was glad enough to have his daughter preferred at court, and the poor girl herself was not able to hide her joy.
modernized: The queen granted my request and managed to secure the farmer's agreement easily. He was overjoyed to have his daughter chosen for court, and the girl herself couldn't contain her happiness.

original: My late master withdrew, bidding me farewell, and saying he had left me in a good service; to which I replied not a word, only making him a slight bow.
modernized: My former master left, wishing me well and stating that he had placed me in a good position. I remained silent in response and only gave him a minor bow.

original: And to urge another argument of a parallel nature.
modernized: To present another parallel argument as well.

original: If Christianity were once abolished, how could the freethinkers, the strong reasoners, and the men of profound learning, be able to find another subject so calculated in all points whereon to display their abilities?
modernized: If Christianity is abolished, would the freethinkers, rational thinkers, and scholars be able to find another topic to showcase their skills?

original: What wonderful productions of wit should we be deprived of, from those whose genius by continual practice hath been wholly turned upon raillery and invectives against religion, and would therefore never be able to shine or distinguish themselves upon any other subject!
modernized: What brilliant works of wit would be lost if those whose genius is mainly focused on religious criticism and satire had no more religion to ridicule?

original: We are daily complaining of the great decline of wit among us, and would we take away the greatest, perhaps the only topic we have left?
modernized: Every day, we complain about the declining wit in our society. Would it be, then, removing the greatest, possibly the only remaining topic we have?

original: Who would ever have suspected Asgil for a wit, or Toland for a philosopher, if the inexhaustible stock of Christianity had not been at hand to provide them with materials?
modernized: Who would have expected Asgil to be considered witty or Toland to be recognized as a philosopher if the abundance of material provided by Christianity hadn't been available?

original: What other subject, through all art or nature, could have produced Tindal for a profound author, or furnished him with readers?
modernized: What other topic, through all art and nature, could have led to Tindal becoming such a profound author, or gained him readers?

original: It is the wise choice of the subject that alone adorns and distinguishes the writer.
modernized: The selection of the appropriate subject is what truly makes a writer shine.

original: For, had a hundred such pens as these been employed on the side of religion, they would have immediately sunk into silence and oblivion.
modernized: If a hundred pens of this caliber had been used to advocate for religion, they would have quickly faded into obscurity.

original: It is true I should be very loth the bright example of your Lordship's virtues should be lost to after-ages, both for their sake and your own; but chiefly because they will be so very necessary to adorn the history of a late reign; and that is another reason why I would forbear to make a recital of them here; because I have been told by wise men that as dedications have run for some years past, a good historian will not be apt to have recourse thither in search of characters.
modernized: I would reluctantly allow the outstanding virtues of your Lordship to be forgotten by future generations, both for their sake and yours. Moreover, they would be particularly valuable to the history of the recent reign. This is another reason why I reluctant to highlight them in this dedication, as I have been advised that historians no longer rely on dedications to find notable figures.

original: About this time the hidden sparks of animosity between the two brothers, buried but not extinguished in the last peace, began to flame out into new dissensions.
modernized: Over time, the underlying tensions between the two brothers re-emerged, erupting into renewed disagreements.

original: Duke Robert had often sent his complaints to the King for breach of articles, but without redress, which provoked him to expostulate in a rougher manner, till at length he charged the King in plain terms with injustice and perjury, but no men are found to endure reproaches with less temper than those who most deserve them, the King, at the same time filled with indignation, and stung with guilt, invaded Normandy a second time, resolving to reduce his brother to such terms as might stop all further complaints.
modernized: Duke Robert repeatedly brought complaints to the King regarding a breach of agreements, but received no resolution, causing him to become increasingly assertive and accuse the King of injustice and dishonesty. In response, the King, seething with anger and guilt, prepared for a second invasion of Normandy in order to reduce his brother to terms that would halt any further disagreements.

original: He had already taken several strong holds, by force either of arms or of money, and intending entirely to subdue the duchy, gave orders to have twenty thousand men immediately raised in England, and sent over to him.
modernized: The Duke had already seized several fortified locations through force or money, with the intention of completely conquering the duchy. To counter this, he raised the order for 20,000 English troops to be sent to him immediately.

original: The Duke, to defend himself against these formidable preparations, had recourse again to his old ally the King of France, who very readily advanced with an army to his assistance, as an action wherein he could every way find his own accounts, for, beside the appearance of glory and justice by protecting the injured, he fought indeed his own battle, by preserving his neighbouring state in the hands of a peaceful prince, from so powerful and restless an enemy as the King of England, and was largely paid for his trouble into the bargain, for King William, either loth to engage in a long and dangerous war, or hastened back by intelligence of some troubles from Wales, sent offers to his army, just ready to embark for Normandy, that upon payment of ten shillings a man they might have leave to return to their own homes.
modernized: To protect himself from these formidable military plans, the Duke turned to his old ally, the King of France, who quickly rallied an army to provide assistance. The King of France saw an opportunity for both personal gain and intervention in the conflict, helping a wronged party and preserving his neighboring state from the King of England's hostile rule while receiving payment for the trouble he incurred. With Wales in turmoil, King William offered the soldiers set to embark for Normandy the opportunity to return home for a fee of ten shillings per man.

original: This bargain was generally accepted, the money was paid to the King of France, who immediately withdrew his troops, and King William, now master of the conditions, forced his brother to a peace upon much harder terms than before.
modernized: The agreement was widely accepted, the money was paid to the King of France, who then withdrew his troops, leaving King William in control of the terms. With this new leverage, King William forced his brother to agree to much harsher peace conditions than before.

original: That Prince, as well as his minister, Mons. de Torcy, either felt, or affected, so much resentment of the usage the latter had met at The Hague and Gertruydenberg, that they appeared fully determined against making any application to the States, where the same persons continued still in power, of whose treatment they so heavily complained.
modernized: The prince and his minister, Mons. de Torcy, expressed or feigned such strong resentment towards their treatment at The Hague and Gertruydenberg, that they seemed resolute in refusing to negotiate with the States, since the same individuals remained in power and were deemed responsible for their grievances.

original: This word is often made the sanction of an oath; it is reckoned a great commendation to be a man of strict honour; and it is commonly understood, that a man of honour can never be guilty of a base action.
modernized: The term 'honor' is frequently used to back up an oath, and it is widely recognized as a great compliment to be a person of strong moral character. However, the common understanding is that a person of honor would never engage in immoral or dishonorable actions.

original: This is usually the style of military men; of persons with titles; and of others who pretend to birth and quality.
modernized: This moral code is typically adhered to by military personnel, those with titles, and those who claim high social status or nobility.

original: It is true, indeed, that in ancient times it was universally understood, that honour was the reward of virtue; but if such honour as is now-a-days going will not permit a man to do a base action, it must be allowed, there are very few such things as base actions in nature.
modernized: In ancient times, honor was widely believed to be a sign of virtue. However, today's notion of honor does not necessarily prevent a person from doing immoral actions, as there are very few actions considered truly immoral in nature.

original: No man of honour, as that word is usually understood, did ever pretend that his honour obliged him to be chaste or temperate; to pay his creditors; to be useful to his country; to do good to mankind; to endeavour to be wise, or learned; to regard his word, his promise, or his oath; or if he hath any of these virtues, they were never learned in the catechism of honour; which contains but two precepts, the punctual payment of debts contracted at play, and the right understanding the several degrees of an affront, in order to revenge it by the death of an adversary.
modernized: Historically, honor has not historically compelled individuals, as the term is commonly understood, to be chaste, temperate, responsible, helpful to society, or charitable towards others. Furthermore, virtues like honesty, integrity, and keeping one's word are not taught in the 'catechism of honor', which contains only two requirements: promptly settling gambling debts and knowing the different levels of an insult, in order to seek revenge by killing an offender.

original: This, I must own, is the natural consequence of poverty and oppression.
modernized: This, I admit, is a logical outcome of poverty and oppression.

original: These wretched people catch at any thing to save them a minute longer from drowning.
modernized: These desperate people grab at anything to buy themselves a moment more time from sinking.

original: Thus Ireland is the poorest of all civilized countries in Europe, with every natural advantage to make it one of the richest.
modernized: Thus, Ireland is the poorest nation among all civilized European countries, despite having natural resources to be one of the wealthiest.

original: But your great comfort is, that as His Majesty's patent does not oblige you to take this money, so the laws have not given the crown a power of forcing the subjects to take what money the King pleases: For then by the same reason we might be bound to take pebble-stones or cockle-shells or stamped leather for current coin, if ever we should happen to live under an ill prince, who might likewise by the same power make a guinea pass for ten pounds, a shilling for twenty shillings, and so on, by which he would in a short time get all the silver and gold of the kingdom into his own hands, and leave us nothing but brass or leather or what he pleased.
modernized: Your comfort lies in the fact that since the king's patent does not compel you to use this money, the laws also do not grant the crown the power to force subjects to use any kind of money the king desires. This means that if we were ruled by an unjust monarch, we could potentially be forced to use stones or shells as currency, or even have a guinea pass for ten pounds, a shilling for twenty shillings, etc. By doing this, the king would quickly seize all the silver and gold in the kingdom, leaving us with only brass or leather or whatever he chose.

original: Neither is anything reckoned more cruel or oppressive in the French government than their common practice of calling in all their money after they have sunk it very low, and then coining it anew at a much higher value, which however is not the thousandth part so wicked as this abominable project of Mr. Wood.
modernized: It's also considered extremely cruel and oppressive in the French government when they periodically change all their money after devaluing it, then mint it again at a higher value. However, this practice is nothing compared to the terrible plan of Mr. Wood.

original: For the French give their subjects silver for silver and gold for gold, but this fellow will not so much as give us good brass or copper for our gold and silver, nor even a twelfth part of their worth.
modernized: In contrast, the French give their people silver for silver and gold for gold. Yet this man will not even supply us with decent brass or copper for our gold and silver, and the worth of the currency we receive is just a fraction of the original value.

original: The church is a private society, and no more power belonging to it than to other private companies and clubs, and, consequently, all the right anyone has to be an ecclesiastical officer, and the power he is entrusted with, depends on the consent of the parties concerned, and is no greater than they can bestow.
modernized: The church operates as a personal organization, owning no more power than other non-governmental societies and organizations. As a result, an individual's right to hold a religious office, along with the authority they are given, relies on the agreement of those involved, and is limited by the consent they are willing to provide.

original: The King had not been many months on his throne, when the news came that Duke Robert, returned from the Holy Land, was received by his subjects with great marks of joy and honour, and in universal reputation for his valour and success against the infidels: soon after which, Ralph Bishop of Durham, either by the negligence or corruption of his keepers, escaped out of prison, and fled over to the Duke; whom he stirred up to renew and solicit his pretensions to the crown of England, by writing to several nobles, who, either through old friendship, or new discontent, or an opinion of his title, gave him promises of their assistance, as soon as he should land in England: but the Duke having returned exceeding poor from the Holy Land, was not yet in a condition for such an undertaking, and therefore thought fit to defer it to a more seasonable opportunity.
modernized: After several months on the throne, the King learned that Duke Robert, back from the Holy Land, was warmly welcomed by his subjects, highly regarded for his bravery and victories against unbelievers. Shortly after, Ralph Bishop of Durham, either due to negligence or corruption of his guards, managed to escape from prison and went to Duke Robert. He motivated the Duke to reclaim his claim to the English throne by writing to various nobles who, due to past friendship, new dissatisfaction, or belief in his title, promised to aid him upon landing in England. However, Duke Robert, having returned from the Holy Land impoverished, was not yet ready for such an undertaking, so he chose to delay his claim to a more suitable opportunity.

original: But it may be objected, that there is an argument of much force to excuse the overflowings of that zeal, which our friend shews or means for our cause.
modernized: It could be argued that there's a strong argument to excuse the intense passion that our friend shows or intends for our cause.

original: And it must be confessed, that the easy and smooth fluency of his elocution bestowed on him by nature, and cultivated by continual practice, added to the comeliness of his person, the harmony of his voice, the gracefulness of his manner, and the decency of his dress, are temptations too strong for such a genius to resist upon any public occasion of making them appear with universal applause: And if good men are sometimes accused of loving their jest better than their friend, surely to gain the reputation of the first orator in the kingdom, no man of spirit would scruple to lose all the friends he had in the world.
modernized: It's hard to deny that the smooth and fluent way our friend speaks, due to his natural talent and years of practice, combined with his attractive appearance, pleasant voice, graceful manner, and decent attire, are powerful temptations that our friend might not be able to resist in public situations, even if it means losing all the friends he has in the world in order to gain the reputation of being the best orator in the kingdom.

original: And first, I am very sensible how much the gentlemen of wit and pleasure are apt to murmur, and be choked at the sight of so many daggle-tailed parsons that happen to fall in their way, and offend their eyes; but at the same time, these wise reformers do not consider what an advantage and felicity it is for great wits to be always provided with objects of scorn and contempt, in order to exercise and improve their talents, and divert their spleen from falling on each other, or on themselves, especially when all this may be done without the least imaginable danger to their persons.
modernized: Initially, I acknowledge the annoyance elite intellectual and pleasure-seeking individuals often feel towards the prevalence of dismissive clergy, which they find visually off-putting. However, these proposed reformers fail to recognize the benefit and convenience for great minds to always have objects of ridicule, allowing them to hone their skills, and alleviate their aggression, avoiding self-inflicted and interpersonal harm. This can all be achieved without any threat to their physical safety.

original: The sailors were all in amazement, and asked me a thousand questions, which I had no inclination to answer.
modernized: The sailors were all shocked and asked me many questions, but I had no desire to answer them.

original: I was equally confounded at the sight of so many pygmies, for such I took them to be, after having so long accustomed mine eyes to the monstrous objects I had left.
modernized: I was equally surprised and confused at the sight of all these small people, since I had become accustomed to enormous objects I had previously seen.

original: But the captain, Mr. Thomas Wilcocks, an honest, worthy Shropshire man, observing I was ready to faint, took me into his cabin, gave me a cordial to comfort me, and made me turn in upon his own bed, advising me to take a little rest, of which I had great need.
modernized: But Captain Thomas Wilcocks, a sincere and honorable man from Shropshire, noticing that I was about to faint, took me into his cabin, gave me some soothing medicine to help me recover, and suggested that I take a short rest, which I really needed.

original: Before I went to sleep, I gave him to understand that I had some valuable furniture in my box, too good to be lost; a fine hammock, a handsome two chairs, a table, and a cabinet.
modernized: Before going to sleep, I explained to him that I had valuable belongings in my box, such as a nice hammock, two chairs, a table, and a cabinet.

original: That my closet was hung on all sides, or rather quilted, with silk and cotton: that if he would let one of the crew bring my closet into his cabin, I would open it there before him, and show him my goods.
modernized: I mentioned that my closet was distributed with silk and cotton all around; if he allowed one of the crew to bring my closet into his cabin, I would show him the contents there.

original: The captain, hearing me utter these absurdities, concluded I was raving: however (I suppose to pacify me), he promised to give orders as I desired, and going upon deck, sent some of his men down into my closet, from whence (as I afterwards found) they drew up all my goods, and stripped off the quilting; but the chairs, cabinet, and bedstead, being screwed to the floor, were much damaged by the ignorance of the seamen, who tore them up by force.
modernized: Upon hearing my absurd speech, Captain Wilcocks assumed I was delirious; yet (perhaps to appease me), he promised to fulfill my requests and went on deck, sending some of his men down into my closet, where (before I knew it) they retrieved all my belongings and removed the insulation; however, the chairs, cabinet, and bedstead, which were screwed to the floor, became damaged as the unskilled sailors tore them apart.

original: Then they knocked off some of the boards for the use of the ship, and when they had got all they had a mind for, let the hull drop into the sea, which, by reason of so many breaches made in the bottom and sides, sunk to rights.
modernized: Then they removed some of the boards for use by the ship, and once they had taken what they wanted, they allowed the wreck to sink into the sea due to the numerous holes made in its bottom and sides.

original: And indeed I was glad not to have been a spectator of the havoc they made; because I am confident it would have sensibly touched me, by bringing former passages into my mind, which I had rather forgotten.
modernized: Indeed, I applauded myself for not witnessing the destruction they caused, as it would have evoked painful memories of my past that I preferred to forget.

original: That the Ministry foresaw this great change, is plain from the Callico-Act; whereby it is now become the occupation of women all over England, to convert their useless female habits into beds, window-curtains, chairs, and joint-stools; undressing themselves (as it were) before their transformation.
modernized: The Ministry has anticipated this significant change, as evidenced by the Enactment of Callico (Callico-Act), which has led to women in England transforming their redundant feminine clothing into comfortable household items such as beds, window hangings, chairs, and stools. This process seems to be a preparation for their upcoming transformation.

original: The Reader will find that the following Collection of polite Expressions will easily incorporate with all Subjects of genteel and fashionable Life.
modernized: The reader will discover that these polite conversations apply to a wide variety of polite and fashionable topics.

original: Those, which are proper for Morning-Tea, will be equally useful at the same Entertainment in the Afternoon, even in the same Company, only by shifting the several Questions, Answers, and Replies, into different Hands; and such as are adapted to Meals will indifferently serve for Dinners or Suppers, only distinguishing between Daylight and Candlelight.
modernized: Expressions appropriate for morning tea may also be used during the same social occasion in the afternoon, simply by exchanging questions, answers, and responses among different individuals. Expressions meant for meals can be used at dinner or supper, just by adjusting them according to whether it's daylight or candlelight.

original: By this Method no diligent Person, of a tolerable Memory, can ever be at a loss.
modernized: With this strategy, no diligent person with a decent memory will find themselves without something to say.

original: I am likewise apt to quarrel with some titles of lords among us, that have a very ungracious sound, which are apt to communicate mean ideas to those who have not the honour to be acquainted with their persons or their virtues, of whom I have the misfortune to be one.
modernized: I often find myself disagreeing with some titles of Irish nobles, as they have unpleasant connotations that can mislead people who aren't familiar with them personally, and I unfortunately fall into that category.

original: But I cannot pardon those gentlemen who have gotten titles since the judicature of the peers among us has been taken away, to which they all submitted with a resignation that became good Christians, as undoubtedly they are.
modernized: I cannot condone those nobles who received titles after the English judiciary was established in Ireland, as they all had to submit with a Christian's resignation to it. It's clear they are noblemen.

original: However, since that time, I look upon a graceful harmonious title to be at least forty per cent. in the value intrinsic of an Irish peerage; and, since it is as cheap as the worst, for any Irish law hitherto enacted in England to the contrary, I would advise the next set, before they pass their patents, to call a consultation of scholars and musical gentlemen, to adjust this most important and essential circumstance.
modernized: Since that time, I believe that a graceful, harmonious title contributes at least 40% to the inherent value of an Irish peerage; given that it's as inexpensive as the worst, I recommend that the next batch of nobles, before they confirm their titles, consult scholars and musical experts to ensure this significant element is well-crafted.

original: The Scotch noblemen, though born almost under the north pole, have much more tunable appellations, except some very few, which I suppose were given them by the Irish along with their language, at the time when that kingdom was conquered and planted from hence; and to this day retain the denominations of places, and surnames of families, as all historians agree.
modernized: The Scottish nobles, born nearly under the North Pole, generally have more acceptable appellations, except a few that I assume were given by the Irish along with their language when that kingdom was conquered and settled. Historians have agreed upon this throughout the ages, and those noblemen still use names of places and family surnames to this day.

original: And whereas the mind of man, when he gives the spur and bridle to his thoughts, does never stop, but naturally sallies out into both extremes of high and low, of good and evil, his first flight of fancy commonly transports him to ideas of what is most perfect, finished, and exalted, till, having soared out of his own reach and sight, not well perceiving how near the frontiers of height and depth border upon each other, with the same course and wing he falls down plump into the lowest bottom of things, like one who travels the east into the west, or like a straight line drawn by its own length into a circle.
modernized: Human thought, when guided and controlled, tends to explore both the highest and lowest extremes of good and evil. The initial flight of our imagination often leads us to envision ideas of what is perfect and complete until we fly beyond our reach and understanding. Unable to perceive the proximity of the highest and lowest points, the same trajectory causes us to fall into the depths, like describing east as west or a straight line forming a circle.

original: Whether a tincture of malice in our natures makes us fond of furnishing every bright idea with its reverse, or whether reason, reflecting upon the sum of things, can, like the sun, serve only to enlighten one half of the globe, leaving the other half by necessity under shade and darkness, or whether fancy, flying up to the imagination of what is highest and best, becomes over-short, and spent, and weary, and suddenly falls, like a dead bird of paradise, to the ground; or whether, after all these metaphysical conjectures, I have not entirely missed the true reason; the proposition, however, which has stood me in so much circumstance is altogether true, that as the most uncivilised parts of mankind have some way or other climbed up into the conception of a God or Supreme Power, so they have seldom forgot to provide their fears with certain ghastly notions, which, instead of better, have served them pretty tolerably for a devil.
modernized: Perhaps it is a touch of malice within us that inclines us to associate every bright idea with its opposite, or possibly reason reflects on the universe, lighting only half, leaving the other half in shadow. Alternatively, our imagination, when reaching toward the highest and best, may become underpowered, grow tired, and come crashing down like a fatigued exotic bird falling to the ground. Or, perhaps, my conjectures about the reasons for this phenomenon are incorrect; nevertheless, the underlying principle I have described remains true: the most primitive societies have, in some way, formed the concept of a deity but have also established terrifying notions to serve as a crude sort of devil.

original: And this proceeding seems to be natural enough, for it is with men whose imaginations are lifted up very high after the same rate as with those whose bodies are so, that as they are delighted with the advantage of a nearer contemplation upwards, so they are equally terrified with the dismal prospect of the precipice below.
modernized: This process seems natural since the more our imaginations soar, the greater our ability to contemplate the heights, yet the more we fear the daunting drop down below.

original: Thus in the choice of a devil it has been the usual method of mankind to single out some being, either in act or in vision, which was in most antipathy to the god they had framed.
modernized: Humanity generally selects a being, in either action or vision, as a devil that is diametrically opposed to the god they have fashioned.

original: Thus also the sect of the AEolists possessed themselves with a dread and horror and hatred of two malignant natures, betwixt whom and the deities they adored perpetual enmity was established.
modernized: The sect of Aeolists harbored a deep dread, loathing, and hatred toward two dismal entities, in constant enmity with the deities they revered.

original: The first of these was the chameleon, sworn foe to inspiration, who in scorn devoured large influences of their god, without refunding the smallest blast by eructation.
modernized: The first of these was the chameleon, the sworn enemy of inspiration, who devoured large shares of their god's energy without returning even the slightest whisper in exchange.

original: The other was a huge terrible monster called Moulinavent, who with four strong arms waged eternal battle with all their divinities, dexterously turning to avoid their blows and repay them with interest.
modernized: The other was a large, terrible creature named Moulinavent, who waged eternal war against all their gods with swift strategic movements, managing to dodge their blows and strike back twice as hard.

original: There is no miracle mentioned in Holy Writ, which, if it were strictly examined, is not as much, contrary to common reason, and as much a mystery, as this doctrine of the Trinity; and therefore we may, with equal justice deny the truth of them all.
modernized: Every miracle mentioned in the Bible, if scrutinized, contradicts common sense as much as the teaching of the Trinity. Thus, we could question the truth of all of them.

original: For instance: It is against the laws of nature, that a human body should be able to walk upon the water, as St Peter is recorded to have done; or that a dead carcass should be raised from the grave after three days, when it began to be corrupted; which those who understand anatomy will pronounce to be impossible by the common rules of nature and reason.
modernized: As examples: It defies the laws of nature for a human body to walk on water, as Saint Peter is said to have done; or for a dead body to rise from the grave after three days, once it has begun to decompose, which anatomists would deem impossible according to natural laws.

original: Yet these miracles, and many others, are positively affirmed in the Gospel; and these we must believe, or give up our holy religion to atheists and infidels.
modernized: However, these miracles, along with many others, are asserted in the Gospel, and accepting them is essential to preserving our religious beliefs, or we risk losing faith altogether.

original: The three former letters from the Drapier, having not received any public censure, I look upon them to be without exception; and that the good people of the kingdom ought to read them often, in order to keep up that spirit raised against this destructive coin of Mr. Wood: As for this last letter, against which a proclamation is issued; I shall only say, that I could wish it were stripped of all that can be any way exceptionable; which I would not think it below me to undertake, if my abilities were equal; but being naturally somewhat slow of comprehension; no lawyer, and apt to believe the best of those who profess good designs, without any visible motive either of profit or honour; I might pore for ever, without distinguishing the cockle from the corn.
modernized: The first three letters written by the Drapier are considered reliable, and the people should read them frequently to maintain their anti-destructive coin stance. The most recent letter, which has sparked a proclamation, could be improved by removing controversial elements. I'm not capable of making these edits due to my slow comprehension, lack of legal expertise, and tendency to trust those with good intentions. I might spend an eternity attempting to differentiate between good and bad without fully understanding.

original: The reader may remember, that when I signed those articles, upon which I recovered my liberty, there were some which I disliked, upon account of their being too servile; neither could anything but an extreme necessity have forced me to submit.
modernized: The reader may recall that, when I agreed to the terms that granted me my freedom, some of them displeased me because they seemed excessively servile. Under such circumstances, I was only able to comply due to an extreme emergency.

original: But, being now a nardac of the highest rank in that empire, such offices were looked upon as below my dignity, and the emperor, to do him justice, never once mentioned them to me.
modernized: However, as a high-ranking nardac in the empire, such tasks were considered beneath my status, and the emperor graciously never brought them up to me.

original: However, it was not long before I had an opportunity of doing his majesty, at least as I then thought, a most signal service.
modernized: But it wasn't long before I had the chance, as I saw it then, to provide his majesty with a significant service.

original: I was alarmed at midnight with the cries of many hundred people at my door, by which, being suddenly awaked, I was in some kind of terror.
modernized: I was jolted awake in the middle of the night by the loud cries of hundreds of people at my door, causing me to feel quite disoriented.

original: I heard the word burglum repeated incessantly.
modernized: I repeatedly heard the word 'burglum' in a panicked tone.

original: Say the Children have fore Eyes; Miss Betty won't take to her Book, &c.
modernized: Tell the children that they have foresight and encourage them to read books, but Miss Betty might not be interested.

original: Make the Misses read French and English Novels, and French Romances, and all the Comedies writ in King Charles II. and King William's Reigns, to soften their Nature, and make them tender-hearted, &c.
modernized: Have the young ladies read French and English novels, and French romances, as well as comedies from the reigns of King Charles II and King William, to make them sensitive and caring.

original: To conclude this head.
modernized: The conclusion of this point is:

original: In answer to that objection of keeping up animosity and hatred between Protestants, by the observation of this day; if there be any sect or sort of people among us, who profess the same principles in religion and government which those puritan rebels put in practice, I think it is the interest of all those who love the Church and King, to keep up as strong a party against them as possible, until they shall, in a body, renounce all those wicked opinions upon which their predecessors acted, to the disgrace of Christianity, and the perpetual infamy of the English nation.
modernized: Regarding the concern about preserving hostility and hatred between Protestants through the celebration of this day: If any group among us maintains the same religious and governmental principles as the Puritan rebels, it would be in the interest of those who support the Church and King to maintain a strong opposition against them until they publicly renounce their detrimental beliefs, which brought shame to Christianity and infamy to the English nation.

original: It was the dismallest rainy day I ever saw: I went to the Secretary in the morning, and he was gone to Windsor.
modernized: On the gloomiest rainy day I've ever experienced, I went to see the Secretary in the morning, but he had already left for Windsor.

original: Then it began raining, and I struck in to Mrs. Vanhomrigh's, and dined, and stayed till night very dull and insipid.
modernized: After that, it started raining, and I sought refuge at Mrs. Vanhomrigh's, where I had lunch and wasted the rest of the day in a boring and uninteresting manner.

original: I hate this town in summer; I'll leave it for a while, if I can have time.
modernized: I dislike this town during summer seasons; I plan to leave for a while, as long as I manage to find the time.

original: This open, bold declaration of mine was so opposite to the schemes and politics of his imperial majesty, that he could never forgive me; he mentioned it, in a very artful manner, at council, where, I was told, that some of the wisest appeared, at least by their silence, to be of my opinion; but others, who were my secret enemies, could not forbear some expressions, which by a side-wind reflected on me.
modernized: My honest opinion, which was contrary to his majesty's schemes, was openly declared. Some of the wisest advisors were reported to agree with me, but my secret enemies spoke against me in a sly manner during council. This began an underhanded plot against me, initiated by his majesty and some malicious ministers within two months, which nearly resulted in my downfall.

original: And, from this time began an intrigue between his majesty and a junto of ministers maliciously bent against me, which broke out in less than two months, and had like to have ended in my utter destruction.
modernized: The plan against me, formed by his majesty and some dishonest advisors, unfolded and threatened my life within two months.

original: Of so little weight are the greatest services to princes, when put into the balance with a refusal to gratify their passions.
modernized: The noblest deeds performed for the prince count for little if he is upset that I did not appease his personal desires.

original: The goddess and her train, having mounted the chariot, which was drawn by tame geese, flew over infinite regions, shedding her influence in due places, till at length she arrived at her beloved island of Britain; but in hovering over its metropolis, what blessings did she not let fall upon her seminaries of Gresham and Covent-garden!
modernized: The goddess, her followers, and the chariot pulled by tame geese journeyed through endless realms, dispersing her power where it was needed, until they finally reached her beloved island of Britain. As they flew over her capital, she brought down blessings onto her educational institutions of Gresham and Covent Garden.

original: And now she reached the fatal plain of St. James's library, at what time the two armies were upon the point to engage; where, entering with all her caravan unseen, and landing upon a case of shelves, now desert, but once inhabited by a colony of virtuosos, she stayed awhile to observe the posture of both armies.
modernized: She eventually arrived at the battlefield of St. James's library, where the two armies were about to clash. Entering undetected, the goddess, along with her entourage, landed on an empty shelf set that was once home to a group of intellectuals, and observed the battle positions of both armies.

original: We at this distance, who see nothing of the spring of actions, are forced by mere conjecture to assign two reasons for your desiring us to repeal the Sacramental Test: One is, because you are said to imagine it will be one step towards the like good work in England: The other more immediate, that it will open a way for rewarding several persons who have well deserved upon a great occasion, but who are now unqualified through that impediment.
modernized: From a distance, unable to see the root causes of actions, we speculate on two potential reasons for your desire to repeal the Sacramental Test: One is that you believe it could be a step towards a similar effort in England. The other is a more immediate goal, providing a path for rewarding several individuals who deserve recognition for their actions on a significant occasion, but who are now unable due to that obstacle.

original: The causes assigned for delaying the publication of this history were principally these: That the manuscript fell into the hands of men, who, whatever they might have been by the generality deemed, were by the Dean believed to be of his party, though they did not, after his death, judge it prudent to avow his principles, more than to deny them in his lifetime.
modernized: The reasons given for the delay in publishing this history were mainly due to the fact that the manuscript was acquired by individuals who, according to the Dean's view, were connected to his political party, although they chose not to publicly announce their beliefs even after his death.

original: These men, having got their beavers, tobacco-boxes, and other trifling remembrances of former friendship, by the Dean's will, did not choose publicly to avow principles, that had marred their friend's promotion, and might probably put a stop to theirs.
modernized: These individuals, having received keepsakes and tokens of previous friendships in the Dean's will, did not feel the need to publicly endorse principles that may have negatively impacted their own careers.

original: Therefore, they gave the inquisitive world to understand, that there was something too strong against many great men, as well as the succeeding system of public affairs in general, in the Dean's History of the Four Last Years of the Queen's Reign, to admit of a publication, in our times; and, with this poor insinuation, excused themselves, and satisfied the weakly well-affected, in suppressing the manifestation of displeasing truths, of however great importance to society.
modernized: Consequently, they chose to hint that there was something highly criticizing numerous influential individuals, as well as the later political system, within the Dean's History of the Four Last Years of the Queen's Reign. This vague insinuation allowed them to cover up the disclosure of uncomfortable truths, which they believed were significant to society.

original: I proceed, therefore, in the third place, to show the perfection of Christian wisdom from above; and I shall endeavour to make it appear from those proper characters and marks of it by the Apostle before mentioned, in the third chapter, and 15th, 16th, and 17th verses.
modernized: In the third point, I will demonstrate the perfection of divine wisdom as presented in Christianity. I will illustrate this by referring to the characteristics and signs mentioned by the Apostle in the third chapter, verses 15th, 16th, and 17th.

original: I have now done with your Memorial, and freely excuse your mistakes, since you appear to write as a stranger, and as of a country which is left at liberty to enjoy the benefits of nature, and to make the best of those advantages which God hath given it, in soil, climate, and situation.
modernized: I have completed addressing the petition you submitted, and I will forgive any errors since you seem to be an outsider, describing a country that enjoys natural resources and aims to make the most of the advantages provided by the environment, including the soil, climate, and geographical position.

original: A while after was revived an old fashion, long antiquated, of embroidery with Indian figures of men, women, and children.
modernized: A while later, an old, outdated fashion of Indian embroidered figures was revived.

original: Here they had no occasion to examine the will.
modernized: They didn't see the need to examine the will.

original: They remembered but too well how their father had always abhorred this fashion; that he made several paragraphs on purpose, importing his utter detestation of it, and bestowing his everlasting curse to his sons whenever they should wear it.
modernized: They vividly remembered their father's strong disapproval of this fashion, having spoken against it multiple times and placing everlasting curses upon them for wearing it.

original: For all this, in a few days they appeared higher in the fashion than anybody else in the town.
modernized: Despite this, within a few days, they were higher in fashion than anyone else in town.

original: But they solved the matter by saying that these figures were not at all the same with those that were formerly worn and were meant in the will; besides, they did not wear them in that sense, as forbidden by their father, but as they were a commendable custom, and of great use to the public.
modernized: They solved the controversy by claiming these figures were not the same as the ones their father had disapproved; they wore them to follow a beneficial tradition, not as specifically forbidden by their father.

original: That these rigorous clauses in the will did therefore require some allowance and a favourable interpretation, and ought to be understood cum grano salis.
modernized: These strict clauses in the will needed some leniency and a considerate interpretation, and should be understood with a grain of salt.

original: Another advantage proposed by the abolishing of Christianity, is the clear gain of one day in seven, which is now entirely lost, and consequently the kingdom one seventh less considerable in trade, business, and pleasure, besides the loss to the public of so many stately structures now in the hands of the Clergy, which might be converted into playhouses, exchanges, market houses, common dormitories, and other public edifices.
modernized: One benefit of abolishing Christianity is the additional workday gained, as one seventh of the kingdom's trade, business, and leisure is currently lost. This includes the loss of grand buildings owned by the clergy, which could be repurposed into cultural centers, marketplaces, dormitories, and other public facilities.

original: Fourthly: The old virtue and loyalty, and generous spirit of the English nation, were wholly corrupted by the power, the doctrine, and the example of those wicked people.
modernized: Fourthly, the ancient sense of virtue, loyalty, and generosity among the English people was entirely undone by the influence, teachings, and behavior of those wicked individuals.

original: Many of the ancient nobility were killed, and their families extinct, in defence of their Prince and country, or murdered by the merciless courts of justice.
modernized: Many members of the old aristocracy were either killed in battle defending their king and country, or were eliminated by unjust courts.

original: Some of the worst among them favoured, or complied with the reigning iniquities, and not a few of the new set created, when the Martyr's son was restored, were such who had drunk too deep of the bad principles then prevailing.
modernized: Some of the most wicked individuals among them supported or tolerated the oppressive practices, and several new figures who emerged as the martyr's son was reinstated had been heavily influenced by the corrupt principles that were prevalent at the time.

original: Before you enter into the common insufferable cant of taking all occasions to disparage the heathen philosophers, I hope you will differ from some of your brethren, by first enquiring what those philosophers can say for themselves.
modernized: Instead of routinely criticizing the philosophers of ancient times, it's best to first consider what arguments they might present in their defense.

original: The system of morality to be gathered out of the writings or sayings of those ancient sages, falls undoubtedly very short of that delivered in the Gospel, and wants besides, the divine sanction which our Saviour gave to His.
modernized: The moral system derived from the works or sayings of these ancient wise men is significantly inferior to the one presented in the Bible, and also lacks the divine endorsement that Jesus provided.

original: Whatever is further related by the evangelists, contains chiefly, matters of fact, and consequently of faith, such as the birth of Christ, His being the Messiah, His Miracles, His death, resurrection, and ascension.
modernized: The parts of the Bible that mainly consist of historical facts and events, like the birth, life, miracles, death, resurrection, and ascension of Christ, are not aspects of human wisdom, but are intended to lead us towards salvation.

original: None of which can properly come under the appellation of human wisdom, being intended only to make us wise unto salvation.
modernized: Therefore, the only criticism that can be justly leveled at the philosophers is that they were unaware of events that occurred after their deaths.

original: And therefore in this point nothing can justly be laid to the charge of the philosophers further than that they were ignorant of certain facts that happened long after their death.
modernized: However, I question whether better commentary on the moral aspects of the Bible could be found elsewhere than in the writings of these wise men, even the precept of loving our enemies is emphasized by Plato, who attributes it to Socrates.

original: But I am deceived, if a better comment could be anywhere collected, upon the moral part of the Gospel, than from the writings of those excellent men; even that divine precept of loving our enemies, is at large insisted on by Plato, who puts it, as I remember, into the mouth of Socrates.
modernized: On the matter of the 'heathen' reproach, I suspect they experienced less criticism than the corrupt Jews during their time period, which I believe shows a level of ignorance among us in regards to their learned and sophisticated era.

original: And as to the reproach of heathenism, I doubt they had less of it than the corrupted Jews in whose time they lived.
modernized: In those refined and intellectual times, even well-educated individuals, let alone the wisest philosophers, only recognized a single almighty power under various names, to,

original: For it is a gross piece of ignorance among us to conceive that in those polite and learned ages, even persons of any tolerable education, much less the wisest philosophers did acknowledge or worship any more than one almighty power, under several denominations, to whom they allowed all those attributes we ascribe to the Divinity: and as I take it, human comprehension reacheth no further: neither did our Saviour think it necessary to explain to us the nature of God, because I suppose it would be impossible without bestowing on us other faculties than we possess at present.
modernized: From my perspective, human understanding reaches its limit in grasping the nature of God, and since Jesus did not explain the nature of God in detail to us, I assume that it would be impossible without bestowing upon us additional abilities that we currently do not possess.
