They, the philosophers, did not have this knowledge.

original: But the true misery of the heathen world appears to be what I before mentioned, the want of a Divine Sanction, without which the dictates of the philosophers failed in the point of authority, and consequently the bulk of mankind lay indeed under a great load of ignorance even in the article of morality, but the philosophers themselves did not.
modernized: The true hardship of the heathen world seems to stem from the absence of a divinely ordained sanction, without which the philosophers' teachings lacked authority, causing the majority of people to remain ignorant about morality. However, the philosophers themselves were not part of this ignorance.

original: Take the matter in this light, it will afford field enough for a divine to enlarge on, by showing the advantages which the Christian world has over the heathen, and the absolute necessity of Divine Revelation, to make the knowledge of the true God, and the practice of virtue more universal in the world.
modernized: When the situation is viewed in this way, a preacher would have plenty to discuss, demonstrating the advantages enjoyed by the Christian world over the heathen, and the absolute requirement of divine revelation to make the knowledge of the true God and the practice of virtue more widespread in the world.

original: But suppose there were not one single halfpenny of copper coin in this whole kingdom (which Mr. Wood seems to intend, unless we will come to his terms, as appears by employing his emissaries to buy up our old ones at a penny in the shilling more than they pass for), it could not be any real evil to us, although it might be some inconvenience.
modernized: If there were no copper coins in the entire kingdom (as it seems Mr. Wood desires, unless we accept his conditions, as suggested by his emissaries buying up our old copper coins at a premium), it wouldn't cause any serious harm to us, though it might cause some inconvenience.

original: We have many sorts of small silver coins, to which they are strangers in England, such as the French threepences, fourpence halfpennies and eightpence halfpennies, the Scotch fivepences and tenpences, besides their twentypences, and three-and-fourpences, by all which we are able to make change to a halfpenny of almost any piece of gold or silver, and if we are driven to Brown's expedient of a sealed card, with the little gold or silver still remaining, it will I suppose, be somewhat better than to have nothing left but Wood's adulterated copper, which he is neither obliged by his patent, nor hitherto able by his estate to make good.
modernized: We possess several types of small silver coins unfamiliar to England, such as French threepences, fourpence halfpennies and eightpence halfpennies, Scottish fivepences and tenpences, along with twentypences, three-and-fourpences. With all these coins, we are capable of making change to half a penny of almost any gold or silver coin. If we run out of options and have to resort to Brown's method of a sealed contract, it would probably be more beneficial than having just the adulterated copper coins produced by Mr. Wood, which he has not been required to produce by his patent, nor has he managed to do so using his resources.

original: The swearing revenues of the town of Cork will be given for ever, by the bank, to the support of poor clergymen's widows; and those of Ringsend will be allowed to the maintenance of sailors' bastards.
modernized: The bank will give the revenue from swearing in Cork to support poor clergymen's widows, and the revenue from Ringsend will be used to maintain illegitimate children of sailors.

original: I entreated this illustrious person, to intercede in my behalf with his majesty, for leave to depart; which he accordingly did, as he was pleased to tell me, with regret: for indeed he had made me several offers very advantageous, which, however, I refused, with expressions of the highest acknowledgment.
modernized: I requested the noble person to speak to the king on my behalf for permission to leave; he obliged me, apparently sad about it, since he had previously offered me several appealing deals, which I politely declined with expressions of great appreciation.

original: Two clergymen, in my memory, stood candidates for a small free school in Yorkshire, where a gentleman of quality and interest in the country, who happened to have a better understanding than his neighbours, procured the place for him who was the better scholar, and more gentlemanly person, of the two, very much to the regret of all the parish: The other, being disappointed, came up to London, where he became the greatest pattern of this lower discretion that I have known, and possessed it with as heavy intellectuals; which, together with the coldness of his temper, and gravity of his deportment, carried him safe through many difficulties, and he lived and died in a great station; while his competitor is too obscure for fame to tell us what became of him.
modernized: Two clergymen whom I remember, competed for a position at a small free school in Yorkshire. A man of influence in the area, who had a better understanding than those around him, secured the spot for the better scholar and more refined candidate, much to the dismay of the parishioners. The other applicant, feeling rejected, moved to London, where becoming the epitome of less intellectually sophisticated discretion, he navigated various challenges with his reserved demeanor, cold disposition, and substantial intellect. He rose to a prominent position and lived and died in high standing, while his competitor's fate remains unknown.

original: These, I say, and the like methods would in corrupt times have been taken to let in this deluge of brass among us; and I am confident would even then have not succeeded, much less under the administration of so excellent a person as the Lord Carteret, and in a country where the people of all ranks, parties and denominations are convinced to a man, that the utter undoing of themselves and their posterity for ever will be dated from the admission of that execrable coin; that if it once enters, it can be no more confined to a small or moderate quantity, than the plague can be confined to a few families, and that no equivalent can be given by any earthly power, any more than a dead carcass can be recovered to life by a cordial.
modernized: In corrupt times, this and similar strategies could have been employed to introduce an overwhelming amount of debased currency into our country. Even then, I believe these attempts would have failed, especially under the administration of such an excellent person as the Lord Carteret. The people of all social classes, political affiliations, and religious beliefs in the country are completely convinced that the ruin of themselves and their future generations would begin with the admission of this abhorrent coin. If it entered the system, it could not be confined to small or moderate amounts, any more than the plague could be contained among a few families. No earthly power could compensate for this, any more than a dead body could be revived with a tonic.

original: Matters being in this posture between me and my lover; I received intelligence that he had been for some time making very pressing overtures of marriage to my rival, until there happened some misunderstandings between them; she gave him ill words, and threatened to break off all commerce with him.
modernized: I found myself in a difficult position with my lover when I learned he had made longstanding proposals of marriage to my rival, which resulted in them having a falling out. She treated him badly and threatened to end their relationship.

original: He, on the other side, having either acquired courage by his triumphs over me, or supposing her as tame a fool as I, thought at first to carry it with a high hand; but hearing at the same time, that she had thoughts of making some private proposals to join with me against him, and doubting, with very good reason, that I would readily accept them, he seemed very much disconcerted.
modernized: Despite his victories against me, he initially acted with arrogance towards my rival, but upon learning she had thoughts of allying herself with me, he became greatly unsettled because he suspected I would readily accept her offer.

original: This I thought was a proper occasion to shew some great example of generosity and love, and so, without further consideration, I sent him word, that hearing there was likely to be a quarrel between him and my rival; notwithstanding all that had passed, and without binding him to any conditions in my own favour, I would stand by him against her and all the world, while I had a penny in my purse, or a petticoat to pawn.
modernized: Believing this was an opportunity to show exceptional generosity and love, I wrote to him, offering to stand by him against my rival and everyone else, regardless of what had transpired between us. I made no conditions in my own favor.

original: This message was subscribed by all my chief tenants; and proved so powerful, that my rival immediately grew more tractable upon it.
modernized: My offer proved powerful as my rival became more cooperative after receiving it.

original: The result of which was, that there is now a treaty of marriage concluded between them, the wedding clothes are bought, and nothing remaineth but to perform the ceremony, which is put off for some days, because they design it to be a public wedding.
modernized: This led to a marriage proposal between them, the wedding preparations are underway, and all that remains is to perform the ceremony, which has been postponed to become a public event.

original: And to reward my love, constancy, and generosity, he hath bestowed on me the office of being sempstress to his grooms and footmen, which I am forced to accept or starve.
modernized: To show gratitude for my support, he gave me the task of being seamstress for his grooms and footmen, although I am forced to take it or risk going hungry.

original: Yet, in the midst of this my situation, I cannot but have some pity for this deluded man, to cast himself away on an infamous creature, who, whatever she pretendeth, I can prove, would at this very minute rather be a whore to a certain great man, that shall be nameless, if she might have her will.
modernized: In spite of my current predicament, I cannot help but pity this foolish man for choosing to marry a woman who, even if she claims otherwise, I can prove would willingly become a mistress to a powerful man if given the chance.

original: For my part, I think, and so doth all the country too, that the man is possessed; at least none of us are able to imagine what he can possibly see in her, unless she hath bewitched him, or given him some powder.
modernized: Generally speaking, people around me believe the man is mad, as no one can figure out what he could possibly see in her, unless she has cast a spell on him or given him some kind of magical substance.

original: Now, from this heavenly descent of criticism, and the close analogy it bears to heroic virtue, it is easy to assign the proper employment of a true, ancient, genuine critic: which is, to travel through this vast world of writings; to peruse and hunt those monstrous faults bred within them; to drag out the lurking errors, like Cacus from his den; to multiply them like Hydra's heads; and rake them together like Augeas's dung; or else to drive away a sort of dangerous fowl who have a perverse inclination to plunder the best branches of the tree of knowledge, like those Stymphalian birds that ate up the fruit.
modernized: From this divine descent of literary criticism, and the close similarity it shares with heroic virtue, it's simple to describe the proper job for a true, old-school, authentic literary critic: to explore the vast ocean of literature; to read and seek out the monstrous errors within them; to uncover hidden errors, much like Cacus from his lair; to multiply them like the many heads of Hydra; and gather them together like Augeas's manure; or instead, to drive away a type of harmful birds that inexplicably plunder the best parts of the tree of wisdom, just like the Stymphalian birds that devoured the fruit.

original: But now it is time to proceed to my predictions, which I have begun to calculate from the time that the Sun enters into Aries.
modernized: I will now present my predictions, starting from the time the Sun enters Aries, which I consider as the start of the year.

original: And this I take to be properly the beginning of the natural year.
modernized: I believe this is an accurate beginning of the natural year.

original: I pursue them to the time that he enters Libra, or somewhat more, which is the busy period of the year.
modernized: I continue to follow these predictions until the Sun enters Libra or slightly beyond, which is the busy time of the year.

original: The remainder I have not yet adjusted, upon account of several impediments needless here to mention: Besides, I must remind the reader again, that this is but a specimen of what I design in succeeding years to treat more at large, if I may have liberty and encouragement.
modernized: However, I have not yet finished calculating the rest. There are certain obstacles I do not wish to go into detail about here. Also, I would like to remind the reader again that this is just a sample of my work, which I plan to expand upon in future if permitted and encouraged.

original: I think it a little unhospitable, and others may call it a subtile piece of malice, that, because there may be a dozen families in this Town, able to entertain their English friends in a generous manner at their tables, their guests upon their return to England, shall report that we wallow in riches and luxury.
modernized: I think it's a bit unfriendly and some might call it subtle acts of spite, that, because there are around a dozen wealthy families in this town who can entertain their English friends generously at their homes, their guests who return to England might report that we are immersed in wealth and luxury.

original: For my own part, I swam as fortune directed me, and was pushed forward by wind and tide.
modernized: I swam as a result of my circumstances, and I was carried forward by the wind and the tides.

original: I often let my legs drop, and could feel no bottom; but, when I was almost gone, and able to struggle no longer, I found myself within my depth; and, by this time, the storm was much abated.
modernized: I flailed my legs and couldn't find the bottom, but when I was barely able to keep going, and could no longer struggle, I discovered I was within a depth that I could stand; and by then, the storm had greatly subsided.

original: Lastly: All offences against our own country have this aggravation, that they are ungrateful and unnatural.
modernized: Ultimately, any harm against our own country is particularly egregious because it is ungrateful and unnatural.

original: It is to our country we owe those laws which protect us in our lives, our liberties, our properties, and our religion.
modernized: We owe our country the laws that safeguard our lives, our freedoms, our possessions, and our religion.

original: Our country produced us into the world, and continues to nourish us so, that it is usually called our mother; and there have been examples of great magistrates, who have put their own children to death for endeavouring to betray their country, as if they had attempted the life of their natural parent.
modernized: Our country raises and nurtures us, so it is often called our mother. In fact, there have been instances of powerful leaders who executed their own children for attempting to betray their country, as if they had attempted to harm their natural parent.

original: I have read somewhere of an eastern king who put a judge to death for an iniquitous sentence, and ordered his hide to be stuffed into a cushion, and placed upon the tribunal for the son to sit on, who was preferred to his father's office.
modernized: I read about an Eastern king who executed a judge for an unjust verdict, and had his hide made into a cushion that the son, who took his father's position, had to sit on. This punishment might have been a reminder to the son of Sir William Scroggs.

original: I fancy such a memorial might not have been unuseful to a son of Sir William Scroggs, and that both he and his successors would often wriggle in their seats as long as the cushion lasted.
modernized: Having such a reminder might not have been useless for a son of Sir William Scroggs and could have made his successors uncomfortable as long as the cushion lasted.

original: I wish the relater had told us what number of such cushions there might be in that country.
modernized: It would have been helpful if the storyteller had informed us how many of such cushions might exist in that country.

original: A fourth was the knavery of those merchants, or linen-manufacturers, or both, when, upon occasion of the plague at Marseilles, we had a fair opportunity of getting into our hands the whole linen-trade of Spain; but the commodity was so bad, and held at so high a rate, that almost the whole cargo was returned, and the small remainder sold below the prime cost.
modernized: Fourthly, the merchants or manufacturers took advantage of the plague in Marseilles to control the entire Spanish linen trade, but the poor quality and high price led to almost the entire cargo being sent back and the remaining stock being sold below cost.

original: Poor Duke of Shrewsbury has been very ill of a fever: we were all in a fright about him: I thank God, he is better.
modernized: The Duke of Shrewsbury has been very ill with a fever, but he is recovering now.

original: I dined to-day at Lord Ashburnham's, with his lady, for he was not at home: she is a very good girl, and always a great favourite of mine.
modernized: I had dinner at Lord Ashburnham's, where only his lady was present because he was absent. She is very kind to me.

original: Sterne tells me he has desired a friend to receive your box in Chester, and carry it over.
modernized: Sterne informs me that he asked a friend to receive your box in Chester and deliver it.

original: I fear he will miscarry in his business, which was sent to the Treasury before he was recommended; for I was positive only to second his recommendations, and all his other friends failed him.
modernized: However, I worry that his business, which was sent to the Treasury without his recommendation, may fail due to others' failures to support him.

original: However, on your account I will do what I can for him tomorrow with the secretary of the Treasury.
modernized: Therefore, I will try to help him with the secretary of the Treasury tomorrow because of your connection.

original: What proofs they bring for our endeavouring to introduce Popery, arbitrary power, and the Pretender, I cannot readily tell, and would be glad to hear; however, those important words having by dexterous management, been found of mighty service to their cause, though applied with little colour, either of reason or justice; I have been considering whether they may not be adapted to more proper objects.
modernized: I'm unsure of the evidence they present to support our supposed intentions to introduce Popery, arbitrary power, and the Pretender. They have effectively used these charged words in their arguments, but with limited relevance or justification. I pondered whether they might be used against more appropriate targets instead.

original: Another clause should be, that none of these twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty pounders may be suffered to marry, under the penalty of immediate deprivation, their marriages declared null, and their children bastards; for some desponding people, take the kingdom to be not in a condition of encouraging so numerous a breed of beggars.
modernized: Another clause should be, none of these twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty pounders may be allowed to marry, facing the penalty of immediate dismissal, their marriages deemed null, and their offspring considered illegitimate. Some pessimistic individuals view the kingdom as unable to accommodate a large number of such potential beggars.

original: In my conscience, I fear I shall have the gout.
modernized: I am worried that I may get gout.

original: I sometimes feel pains about my feet and toes: I never drank till within these two years, and I did it to cure my head.
modernized: I occasionally have pain in my feet and toes. I haven't had alcohol for the past two years, and I did it to help my headaches.

original: I often sit evenings with some of these people, and drink in my turn; but I am now resolved to drink ten times less than before; but they advise me to let what I drink be all wine, and not to put water to it.
modernized: I often spend evenings with some of these people, drinking occasionally. However, I have decided to limit my alcohol intake significantly. They suggest all alcohol I drink should be wine, without mixing it with water.

original: Tooke and the printer stayed to-day to finish their affair, and treated me and two of the Under Secretaries upon their getting the Gazette.
modernized: Tooke and the printer stayed to complete their project, and have treated me and two of the lower-ranking secretaries upon receiving the Gazette.

original: Then I went to see Lord Treasurer, and chid him for not taking notice of me at Windsor.
modernized: I then went to see the Lord Treasurer and scolded him for not acknowledging me at Windsor.

original: He said he kept a place for me yesterday at dinner, and expected me there; but I was glad I did not go, because the Duke of Buckingham was there, and that would have made us acquainted; which I have no mind to.
modernized: He said that he had set a place for me at dinner the previous day and expected me to attend, but I was glad I didn't go since the Duke of Buckingham was there, which I do not wish to become acquainted with.

original: However, we appointed to sup at Mr. Masham's, and there stayed till past one o'clock; and that is late, sirrahs: and I have much business.
modernized: We planned to dine at Mr. Masham's later, and stayed until after one o'clock; that is quite late, I'm afraid, and I have a lot of work.

original: And now I conceive the main design I had in writing these papers, is fully executed.
modernized: Now, I believe the main purpose for penning these writings has been completely realized.

original: A great majority of the nation is at length thoroughly convinced, that the Qu[een] proceeded with the highest wisdom, in changing her ministry and Parliament.
modernized: A majority of the populace have finally come to understand that the Qu[een] exercised exceptional wisdom in replacing her ministry and Parliament.

original: That under a former administration, the greatest abuses of all kinds were committed, and the most dangerous attempts against the constitution for some time intended.
modernized: Under the previous administration, the most significant abuses of various kinds occurred, and there were dangerous attempts to undermine the constitution for a while.

original: The whole kingdom finds the present persons in power, directly and openly pursuing the true service of their QUEEN and country; and to be such whom their most bitter enemies cannot tax with bribery, covetousness, ambition, pride, insolence, or any pernicious principles in religion or government.
modernized: The entire kingdom acknowledges that the current leaders are transparently and devotedly serving their QUEEN and country, and that they cannot be accused of bribery, greed, ambition, pride, insolence, or dangerous ideologies in their religious or political beliefs.

original: The overtures made by this minister, of paying so vast a debt, under the pressures of a long war, and the difficulty of finding supplies for continuing it, was, during the time of his illness, ridiculed by his enemies as an impracticable and visionary project: and when, upon his return to the House, he had explained his proposal, the very proprietors of the debt were, many of them, prevailed on to oppose it; although the obtaining this trade, either through Old Spain, or directly to the Spanish West Indies, had been one principal end we aimed at by this war.
modernized: The proposals made by the minister to pay off such a massive debt during a war and under financial strain were initially met with ridicule by his opponents. However, when he returned to the House to explain his plan, some of the debtors themselves were convinced to oppose it, despite the fact that controlling trade between England and the Spanish West Indies, which was one of our main objectives in this war, was a key aspect of this debt-reduction plan.

original: However, the bill passed; and, as an immediate consequence, the naval bills rose to about twenty per cent., nor ever fell within ten of their discount.
modernized: Upon the bill's passage, the rates on naval bills rose to approximately 20%, never dropping below 10% thereafter.

original: Another good effect of this work appeared by the parliamentary lotteries, which have been since erected.
modernized: One positive result of these efforts became evident through the creation of parliamentary lotteries, which have been established since then.

original: The last of that kind, under the former ministry, was eleven weeks in filling; whereas the first, under the present, was filled in a very few hours, although it cost the government less; and the others, which followed, were full before the Acts concerning them could pass.
modernized: The previous lottery, run under the previous administration, took eleven weeks to fill; meanwhile, the initial lottery under the current administration was filled in a short time, despite costing the government less, as did the subsequent lotteries.

original: And to prevent incumbrances of this kind from growing for the future, he took care, by the utmost parsimony, or by suspending payments, where they seemed less to press, that all stores for the navy should be bought with ready money; by which cent. per cent. hath been saved in that mighty article of our expense, as will appear from an account taken at the victualling office on the 9th of August, one thousand seven hundred and twelve.
modernized: In order to prevent future financial burdens, the minister ensured that all necessary navy supplies were purchased using readily accessible funds. This careful expenditure saved a significant amount of money in the navy's supply costs, as will be clear from an account taken at the victualling office on August 9, 1712.

original: And the payment of the interest was less a burthen upon the navy, by the stores being bought at so cheap a rate.
modernized: Furthermore, the payment of interest on the debt was lessened by purchasing supplies for the navy at a lower cost.

original: The peers of Scotland, who are very numerous, were content to reside in their castles and houses, in that bleak and barren climate; and although some of them made frequent journeys to London, yet I do not remember any of their greatest families, till very lately, to have made England their constant habitation, before the Union: Or, if they did, I am sure it was generally to their own advantage; and whatever they got, was employed to cultivate and increase their own estates; and by that means enrich themselves and their country.
modernized: The peers of Scotland, who are very numerous, preferred to stay in their castles and houses, in their harsher and barren northern climate; even though some made frequent trips to London. I cannot recall any of their prominent families, prior to the Union, choosing to live in England continuously. If they did, it was mainly for personal gain, using their resources to improve and enrich their own lands and country.

original: The thirteenth, is where the people are not obliged, unless they find it for their own interest, or conveniency, to receive any monies, except of their own coinage by a public mint, after the manner of all civilized nations.
modernized: In the 13th case, people are free to accept currency only from their own mint, according to the practice of civilized societies, unless it's in their best interest or convenient for them.

original: The Ladder is an adequate symbol of faction and of poetry, to both of which so noble a number of authors are indebted for their fame.
modernized: The Ladder symbolically represents both faction and poetry, both of which have contributed significantly to the renown of numerous authors.

original: Of faction, because ...(Hiatus in MS.)... Of poetry, because its orators do perorare with a song; and because, climbing up by slow degrees, fate is sure to turn them off before they can reach within many steps of the top; and because it is a preferment attained by transferring of propriety and a confounding of meum and tuum.
modernized: Of faction, the ladder is symbolic due to... (hiatus in MS.)... Of poetry, the speakers elaborate with a song; and as they ascend slowly, fate inevitably ends their journey before reaching nearly the top; and as it is a position earned through the transfer and confusion of ownership and the mixing up of 'mine' and 'yours'.

original: This is the proposal made to us by Wood in that pamphlet written by one of his commissioners; and the author is supposed to be the same infamous Coleby one of his under-swearers at the committee of council, who was tried for robbing the treasury here, where he was an under-clerk.
modernized: Wood proposed in this pamphlet, written by one of his commissioners, that we'd received a questionable offer. The suspected author of this proposal is Coleby, one of Wood's underlings at the council committee, who faced trial for embezzlement in thetreasury while serving as an under-clerk.

original: I advise likewise, that no commodity whatsoever, of this nation's growth, should be sent to any other country except England, under the penalty of high treason; and that all the said commodities shall be sent in their natural state; the hides raw, the wool uncombed, the flax in the stub; excepting only fish, butter, tallow, and whatever else will be spoiled in the carriage.
modernized: I also suggest that no products whatsoever, grown within this nation, should be shipped to any country other than England, under the threat of high treason. These products should be sent in their natural state, unprocessed: with hides left uncleaned, wool not combed, and flax still in the stem. The exceptions are fish, butter, tallow, and anything else that is likely to spoil during transportation.

original: On the contrary, that no goods whatsoever shall be exported hither, except from England, under the same penalty: that England should be forced, at their own rates, to send us over clothes ready made, as well as shirts and smocks to the soldiers and their trulls; all iron, wooden, and earthen ware, and whatever furniture may be necessary for the cabins of graziers; with a sufficient quantity of gin, and other spirits, for those who, can afford to be drunk on holidays.
modernized: On the contrary, it should not be allowed for any goods whatsoever to be imported here, except from England, under the same penalty: England should be compelled to send over ready-made clothes, as well as shirts and smocks for the soldiers and their companions, all iron, wooden, and earthenware items, and any furniture necessary for the cabins of graziers; along with an adequate supply of gin and other spirits, for those who can afford to get drunk on holidays.

original: The expression in Apocrypha about Tobit and his dog following him I have often heard ridiculed, yet Homer has the same words of Telemachus more than once; and Virgil says something like it of Evander.
modernized: I've frequently heard the story in Apocrypha about Tobit and his dog following him mocked, yet Homer used similar words for Telemachus multiple times; and Virgil says something similar about Evander.

original: And I take the book of Tobit to be partly poetical.
modernized: Regarding the book of Tobit, I believe it contains some poetic elements.

original: I have a little interrupted the order of time, in relating the Duke of Ormonde's proceedings, who, after having placed a garrison at Bruges, and sent a supply of men and ammunition to Dunkirk, retired to Ghent, where he continued some months, till he had leave to return to England.
modernized: In my narrative, I've slightly altered the sequence of events regarding the Duke of Ormonde: following the placement of a garrison in Bruges and the dispatch of troops and ammunition to Dunkirk, he temporarily relocated to Ghent, where he stayed for some months, awaiting permission to return to England.

original: The nurseries for males of noble or eminent birth, are provided with grave and learned professors, and their several deputies.
modernized: Nurseries for high-ranking males are staffed with serious, scholarly instructors and their administrative assistants.

original: The clothes and food of the children are plain and simple.
modernized: The children's clothing and meals are straightforward and simple.

original: They are bred up in the principles of honour, justice, courage, modesty, clemency, religion, and love of their country; they are always employed in some business, except in the times of eating and sleeping, which are very short, and two hours for diversions consisting of bodily exercises.
modernized: They are raised to respect principles like honor, justice, courage, modesty, compassion, religion, and patriotism. They are constantly engaged in activities, except during meal or sleep times, which are very brief; they also have two hours each day for recreational activities involving physical exercise.

original: They are dressed by men till four years of age, and then are obliged to dress themselves, although their quality be ever so great; and the women attendant, who are aged proportionably to ours at fifty, perform only the most menial offices.
modernized: They are dressed by men until they are four years old, and then they must start dressing themselves, even if they come from a high noble family; the older female caretakers, who are similar in age to our 50-year-olds, perform only the most menial tasks.

original: They are never suffered to converse with servants, but go together in smaller or greater numbers to take their diversions, and always in the presence of a professor, or one of his deputies; whereby they avoid those early bad impressions of folly and vice, to which our children are subject.
modernized: They are not allowed to interact with servants, but instead go in groups to have their recreational activities, all under the supervision of a professor or one of their assistants; in this way, they avoid the negative influences that our children often experience.

original: Their parents are suffered to see them only twice a year; the visit is to last but an hour; they are allowed to kiss the child at meeting and parting; but a professor, who always stands by on those occasions, will not suffer them to whisper, or use any fondling expressions, or bring any presents of toys, sweetmeats, and the like.
modernized: Their parents can only visit them twice a year, and each visit lasts just an hour; they are only allowed to greet and bid farewell to the child, but a professor stands by on those occasions, preventing them from whispering, displaying affection, or giving presents like toys or sweets.

original: I am the more earnest in this matter, because it is a general complaint, and the justest in the world.
modernized: I'm extremely concerned about this issue because it's a common grievance and the most justifiable one.

original: For a divine has nothing to say to the wisest congregation of any parish in this kingdom, which he may not express in a manner to be understood by the meanest among them.
modernized: A divine should be able to communicate effectively with the smartest congregation in any parish across the kingdom, using language that even the least educated members can understand.

original: And this assertion must be true, or else God requires from us more than we are able to perform.
modernized: If this statement isn't accurate, then God expects more from us than we are capable of achieving.

original: However, not to contend whether a logician might possibly put a case that would serve for an exception, I will appeal to any man of letters, whether at least nineteen in twenty of those perplexing words might not be changed into easy ones, such as naturally first occur to ordinary men, and probably did so at first to those very gentlemen who are so fond of the former.
modernized: I'm not going to argue whether a logical reasoning may find an exception, but I'm asking any scholarly person if at least 95% of those confusing terms could not be replaced with simpler ones that naturally come to mind for ordinary people, and for those very prominent people who prefer the esoteric expressions.

original: In a very few centuries after Christianity became national in most parts of Europe, although the church of Rome had already introduced many corruptions in religion; yet the piety of early Christians, as well as new converts, was so great, and particularly of princes, as well as noblemen and other wealthy persons, that they built many religious houses, for those who were inclined to live in a recluse or solitary manner, endowing those monasteries with land.
modernized: In a few centuries after Christianity became widespread, wealthy individuals built monasteries and endowed them with land, providing a solitary place for individuals who were inclined to a religious lifestyle. This practice, though noble in intent, led to the decline of monasteries into laziness, ignorance, greed, ambition, and luxury.

original: It is true, we read of monks some ages before, who dwelt in caves and cells, in desert places.
modernized: Monks were known to live in caves and solitary cells in isolated areas long before the construction of monasteries.

original: But, when public edifices were erected and endowed, they began gradually to degenerate into idleness, ignorance, avarice, ambition, and luxury, after the usual fate of all human institutions.
modernized: As monasteries were developed with funds, they began to fall into decline, becoming indolent, uneducated, self-interested, power-hungry, and luxurious, following the usual trend of human institutions.

original: The Popes, who had already aggrandized themselves, laid hold of the opportunity to subject all religious houses with their priors and abbots, to their peculiar authority; whereby these religious orders became of an interest directly different from the rest of mankind, and wholly at the Pope's devotion.
modernized: The Popes, already powerful, used this opportunity to place their influence over religious houses and their leaders. This made these religious orders differ greatly from the rest of society, becoming completely devoted to the Pope.

original: I need say no more on this article, so generally known and so frequently treated, or of the frequent endeavours of some other princes, as well as our own, to check the growth, and wealth, and power of the regulars.
modernized: There's no need to discuss this issue further, as it's well-known and frequently discussed, or the efforts by various rulers, including our own, to curb the growth, wealth, and power of the religious groups.

original: The farmer by this time was convinced I must be a rational creature.
modernized: By now, the farmer was certain that I must be a reasonable being.

original: He spoke often to me, but the sound of his voice pierced my ears like that of a water-mill, yet his words were articulate enough.
modernized: He conversed with me frequently, but the sound of his voice rang in my ears like a watermill's, yet his speech was clear enough.

original: I answered as loud as I could in several languages, and he often laid his ear within two yards of me; but all in vain, for we were wholly unintelligible to each other.
modernized: I responded loudly in several languages, and he would bring his ear close to me, but we were unable to understand each other.

original: He then sent his servants to their work, and taking his handkerchief out of his pocket, he doubled and spread it on his left hand, which he placed flat on the ground, with the palm upwards, making me a sign to step into it, as I could easily do, for it was not above a foot in thickness.
modernized: He then sent his servants back to work, and he spread out his handkerchief on his palm, signaling for me to step onto it, as it was barely a foot thick.

original: Since the reduction of Normandy to the King's obedience, he found it necessary for his affairs to spend in that duchy some part of his time almost every year, and a little before the death of Robert he made his last voyage there.
modernized: For several years, the King had to visit Normandy annually due to its submission to his rule, and just before Duke Robert's death, he made one last journey there.

original: It was observable in this prince, that having some years past very narrowly escaped shipwreck in his passage from Normandy into England, the sense of his danger had made very deep impressions on his mind, which he discovered by a great reformation in his life, by redressing several grievances, and doing many acts of piety; and to shew the steadiness of his resolutions, he kept them to the last, making a progress through most parts of Normandy, treating his subjects in all places with great familiarity and kindness, granting their petitions, easing their taxes, and, in a word, giving all possible marks of a religious, wise, and gracious prince.
modernized: This prince was noticeable for the significant changes in his behaviors after narrowly avoiding a shipwreck during his passage from Normandy to England. As a result, he made improvements in his life, rectified several injustices, and performed numerous acts of piety. He kept these changes consistent until his last days, traveling through most of Normandy and treating his subjects with warmth and kindness, granting their requests, easing their burdens, and demonstrating the characteristics of a religious, wise, and benevolent monarch.

original: It was necessary to give the reader this information, without which he would be at the same loss with me to understand the proceedings of these people, as they conducted me up the stairs to the top of the island, and from thence to the royal palace.
modernized: The reader needs to understand the customs of these people in order to follow along with the account of my journey to the royal palace. On the way up the stairs and to the top of the island, the people seemed lost at times, and only recalled what they were doing due to their flapper assistants.

original: While we were ascending, they forgot several times what they were about, and left me to myself, till their memories were again roused by their flappers; for they appeared altogether unmoved by the sight of my foreign habit and countenance, and by the shouts of the vulgar, whose thoughts and minds were more disengaged.
modernized: As we climbed, they appeared preoccupied and forgetful, leaving me alone at times until their flapper assistants awoke them. They seemed unaware of my foreign appearance, and the shouts of the crowd did not break their deep thoughts.

original: There is likewise a kind of beggarly princes in Europe, not able to make war by themselves, who hire out their troops to richer nations, for so much a day to each man; of which they keep three-fourths to themselves, and it is the best part of their maintenance: such are those in many northern parts of Europe.
modernized: There are also poverty-stricken monarchs in Europe who can't wage war alone, so they rent out their military troops to wealthier nations on a daily wage; they personally keep a large majority of this wage as their maintenance, and these states are commonly found in the northern regions of Europe.

original: While the King continued at Gloucester, Malcolm King of Scotland came to his court, with intentions to settle and confirm the late peace between them.
modernized: During King's stay at Gloucester, Malcolm King of Scotland arrived at the court with the intention of finalizing and securing the recent peace between them.

original: It happened that a controversy arose about some circumstances relating to the homage which Malcolm was to pay, in the managing whereof King William discovered so much haughtiness and disdain, both in words and gestures, that the Scottish prince, provoked by such unworthy treatment, returned home with indignation; but soon came back at the head of a powerful army, and, entering Northumberland with fire and sword, laid all waste before him.
modernized: A disagreement emerged over some specific conditions concerning Malcolm's homage. King William's unpleasant behavior and disdainful gestures enraged Malcolm so much that he returned home indignant, but soon returned with a strong army, plundering Northumberland with fire and swords.

original: But as all enterprises have in the progress of them a tincture of those passions by which they were spirited at first, so this invasion begun upon private revenge, which is a blind ungovernable passion, was carried on with equal precipitation, and proved to be ruinous in the event; for Robert Mowbray, Earl of Northumberland, to prevent the destruction of his own country, where he had great possessions, gathering what forces he could suddenly raise, and without waiting any directions from the King, marched against the Scots, who were then set down before Alnwick Castle: there, by an ambush, Malcolm and his eldest son Edward were slain, and the army, discouraged by the loss of their princes, entirely defeated.
modernized: As all actions take on the flavor of the initial emotions that started them, this invasion motivated by personal revenge, a blind and uncontrollable passion, was carried out hastily and ended disastrously. Robert Mowbray, Earl of Northumberland, sought to save his own land from destruction since it had significant possessions. Without waiting for the King's orders, he quickly raised an army and attacked the Scots, who were camped before Alnwick Castle. There, through a surprise ambush, Malcolm and his eldest son Edward were killed, and the demoralized army was defeated.

original: This disaster was followed in a few days by the death of Queen Margaret, who, not able to survive her misfortunes, died for grief.
modernized: A few days later, Queen Margaret died from grief over the tragedies.

original: Neither did the miseries of that kingdom end till, after two usurpations, the surviving son of Malcolm, who had fled to England for refuge, was restored to his crown by the assistance of King William.
modernized: The tribulations of the kingdom did not end until, following two usurpations, the surviving son of Malcolm, who sought refuge in England, was restored to his throne with King William's help.

original: All this I was told; for, while the whole operation was performing, I lay in a profound sleep, by the force of that soporiferous medicine infused into my liquor.
modernized: I was informed about the whole process as it was happening, but I was fast asleep due to a sleep-inducing substance in my drink.

original: Fifteen hundred of the emperor's largest horses, each about four inches and a half high, were employed to draw me towards the metropolis, which, as I said, was half a mile distant.
modernized: Fifteen hundred of the emperor's horses, each around four and a half inches tall, were tasked with pulling me towards the city, which I mentioned earlier was half a mile away.

original: If any of the Combings happen to be sent up with the Victuals, you may safely lay the Fault upon any of the Footmen that hath vexed you: As those Gentlemen are sometimes apt to be malicious, if you refuse them a Sop in the Pan, or a Slice from the Spit, much more when you discharge a Ladle-full of hot Porridge on their Legs, or send them up to their Masters with a Dishclout pinned at their Tails.
modernized: If a servant brings a hair comb with the food, blame the footmen who are being mischievous. Servants sometimes act out of spite if you deny them a taste or slices of food, especially if you spill hot porridge on them or send a dish towel pinned to their backs. It is not uncommon for servants to misbehave when denied food or made to look foolish.

original: It should seem a strange, unaccountable thing, that those who have probably been reduced to want by riot, lewdness, and idleness, although they have assurance enough to beg alms publicly from all they meet, should yet be too proud to wear the parish badge, which would turn so much to their own advantage, by ridding them of such great numbers, who now intercept the greatest part of what belongeth to them: Yet it is certain, that there are very many who publicly declare they will never wear those badges, and many others who either hide or throw them away: But the remedy for this is very short, easy, and just, by trying them like vagabonds and sturdy beggars, and forcibly driving them out of the town.
modernized: It appears strange that those who are likely to be destitute due to reckless behavior, theft, and laziness, who publicly solicit charity from others, would refuse to wear identifying badges that could help them access more support and limit the number of beggars. However, many still refuse to wear these badges or hide or discard them. A solution to this issue is to punish and forcefully remove these individuals from the town, who should be considered vagrants and stubborn beggars.

original: The Empress Maud was now happily delivered of a son, who was afterwards King of England by the name of Henry the Second: and the King calling a Parliament, had the oath of fealty repeated by the nobles and clergy to her and her issue, which in the compass of three years they all broke or forgot.
modernized: Empress Maud gave birth to a son, who later became King Henry II of England. The King convened a Parliament and received an oath of loyalty from the nobles and clergy to Maud and her descendants. However, within three years, everyone forgot or abandoned their pledge.

original: But enthusiasm is none of his Lordship's faculty: I am inclined to believe he might be melancholy enough when he writ this Introduction: The despair at his age of seeing a faction restored, to which he hath sacrificed so great a part of his life: The little success he can hope for in case he should resume those High-Church Principles, in defence of which he first employed his pen: No visible expectation of removing to Farnham or Lambeth: And lastly, the misfortune of being hated by every one, who either wears the habit, or values the profession of a clergyman: No wonder such a spirit, in such a situation, is provoked beyond the regards of truth, decency, religion, or self-conviction.
modernized: The Lordship's enthusiasm is nonexistent, I suspect he may have felt severely disappointed when writing this Introduction: feeling hopeless about the restoration of a faction that has consumed a significant part of his life, seeing little chance of success if he were to return to High-Church principles, no signs of moving to Farnham or Lambeth, and being hated by many who identify with the clergy: in such a tough situation, it's no surprise he feels frustrated beyond the boundaries of truth, decency, religion, and self-conviction.

original: To do him justice, he seems to have nothing else left, but to cry out, halters, gibbets, faggots, inquisition, Popery, slavery, and the Pretender.
modernized: In an attempt to be fair, it seems he has nothing left but to cry out about halters, gibbets, faggots, inquisition, Popery, slavery, and the Pretender,

original: But in the meantime, he little considers what a world of mischief he does to his cause.
modernized: Meanwhile, he doesn't seem to understand the problems he's causing for his cause

original: It is very convenient, for the present designs of that faction, to spread the opinion of our immediate danger from Popery and the Pretender.
modernized: It is strategic for that faction to perpetuate the belief of imminent danger from Popery and the Pretender

original: His directors therefore ought, in my humble opinion, to have employed his Lordship in publishing a book, wherein he should have asserted, by the most solemn asseverations, that all things were safe and well; for the world has contracted so strong a habit of believing him backwards, that I am confident, nine parts in ten of those who have read or heard of his Introduction, have slept in greater security ever since.
modernized: His supervisors should, in my humble opinion, have gotten him to write a book emphasizing that things are safe and secure, as the world is accustomed to believing him pessimistic. Given that nine out of ten people who have read or heard about his Introduction feel safer since, I am certain.

original: It is like the melancholy tone of a watchman at midnight, who thumps with his pole, as if some thief were breaking in, but you know by the noise, that the door is fast.
modernized: This portrays a melancholic attitude of a night watchman, beating his pole as if there's a thief around, but you can tell by the noise that the door is secure.

original: These diversions are often attended with fatal accidents, whereof great numbers are on record.
modernized: These acrobatics frequently result in painful accidents, with many incidences on record.

original: I myself have seen two or three candidates break a limb.
modernized: I have personally witnessed two or three candidates suffer broken limbs.

original: But the danger is much greater when the ministers themselves are commanded to show their dexterity! for, by contending to excel themselves and their fellows, they strain so far that there is hardly one of them who hath not received a fall, and some of them two or three.
modernized: However, the risk is far greater when the officials themselves are tasked to perform, as they push themselves so hard that almost all suffer falls, and some even multiple falls.

original: I was assured that a year or two before my arrival, Flimnap would have infallibly broke his neck if one of the king's cushions, that accidentally lay on the ground, had not weakened the force of his fall.
modernized: It was told to me that a year or two prior to my arrival, Flimnap would have surely fractured his neck if not for a cushion that happen to be on the ground cushioning the impact.

original: To this end the philosopher's way in all ages has been by erecting certain edifices in the air; but whatever practice and reputation these kind of structures have formerly possessed, or may still continue in, not excepting even that of Socrates when he was suspended in a basket to help contemplation, I think, with due submission, they seem to labour under two inconveniences.
modernized: In order to be heard, philosophers throughout history have built platforms or structures high in the air. While these structures may have been successful or respected in the past, such as the one used by Socrates when he was suspended in a basket for contemplation, I believe they are burdened by two disadvantages. First, because the foundations are high up, they can often be out of sight and out of earshot.

original: First, that the foundations being laid too high, they have been often out of sight and ever out of hearing.
modernized: The primary issue is that the buildings are prone to being out of sight and hard to hear due to their foundations being too elevated.

original: Secondly, that the materials being very transitory, have suffered much from inclemencies of air, especially in these northwest regions.
modernized: Furthermore, because the materials used are quite fragile, they can deteriorate over time, especially in northern and western regions due to weather conditions.

original: A third cause of our great want of brotherly love seemeth to be, that this duty is not so often insisted on from the pulpit, as it ought to be in such times as these; on the contrary, it is to be doubted, whether doctrines are not sometimes delivered by an ungoverned zeal, a desire to be distinguished, or a view of interest, which produce quite different effects; when, upon occasions set apart to return thanks to God for some public blessing, the time is employed in stirring up one part of the congregation against the other, by representations of things and persons, which God, in his mercy, forgive those who are guilty of.
modernized: One of the main reasons we struggle to show brotherly love is because it isn't emphasized enough from the pulpit in these troubled times. Instead, there's a question about whether doctrines aren't sometimes delivered with undisciplined passion, a desire for recognition, or self-interest, which lead to very different outcomes. On occasions meant to thank God for a public blessing, the time is often spent inciting one part of the congregation against the other with inappropriate statements about people, which God might forgive those who make.

original: I need not tell you, sir, that this griping want, this dismal poverty, this additional woe, must be put to the accursed stocks, which have desolated our country more effectually than England.
modernized: It's obvious, sir, that the suffering, the poverty, and further hardship that our country endures were caused by the corrupt stocks. These stocks have ravaged our nation more thoroughly than England itself.

original: Stockjobbing was a kind of traffic we were utterly unacquainted with.
modernized: Trading in the South Sea market was something our people had no experience with.

original: We went late to the South Sea market, and bore a great share in the losses of it, without having tasted any of its profits.
modernized: We entered the South Sea market late and suffered significant losses, yet did not reap any profits.

original: Another part of the report concerned the Duke of Marlborough, who had received large sums of money, by way of gratuity, from those who were the undertakers for providing the army with bread.
modernized: Another part of the report implicated the Duke of Marlborough, who had accepted large sums of money as gratuities from the contractors responsible for supplying the army with bread.

original: This the Duke excused, in a letter to the commissioners, from the like practice of other generals: but that excuse appeared to be of little weight, and the mischievous consequences of such a corruption were visible enough; since the money given by these undertakers were but bribes for connivance at their indirect dealings with the army.
modernized: In a letter to the commissioners, the Duke offered an explanation, attributing his actions to the same practice among other generals. However, this excuse was deemed insufficient and the detrimental effects of such corruption were apparent. The money given by the contractors was essentially bribes that allowed them to hide questionable dealings with the army.

original: And as frauds, that begin at the top, are apt to spread through all the subordinate ranks of those who have any share in the management, and to increase as they circulate: so, in this case, for every thousand pounds given to the general, the soldiers at least suffered fourfold.
modernized: Similarly, corruption that originates from those in power can rapidly spread to lower ranks of those involved in the management, and grow as it permeates deeper. Here, for every thousand pounds given to the general, the soldiers suffered at least four times as much.

original: Mean time the King was equally successful against his rebellious lords at home, having taken most of their castles and strongholds; and the Earl of Gloucester himself, no longer able to make any resistance, withdrew into Normandy, to concert new measures with the Empress his sister.
modernized: In the meantime, the King was highly successful against his rebellious barons at home, capturing most of their castles and fortresses. The Earl of Gloucester, no longer able to resistance, retreated to Normandy to discuss new strategies with his sister, the Empress.

original: Thus the King had leisure and opportunity for another expedition into Scotland, to pursue and improve his victory, where he met with no opposition: however, he was at length persuaded with much difficulty to accept his own conditions of a peace; and David delivered up to him his eldest son Henry, as hostage for performance of articles between them.
modernized: With this fresh opportunity, the King embarked on another campaign into Scotland, continuing his victories without opposition. However, he was eventually persuaded with great difficulty to accept his own terms for peace. King David handed over his eldest son, Henry, as a hostage to ensure compliance with the agreed-upon conditions.

original: To enter upon particulars: A Church of England man hath a true veneration for the scheme established among us of ecclesiastic government; and though he will not determine whether Episcopacy be of divine right, he is sure it is most agreeable to primitive institution, fittest of all others for preserving order and purity, and under its present regulations best calculated for our civil state: He should therefore think the abolishment of that order among us would prove a mighty scandal and corruption to our faith, and manifestly dangerous to our monarchy; nay, he would defend it by arms against all the powers on earth, except our own legislature; in which case he would submit as to a general calamity, a dearth, or a pestilence.
modernized: A Church of England follower respects the established church governance system in our country. While they may not definitively claim Episcopacy as divinely ordained, they believe it aligns with early church practices, and is extremely suitable for maintaining order and purity. They would consider the abolishment of this order as detrimental to our faith and threatening to our monarchy. They would even defend it with armed force, except against our own legislature. In that scenario, they would acquiesce as a dire necessity, such as a famine or plague.

original: Mrs. Van would have me dine with her again to-day, and so I did, though Lady Mountjoy has sent two or three times to have me see and dine with her, and she is a little body I love very well.
modernized: Mrs. Van invited me to dine with her again today, and I accepted, though Lady Mountjoy has repeatedly asked me to see and dine with her. I hold Mountjoy in high regard.

original: My head has ached a little in the evenings these three or four days, but it is not of the giddy sort, so I do not much value it.
modernized: I have had minor headaches in the evenings for the past few days, but they aren't of the dizziness kind, so I don't think too much of it.

original: I was to see Lord Harley to-day, but Lord Treasurer took physic; and I could not see him.
modernized: I was supposed to see Lord Harley today, but Lord Treasurer took medicine; thus, I couldn't see him.

original: He has voided much gravel, and is better, but not well: he talks of going on Tuesday to see the Queen at Hampton Court; I wish he may be able.
modernized: He has eliminated a significant amount of gravel and is improving, but he's still not well. He plans to visit the Queen at Hampton Court on Tuesday; I hope he recovers enough to go.

original: I never saw so fine a summer day as this was: how is it with you, pray? and can't you remember, naughty packs?
modernized: The weather today has been absolutely beautiful. How are you doing? Do you remember, naughty one?

original: I han't seen Lord Pembroke yet.
modernized: I have not seen Lord Pembroke yet.

original: He will be sorry to miss Dilly: I wonder you say nothing of Dilly's being got to Ireland; if he be not there soon, I shall have some certain odd thoughts: guess them if you can.
modernized: He will be disappointed to miss Dilly. I'm surprised you don't mention Dilly's arrival in Ireland; if he doesn't get there soon, I'll have some serious concerns; can you guess them?

original: I did intend, for brevity sake, to have given the reader only an abstract of it; but, upon trial, found myself unequal to such a task, without injuring so excellent a piece.
modernized: I initially aimed to provide a summary of it instead of the full text due to its brevity, but upon testing, I realized I was not capable of doing so without ruining the quality of the text.

original: And although I think historical relations are but ill patched up with long transcripts already printed, which, upon that account, I have hitherto avoided; yet this being the sum of all debates and resolutions of the House of Commons in that great affair of the war, I conceived it could not well be omitted.
modernized: I had previously avoided providing historical accounts using lengthy printed excerpts, but as this compilation represents all debates and resolutions of the House of Commons regarding the war, I believed it was essential not to omit it.

original: If I could wonder at anything barbarous, ridiculous, or absurd, among us, this should be one of the first.
modernized: If I could find something shockingly primitive, foolish, or strange among us, this would definitely be one of the worst examples.

original: I have often lamented that Agricola, the fatherin-law of Tacitus, was not prevailed on by that petty king from Ireland, who followed his camp, to come over and civilize us with a conquest, as his countrymen did Britain, where several Roman appellations remain to this day, and so would the rest have done, if that inundation of Angles, Saxons, and other northern people, had not changed them so much for the worse, although in no comparison with ours.
modernized: I frequently regret that Agricola, Tacitus' father-in-law, didn't accept the invitation from a small Irish king who followed him during his campaign, to conquer and civilize us, as the Irish did Britain. Roman names are still used there, and they probably would have beencommon here, too, if an invasion of Angles, Saxons, and other northern peoples hadn't spoiled it so badly. This invasion happened centuries ago and was much less civilized than what we have now.

original: In one of the advertisements just mentioned, I encountered near a hundred words together, which I defy any creature in human shape, except an Irishman of the savage kind, to pronounce; neither would I undertake such a task, to be owner of the lands, unless I had liberty to humanize the syllables twenty miles round.
modernized: I came across a cluster of nearly a hundred difficult-to-pronounce words in one of the advertisements I mentioned. I doubt anyone but a primitive Irishman could pronounce these words. I wouldn't risk purchasing the land unless I could modernize the syllables within a twenty-mile radius.

original: The legislature may think what they please, and that they are above copying the Romans in all their conquests of barbarous nations; but I am deceived, if anything has more contributed to prevent the Irish from being tamed, than this encouragement of their language, which might be easily abolished, and become a dead one in half an age, with little expense, and less trouble.
modernized: The government might have their own opinions about copying the Romans in their conquest of barbarous nations. However, I believe that encouraging the Irish language has been a significant factor in preventing the Irish from being civilized. The Irish language could easily be eliminated and become extinct within half a century, at minimal cost and effort.

original: Now, the Moderns had not proceeded in their late negotiation with secrecy enough to escape the notice of the enemy.
modernized: The Moderns hadn't been discreet enough during their recent negotiations to avoid the enemy spotting them.

original: For those advocates who had begun the quarrel, by setting first on foot the dispute of precedency, talked so loud of coming to a battle, that Sir William Temple happened to overhear them, and gave immediate intelligence to the Ancients, who thereupon drew up their scattered troops together, resolving to act upon the defensive; upon which, several of the Moderns fled over to their party, and among the rest Temple himself.
modernized: Advocates who initially started the argument over priority began loudly discussing potential battle, which caught Sir William Temple's attention. He promptly informed the Ancients, who consequently gathered their forces, deciding to be defensive. At this, several Moderns, including Temple himself, defected to the Ancients.

original: This Temple, having been educated and long conversed among the Ancients, was, of all the Moderns, their greatest favourite, and became their greatest champion.
modernized: Being schooled and frequently interacting with the Ancients, Temple was the most favored Modern and eventually became their strongest supporter.

original: This contrivance of crowning the son during the life and reign of the father, which appears so absurd in speculation, was actually performed in the succeeding reign, and seems to have been taken up by those two princes of French birth and extraction, in imitation of the like practice in their native country, where it was usual for kings grown old and infirm, or swayed by paternal indulgence, to receive their eldest son into a share of the administration, with the title of King; a custom borrowed, no doubt, from the later emperors of Rome, who adopted their Caesars after the like manner.
modernized: The practice of having a the son share the crown and administration during the father's lifetime, which seemed ludicrous to contemplate, was actually implemented during the following reign. This apparently was imitated by two princes of French origin, as it was common practice in their homeland for aging and unwell kings, or those influenced by paternal affection, to invite their eldest son to be a co-ruler, with the title of king. This custom was probably adopted from the late Roman emperors who would install their Caesars in a similar manner.

original: There are some people who think they sufficiently acquit themselves and entertain their company with relating of facts of no consequence, nor at all out of the road of such common incidents as happen every day; and this I have observed more frequently among the Scots than any other nation, who are very careful not to omit the minutest circumstances of time or place; which kind of discourse, if it were not a little relieved by the uncouth terms and phrases, as well as accent and gesture peculiar to that country, would be hardly tolerable.
modernized: Some individuals believe they entertain their company adequately by sharing insignificant facts that are commonplace or mundane. I've noticed this more often in the Scots, who are particular about including every minor detail of time and location. This type of dialogue, if not occasionally lightened by Scotland's unique linguistic terms, phrases, accents, and gestures, would be hard to bear.

original: It is not a fault in company to talk much; but to continue it long is certainly one; for, if the majority of those who are got together be naturally silent or cautious, the conversation will flag, unless it be often renewed by one among them who can start new subjects, provided he doth not dwell upon them, but leaveth room for answers and replies.
modernized: In social gatherings, it's not a fault to talk a lot, but to persist in conversation is indeed an issue; if most participants are naturally quiet or reserved, the conversation will stagnate unless revived by someone who can introduce new topics, as long as they do not linger on them and leave space for responses.

original: I shall not be very uneasy under the obloquy that may, perhaps, be cast upon me by the violent leaders and followers of the present prevailing party.
modernized: I will not be unduly concerned about the criticism that I might face from the extreme supporters of the current ruling party.

original: And yet I cannot find the least inconsistence with conscience or honour, upon the death of so excellent a princess as her late Majesty, for a wise and good man to submit, with a true and loyal heart, to her lawful Protestant successor; whose hereditary title was confirmed by the Queen and both Houses of Parliament, with the greatest unanimity, after it had been made an article in the treaty, that every prince in our alliance should be a guarantee of that succession.
modernized: It is conscientiously and honorably acceptable for a wise and virtuous man, with a loyal heart, to support the lawful Protestant successor of the late sovereign Queen whose title was confirmed by the Queen, both Houses of Parliament, and an article of the treaty ensuring that every prince in our alliance guarantees that succession.

original: Nay, I will venture to go one step farther; that, if the negotiators of that peace had been chosen out of the most professed zealots for the interests of the Hanover family, they could not have bound up the French king, or the Hollanders, more strictly than the Queen's plenipotentiaries did, in confirming the present succession; which was in them so much a greater mark of virtue and loyalty, because they perfectly well knew, that they should never receive the least mark of favour, when the succession had taken place.
modernized: Furthermore, I dare say that if the negotiators of that peace deal were die-hard supporters of the Hanover family, they could not have ensured the French King or the Dutch more resolutely than the Queen's representatives did in confirming the current succession, as it required greater virtue and loyalty since they knew they would never receive recognition when the succession took place.

original: They have had the art of printing, as well as the Chinese, time out of mind: but their libraries are not very large; for that of the king, which is reckoned the largest, does not amount to above a thousand volumes, placed in a gallery of twelve hundred feet long, whence I had liberty to borrow what books I pleased.
modernized: The king's subjects have been printing books for a long time, like the Chinese, but their libraries are not large. The largest library, which is owned by the king, contains approximately 1000 volumes, housed in a gallery that is 1200 feet long, from which I was allowed to borrow any books I wanted.

original: The queen's joiner had contrived in one of Glumdalclitch's rooms, a kind of wooden machine five-and-twenty feet high, formed like a standing ladder; the steps were each fifty feet long.
modernized: The queen's carpenter had designed a wooden structure in one of Glumdalclitch's rooms. The structure is a 25-foot-tall ladder-like contraption, built with steps that are 50 feet long each.

original: It was indeed a moveable pair of stairs, the lowest end placed at ten feet distance from the wall of the chamber.
modernized: This structure was mobile, with the lowest end positioned 10 feet away from the chamber wall.

original: The book I had a mind to read, was put up leaning against the wall: I first mounted to the upper step of the ladder, and turning my face towards the book, began at the top of the page, and so walking to the right and left about eight or ten paces, according to the length of the lines, till I had gotten a little below the level of mine eyes, and then descending gradually till I came to the bottom: after which I mounted again, and began the other page in the same manner, and so turned over the leaf, which I could easily do with both my hands, for it was as thick and stiff as a pasteboard, and in the largest folios not above eighteen or twenty feet long.
modernized: The book that I wanted to read was placed up against the wall. I climbed to the top step of the ladder, turned to face the book, and began reading from the top of the page. I then walked sideways along the step according to the length of the lines, stopping just below eye level, before descending to the bottom. After that, I climbed back up, turned over the page, and repeated the process until I finished the book. The book was thick and rigid, with the largest ones not exceeding 18-20 feet in length.

original: That Her Majesty did not only consent, but desire to have a plan settled for carrying on the war, as soon as the negotiation of peace should begin; but expected to have the burthen more equally laid, and more agreeable to treaties; and would join with the States in pressing the allies to perform their parts, as she had endeavoured to animate them by her example.
modernized: The Queen not only agrees but desires to establish a plan for continuing the war as soon as peace negotiations commence, but expects the burden to be shared more evenly, in accordance with treaty standards. She will join with the States in encouraging the allies to fulfill their obligations, having previously motivated them with her actions.

original: The first was, the building of the barracks; whereof I have seen above one-half, and have heard enough of the rest, to affirm that the public has been cheated of at least two-thirds of the money raised for that use, by the plain fraud of the undertakers.
modernized: The first issue was the construction of the barracks, where I have personally seen more than half of it, and obtained additional insights about the rest, confirming that at least two-thirds of the money collected for this project was fraudulently misused by the contractors.

original: So Cardinal Perron after having spoke for an hour to the admiration of all his hearers, to prove the existence of God; told some of his intimates that he could have spoken another hour, and much better, to prove the contrary.
modernized: After speaking for an hour in support of the existence of God, Cardinal Perron confided to his companions that he could have presented an even stronger case for the contrary.

original: Being now arrived at the proper age for producing themselves, they came up to town and fell in love with the ladies, but especially three, who about that time were in chief reputation, the Duchess d'Argent, Madame de Grands-Titres, and the Countess d'Orgueil.
modernized: Upon reaching maturity, the three brothers visited the town and became smitten by three prominent ladies: the Duchess d'Argent, Madame de Grands-Titres, and the Countess d'Orgueil.

original: On their first appearance, our three adventurers met with a very bad reception, and soon with great sagacity guessing out the reason, they quickly began to improve in the good qualities of the town.
modernized: Upon their initial introduction, the brothers received a very cold reception, but with keen intuition, they promptly began to improve their conduct within the town.
