original: They wrote, and rallied, and rhymed, and sung, and said, and said nothing; they drank, and fought, and slept, and swore, and took snuff; they went to new plays on the first night, haunted the chocolate-houses, beat the watch; they bilked hackney-coachmen, ran in debt with shopkeepers, and lay with their wives; they killed bailiffs, kicked fiddlers downstairs, ate at Locket's, loitered at Will's; they talked of the drawing-room and never came there; dined with lords they never saw; whispered a duchess and spoke never a word; exposed the scrawls of their laundress for billet-doux of quality; came ever just from court and were never seen in it; attended the levee sub dio; got a list of peers by heart in one company, and with great familiarity retailed them in another.
modernized: They began writing, witily commenting, composing songs, reciting poems, and making a variety of statements; they consumed alcohol, fought, and gambled; they attended premieres, frequented coffeehouses, and provoked the night watch; they cheated cab drivers, racked up bills with merchants, and slept with married women; they assaulted bailiffs, kicked musicians off stages, dined at Locket's, and loitered at Will's; they discussed high society events but never attended them; dined with nobles they never met; conversed with duchesses but did not speak a word; displayed their laundress's writing as elite love letters; claimed to just depart from court, but never appeared there; attended the levee sub dio; memorized the names of peers in one gathering and casually spoke of them in others.

original: Above all, they constantly attended those committees of Senators who are silent in the House and loud in the coffeehouse, where they nightly adjourn to chew the cud of politics, and are encompassed with a ring of disciples who lie in wait to catch up their droppings.
modernized: Above all, they regularly joined the committees of senators, silent in the chamber and loud in the coffeehouse, where they congregated to discuss politics and were surrounded by disciples eager to catch their wisdom.

original: The three brothers had acquired forty other qualifications of the like stamp too tedious to recount, and by consequence were justly reckoned the most accomplished persons in town.
modernized: The brothers had developed additional forty similar virtues, and as a result, were widely recognized as among the most refined individuals in town.

original: But all would not suffice, and the ladies aforesaid continued still inflexible.
modernized: Despite their many accomplishments, the aforementioned ladies remained unimpressed.

original: To clear up which difficulty, I must, with the reader's good leave and patience, have recourse to some points of weight which the authors of that age have not sufficiently illustrated.
modernized: To explain their persistent resistance, I must provide additional, weighty information that the authors of that era did not thoroughly cover.

original: Their style is clear, masculine, and smooth, but not florid; for they avoid nothing more than multiplying unnecessary words, or using various expressions.
modernized: Their writing style is concise, masculine, and straightforward, avoiding using multiple excess words or varying expressions.

original: I have perused many of their books, especially those in history and morality.
modernized: I've read many of their books, particularly those focusing on history and morality.

original: Among the rest, I was much diverted with a little old treatise, which always lay in Glumdalclitch's bedchamber, and belonged to her governess, a grave elderly gentlewoman, who dealt in writings of morality and devotion.
modernized: One book in particular amused me, a small, older book that always stayed in Glumdalclitch's bedroom. It belonged to a mature woman who specialized in writing about morality and piety.

original: The book treats of the weakness of human kind, and is in little esteem, except among the women and the vulgar.
modernized: The book discusses the vulnerability of human beings and is regarded with little respect, except among women and the common folk.

original: However, I was curious to see what an author of that country could say upon such a subject.
modernized: Despite its lack of respect, I was eager to see what this author from that region had to say about such a subject.

original: But when the 'squire turns farmer and merchant himself, all the good money he gets from abroad, he will hoard up or send for England, and keep some poor tailor or weaver and the like in his own house, who will be glad to get bread at any rate.
modernized: When the landlord becomes a farmer and merchant, the income he receives from abroad, he will either hoard or send to England, and keep a struggling tailor or weaver, and similar individuals, in his employ, who would gratefully receive bread regardless.

original: On Tuesday the 13th of October, Mr. Whiston held his lecture, near the Royal Exchange, to an audience of fourteen worthy citizens, his subscribers and constant hearers.
modernized: On October 13th, Mr. Whiston gave his lecture near the Royal Exchange to 14 subscribers and constant attendees.

original: Besides these, there were five chance auditors for that night only, who had paid their shillings a-piece.
modernized: Beyond the subscribers, there were five other attendees who paid their entry fee for that specific night.

original: I think myself obliged to be very particular in this relation, lest my veracity should be suspected; which makes me appeal to the men who were present; of which number I myself was one.
modernized: I feel compelled to provide detailed information about this event to ensure my credibility and to appeal to the witnesses who were present, of which I was one.

original: The number of souls in this kingdom being usually reckoned one million and a half, of these I calculate there may be about two hundred thousand couple whose wives are breeders; from which number I subtract thirty thousand couple, who are able to maintain their own children, (although I apprehend there cannot be so many, under the present distresses of the kingdom) but this being granted, there will remain an hundred and seventy thousand breeders.
modernized: In this kingdom, the number of families with mothers who are able to produce children is estimated to be about two hundred thousand. After accounting for those families that can afford to support their own children (despite the current economic distress), there will be 170,000 families that are unable to support their children.

original: I again subtract fifty thousand, for those women who miscarry, or whose children die by accident or disease within the year.
modernized: Further, I'll deduct 50,000 families due to miscarriages or deaths of their children within the first year.

original: There only remain an hundred and twenty thousand children of poor parents annually born.
modernized: So, there will be approximately 120,000 children born to impoverished families every year.

original: The question therefore is, How this number shall be reared, and provided for? which, as I have already said, under the present situation of affairs, is utterly impossible by all the methods hitherto proposed.
modernized: The issue then becomes, how can these children be nourished and cared for, considering the current circumstances, which render the methods proposed so far inadequate?

original: For we can neither employ them in handicraft or agriculture; we neither build houses, (I mean in the country) nor cultivate land: they can very seldom pick up a livelihood by stealing till they arrive at six years old; except where they are of towardly parts, although I confess they learn the rudiments much earlier; during which time they can however be properly looked upon only as probationers: As I have been informed by a principal gentleman in the county of Cavan, who protested to me, that he never knew above one or two instances under the age of six, even in a part of the kingdom so renowned for the quickest proficiency in that art.
modernized: We cannot employ these children for handicraft or agriculture. We do not build houses or cultivate land, and they can hardly make a living by stealing until they are six years old (unless they show noticeable abilities). During this learning period, they can only be considered as trainees. A high-ranking gentleman from the county of Cavan informed me that he has seldom seen instances of children exhibiting remarkable abilities before they reach the age of six.

original: But this proceeding is rejected by all the best lawyers as contrary to law, the Privy-council here having no such power.
modernized: This method is deemed unlawful by the most competent lawyers because the Privy Council lacks the necessary authority to implement it.

original: And besides it is to be considered, that the Queen was then under great difficulties by a rebellion in this kingdom assisted from Spain, and whatever is done in great exigences and dangerous times should never be an example to proceed by in seasons of peace and quietness.
modernized: It's important to note that the Queen was facing difficult circumstances due to a rebellion in this kingdom aided by Spain. Actions taken during critical times of urgency and danger should not serve as precedents for peaceful and quiet periods.

original: No law in that country must exceed in words the number of letters in their alphabet, which consists only of two and twenty.
modernized: Laws in that country can't have more words than the number of letters in their alphabet, which has only 22 letters.

original: But indeed few of them extend even to that length.
modernized: However, not many laws even reach this length.

original: They are expressed in the most plain and simple terms, wherein those people are not mercurial enough to discover above one interpretation: and to write a comment upon any law, is a capital crime.
modernized: These laws are written in extremely simple language; it's hard for people to interpret more than one meaning, and commenting on laws can be punishable by death.

original: As to the decision of civil causes, or proceedings against criminals, their precedents are so few, that they have little reason to boast of any extraordinary skill in either.
modernized: Regarding civil court decisions or criminal proceedings, they have very few precedents, so they can't boast of significant legal expertise.

original: These postulata being admitted, it will follow in due course of reasoning that those beings which the world calls improperly suits of clothes are in reality the most refined species of animals, or to proceed higher, that they are rational creatures or men.
modernized: If these assumptions are accepted, it can be logically inferred that beings which the world incorrectly terms 'suits of clothes' are actually the most sophisticated species of animals or, to put it another way, that they are rational beings or humans.

original: For is it not manifest that they live, and move, and talk, and perform all other offices of human life?
modernized: Isn't it obvious that they live, move, converse, and perform all other duties of human living?

original: Are not beauty, and wit, and mien, and breeding their inseparable proprieties?
modernized: Don't beauty, intelligence, manners, and class belong to them inherently?

original: In short, we see nothing but them, hear nothing but them.
modernized: In essence, we only perceive them and hear them.

original: Is it not they who walk the streets, fill up Parliament-, coffee-, play-, bawdyhouses.
modernized: Aren't they the ones walking the streets, filling parliaments, coffeehouses, playhouses, and brothels?

original: It is true, indeed, that these animals, which are vulgarly called suits of clothes or dresses, do according to certain compositions receive different appellations.
modernized: It's true that these animals, which are commonly referred to as 'suits of clothes' or 'apparel', acquire different titles based on certain arrangements.

original: If one of them be trimmed up with a gold chain, and a red gown, and a white rod, and a great horse, it is called a Lord Mayor; if certain ermines and furs be placed in a certain position, we style them a judge, and so an apt conjunction of lawn and black satin we entitle a Bishop.
modernized: If one is adorned with a gold chain, a red robe, a white staff, and a large horse, they are called a Lord Mayor. When ermines and furs are arranged in a specific way, they are referred to as judges. Similarly, a proper combination of lawn and black satin earns one the title of a Bishop.

original: If your Master be a Minister of State, let him be at Home to none but his Pimp, or chief Flatterer, or one of his Pensionary Writers, or his hired Spy, and Informer, or his Printer in ordinary, or his City Sollicitor, or a Land-Jobber, or his Inventor of new Funds, or a StockJobber.
modernized: If your employer is a high-ranking government official, he should limit his guests to his most influential advisors, top flatterers, writers on pension, spies, informers, his regular printer, city solicitor, land speculators, inventors of new investment strategies, or stock brokers.

original: Bentley durst not reply, but, half choked with spleen and rage, withdrew, in full resolution of performing some great achievement.
modernized: Bentley remained silent, visibly agitated and determined to accomplish a significant deed.

original: With him, for his aid and companion, he took his beloved Wotton, resolving by policy or surprise to attempt some neglected quarter of the Ancients' army.
modernized: With him, his trusted friend Wotton by his side, Bentley planned to strike a neglected area of the Ancient army using strategy or surprise.

original: They began their march over carcases of their slaughtered friends; then to the right of their own forces; then wheeled northward, till they came to Aldrovandus's tomb, which they passed on the side of the declining sun.
modernized: Their march led them over the remains of their comrades; they moved to the right of their own forces and then turned northward, passing by Aldrovandus's tomb as the sun was setting.

original: And now they arrived, with fear, toward the enemy's out-guards, looking about, if haply they might spy the quarters of the wounded, or some straggling sleepers, unarmed and remote from the rest.
modernized: As they ventured nearer to the enemy's outposts, they cautiously scanned the area, hoping to find wounded or isolated soldiers distant from the rest.

original: As when two mongrel curs, whom native greediness and domestic want provoke and join in partnership, though fearful, nightly to invade the folds of some rich grazier, they, with tails depressed and lolling tongues, creep soft and slow.
modernized: Like two stray dogs driven by hunger and lack of resources, Bentley and Wotton approached cautiously, looking nervous yet determined to raid the possessions of some wealthy shepherd.

original: Meanwhile the conscious moon, now in her zenith, on their guilty heads darts perpendicular rays; nor dare they bark, though much provoked at her refulgent visage, whether seen in puddle by reflection or in sphere direct; but one surveys the region round, while the other scouts the plain, if haply to discover, at distance from the flock, some carcase half devoured, the refuse of gorged wolves or ominous ravens.
modernized: Meanwhile, the moon, now at its peak in the sky, cast her piercing rays on the wrongdoers below, and the dogs remained silent, terrified of her brightness, whether bouncing off puddles or shining directly upon them; one kept watch on the surroundings, while the other surveyed the distance for any signs of half-eaten carcasses left by wolves or ravens.

original: So marched this lovely, loving pair of friends, nor with less fear and circumspection, when at a distance they might perceive two shining suits of armour hanging upon an oak, and the owners not far off in a profound sleep.
modernized: This timid, loving pair crept along, taking care not to alert the enemy, and they momentarily stopped when they saw two sets of armor hung on an oak, with the owners dozing not far away.

original: The two friends drew lots, and the pursuing of this adventure fell to Bentley; on he went, and in his van Confusion and Amaze, while Horror and Affright brought up the rear.
modernized: They drew lots, and Bentley was assigned the responsibility to pursue this adventure ahead; behind him came Confusion and Awe, while Fear and Terror trailed behind.

original: As he came near, behold two heroes of the Ancient army, Phalaris and AEsop, lay fast asleep.
modernized: As he drew closer, Bentley saw two warriors from the Ancient army, Phalaris and Aesop, fast asleep.

original: Bentley would fain have despatched them both, and, stealing close, aimed his flail at Phalaris's breast; but then the goddess Affright, interposing, caught the Modern in her icy arms, and dragged him from the danger she foresaw; both the dormant heroes happened to turn at the same instant, though soundly sleeping, and busy in a dream.
modernized: Bentley desired to kill both warriors silently and tried to strike Phalaris with his flail, but the goddess Fear, stepping in, seized Bentley and pulled him away from imminent danger. Both sleeping warriors turned simultaneously, though deeply asleep and engaged in dreams.

original: For Phalaris was just that minute dreaming how a most vile poetaster had lampooned him, and how he had got him roaring in his bull.
modernized: Phalaris was merely dreaming of a vile poet who had ridiculed him, causing him to roar like a bull.

original: And AEsop dreamed that as he and the Ancient were lying on the ground, a wild ass broke loose, ran about, trampling and kicking in their faces.
modernized: Aesop, however, was dreaming of a wild donkey breaking free and running around, kicking and trampling them.

original: Bentley, leaving the two heroes asleep, seized on both their armours, and withdrew in quest of his darling Wotton.
modernized: Having left the two warriors asleep, Bentley took both their armors and departed to find Wotton.

original: But Wood is still working underhand to force his halfpence upon us, and if he can by help of his friends in England prevail so far as to get an order that the commissioners and collectors of the King's money shall receive them, and that the army is to be paid with them, then he thinks his work shall be done.
modernized: Wood continues to clandestinely push his halfpence on us, hoping to get an order requiring commissioners, collectors, and the army to accept them. If he manages to do so, then he thinks he will have completed his mission.

original: And this is the difficulty you will be under in such a case.
modernized: This is the challenge one would face in such a situation.

original: For the common soldier when he goes to the market or alehouse will offer this money, and if it be refused, perhaps he will swagger and hector, and threaten to beat the butcher or alewife, or take the goods by force, and throw them the bad halfpence.
modernized: Common soldiers may display aggression when they offer this money in markets or taverns. If it is refused, they might threaten to physically harm the shopkeeper or alewife, or forcefully take the goods and pay with bad halfpence.

original: In this and the like cases, the shopkeeper or victualler, or any other tradesman has no more to do, than to demand ten times the price of his goods, if it is to be paid in Wood's money; for example, twentypence of that money for a quart of ale, and so in all things else, and not part with his goods till he gets the money.
modernized: In such situations, shopkeepers, tavern owners, or any tradesperson only needs to ask for ten times the regular price if they are paid in Wood's coins. For instance, 20 pieces of that currency would be equivalent to a quart of ale, and the tradesperson should refuse to give their goods until they receive the money.

original: It would be in vain for one intelligent being to pretend to set rules to the actions of another, if he had it not in his power to reward the compliance with, or punish the deviations from, his rules by some good, or evil, which is not the natural consequence of those actions; since the forbidding men to do or forbear an action on the account of that convenience or inconvenience which attendeth it, whether he who forbids it will or no, can be no more than advice.
modernized: An intelligent being cannot effectively set rules for another's actions if they are unable to enforce compliance or punish rule violations with consequences separate from the natural outcomes of those actions. Forbidding actions based on the convenience or inconvenience associated with them provides no more than advice, as the threat of punishment by the rule-giver is not a natural consequence of the action itself.

original: All these may be ascribed to the strength of his passions, and to the prejudices, early imbibed, in favour of his indulgent royal mistress and her favourites and servants.
modernized: All these can be attributed to the intense emotions and long-held biases of the author, who seemingly favors his indulgent queen and her associates.

original: The judicious will look through the elegant clothing, and dispassionately consider these as mere human errors, to which no well-informed mind can assent.
modernized: The sensible reader will peel back the fancy language and objectively view these points as mere human flaws, which a reasonable mind would not condone.

original: The editor thinks himself bound to protest against them.
modernized: The editor feels a responsibility to voice objections to these claims.

original: And thus having done with the several reasons why man, the only creature in the world that can reflect and look into himself, is so very ignorant of what passes within him, and so much unacquainted with the standing dispositions and complexions of his own heart: I proceed now, in the
modernized: And now, moving forward, I will explain several reasons why human beings- the only creatures capable of introspection - are so ignorant of their inner workings and unaware of the consistent traits of their own hearts. Having done so, I will discuss the advantages of self-knowledge.

original: In this objection there are two questions included: First, whether upon the foot of our constitution, as it stood in the reign of the late King James, a king of England may be deposed?
modernized: Is it possible, according to our constitution during the rule of King James, for a king of England to be removed or deposed?

original: The second is, whether the people of England convened by their own authority, after the king had withdrawn himself in the manner he did, had power to alter the succession?
modernized: Did the people of England, who gathered on their own authority after the king retired, have the power to change the line of succession?

original: I would not for a guinea have a letter from you till this goes; and go it shall on Saturday, faith.
modernized: I would prefer not to receive a letter from you for a guinea until this letter is sent on Saturday.

original: I dined with Mrs. Vanhomrigh, to save my shin, and then went on some business to the Secretary, and he was not at home.
modernized: I dined with Mrs. Vanhomrigh to save my shin, and afterward went on some business to the Secretary but found him absent.
